GENERAL GLOSSARY

/ʾ/

ʾabaya, ʾabbaya n.m. (pl. ʾabaye, ʾabbaye) (A.) man’s cloak | ʾabàyele dǝ́rya b-réša| He put his cloak over her (A26:50); ʾɛ́-ga kúlla ʾaġăwáθa šexìye| kúlla b-ʾabbàye-wawa| At that time all aghas and elders wore the abbaya gown (A26:47); ʾíman ṱ‑ila‑nabólle bə̀dra| m‑gu‑ʾằra,| mattíwa … ʾabàya y‑amrə́xwale| When they took it (the rice) to the threshing floor from that ground, they would lay down what we called a cloak (B5:80).

ʾabona n.m. (pl. ʾabone) (A.) bishop

ʾabresəm → habresəm

ʾăbu part. attributive particle (A. literally: father of) | ʾăbu‑bə̀rqa| electrician(s) (B10:50); băyánni ʾə́mma bnàθa| ṱ-áwa ʾăbu tā̀j| I want for myself a hundred girls wearing crowns (A25:74). In expressions of age: ʾo‑yála zòra| ʾábu ʾəsrì-šənne| The youth, who was twenty years old (A17:2).

ʾAðər n.m. March

ʾadət n.f. (pl. ʾadətte, ʾadəttaθa) custom | ʾáxni ʾádət díyən hàtxɛla| Our custom is this (A4:30).

ʾafsara n.m. (pl. ʾafsare) rope for leading a mule

ʾaġa, ʾaxa n.m. (pl. ʾaġaye, ʾaġăwaθa) nobleman | ʾàġay| My lord (A25:13); ʾáxa ṱ‑áwət basìma| Sir, if you please (A42:1).

ʾa-ġða, ʾa-ġðaha pron. fs. demonstrative (§14.3.5.) | Denoting the accessibility of a referent in memory: txárət ʾa-ġða-báxta k̭óre t‑wáwa gu-màθa?| Do you remember the blind woman who was in the village?

ʾahwāl n.f. (pl. ʾahwalətte) circumstance, condition | xázəx ʾahwalə́ttət màlka| Let’s see what the circumstances of the king are (A8:80); dìya| ʾahwalə́tte šuxlə̀pla| Now circumstances have changed (B5:72).

ʾajəbuθa n.f. wonder; marvel | xzéli xá-məndit ʾajəbùθa| I have found something amazing (A8:16); xzélən ʾajəbùθa!| We have seen a miracle! (B9:21).

ʾajib adj. invar. (A.) amazing | ʾàjib!| It was amazing! (A4:28).

ʾakara n.m. (pl. ʾakare) farmer

ʾăkīd adj. invar. (A.) sure, certain

ʾal- prep. (Urm.) on, upon | ʾal‑ʾằra| on the ground (A21:5), ʾal‑rùše díye| on his shoulder (A22:18).

ʾalaha n.m. God (§5.3.) | škìra‑ʾalaha| God be praised; ʾálaha ṱ-áwe mənnɛ̀xu| May God be with you (A8:29); b-àlaha| By God; mə́ra ha?| mə́ra b‑àlaha!| She said “Is it so?” They said “Yes” (A38:2); ʾálaha mbasə̀mlux| May God cure you; ʾálaha manìxle| May God grant him rest; ʾálaha mazyə̀dle May God increase it (the food in your house — said by guest to the host after a meal); ʾíθwa lìθwa| biš-m-aláha góṛa lìθwa| There was or there was not, there was no greater than God (opening formula of a story) (A4:1); xá-yoma mən-yománət ʾaláha one fine day (literally: one of the days of God) (A48:2); tíwɛle xáṣət súse dìye| ʾu-ya-ʾálaha zìlɛle| He sat on the back of his horse and off he went off (A28:9).

ʾalahuθa n.f. divinity; divine deed; miracle | xzígən ʾalahùθa| See what a miracle! (A51:21).

ʾălīq n.m. (A.) fodder | súse b-gáne măzidle ʾălìqe| A horse by itself increases its fodder (D:34).

ʾalma n.m. world; crowd of people | bréla ðá xadúθa gu-d-ò-ʾalma| A (great) joy arose among the people (A4:56); ʾaw-ʾálma ṱ-íle jmíya tàma| The crowd of people that is gathered there (A26:64).

ʾalmās n.pl. (A.) diamonds

ʾalola n.m. (pl. ʾalole) alley; narrow street

ʾalpa n.m. (pl. ʾalpe, ʾalpaye) thousand | tre ʾalpe two thousand; ṭḷaθa ʾalpe three thousand; ʾína ʾalpàye maymúne píše táma| Thousands of monkeys had appeared there (A14:43); m-ʾálpa ʾáxni lá raba‑ʾi‑mapəlxə̀xwala| We rarely used it (literally: in a thousand (times) we did not use it much) (B10:18).

ʾalqošnaya n.m./adj. (pl. ʾalqošnaye) man from Alqosh

ʾalulta n.f. (pl. ʾalulyaθa) alley (§10.5.2.3.)

ʾalwān → lawn

ʾama n.m. paternal uncle | only in: brət ama (pl. bərtamwaθa) (distant) cousin (m.) (second degree and more distant) and bratət ama (distant) cousin (f.).

ʾamana n.m. (pl. ʾamane) vessel, container

ʾamara n.m. (pl. ʾamare) teller, recounter | ʾáyya mártət ʾamàre| This is what they say (literally: This is the saying of the sayers) (A32:24).

ʾamədyana n.m. Amedia stitching, cross-stitch

ʾamina adj. (f. ʾaminta, pl. ʾamine) safe; reliable

ʾaminuθa n.f. safety

ʾamoma n.m. scarecrow

ʾamra n.m. (pl. ʾăwamər) (A.) order, command | ʾámrət màlkɛle| It is the order of the king (A8:9).

ʾamṛa n.m. wool

ʾamta n.f. (pl. ʾamtaθa) paternal aunt

ʾamuqa adj. (f. ʾamuqta, pl. ʾamuqe) deep

ʾamura adj. (f. ʾamurta, pl. ʾamure) dense (vegetation); thickly planted (crops) | ṭəlla ʾamurta deep shade

ʾamuṛa n.m. (pl. ʾamuṛe) tool

ʾana pron. cs. I

ʾănaha, naha; ʾănaʾha, naʾha pron. pl. far deixis demonstrative (§7.4., §14.3.2.) | xzáyət ʾănáha naše-ṱ-íla ráqa bàθri?| Do you see those people who are running after me? (A7:17).

ʾanani adj. (A.) selfish

ʾanbar n.m. (pl. ʾanbare) storeroom (for produce)

ʾani, ʾan pron. pl. default demonstrative (§7.4., §14.3.2.) | kúlla ʾan-waríðəx qăṭə̀nna| ‘I shall cut all those roots of yours’ (A25:64). Used anaphorically: šwíqle zúze díye táma zìlle.| θéle xa-xèna,| ʾan-zúze šqilíle ʾu-zìlle.| He left his money there and went off. Another man came. He took that money and went off (A15:15). xárθa ʾáni mə́ṭyela tàma| l‑márzət yàma| Then they arrived there, by the shore of the sea (A14:37).

ʾaniða n.m./adj. (pl. ʾaniðe) deceased, dead | dúkθət xamɛ́θət ʾanìðe| a place for burying the deceased (B3:19)

ʾanna pron. pl. speaker deixis demonstrative (§7.4., §14.3.2.) | ʾánna ʾálpa-w xamšá-mma dìyuxila| ʾánna ʾálpa-w xamšá-mma dìyila| These one thousand five-hundred are yours and these one thousand five-hundred are mine (A1:20). Used anaphorically: rába gáye wítɛla ʾánna məndiyàne| Many times such things happened (B5:163).

ʾan-xa, ʾan-xaha pron. pl. demonstrative (§14.3.5.) | Denoting the accessibility of a referent in memory: txárət ʾán-xa xonăwáθa k̭óre t-wɛ́wa gu-màθa?| Do you remember the blind brothers who were in the village?; txárət ʾan-xa-tré t-mutəpqíwalən b‑ġðàðe?| Do you remember the couple that we brought together? (A4:45).

ʾap, ʾup part. also, even; connective particle (§18.1.3.). (1) also | ʾap-àna mjaṛbǝ́nna| ḥàð̣ð̣ díyi| I also shall try my luck (A1:4); ʾàp‑təmməl ʾáxləx mǝ́nna| We could eat them also tomorrow (A2:2); ʾap-xmárey šqìləlla| They took also their asses (A7:15); xuš-pɛ́šən képa ʾap-àna| Let me also become a stone (A8:55); ʾap-šlàma lɛ́la dǝ́ryəlle| They did not offer him even a greeting (A15:13); ʾáp‑xa lɛle-mṣáya mbasə̀mla| Nobody (literally: even one) can cure her (A4:12). (2) connective particle | combined with a topical constituent at boundaries of discourse sections: ʾap-aw-zìlɛle| xíša mə́ṭya kəs‑màlka| So, he went and he entered into the presence of the king (A1:6-7); ʾáp-awwa sìqɛle gu-ṭúra| So, he went up into the mountains (A4:1-2); ʾáp-awwa qəm-parmìle| So, they slaughtered him (A15:9-10).

ʾaparuθa n.f. household goods | dəkkánət ʾaparùθa| general store (A22:11)

ʾapɛθa n.f. (pl. ʾapayaθa) cloth put over bread when it is stored

ʾapṣa m. (pl. ʾapṣe) gallnut of oak tree (mɛša) | ʾilanət ʾapṣe oak tree (mɛša) bearing such gallnuts; hot-píša ʾápṣa milàna| You have become a green gallnut (i.e. you have not been seen for a long time) (D1:4).

ʾaqall adj. invar. (A.) less

ʾaqara n.m. (pl. ʾaqare) area of cultivated land → ʾqr to dig up, to plough

ʾaqərwa n.f. (pl. ʾaqərwe) scorpion

ʾaqla n.f. (pl. ʾaqlaθa, ʾaqle) leg; foot | xaṣət ʾaqla top of the foot; ʾărət ʾaqla bottom of the foot; dawɛ́ra ʾíðe‑w ʾàqle| A mule (is a man’s) arms and legs (B5:124); šǝ́ryəlla ʾáqle w‑ìðe| He untied the legs and arms (A10:13); ða-ʾáqla rēš-d-àyya ʾɛ́nən| ʾu-ðá rēš-d-àyya| We shall treat you with respect (literally: one leg on this eye of ours and one on this other one B9:10).

ʾaqolta n.f. (pl. ʾaqolyaθa) rope lock used to tighten a rope holding the burden on the back of an animal | This consisted of a triangle of p̣aṛma wood through which the ends of the rope were threated and and then pulled tight.

ʾaqra, ʾəqra n.m. (pl. ʾaqrare, ʾəqrare) trunk of a tree; stem of plant; bottom (of ear) | xəzyali l‑ʾaqrət tena I saw her by the trunk of the fig tree (C2:24); ʾárya mə́xyəlle šaqqána l‑ʾəqər‑náθət dèwa| The lion clouted the wolf on the root of his ear (A42:2); ʾəṣrà ʾaqráre| ten stems (of tobacco plants) (B7:13); ʾəqrət ṭura the foot of the mountain.

ʾaqraya n.m. (pl. ʾaqraye) (Ṭiy.) turtle, tortoise

ʾaqubra n.m. (pl. ʾaqubre) mouse

ʾăra, ʾarra n.f. (pl. ʾăraθa) ground, land | ʾăráθe díye zărèwala| He cultivated his lands (B5:73); măṛòyənwala| gu‑ðà‑ʾăra| I was grazing it (the mule) in a certain piece of land (B5:131); ʾo‑gavána bēl‑ʾắra| l‑ʾằra| The boundary area is between one plot of land and another (B5:131); xákma har‑damxíwa l‑ằra| Some would sleep only only the floor (B5:204).

ʾarabaya n.m./adj. (pl. ʾarabaye) Arab

ʾaramnaya n.m./adj. (pl. ʾaramnaye) Armenian

ʾăraq n.f. arak | ʾăraq xɛlanta strong arak; ʾắraq mpalṭə̀xla| m‑yabìše| We produce arak from raisins (B5:12).

ʾaraqa n.m. (pl. ʾaraqe) fugitive

ʾaraqta n.f. (pl. ʾaraqyaθa) fugitive (f.)

ʾarba, ʾarpa num. (f. ʾarbe) four | ʾurzət ʾarba the fourth man; baxtət ʾarbe the fourth woman

ʾarbassər num. fourteen

ʾarbaθn– num. four of | base for pronominal suffixes: ʾarbaθnən the four of us; ʾarbaθnɛxu the four of you; ʾarbaθnéy the four of them.

ʾarbi num. forty | b‑ʾarbìye in the (19)40s (B5:161)

ʾarbilnaya n.m./adj. (pl. ʾarbilnaye) man from Arbil

ʾarbušeba n.m. Wednesday | ʾarbušeba xəška, ʾarbušeba b-lɛle Wednesday night

ʾarda n.f. (pl. ʾardaθa) bottom; floor | ʾardət ṣawle sole of shoes; ʾărəd ʾaqla bottom of the foot; ʾardət bɛθa the floor of the house; ʾárde díye kúlla képe góṛe pàrše| Its (the church’s) floor was all large flat stones (B14:5).

ʾarəkθa n.f. (pl. ʾarəkyaθa) bag | ʾarəkθa t‑rəzza bag of rice

ʾarəmla n.m. (pl. ʾarəmle) widower

ʾareta n.f. (pl. ʾarayaθa) algae and detritus floating on stagnant water | put in gaps between stones in a garra to seal in the water

ʾarəxta n.f. (pl. ʾarəxyaθa) guest (f.)

ʾarəšwɛrəš, ʾəšwɛrəš n.f. commercial dealings | ʾíθwa ʾarəšwɛ́rəš benaθéy There were dealings between them

ʾariθa n.f. (pl. ʾariyaθa) lionness

ʾarməlθa n.f. (pl. ʾarməlyaθa) widow

ʾarmonta → harmonta

ʾarnuwa → harnuwa

ʾarxa n.m. (pl. ʾarxe) guest | mare ʾarxe hospitable man; də-háyyo puš-ʾàrxi ʾədlɛ́le| Come, be my guest today (A8:42); ʾɛ́ka pɛ́šən ʾàrxa?| Where can I stay (A26:26); ʾána hon-ʾə́θya ʾárxa kə̀slux| I have come as your guest (C7:3).

ʾarxe, ʾərxe n.f. (pl. ʾarxaθa, ʾərxaθa) water-mill

ʾarya, ʾɛrya n.m. (pl. ʾarye, ʾɛrye) lion

ʾarzāq → rəsqa

ʾarzən adj. invar. (K.) cheap

ʾarθa n.f. (pl. ʾaraθa) rival wife | only used in oaths: hàtxa ṱ-óðən b‑ʾárθux| (I swear) by your rival wife that I shall do it.

ʾasās n.m. (pl. ʾasase) (A.) foundation

ʾasbab n.m. (pl. ʾasbabe) (K./A.) equipment, weapon

ʾašəq adj. (invar.) (A.) in love | ʾàšəq wéwa He was in love (A8:33); ʾáyya ʾášəq‑ila l-áwwa gàwṛa| She is in love with this man.

ʾašəquθa n.f. love making; coquetry | kəmət jawja b‑ʾašəquθa naše nabli šəkkuθa Whenever she moves coquettishly, people become suspicious (C2:73).

ʾaṣərta n.f. (pl. ʾaṣrare) evening; late afternoon | ʾaṣǝ́rta θìθɛla| bắyi ṱ‑áxli xa-ràmša| The evening came and they wanted to eat dinner (A2:2); y‑oðíwa ʾaṣràre| They would hold evening celebrations (B5:18).

ʾaṣi adj. invar. (A.) rebellious, rebel; difficult (terrain) | ʾánna hóla ʾàṣi ʾə́lle díye| They are rebelling against him (A12:58); ṭúra ʾàṣile| The mountain is difficult.

ʾasira n.m. (pl. ʾasire) captive | kulla dwiqe jundiye ʾasire All (the grooms) were taken as captured soldiers (C3:4).

ʾaširət n.f. (pl. ʾaširatte) (A./K.) tribe, community

ʾašitnaya n.m./adj. (pl. ʾašitnaye) man from Ashitha

ʾašiθa n.f. (pl. ʾašiyaθa) avalanche

ʾaskar, ʾaskariya n.f. (pl. ʾaskaryaθa, ʾaskarwaθa) (A.) army | ṱ-ázət ʾaskarìya| You shall go to the army (A17:22); lázəm ʾáwəð ʾaskarìya| He must serve in the army (A17:22).

ʾaskăraya n.m. (pl. ʾaskăraye, fs. ʾaskărɛθa, fpl. ʾaskărayaθa) solider | xə́zyəlla ʾán ʾaskăràye| He saw the soliders (A25:79); xamša-ʾəmmà ʾaskărayáθa bnáθa kúlla| five hundred soldiers, all girls (A25:74).

ʾaṣl, ʾăṣəl n.m. (A.) origin

ʾaṣli adj. invar. (A.) original

ʾaṣoṭa n.m./adj. (pl. ʾaṣoṭe) delinquent; tiresome

ʾasrār → sərr

ʾaswad adj. (A.) black

ʾaṣya n.m. difficulty, embarrassment | jwanqone drɛla l‑ʾaṣya She has caused the young men embarrasment (C2:59)

ʾati pron. cs. you

ʾatiqa adj. (f. ʾatiqta, pl. ʾatiqe) ancient | ʾaw‑bə́nyɛle m‑jálde ʾatìqa| It was built in very ancient times (B14:2).

ʾatko n.f. (pl. ʾatkowaθa) piece of stomach of a young goat used to make rennet

ʾatkore n.m. marble game | The aim is to shoot marbles into a hole in the ground (B11:28).

ʾaṭma n.f. (pl. ʾaṭmaθa) side, thigh

ʾatnabəl n.m. (pl. ʾatnabele) car

ʾatuna n.m. (pl. ʾatune) furnace, kiln | y‑oðíwa ʾatùna,| qá‑t mtarṣíwa kə̀lša| They set up a furnace to make gypsum (B5:182).

ʾatwana n.m. (pl. ʾatwane) one who sits | ʾatwánə xáṣə susăwàθa| horsemen (A12:58)

ʾaθoraya n.m./adj. (pl. ʾaθoraye), ʾaturaya (Urm.) Assyrian

ʾaθṛa m.n. (pl. ʾaθṛăwaθa) land, country; homeland | gu-ʾaθṛa in the home country; lɛ́wət d-áwwa ʾàθṛa| You are not from this land (A25:82).

ʾaθuθa n.f. (pl. ʾaθuwaθa, ʾaθwaθa) letter (of the alphabet)

ʾavi adj. invar. (K.) irrigated | zruta avi irrigated cultivation, xəṭṭe ʾavi irrigated wheat (opposite of dēm, demi, dema unirrigated)

ʾaw part. or

ʾaw, ʾo pron. ms. default demonstrative (§7.4., §14.3.2.) | hálli ʾo‑kθàwa| Give me that book (which you are holding). Used anaphorically: ʾíθwa xa-málka gu-ða-màθa.| ʾo-màlka| ʾíθwale tə̀rte bnáθa| There was a king in a village. That/the king had two daughters (A25:1); ʾo‑Barzǝ́kko zíla dmìxa| Barzəkko went and slept (A12:10); ʾaw-ṃəḷyále tópe díye spày| He loaded his gun well (A31:7).

ʾawaða n.m. (pl. ʾawaða) doer

ʾăwaha, waha; ʾăwaʾha, waʾha pron. ms. far deixis demonstrative (§7.4., §14.3.2.) | y‑ásqəx mɛ́θəx míya mən-d-ăwàha ṭúra| We shall go up and fetch water from that mountain over there (A39:9); mə́re kɛ̀le bɛ́θa díya?| … mə́ra ʾăwáʾha qáṣra ṱ-it-xzàyəlle| He said ‘Where is her house?’ … They said ‘That villa that you can see over there’; (A40:11) gu‑măḥàll‑ži| kút‑yum gánu kθɛ́θa d‑àwwa,| ʾɛ́‑ga y‑azǝ́lwa féka d‑ăwàha| Every day in the neighbourhood he would steal the chicken of one person, then go (and steal) the fruit of another (A14:7).

ʾawahaθa, ʾawahe n.pl. parents | ʾawáhe dìyən| our parents (B16:24)

ʾawqana, ʾoqana n.m. (pl. ʾawqane, ʾoqane) predicament, distress | Mắmo-w Zíne hóla npíle gu-ʾoqàna| Mămo and Zine are in a predicament (A26:51).

ʾawṣāf n.pl. (A.) features, attributes

ʾawwa pron. ms. speaker deixis demonstrative (§7.4., §14.3.2.) | yába là dámxəx gu‑d‑áwwa qáṣra.| dámxəx l‑wằdər| Let’s not sleep in this palace. Let’s sleep outside (A12:11). Used anaphorically: ʾíθwa xa-màlka.| ʾáwwa málka xzéle xa-xǝ̀lma| There was a king. This king had a dream. (A1:2); ʾáwwa zílɛle b-ʾùrxa| He went on his way (A17:12).

ʾawwal, ʾawwəl num. (A.) first | ʾáwwəl dórta the first round (B10:13); ʾáwwəl ma‑t‑ràxəθ| as soon as it boiled (B10:87).

ʾax prep. (with pronominal suffixes: ʾaxwaθe, ʾax-diye) (§13.3.1., §19.3.4.) like, as; when. (1) Before a noun or clause like, as | ʾáp‑ana dàqrən| ʾax‑déwa k̭òra| I am worth the same as a blind wolf (A10:1); hàtxɛwa,| ʾax‑mə̀rya.| He was like this, as if he were ill (A12:52); xwára ʾax-tàlgɛle| It is white as snow (A8:67); mattìwa| ṱ‑ámrəx xá xámša dinàre| ʾən‑hàtxa mə́ndi| yáʿni ʾax‑mṣɛ̀θa| They would deposit let’s say a sum of five dinars, or thereabouts, according to their ability (B5:6); ʾax‑txàra| as (I) remember. Before a demonstrative: ʾax‑d‑ó‑dewa k̭òra| like that blind wolf (A10:5), ʾax‑d‑an‑ṱ‑íla míθe tàma| like those who have already died there (A14:70). Before a clause: mɛ́θən ʾax‑t‑̭ila‑ʾànna míθe| I shall die like these people have died (A14:73); ʾáx ṱ-àmrət,| xáčča biš-šlèla| She seemed (literally: as you say) to become a little calmer (A4:17). (2) when | ʾax-ṱ-íla plíṭṭa Səttìye,| xzìθəlle| xrìwɛle lə́bba díya| When Səttiye came out, she saw him and her heart was broken (A26:30); ʾax‑ṱ‑íle qìma,| ʾu-šúryela pláša m-ġðàðe,| ʾàwwa| maxèle| sɛ̀pe| l‑qðála d-o-Déwa Zàr| ʾu-ṣále kəndàla| When he got up and they started fighting with one another, he struck his sword into the neck of that Dewa Zar and he went down the slope (A28:19).

ʾaxala n.m./adj. (pl. ʾaxale) big eater

ʾaxalta n.f./adj. (pl. ʾaxalyaθa) big eater (f.)

ʾaxči part. just, only; but. (1) just, only | xúwwe ʾáxčile múdwa rìqa| The snake just managed to escape (A1:15); ʾáxči ʾáp ʾayya-béna múrri mòdile| Just one more time tell me what it is (A1:18); malàxe yắði,| ʾàxči| Only the angels know (A4:9); ʾáxči xoš-qàyəm| xazyánne xàmša daqíqe,| ʾan-xéne kúlla ṭla-d-àw| Just let him rise for me to see him for five minutes, and all the other (sixty years) be for him (A4:49). (2) but | ʾə́č̣č̣i-u ʾə̀č̣č̣a,| ʾáxči ʾána max-xšàwti,| ʾáyya kìsta| hóle mxožə́bnəlla max-xà| (There are) ninety-nine (coins), but according my opinion, he has reckoned this bag as one (A6:3)

ʾaxḍar adj. invar. (A.) green

ʾaxəl-qarṣa n.m. the devil

ʾaxlana n.m./adj. (pl. ʾaxlane) big eater

ʾaxlanta n.f./adj. (pl. ʾaxlanyaθa) big eater (f.)

ʾaxni pron. pl. we

ʾaxola n.m./adj. (pl. ʾaxole) big eater

ʾaxtu pron. pl. you

ʾaxulka n.m. (pl. ʾaxulke) small fly that bites

ʾaxxa adv. here | ʾàxxa ṱ‑áwən dmíxa| I shall sleep here (A10:5); plúṭ m‑àxxa!| Leave here! (A12:5); ʾu‑táwra píšle mangóle ʾáxxa l‑tàmma| The ox began to limp back and forth (A22:3); qedámta qímtɛla bràta-w| mxŭláltəlla ʾay-dùkθa| ʾáxxa-w tàmma| In the morning the girl got up and cleaned the place, and so forth (A17:27). Repeated to express movement: xa‑núra ʾə́θyɛle b‑lɛ̀le| ʾax‑ʾáxxa sàqa| A light came in the night, coming up here (A29:23). With temporal sense: mu‑ṱ‑óðəx m-áxxa-w hàtxa?| What can we do from now on? (A8:59). Used with pronominal suffixes: ʾáxxi hóle mràya| It hurts me here (literally: My here hurts); ṣléla béʾe ʾàx‑ʾaxxe díye| The eggs ran down him here and here (literally: his here and here) (A23:8).

ʾaxxane adv. here, hereabouts | kú‑t‑̭ile ferə́ssa ʾáθe ʾàxxane| Whoever is a warrior, let him come here (A29:59); ʾína réši šmíṭa ʾaxxàne| My head was injured around here (B5:132).

ʾay mod. which? | Marginally attested in indirect questions: ʾáti xázət ʾày‑mənna bắyət| See which one you like (A14:80).

ʾay, ʾey, ʾɛ, ʾa pron. fs. default demonstrative (§7.4., §14.3.2.) | ða-kista-xéta max-d-áy yawə̀nnəx| I’ll give you another purse like that one (you are holding) (A4:15-16). Used anaphorically: ʾímət mṭéla ṭúnte dìye,| θéle xa-nàša,| qəm-šaqə̀lla ʾɛ-ṭúnte díye| When its fruit became ripe, a man came and took its fruit (A17;33); ʾu-ʾɛ-Lelíθa θèla| The Leliθa came (A19:4); ʾáy píšla tàma| She remained there (A19:6).

ʾăyaha, yaha; ʾăyaʾha, yaʾha pron. fs. far deixis demonstrative (§7.4., §14.3.2.) | réšux mattánne gu-d-yàha káwe| ṱ-íla pyàša| I shall put your head in that opening over there that remains (A25:62); zílla dwíqla náwba l-ăyàʾha qunjə́lta t-hódəx| They went and kept a guard in that far corner (A18:3); mattíwala gu‑d‑ɛ́ məššára … ʾə́ṣra gu‑d‑àyya,| ʾə́ṣra gu‑d‑yàha| They would plant them in the paddy field … ten in this (row), ten in that one (B7:13).

ʾayale n.pl. children → yala

ʾayya pron. fs. speaker deixis demonstrative (§7.4., §14.3.2.) | qu‑šqúlla ʾáyya skìnta| Get up and take this knife (A15:8). Used anaphorically: ʾíθwa xá bàxta,| … ʾáyya bàxta| kùt‑yum| goyàwa,| maxláwa ṭla‑bróna dìya| There was a woman … Everyday this woman would beg to feed her son (A14:4); ʾàyyɛla,| čú-mdi xéna lìθən| That is it. There is nothing else (that is possible) (A4:43).

ʾazəduθa n.f. permission; freedom consent | ʾána mbáqrən mə́nnux ʾazədúθa yàtwən| I ask you for permission to sit down.

ʾazəd adj. (invar.) (K./P.) allowed, permitted

ʾăzīz n.m./adj. dear (A.) | yà ʾăzízi| my dear (A7:17); ʾăzizət ləbbi my dear; ʾăzizət xone beloved of his brother (C4:6)

ʾazla-kuše n.f. (pl. ʾazla-kuše) dragonfly | Literally: spinner of distaffs, so-called because it rotates around water.

ʾazola n.m. (pl. ʾazole) weaver | ʾazolət kuša weaver who uses a spindle

ʾažvana n.m. (pl. ʾažvane) (K.) miller, caretaker of a water-mill

ʾeða n.m. (pl. ʾeðăwaθa) festival; festival visit. (1) festival | ʾéðux brìxa!| May your festival be blessed!; y‑óði ʾèða| They hold a festival (B6:22); ʾeða goṛa the Great Festival (Easter); ʾeðət qyamta the festival of resurrection (Easter); ʾeða zora the Small Festival (Christmas); ʾeðət be-yalda Christmas; ʾeðət musarde festival commemorating the baptism of Christ (100 days after Easter); ʾeðət ṣliwa Festival of the Cross (13th of September). (2) festival visit | xaðríwa náše ʾeðăwàθa| People would go around (the village offering) festival blessings (B10:3); zavrə́xwa ʾeðăwàθa| We used to go around (the village offering) festival blessings (B6:13); mšɛrìwa| … jwája l‑ʾeðăwáθa d‑an‑xène| They would begin to go and make festival visits to other people (B5:63); qamáye y‑azə́xwa l‑ʾéðət qàša| First we would go and offer a festival blessing to the priest (B6:14).

ʾɛka (ʾayka marginal) where? how? (1) where | ʾɛ̀kɛle?| ‘Where is he?’ (A4:19); lé-y-yăðən ʾána ʾɛ̀kən| I do not know where I am (A14:88); ʾáw xzèle ʾo‑dídwa ʾɛ́ka wìrre| He saw where the fly had entered (A11:9); ʾɛ̀kɛt zála?| Where are you going?; m-ɛ̀kət ʾəθya? From where has he come? (2) how? | ʾɛ́ka pɛ́šət xwàrθi?!| How will you become my friend?! (A52:5); huðáya ʾə́č̣č̣i-u ʾə́č̣č̣a dáwe zìle mə́nne,| ʾɛ́ka ṱ-áθya šə̀nθe?!| The Jew has lost ninety-nine gold coins. How could he sleep!? (A6:3); m-ɛ̀kɛle pč̣íla?| How can it be crooked? (A17:20); m‑àyka| har‑là‑mṣən ṱ‑amrə́nnux| I cannot tell you how (A11:2).

ʾeliθa f. (pl. ʾəlyaθa) fat tail of sheep; fat of the tail | p̭azesór b‑ʾəlyàθa| big red eared sheep with fat tails (A7:22); ʾelíθa qalə̀xwa| We would fry the tail fat (B10:1).

ʾenir n.m. aromatic lily | pɛšət ʾenir lɛle You are (like) the lily of the night (C4:14).

ʾeta n.f. (pl. ʾetaθa) church (as an institution)

ʾetanaya adj. (f. ʾetanɛθa, pl. ʾetanaye) ecclesiastical | gu-d-ánna tre-ʾumràne| xə́lmət ʾetanɛ́θa y‑oðə́xwala gáwe dìye| In these two churches we used to hold church services (B1:6).

ʾɛba n.m. shame, wrong | ʾɛ̀bɛle| It is shameful; lɛle-ʾɛ́ba ʾəllì?| Would not that be a shame on me? (A8:55).

ʾɛna n.f. eye; aperture; spring of water. (1) eye (pl. ʾɛne) | murmə́lla ʾɛ́ne dìye He raised his eyes, ʾu-ʾɛ́ni-žigən hóla bṣìre| My eyes have deteriorated (A24:10); xonăwáθi θéla qam-ʾɛ̀ni| My brothers have come to mind (A18:12); rába xzìθa ʾɛ́ne díye| m-d-ò-məndi| He had suffered a lot from that affair (A18:32); garət ʾɛna eyelid. (2) aperture (pl. ʾɛnaθa) | in a field boundary for the introduction of irrigation water: dwíqle ʾɛ́nət xáqla b-màssa| He closed the irrigation aperture of the field with a pole. (3) spring of water (pl. ʾɛnaθa, ʾɛnăwaθa) | ʾɛ́na hóla nwàʾa| A spring is welling up, ʾƐ̄n-Nune Spring of Fishes (village name), ʾɛ́nət K̭ùtto| … ʾɛ́nət ʾùmra| the spring of K̭utto … the spring of the church (the two water springs in ʾƐn-Nune B10:61); ʾu-píšla rəš-ʾɛ̀na| She remained at the spring (A25:57); zílle rəš-ʾɛ̀na| He went to the spring (A15:2). (4) Idioms: gu‑d‑ànna ʾɛ́ni bṱ‑áθən| (I promise) by these eyes (of mine) that I shall come (A22:20); ða-ʾáqla rēš-d-àyya ʾɛ́nən| ʾu-ðá rēš-d-àyya| We shall treat you with respect (literally: one leg on this eye of ours and one on this other one B9:10).

ʾɛnəkθa n.f. (pl. ʾɛnəkyaθa) small hole | in shoes, through which a srap (gaðilta) is inserted; in the middle of a grind-stone (pənxa).

ʾɛni part. who?; which? (§14.9.14.). (1) who? | ʾɛ̀nile?| Who is he? (A2:7); ʾɛ̀ni híwle‑lləx?| Who gave it to you? (A4:19); ʾɛ́nile qṭìləlle?| Who has killed him? (A15:16). (2) which | ʾɛ́ni mənnɛ́xu ṱ-àzəl?| Which of you will go? (A30:1); ʾɛ̀ni-mənnən| biš‑šapìrtɛla| Which of us is most beautiful (A25:17). Modifier of a noun: ʾɛ́ni báxtɛla mubrɛ̀θa?| Which woman has given birth? (A25:6); ga-ʾɛ́ni Zìne| ʾáxni lɛ̀ðəx| Now, which Zine we do not know (A26:61); pə́nxa ʾɛ́ni mənnɛ̀le?| Which of the (types of) grind wheel is it? (B5:92).

ʾɛ̄n-nunaya n.m./adj. (pl. ʾɛ̄n-nunaye) man from ʾƐn-Nune

ʾɛnta n.f. (pl. ʾɛnyaθa) airhole of oven; hole in a wheat storage bin (kwara) to take out the wheat

ʾɛra adj. (invar.) fitting | ṣáwle ʾɛ́rɛla ṭla-ʾaqlàθi| The shoes fit my feet.

ʾɛwa n.m. (pl. ʾɛwe) cloud | míya m-ʾɛ̀we šáte| He drinks water from the clouds (= He is arrogant); in 1st person boasting about own power: ʾu‑ʾána míya m-ʾɛ̀wən štáya| I can drink water even from the clouds (I have such power) (A26:34).

ʾɛwana adj. (f. ʾɛwanta, pl. ʾɛwane) cloudy | dúnye hóla ʾɛwànta| It is cloudy.

ʾəč̣č̣a num. (f. ʾəčča) nine | ʾurzət ʾəč̣č̣a the ninth man; baxtət ʾəčča the ninth woman

ʾəč̣č̣assər num. nineteen

ʾəč̣č̣aθn– num. nine of | base for pronominal suffixes: ʾəč̣č̣aθnən the nine of us; ʾəč̣č̣aθnɛxu the nine of you; ʾəč̣č̣aθnéy the nine of them

ʾəč̣č̣i num. ninety

ʾədara n.f. (A.) administration

ʾədda n.m. weed; weeds (collective) | ʾay-ʾắra máre ʾə̀ddɛla| That ground is full of weeds.

ʾədlɛle adv. tonight | ʾə́dlɛle dámxəx ʾàxxa| Let’s sleep here tonight (A4:29).

ʾəðma n.m. (pl. ʾəðmăwaθa) brother of husband

ʾədyo, ʾədyoma (marginal) adv. today | qámθa ʾu-ʾə́dyo yòma| formerly and nowadays

ʾəḥtəfāl n.m. (A.) celebration

ʾəjara n.f. (A.) wages, hire | ʾáxni šáqləx ḥáqqət ʾəjàra mǝ́nne díye| We shall receive wages from him (A14:15).

ʾəjbona n.m. will (of God) | hár ʾəjbóna dìyux‑ile| It is your will (A9:4).

ʾəlla part. unless, only if, except, but, particle of insistence; or not (§19.5.5.). (1) unless | b‑ču‑ʾúrxa ʾo‑Dəmdə́ma lɛ́ šaqlìtule| ʾə́lla qăṭítula míyət Dəmdə̀ma| By no means will you capture Dəmdəma unless you cut off the water of Dəmdəma (A11:17); xə́tna lè-y-axəl| ʾə́lla qablíle xà-məndi| The groom would not eat unless they pledged something to him (B10:40); là qɛṣə́nne káwsux,| ʾə́lla ṱ‑amrə́tli ʾánna ma‑brinànela gu‑réšux| I shall not cut your hair, unless you tell me what these wounds are on your head (A29:5-6). (2) only if | ʾána míθənwa l-márya ʾalàha| ʾə́lla ṱ-aθyáwa báxta bàθri,| ṱ-azànwa| I had sworn to the Lord God that only if a woman came after me would I go (A8:94). (3) except | combined with a negator = only: w-ána hon-mə́rta ṭla-Nozàli| ʾána le-gáwrən ʾə́lla xóna díya Gozàli| I said to Nozali that I would only marry her brother Gozali (A8:95). (4) but, but rather | ʾu-čú bəṛ-náša la‑máṭəlla ʾə́lla b-rzáyət gána-diya ṱ-àθya| Nobody can reach her, but rather she comes of her own will (A8:65). (5) particle of insistence | ʾə̀lla gáwrət| You must marry (A16:6); ʾə́lla xazyánne xòni| I must see my brother (A8:66). (6) or not | ʾáw lɛ́ðe čádrət bábe díyila ʾə̀lla| He did not know whether it was his father’s tent or not (A28:33).

ʾəḷḷaya, ḷaya adj. (f. ʾəḷḷɛθa, pl. ʾəḷḷaye) upper | → be-ḷaye upper room

ʾəltəx adv. below

ʾəmma n.m. (pl. ʾəmmaye) hundred | tre ʾəmma ~ tre-mma two hundred; ṭḷaθa ʾəmma ~ ṭḷaθa-mma three hundred; ʾáwwa ʾə́mma mən-ʾə́mma ʾíle Fàrxo| This is a hundred percent (=certainly) Farxo (A25:45); zìlela| ʾəmmáyət náše mɛθóye Bə́lbəl Hazàr| Hundreds of people went to bring back Bəlbəl Hazar (A8:30).

ʾən part. if (§19.5.); either/or (§19.5.6.1.); interrogative particle. (1) if | ʾən‑pálšəx mən‑d‑áni qaṭlìlən| If we fight with them, they will kill us (A14:44); ʾən-lá-ʾazən mšàyðən| If I do not go, he will go mad (A4:27); ʾən‑kpìnni,| ṱ‑axlə̀nne| If I get hungry, I shall eat it (A23:5); ʾən-íle mìθa,| gắrəg mɛ̀θən| If he is dead, I must die (A8:61); ʾən‑ʾíθ pàwxa,| ʾi‑marmíle gu‑hàwa| If there is wind, they raise it in the air (B5:97); ʾə́n-in ʾàna ʾə́θya gu-šwíθəx,| qrɛ́gən xaddàməx| If I have come to sleep in you bed, call your servants (A26:4); máṣət ṱ‑óðət rába məndiyáne mə́nne dìye,| ʾən‑ila zawdàne| You can make make many (other) things from them, if they are left over (B5:219). Complement of the verb ‘to wait’: sàpri| ʾən‑háwe pàwxa| They wait for there to be wind (B5:97). (2) either/or | là‑barya| gànwi| ʾən‑sàlbi| They cannot steal or plunder (A29:39); ʾən‑qaṭlə́nnux ʾáyya bráta šaqlə̀nna| ʾən‑la‑pálṭən m‑àxxa| Either I shall kill you and take this girl or I shall not go out from here (A29:28); ʾən‑ile-qṭìla,| ʾən-ile xìla| He has either been killed or he has been eaten (by wild animals) (A39:17); lɛ́la ðáʾa módi bràya,| hadíya pɛ́ša kèpa| ʾə́n la-pɛ́ša kèpa| She did not know what was happening, whether she would now turn to stone or not turn to stone (A8:73). (3) interrogative particle | ʾə́n máṣət šaqlə̀tla?| Can you take it? (A39:9).

ʾəngaliyon n.f. Gospel

ʾəngləznaya n.m. /adj. (pl. ʾəngəznaye) English

ʾənjaṣa n.m. (pl. ʾənjaṣe) wild plum

ʾənwa n.m. (pl. ʾənwe) grape | ʾənwe kome black grapes; ʾənwə baṣirana type of grapes (slow to ripen); ʾənwe zarrək type of yellow grape

ʾəqba n.f. (pl. ʾəqbaθa) heel | ʾəqbət ʾaqli heel of my foot

ʾərba n.m. (pl. ʾərbe, ʾərwe) sheep; goat | ʾərwət xware sheep; ʾərwət kome goats; ʾərwət wala wild goats, ibexes

ʾərbala n.f. (pl. ʾərbale) sieve with medium sized holes

ʾəršana adj. (f. ʾəršanta, pl. ʾəršane) mirky

ʾəršanuθa n.f. mirkiness

ʾərwana n.m. (pl. ʾərwane) charity; charitable gift, good deed | wídle xa‑ʾərwàna| He did a good deed

ʾərwe → ʾərba

ʾərxe → ʾarxe

ʾərxuθa n.f. length

ʾəryana n.f. rainfall, rain storm | gu‑ʾəryàne| in rain storms (B5:124); bás l‑ʾəryàna zăríla| They sow it relying only on rainfall (B5:94).

ʾərzala n.f. (pl. ʾərzale) portable bed | made of wood with bedding of grass and hay: ṣlele m‑ərzala čira He got out of bed in a temper (C2:38).

ʾəspa n.m. (pl. ʾəspe) loan (in kind) | šqílli zeðáye b-ʾə̀spa| I borrowed some flat-breads; šqílli xə́ṭṭe b-ʾə̀spa| I borrowed wheat; híwle zeðáye b-ʾə̀spa| I lent some flat-breads. Not used for the loan of money → dyn (III m-dyn).

ʾəsra n.f. (pl. ʾəsraθa) large storage basket | made of willow cane (xelape) or twigs from the mulberry tree (tuθa)

ʾəsri num. twenty

ʾəstaðta n.f. mistress | mə́ra:| xadàmta!| béna ʾəstàðti| She said ‘Servant!’ (The servant said) ‘(I am coming) at once, madam’ (A37:13).

ʾəstəqbāl n.m. (A.) reception

ʾəṣər n.f. intense cold (of winter) | ʾəṣərila It is very cold; ʾəṣər brizta dry cold

ʾəṣra num. (f. ʾəssər) ten | ʾurzət ʾəṣra the tenth man; baxtət ʾəssər the tenth woman.

ʾəṣraya n.m. (pl. ʾəṣraye) udder

ʾəṣraθn– num. ten of | base for pronominal suffixes: ʾəṣraθnən the ten of us; ʾəṣraθnɛxu the ten of you; ʾəṣraθnéy the ten of them.

ʾəṣya adj. (f. ṣiθa, pl. ʾəṣye) stuck, trapped

ʾəškăra → škăra

ʾəšrāf n.m. (A.) supervision | ʾána ṱ-óðən ʾəšrāf ʾəllèy| I shall look after them (A8:18).

ʾəššeta adv. this year

ʾəšta num. (f. ʾəššət) six | ʾurzət ʾəšta the sixth man; baxtət ʾəššət the sixth woman.

ʾəštassər num. sixteen

ʾəštaθn– num. six of | base for pronominal suffixes: ʾəštaθnən the six of us; ʾəštaθnɛxu the six of you; ʾəštaθnéy the six of them.

ʾəšti num. sixty

ʾəšwəṭ n.m. February

ʾəšwɛrəš → ʾarəšwɛrəš

ʾəttəfāq n.m. (A.) agreement

ʾəxre n.pl.tan. excrement

ʾəzla n.m. (pl. ʾəzle) yarn | guttət ʾəzla a ball of yarn; ʾə̀zlɛle zqíra| It is knitted with yarn.

ʾəzza n.f. (pl. ʾəzze) nanny goat

ʾəzzəkθa n.f. nanny goat

ʾəzzət wala n.f. (pl. ʾəzzət wala) wild goat (inhabiting mountains)

ʾi- → ʾiθ

ʾiða n.f. (pl. ʾiθaθa, ʾiðăwaθa ʾiðe) hand; handle; arm; foot (of an animal); round of a game. (1) hand | ʾíðux lá-darət gu-nùra| t-là-ʾaqða| Do not put your hand in the fire, lest it burn (D2:8); b‑ʾíðe díye dawùqle| He would hold it in his hand (B6:3); zríyənwale b‑iθàθi| I had cultivated it with my hands (A17:32); b‑ìðən xɛṭə́xwa| We would sew by hand (B10:59); hállule l-ʾìði| Hand him over into my custody (A28:25). (2) handle | ʾiðət tăra handle of a door; ʾiðət magreta the handle of the shaving knife. (3) arm | dawɛ́ra ʾíðe‑w ʾàqle| A mule (is a man’s) arms and legs (B5:124); šǝ́ryəlla ʾáqle w‑ìðe| He untied the legs and arms (A10:13). (4) foot (of an animal) | qímle tàwra| primále ðá ʾíðe dìye| He cut off one of the feet of the ox (A22:3). (5) round of a game | kəmà ʾiθáθa mṭáləx?| How many rounds shall we play?; ṭḷà-ʾiθaθa muxsə́rre Mắmo| Mămo lost three rounds (of chest) (A26:66). (6) Idiom: l‑ʾiθàθux| in your presence (A12:29).

ʾiðamta, ʾiðamθa n.f. (pl. ʾiðamyaθa) sister of husband; wife of brother of husband | pl. ʾiðamyaθa wives of brothers

ʾilakka, yălək, yălakka n.m. (pl. ʾilakke) (T.) waistcoat | worn over a shirt (ṣudra)

ʾilana n.f. (pl. ʾilane, ʾilanane) tree

ʾilanta n.f. (pl. ʾilanyaθa) tree, small tree

ʾilul n.m. September

ʾimān n.m. (A.) faith, trust

ʾiman, ʾima part. when. (1) interrogative particle: ʾíman ṱ-àθət? When will come?; hal‑ʾíma dàməx?| Until when will he sleep? (A12:8); bắyən t-yắðən ʾána ʾíman mɛ̀θena| I want to know when I shall die (A16:1). (2) Governing temporal subordinate clause: ʾíman ṱ‑àθyət,| ða-kista-xéta max-d-áy yawə̀nnəx| When you come back, I’ll give you another purse like that one (A4:16). ʾiman-t >ʾimə(t): ʾímət xílla ʾap-o-t-trè,| píšla xà-šabθa,| tré šabbàθa,| kpìnna| When they had eaten the second one, a week, two weeks went by and they became hungry (A20:9); ʾímə zílle kəs-màlka,| díwənt málka hóle ṃḷíθa náše ràbe| When he went to the king, the audience chamber of the king was full of many people (A17:31).

ʾina part. presentative particle; but; otherwise (§18.1.5.). (1) presentative particle | in association with verbs of perception: ʾə́θyela xə̀zye| ʾína ṭéna kúlle ṃə́ḷya šə̀xta| They came and saw that the saddle bag was completely full of filth (A7:11); qímela zíle xǝ́zye ʾína dū̀s| They went and saw that it was true (A14:13); xazéle ʾína bɛ́θe ṃə̀ḷya| He sees that his house is full (A21:8); paθə̀xle tắra,| ʾína xazéle ʾo‑ʾažvána tàma| He opened the door and saw the caretaker there (A22:43). Implied verb of perception: mátti bála gu‑yàma,| ʾìna| ʾa‑sústət yamàθa| nabòləlla| Čəlkằze| They looked at the sea (and saw) the mare of the seas taking away Čəlkăze (A12:34); ʾo-xabúša pθìxtəlle,| ʾína ʾisə́qθa dìya| She opened up the apple and (saw) her ring (A4:19). Introducing preliminary background material: ṭḷáθna hon‑yíwtəlla mòʿəd.| ʾína ṱ‑áθi làxxa.| ʾáti kúl fàtra| mṭašə́tla gánux baràye| I have made an assignation with the three of them. Now, (when) they come here, each time you hide yourself outside (A22:21-22). Climactic result: ṣléla tàma.| ʾína kúlla gɛ́rme díya šmìṭe.| She went down there and all her bones were broken (A20:4). In commands: ʾína m-báθər maqðàli| ʾaw-qə̀ṭma| šaqlìtule| mxamìtule| Now, after she burns me, take the ashes and keep them (A26:85). (2) but | drawing attention to something unexpected: ʾána bắyənwa šaqlə́nwali xáčča mə̀šxa| … ta‑ṱ‑áxlən b‑ʾùrxa| xáčča mə́šxa‑w lə̀xma| ʾína ʾíði ṣéla gu‑d‑áwwa hə́nna lìnta| I wanted to take a little oil to eat on the way, a little oil and bread, but my hand has got stuck in this thing, the pot (A23:8); ʾə̀θyela,| plíṭe bárqul mðitèy.| ʾína mðitéy kúlla mxíθa l-kòma| They came out opposite their town. But, their town was all covered in black. (A4:28). In exclamatory constructions: ʾánna ṣàli| ʾína mò ṣáli| They went and what (a surprise when) they went down! (A25:13); xá‑bena plíṭṭɛla xa‑bràta.| ʾína mù‑brata!| Then a girl came out, but what a girl! (A13:11); xílənna ʾína mòdi!| I have eaten it, so what! (A2:11). (3) otherwise | ʾána hon-márəllux b-àyya šárṭ ʾaláha t-yawə́llux,| ʾína là-yawəllux| I am telling you, God will give to you on this condition, otherwise he will not give to you (A3:5).

ʾinta n.f. (pl. ʾine) small edible nut (small terebinth bəṭma) | ʾilanət ʾinta a tree with bunches (qonṭepe) of such nuts

ʾipta n.f. (pl. ʾipyaθa) strap made of gut connecting yoke of animals to the plough

ʾiqa adj. (f. ʾiqta, pl. ʾiqe) narrow; distressed | tắrət gómi ʾìqɛle| The door of my basement stable is narrow (A7:24); yắðət b-gànux| ʾìqənwa,| danànənwa| You know, by your soul, that I was in trouble, I was in debt (A1:10).

ʾiqara n.m. honour; respect; privilege | maṣlɛ́lən b-iqàra| They bring us down (to the town) with honour (A4:30); ʾáwwa wéwa xa‑ʾiqàra| This was a (sign of) respect (B5:68); ʾána mattə́nnux ʾiqàra I respect you; rába mattə́xwa ʾiqára ʾəllèy| We felt great respect for them (B15:10); mattə́xwa ʾiqára xa‑qa‑d‑o‑xèna| We used to show respect to one another (B5:229); wéləx hawnànta,| b-ʾiqárət ṣáwθa basìmta,| ʾu-màqul| You have been clever, with the gift of sweet and fine words (A40:16).

ʾiquθa n.f. distress | hóle npíla gu-ʾiqùθa| He has fallen into distress (A29:29)

ʾiranaya n.m./adj. (pl. ʾiranaye) Iranian

ʾisaqta n.f. ascension | ʾisáqtət Mšíxa l‑šmàyya| the ascension of Christ to Heaven (B6:7)

ʾisara n.m. (pl. ʾisare) large rock; cliff | ṭúra ʾisáre ramàne| a mountain with high rocks (A15:13); ma-ṱ-íle ʾisára m-kúlla goyàθa| since there is such a huge rock on all sides (of the mountain) (A8:48).

ʾisarta n.f. gravel | put in foundations of a house

ʾisəqθa n.f. (pl. ʾisəqyaθa) ring

ʾitawa n.m. sitting | dúkθət ʾitàwa| a sitting place, a seat (B6:7)

ʾixala n.m. (pl. ʾixalyaθa) food, a meal

ʾiyyətnaya n.m. (pl. ʾiyyətnaye) a man from ʾIyyət

ʾiθ part. (variants: ʾiθən, ʾiθena, ʾiθga, ʾiθgən, ʾiθgena. past: ʾiθwa) existential particle (§8.20.1., §15.3.8., §17.3.) (1) Used without suffixes | ʾíθən xa-ṭùra| There is a mountain (A24:11); ʾána ʾíθ šùla qámi| There is work in front of me (to do) (A24:45); hóla ʾíθən jə̀nne gáwa!| There are jinn in it! (A22:33); ʾíθwa xa-màlka| There was a king (A1:2). (2) With L-suffixes expressing possession: ʾitle, ʾiθwale | ʾítli ðá bratət-màma| I have a cousin (A7:17); ʾíθwalən xa‑màlka| We had a king (A4:31). (3) With pronominal suffixes attached to b-: ʾiθbe, ʾiθwabe, ʾibe, ʾiwabe | mə́ṭyɛle xa-káwtət ʾə̀rwe,| ʾíbe tre-ṭḷáθa ʾálpa rēš-ʾə̀rwe| He came to a flock of sheep, in which there were two or three thousand head of sheep (A32:14); ʾìwabi| ʾəṣrá šə̀nne| I was ten years old (B5:130); mo‑ʾìba! What is there in it (= That is fine, OK) (A13:1).

ʾo part. vocative particle | ʾó Dànno| Hey Danno!

ʾojəx n.m. (pl. ʾojaxe) tribe | goṛət ʾojəx head of tribe; le‑y‑yawíwa mən‑ʾójəx l‑ʾòjəx| They did not give (brides) from one tribe to another (B5:3).

ʾore n.f. (pl. ʾorăwaθa) manger | qəm-darɛ́le gu-ʾórət susăwàθa| They have put him in the horses’ manger (A25:11)

ʾorta n.m./f. (K.) marble game | The aim is to dislodge marbles in a central target by shooting other marbles at them (B11:25ff.)

ʾosta → hosta

ʾotel n.f. hotel

ʾotəx, ʾotaxa n.f./m. (pl. ʾotaxe) (K./T.) room

ʾo-xa, ʾo-xaha pron. ms. demonstrative (§14.3.5.) | Denoting the accessibility of a referent in memory: txárət ʾo-xa-náša t-wéwa láxxa qam-šàbθa?| Do you remember the man who was here a week ago?; ʾána ʾo‑xà qáša| ṱ‑ín ʾə́θya gu‑Ṭiyàre,| qəm‑doqə́tli xošə́tli gu‑gòma| I am the priest who (you remember) came to Ṭiyare, whom you seized and confined me in the basement stable (B17:15).

ʾuðala → huðala

ʾujaje n.pl. pelvis bones

ʾuḷḷuḷ adv. above

ʾumqa n.m. depth | maṣlánnux gu‑ʾúmqət yamàθa| I shall take you down into the depth of the seas (A12:31)

ʾumra n.m. (pl. ʾumre, ʾumrane) church

ʾumra, ʾŭmur m. age | kmɛ́le ʾumrùx?| How old are you?; ʾána ʾŭ́mur díyi ʾəštà-šənnewa| I was six years old (B15:32).

ʾŭmur → ʾumra

ʾupra n.m. (pl. ʾuprane) soil, ground; land | bắyən t‑xazə́nne ʾúpra dìyi| I want to see my land (A14:47)

ʾurədxa n.f. (pl. ʾurədxe, ʾurədxaθa) long needle | lá-maxət gúšma ʾurə̀dxa| Do not punch a needle (D2:59)

ʾurṭiθa n.f. (pl. ʾurṭiyaθa) noisy fart → m-rṭ, ṭur

ʾurwa, hurwa n.m. (pl. ʾurwe) raven

ʾurxa n.f. (pl. ʾurxaθa) road; way. (1) road, way (physical) | b-ʾúrxa tfíqɛle xá-xuwwe bìye| On the road a snake met him (A1:4); ṣléle ʾurxa‑úrxa xzéle ʾína pyáša dəbbòre| He went down and along the way saw that they were becoming hornets (A10:10); kút-yom dawə́qwala ʾúrxe b-ʾìðe| Every day he went the same way (A34:29); bálki lɛ́la ʾúrxət dyàṛa| Perhaps it is the road of no return (A37:10); ʾurxət genawe the Milky Way; ʾurxət šaqiθa the track of a waterchannel. (2) way (abstract), method | ʾíθwa rába ʾurxáθa mṭawòle| There were many ways to play (B15:5); dáx ʾúrxa muxzélux ʾə́lla lípla ʾàwwa šúla?| How did you show her the way to learn this work? (A21:34). (3) Idioms: báxte díye hóla b-ʾùrxa díya| His wife is now pregnant (A8:5); báxte díye láwa píšta b-ʾùrxa| His wife has not become pregnant (A8:5).

ʾurza n.m. (pl. ʾurze) man; male | ʾúrzət bɛ̀θa| the man of the house, the householder (B5:117)

ʾustāð n.m. (pl. ʾustaðe) (A.) teacher, master


/ʿ/

ʿabīd n.m. (A.) slave, slaves

ʿadi adj. invar. (A.) ordinary

ʿafrīt n.m. (A.) demon

ʿaksa, ʿaks, ʿăkəs n.m. (A.) contrary. part. opposite | xá l-ʿáks d-o-xèna| (A26:8).

ʿălaqa n.f. (A.) connection, relation

ʿalwa n.f. (A.) auction house

ʿal‑ʾasās part. (A.) in order that, because; that (complementizer)

ʿăqīd n.m. (A.) colonel

ʿărăbi n.m. (A.) Arabic (language)

ʿăṣăbi adj. invar. (A.) nervous, angry

ʿăšira n.f. (pl. ʿăšaʾər) n.pl. (A.) tribe

ʿaʾəla n.f. (pl. ʿăwaʾəl) (A.) family

ʿəllaga n.f. (A.) bag



/b/

b- prep. (rare variant biyət; with pfronominal suffixes, biye, biye diye, bi-diye, ʾəbbe) (§13.3.2., §16.1.) in, at, on, with, by means of. (1) Spatial and temporal location: šqílɛle qɛ́sa b‑ʾíðe dìye| He took the stick in his hand (A22:30); b-lɛ̀le at night (A15:8). (2) Instrument: zríyənwale b-iθàθi| I have cultivated it with my hands (A17:32). (3) Comitative and associative: ʾáθi b‑dáwla-w zórna-w tópe-w Let them come with the drum and pipe and with guns (A4:33); lìtlən šúla bíye| We have no business with it (= It is not our business) (A48:6). (4) Attributive: ʾána b‑zawnə́nne ʾən‑háwe b‑tə́rte ʾaqlàθa| I shall buy it if it has one leg (A22:9). (5) Material: ṱ-oðə́tli gə́šra b‑qɛ̀sa| Make me a bridge of wood (A17:18). (6) Price: xá-kilo ʾə́xre b-ṭḷáθa dàwɛle| One kilo of dung sells for three gold pieces (A7:14). (7) Manner: maṣlɛ́lən b-iqàra| They bring us down with honour (A4:30). (8) Cause: ʾámər b‑àyyət mšúdrəlli?| Was it for this (reason) you sent for me? (A21:32). (9) Oath: b‑álaha ʾáwwa xoš‑yàlɛle| By God, he is a good lad (A21:5). (10) Combined with other prepositions: hóle də́rya jùlla b-réša| He put a cloth over them (A25:48). → bəd, bud

baʾuθət ninwaye n.f. the Rogation of the Ninevites (Assyrian national festival) | Three days fast commemorating the flood of Nineveh (B6:17ff.)

baʿd part. (A.) then | báʿd módi xèna?| Then, what else? (A23:35)

baʿdēn part. (A.) afterwards

baba n.m. (pl. babăwaθa) father; term of endearment. (1) father | bábi muttúle táma bɛ̀θa| My father set up home there (B8:10); xá-naša l-xóðe lítle la-bába la-yə́mma la-ʾàp-xa,| ʾáw y‑amrìle| lìtle náše| A man by himself, who does not have a father, a mother or anybody—he—they say concerning him that he has no relatives (A17:17); bábe díye ʾu-d-áni ʾə̀θyela| His father and his father’s family came (A4:55); bábən t-šmàyya| our heavenly father (B8:16). (2) term of endearment | babi my dear (said by parent to child, or by a person to a friend); ṭla-mòdi bábi?| Why my dear? (mother to son) (A26:71); mòdi mára,| bàbi?| What is he saying, my friend? (A7:25); bábət yə́mmux dear one of your mother (= my dear son) (A37:9).

bădal, m-bădal part. (A.) instead of | qímla ʾáy m‑bắdal xmáθa dìya| She got up instead of her mother-in-law (A21:22).

badəkka n.m. (pl. badəkke) hut

badiya n.m. (pl. badiye) brass vessel (for water and dawwe)

badoda n.m. (pl. badode) long wooden poker for stirring up the fire of an oven

baġdednaya n.m. (pl. baġdednaye) man from Baghdad

băgəbăgi n.m. multicoloured embroidered fabric

băḥar n.m. (A.) sea

băharāt n.pl. (A.) spices

bahər, bɛhər, bɛhɛri n.m (pl. bahare, bɛhɛre, bɛhɛriye) (K.) Spring (season)

bahogər, buhugar n.f. (K.) blizzard (of snow)

bahs, bas prep. (with pronominal suffixes: bahs diye) about, concerning | bahsət šuli about my job; bahs d-awwa məndi about his thing; hon-šə̀mya bas-díye| I have heard about it (A8:41).

bahura adj. (f. bahurta, pl. bahure) shining, resplendent | mjagra m-kima bahurta She contends with the resplendent Pleiades (C2:74)

băjara n.m. (K.) alternative, choice | líθ băjàra| ʾə́lla bṱ-àzəx| There is no alternative, we must go (A8:27).

bajəlla n.m. (pl. bajəlle) broad bean

bajoniya n.m. (pl. bajoniye) lycium barbarum berry | edible red berry

baksăma n.m. (pl. baksăme) big loaf made from flour of wheat

bala n.m. mind | másyəm bàla!| Pay attention!; másyəm bála l-gànux! Look after yourself!; ʾánna gắrəg xamǝ̀xla-w| masíməx bála ʾǝ̀lla| We must care for them and look after them (A8:15); mattítu bàla!| Pay attention! (A8:28); mátti bála gu‑yàma| They looked at the sea (A12:34); máttu bála b‑gáne dìye| nubə́lle rəš‑d‑o‑ṭùra| He realized that it had taken him onto the mountain (A14:69); Čúxo híwle bále l-bɛ̀θa| Čuxo set off for home (A7:12); kúlla lɛ̀lela l-bálux?| Has it been on your mind all night? (A25:67); hál hadíya ʾáwwa məndiyáne píšela l-bàlən| Until now these things remain in my mind (B15:1); b‑álaha l‑bàli| It just occurred to me (A8:41).

balakšənka | xuwwe balakšənka type of snake

bălam n.f. (pl. bălame) boat

bălāš adj. invar. (A.) free, without charge

balaya n.m. (pl. balaye) problem; trouble; disaster | npílli gu-balàya| I am in trouble, I have a problem; m-ɛ́ka píšlux baláya ʾə̀lli?| Why are you such a trouble to me? (A17:4).

balazeze n.pl. (sing. balazeza f.) yellowy white Spring flowers | grows with four stems (taqane)

balki part. perhaps | bálki ʾàθya| Perhaps she will come (A8:49); bálki lá‑ʾawðən xàbrux| Perhaps I shall not do as you say (A21:43); bálki qam-xa-šàbθɛle ʾə́θya| He has come perhaps just a week ago (A8:56). Governing a clause introduced by D: bálki ṱ‑íla mìθta,| bálki ṱ‑íle xa‑mə́ndi θíθa bìya| Perhaps she is dead. Perhaps something has happened to her (A21:25); bálki yăðálux ʾáti ṱ-it-Gozàli| Perhaps she knows that you are Gozali (A8:49).

balla n.m./adj. (f. and pl. balle) (K.) erect; sheep with erect ears | qumta rixana balla Her figure is (that of) an erect odiferous basil (C2:44)

bălo n.f. (pl. bălowaθa) whirlpool

balota n.f. (pl. baloyaθa) throat | balotət tope muzzle of a gun; balotət pənxa hole of a millstone (into which grain is introduced)

baluṭa m.n. (pl. baluṭe) acorn, nut of fruit that grows on oak trees (mɛša, paṛma) tree | given to animals to eat

baluʿa n.m./f. (A.) drain, conduit, sewer

bambula n.m. (pl. bambule) spout (on a pot)

banaya, bannaya n.m. (pl. banaye, bannaye) builder

banda n.m. (pl. bande) (K.) section of a song

bandək n.m. (pl. bandake) (K.) harness made of rope used to secure bundles of wood on back of animal

banjane (sing. banjanta f., banjana m.) tomatoes, aubergines | banjane smoqe tomatoes; banjane kome aubergines

bănude n.pl. (K.) swaddling bands (wrapped around baby in a cradle) | bănúde qmìṭela| The bands are tied; šaryáwa bănúda dìya| She untied her bands (A18:1).

banyo n.m. (A./I.) bath, bathtub

baqa n.m. (pl. baqe) gnat; small waterborn insect | ʾani‑míya lɛ́la qa-štɛ̀θa,| ʾítla bàqe| This water is not for drinking, it has insects in it.

baqara n.m. (pl. baqare) cowherd, keeper of cows | dmáyɛle l-xa-rámšət baqàra| It resembles a cowherd’s dinner (i.e. it is a hotchpotch—the cowherd’s wife used to collect various different items of food from people around the village)

baqča n.m. (pl. baqče) (K.) vegetable garden, orchard

baqla n.m. (pl. baqle) red bean

baqəlla n.m. (pl. baqəlle) bean; broad bean

baqloša n.m. (pl. baqloše) pebble, small stone | tiwex xmala b-baqloše dax-xurəkke We sit and amuse ourselves (by playing with) small stones like friends (C2:31)

baqta n.f. small gnat | dukθa raba mare baqta a place with many gnats

baqurka n.m. (pl. baqurke) piglet

bar + numeral | ʾaw-ríqle bar-ʾàrbe-u| bar-xàmməš,| bar-ʾə̀ššət| He ran away with four, five or six bounds (A18:23)

băra n.m. (pl. băre) (K.) sheet

bara n.m. (pl. bare) (K.) side | m‑àwwa bára| on this side (B10:53); xríwla m‑kúlla bàre| It is utterly ruined.

barana n.m. (pl. barane) (K.) adult male sheep (four years old and upwards) | šwara barane jumping the rams (game similar to leap-frog B11:15ff.)

baraye, baray adv. outside

barbehn n.m. (pl. barbehne) window | ṣríxtɛla m-gu-barbèhn| She called out of the window (A25:59).

barbēn, barbena n.f. (pl. barbene) open space in front of house

barbiya n.f. (pl. barbiye, barbiyaθa) bridesmaid

barða n.f. hail | barða b‑qanane heavy hail; ða gəmbəltət barða a hailstone

bardi n.m. (A.) canebrake

barəbar– (K.) around | inside an area: ʾu-y-azíwa xaðrìwa| barəbárət màθa| They would go around the village (B15:66)

bărəkθa n.f. (K.) (small) sheet | pšúṭla ʾàqlux| qắdər bărə̀kθux| Stretch your legs according to your cloth (D1:6)

bar-eli adv. upwards, on the upper side | m-pálgə d-áw ʾu-bàr-eli| from its middle and upwards (A8:58); múrməlla ʾaqláθa l-bàr-eli| ʾu-réša xtàya| They lifted her legs upwards and her head downwards (A27:34).

barəšta, berəšta n.f. (pl. barəšyaθa, berəšyaθa) pillow, cushion

barəxmaya n.m. (pl. barəxmaye) brother of wife

barəxmɛθa n.f. (pl. barəxmayaθa) sister of wife

băriya n.f. (A.) creation, creatures

bariyya, bɛriyya n.f. (A.) desert

barje → xarja

barju n.f. (pl. barjuwaθa) (K.) channel connecting sections (sadde) of a paddy field

barmiya n.m. water weed (growing in rice paddy fields)

baṛ-našuθa, bəṛ-našuθa n.f. humanity, people, population | baṛ-našuθət ʾƐ̄n-Nune the people of Ɛn Nune

baroqa n.m. (pl. baroqe) shooting pain in back | mxéla baróqe gu‑xàṣi| I have shooting pains in my back.

barora n.m. (pl. barore) roll (of fabric)

ba-roža n.f./adv. (K.) side of the mountains on which the morning sun shines | ba‑ròža| ʾáy šəmšɛ̀θɛla| The ba-roža side is sunny (B5:148); ʾan‑ṱ‑íla ʾíða č̣àple| ʾíla ba-ròža| The ones (mountains) on the left are (known as) the ‘sunny side’ (B3:1); y-asqə́xwa gu-ba-ròža| We would go up onto the ‘sunny side’.

bar-qamaya n.m. front strap on a mule | This was tied round its front legs to prevent a load from falling backwards when it went up hill → bar-xaraya.

barqūl prep. (with pronominal suffixes: barqulux) opposite | plíṭe bárqūl mðitèy| They came out opposite the town (A4:28); ʾáw kə́lyɛle barqúlət bàbe| He is standing opposite his father.

barriya n.f. (A.) desert

barša n.m. namesake | barši my namesake (mode of address to somebody of the same name as that of the speaker).

bar-təxti adv. downwards; on the lower side | prùmle| m‑áxxa‑w bar‑tə̀xti| Cut it from here downwards (A14:67); gášəq bàr-təxti| He looks downwards (A28:3).

barūd n.m. (K./T.) gunpowder

baruza adj. (f. baruzta, pl. baruze) dry, dryish, characteristically dry | cf. briza (completely) dry

bar-xaraya n.m. back strap on a mule | This was tied around its hind legs to prevent a load from falling onto its neck when it went down hill → bar-qamaya.

baṛ-xəlya n.m. fennel | This is put in arak

barxošta n.f. (pl. barxošyaθa) big stirring spoon, ladle

baṛ-xoxa n.m. (pl. baṛ-xoxe) thorny pod

barziva n.m flint | used to strike fire with metal instrument known as manquš

bas part. only; no more; if only; only if; but. (1) only | Governing clause constituent: bas‑yə̀mma ʾíθwale| He had only a mother (A21:3); bas-ànən šríṭa| They have all been killed. Only I have escaped (B19:8); bas‑mìya máttət qam‑réša díya| Place only water by her head (A21:37); bas-ʾɛ́ni t-xzéla ʾày xoš-ʾáza gu-jahànnam| Only my eye, which saw it—let that go to Hell (A16:2); ʾánna júlle dìye xə́zye bás| We only found these clothes of his (A14:17). (2) no more |. mattátla xa‑kawázət míya kəs‑réša‑w bàs| Put out for her a jar of water by her head and no more (A21:10). (3) if only | Clausal connective: xuš-mɛ̀θən| bas-xáθi Nozáli xazə̀nwala| Let me die, if only I could see my sister Nozali (A8:57). (4) only if | bas-ʾánna xonăwáθi bàsmi,| gorànnux| Only if you cure these brothers of mine, shall I marry you (A34:22). (5) but | Clausal connective: ʾɛ́ne pθìxtɛla,| bas-ṭlìya hóle| His eye is open, but he is asleep (A31:6); lɛ̀le‑xəzya čù‑náša| bas‑yắðəx hóla tlíxe ʾánna bàte| Nobody has been seen, but we know that the houses have been destroyed (A29:52). Before a reduced predication: ʾax‑sinìyele| bas‑gòṛa| It is like a tray, but (it is) bigger (B6:45).

base, buse n.pl. scorn, mocking | base buse b-draya He is making all kinds of disparaging remarks (A50:2)

basəsta n.f. dish of crushed wheat cooked with husks

basima adj. (f. basimta, pl. basime) pleasant, beautiful; delicious; healthy; sharp. (1) pleasant, beautiful | dúnye basìmtɛla| The weather is pleasant; ʾu‑qále díye rába basìmɛwa| His voice is very beautiful. (A25:43-44); ʾáθṛa rába basìmɛle| It is a very pleasant place (B5:148); rába ʾítley xayúθa basímta bəd‑àyya| They had a very good life on account of this (B5:106). (2) delicious, tasty | kəma‑basìmtɛla ʾixála!| ‘How delicious the food is!’ (A21:31); lɛ̀la basíme ṭla‑xála| They are not good for eating (A43:3). (3) healthy | málka ṱ-áwət basìma| King, may you be well (A1:14); réšux ṱ-áwe basìma| May you (literally: your head) be healthy (said to a person who has been recently bereaved); basima raba Thank you very much (basimta raba said to a woman); háwət basíma ràba| qa‑d‑áwwa ʾixála ṱ‑it‑yíwəlle qa‑dìyi| Thank you very much for this food that you have given me (A22:31); ʾàyya basímta| She is the one to thank (A14:96); gánux basìmta!| Well done! (A39:21). (4) sharp | púmmət maqára basìmɛle The mouth of the gouge is sharp.

basimuθa n.f. pleasantness; health | ʾálaha yawə́llux basimùθa| God grant you good health.

basiṭa adj. (f. basiṭṭa, pl. basiṭe) easy | basìṭɛla| That is easy (A16:9).

bassa part. enough! stop! | yába dɛ̀ṛəx.| bàssa,| wídlən ṣɛ̀da,| bàssa.| Let’s return. That’s enough. We have done some hunting. That’s enough. (A4:6); bássa bxɛ̀gən| bássa wuð-tàzi| Do not weep any more! Do not mourn any more! (A26:88); bássa mgàləj!| Stop talking nonsense!; bássa ští ʾu-rwì!| Don’t drink any more and get any more drunk! With pronominal suffixes (§8.20.2.): bassi I have had enough; bassux You (ms.) have had enough; baswali I had had enough; bàssi m-xáye| I have had enough of life (A8:59); bàssən mə́nne| We have had enough of him (A41:2); ʾána ʾǝ́mma bàssi| A hundred is enough for me (A1:6).

baste n.f. (pl. bastăwaθa) expanse of stones in dried up river

baṣirana n.m. type of grape | ʾə́nwə baṣírana qarùṭela| The baṣirana grapes are tough.

baṣora adj. (f. baṣorta, pl. baṣorta) little, small (in quantity); a few. (1) little, small (in quantity) | zrúta rába baṣórta ʾìθena| There is very little cultivation (B5:75); b‑kúlla yóma zór maṣìwa| xàzdi| xá‑mdi rába baṣòra| In the whole day they can barely harvest something very little (B5:144). (2) a few | baṣóra mənnèy| ʾi-pɛšíwa yáʿni t-la maṭíwa ʾɛ́kɛle bɛθèy| A few of them remained without arriving at their house (B15:44). (3) biš-baṣora less | hálli zúze biš-baṣòre| Give me less money; ; taqríban ʾo-bíš-baṣora ʾànənwa šqíla| It was I who received almost the least (B1:19).

baṣore adv. rarely, seldom | rába baṣòre xazə́nne I rarely see him.

bašila n.m. (pl. bašile) long melon

baška n.m. (pl. baške) (K.) white mark on forehead of sheep or horse

bašqəp n.f. (pl. bašqape) saucer

băṭăna n.m. inside of wall facing into the house | as opposed to paθət guda front of wall, facing outwards

băṭaniya n.m. (pl. baṭaniye) (A.) blanket

bati n.f. my little daughter | familiar form of brati.

baθər, bar prep. (with pronominal suffixes: baθre, bare) behind; after; through. (1) behind, after (locative) | báθər tằra behind the door (A23:25); ʾaw-yála qímle npílle bàra| The boy went after her (A24:54); kɛ̀la quṣárta?| hon-θíθa báθra dìya.| Where is the cooking pot? I have come looking for it (A5:9); kú‑ṱ‑ile bàθri| mɛ́θe xa‑kɛ́rtə qɛ̀sa| Whoever is behind me (= supports me), let him bring a bundle of wood (A12:69). (2) after (temporal) báθər ṭḷá-yarxe after three months (A17:28). Combined with m- when used with temporal sense: m‑báθər xámša daqìqe| after five minutes (A22:23); ʾána m-díya m-bàθər| brátux băyə̀nna| I from now on love your daughter (A17:35). (3) through | ʾo‑gə́lda hàdəx ʾoðə́tle| naqíða ta‑t‑ʾáwər bar‑bóyət xmàṭa| Make this skin a fine (thread) so that it will go through the eye of a needle (A11:12).

baθra, bara adv. behind | ʾána qamɛ̀θa| ʾu-Zíne bàθra| ʾu-Səttíye xarɛ̀θa.| ‘me first, Zine behind and Səttiye last’ (A25:19); la-baθra, la-bara backwards

baṭibaṭo n.f. (sing. and collective, or pl. baṭibaṭowaθa) (K.) firefly

baṭila adj. (f. baṭilta, pl. baṭile) idle, without work | ta-mút baṭíla tíwa gu-bɛ̀θa?| Why are you idle sitting in the house? (A39:1); sǝ́twa baṭìle‑wɛwa náše| In winter people were unoccupied (B11:12).

baṭila n.m. (pl. baṭile) horn container | It is used to carry č̣ita (butter) as a lubricant for sharpening implements on a məšna (whetstone).

baṭiluθa n.f. lack of work

baṭman n.m. (pl. baṭmane) batman (measure of weight, approx. 7 kilos)

baṭoya n.m. (pl. baṭoye) (Urm.) piece of baked bread crust that falls from the wall of the oven

bawa n.m (pl. bawe) window without glass; open balcony of house | In winter it was blocked with woven wicker (gədla)

bawar n.m. (K.) trust | ʾána lítli báwar ʾə̀bbe| I do not trust him.

bawaruθa n.f. (K.) trust | ʾána bawarúθi θáya biyɛ̀xula| My trust is in you (said by bride to the family of the groom) (B5:41)

bawsa n.m. (pl. bawse) piece of matting (xaṣira) connecting beam between the oxen (qaṭira) to remainder of the plough

baxaya n.m/adj. (pl. baxaye) constantly weeping

baxəra n.f. (A.) steamship

băxət n.m. fate, lot, trust (K.) | bắxət ʾaláha dìyux| I implore you (to forgive me) (A1:18); bắxət ʾàlaha!| For God’s sake! (do sth. for me/us).

băxila adj. (A.) miserly; envious

baxiluθa n.f. miserliness; envy

baxlana → mbaxlana

baxoya n.m./adj. (pl. baxoye) constantly weeping

baxta n.f. (pl. baxtaθa) woman; wife | baxtət babi, băxət babi my step-mother.

baxyana adj. (f. baxyanta, pl. baxyane) constantly weeping

baybuna n.m. (pl. baybune) yellow and white flower

baybune n.pl. type of game (B7:6)

baza (i) n.m. jump, bound | tre-bàze| šwirìle Qaṭína| Qaṭina leapt two bounds (A50:10); xa-báza rìqle| He ran with one bound.

baza (ii) n.m. (pl. baze) falcon; great person | mən‑báze bára bazbùze| ʾu‑m‑bazbúze bára bàze| From great people little insignificant ones grow, and from insignificant ones great ones grow (D2:57); bazi qṭille neriya My lord (lover) killed a male goat (C2:18).

baza (iii) n.m. type of fabric

bazbuza n.m. (pl. bazbuze) small bird, insignificant person | mən‑báze bára bazbùze| ʾu‑m‑bazbúze bára bàze| From great people little insignificant ones grow, and from insignificant ones great ones grow (D2:57).

bazəkka (i) n.m. (pl. bazəkke) little jump | hóle sxáya b-bazə̀kke| He is swimming the crawl.

bazəkka (i) n.m. (pl. bazəkke) stem of a pipe (qălunka) | qălúnka bazə́kka díya rìxa y‑awéwa| The stem of the pipe was long (B7:19).

bažər n.f. (pl. bažăre) (K.) town

bázzune adv. last year, next year

bdila adj. (f. bdilta, pl. bdile) changed in colour, faint

b‑ð̣ăbəṭ adv. (A.) exactly

be- n.m. (cst.) household of; family of | nábəlla ṭla-be-šwàwən| Take it to the neighbours’ house (A5:3); ʾáwwa zílɛle be‑ʾámte dìye| He went to the home of his paternal aunt (A23:2); be-Xàmmo| the family of Xammo (A19:1); ṱ-ázən bɛ́θə be-xàli| I shall go to the house of my uncle’s family (A25:66).

be-ʾɛna n.m. forehead

be-ʾilone September (C2:80) → ʾilul

be-băxət adj. (K.) untrustworthy; dishonest | báxta be-bằxət-ila| The woman is not trustworthy (A4:3); ʾána lán-mirəllux be-bằxət-iwət| I did not say that you are dishonest (A1:21).

be-baxtuθa n.f. unfairness; untrustworthiness | xzélux be-baxtùθa| You have seen something unfair (A2:10); t‑là‑ʾamrət ʾána wáðən| be‑baxtùθa ʾǝ́llux| Don’t say that I am being deceitful to you (A13:8).

bečiya n.m. (pl. bečiye) (K.) lamb (1–3 weeks old) | qá‑t‑yátwəx qam‑bečìye| in order to look after the lambs (B5:226)

be-dənxa n.m. Epiphany

be-dyuθa n.f. inkpot; ink

beðəlta n.f. (pl. beðəlyaθa, beθaθa) sleeve

be-gwina n.m. (pl. be-gwine) eyebrow

be-kalo n.m. the family of the bride

belati | xəgga belati type of dance performed with a line of people in a row with linked arms. This is the same as the dance known as xəgga xḷiya.

be‑ḷaye n.f. (pl. be‑lăwaθa) upper room, room on first floor of a house

be-maʿna (K./A.) without meaning | formula used to soften an obscenity: be-máʿna ṭízux yawə́tle l‑gùda| excuse me — turn your bum to the wall (A25:12).

bēn, bēl prep. (with pronominal suffixes: bene, bele, benaθən) between | bēn‑ʾisàre| between the rocks (B9:4); ʾə́θyəx xa-néra benàθən| We came to a river between us (and the town) (A17:9); ʾáwwa ḥákəm béni ʾu-bènəx| He will arbitrate between me and you (A47:3); bēl‑pə́nxa l‑pə̀nxa| between one grinding wheel and the other (B5:91).

bena n.f. (pl. bene, benaθa) (K.) breath; time, instance; yes. (1) breath | graša bena to take a breath; gríšle béna rìxta| He took a deep breath; tré‑gaye gríšle bèna| He took two breaths; hóle šqála bèna| He is breathing; píšta bénux l-hàwa| You are panting. (2) time, instance | tre bene twice; raba benaθa many times; xà-bena ʾázi náše| People should go (only) once (B15:91); har‑wéla taq‑táq mxàya| ʾu‑taq‑tàq,| xá‑bena‑w trè,| w‑áwwa sqìdle| They made a taq-taq knocking noise, taq-taq, once, then twice, then he became fed up (A14:68); ku‑bénət šátən čáy dɛ́rən šékər gàwa| Every time I drink tea I put sugar in it; ʾáyya bèna| ʾǝ́n ʾamrǝ̀nnux| pălǝ́tla pálga mǝ̀jjəd?| This time, if I tell you, will you really divide them in half? (A1:12); čú-bena lat-ṭlíbta hátxa məndiyáne díya hot-ṭlàba!| You have never requested such things are you are requesting now (A26:45); kut-mɛ́θela ʾána t-yánne zùze| ʾax-ṱ-in-híwəlle xa-béna xèta| I shall give money to whoever brings her back, as I gave (money) once before (A27:30). xa-bena for a while, after a while, then | tíwela xá-bena hàdəx| They sat for a while like that (A26:17); zàlɛwa,| xá‑bena xzéle m‑rə́ḥqa xá‑mdi xwàra| He was going along and then he saw in the distance something white (A14:28). xa-bena xeta/xena again | xá‑bena xéta qìmela| qèdamta| Again they got up in the morning (A21:16); ṣlàya,| ṣálya šátya mìya,| ta-t-qàlba xá-bena xéna| She went down to drink water and then finally returned again (A33:8). (3) yes | mə́ra:| xadàmta!| béna ʾəstàðti| She said ‘Servant!’ (The servant said) ‘Yes, madam’ (A37:13); qəryali mərra bena I called her and she said “Yes” (C2:24) → mare bena

be-nisane n.m. Spring (season)

be-nisane n.m. Spring

be-nxəpθa adj. shameless

benzīn n.m. (E.) benzene

be-palga → palga

be-qanke, beθ-qanke n.f. chancel of church

bera n.f. (pl. beraθa) well, cistern

berəšta → barəšta

beṛa n.m. light | béṛɛle qam‑tằra| It is light outside.

beṛana adj. (f. beṛanta, pl. beṛane) light, lightsome

beta n.f. (pl. beʾe) egg | beʾe swiye coloured eggs; qɛ́mi mxáya bèʾe| They begin to knock eggs together (Easter custom) (B5:58); betət saṭana snail shell.

be-təkke n.f. waist | ʾó-t šawə́rra šáwwa sə̀kke,| ða-qɛ́θa gu-be-tə̀kke| He who jumps seven stakes, (one) will hit him in his waist (D2:1). → təkθa trouser cord

be-təlmən adj. invar. without discipline, unruly | brónux be-tə̀lmənile| Your son is unruly → tlm

be-tune n.f. store for straw | built of stones

beθaθa n.pl. (sing. beðəlta) sleeves | also plural beðəlyaθa

be-xelape | nera be-xelape Willow River (running through Barwari Bala)

be-xənxe n.f. oesophagus

be‑xtaye n.f. (pl. be-xtaye) lower floor in a house, basement

be-yalda n.m. Christmas

beza n.f. muslin fabric | xa‑kísa xwára t‑bèza| a white muslin bag (B6:42)

bɛθa n.m. (pl. bate, bɛθăwaθa, bɛθwane; cst. be-) house; home; verse (of poetry/song) | mu-ṣṭímlux bɛ̀θi?| Why have you ruined me? (literally: Why have you destroyed my house?) (A15:14); mapəlxíwa náše ṭla‑gu‑bɛ̀θa| People used it for their household (B5:171); bábi muttúle táma bɛ̀θa| My father set up home there (B8:10); bɛθət qəqwane cage for partridges; bɛ̄θ‑mìθe tomb (B6:1); be-Bakus the family of Bakus. Adverbial: mɛθɛ́le bɛ̀θa| They bring it back home (B5:164).

bɛθ-qora n.m. (pl. bɛθ-qore, bɛθ-qorăwaθa, bɛθ-qorayaθa) cemetery

bɛθuθa n.f. household, family | sáma zóda ṭla‑bɛθuθéy mapəlxìwala| ṭla‑našèy| Most people used it (the honey) for their household, for their family (B5:178)

bəd, bud prep. (§16.1.11.) about, concerning; on account of; in, by. (1) about, concerning | ʾánna šə́mye-wawa bəd-Mắmo mən-Zìne| They had heard about Mămo from Zine (A26:25); qímən molə́xmənna ʾánna šére bud-dìye| I composed these verses about him (C4:3). (2) on account of, by means of | rába ʾítley xayúθa basímta bəd‑àyya,| yáʿni zrátət xabùše| They had a very good life on account of this, that is the cultivation of apples (B5:106). (3) in, by | only in fixed expressions: hɛr‑dmíxtɛla bəd‑lə́bba gu‑bɛ́θət bába dìyɛla| She continued sleeping, thinking that she was in her father’s house (A21:18); ʾi-banɛ́wa báte b-képa mnùjra,| mnújra bəd‑ʾìða| They would build houses with dressed stone, dressed by hand; báxta hóla yaqúrta bud‑yàla| The woman is pregnant with a child.

bədra n.f. (pl. bədraθa) threshing floor

bəðya adj. (f. bðiθa, pl. bəðye) luxuriant (plant) | xa ṭaqət rixana bəðya (She is like) a sprig of luxuriant basil (C2:72).

bəjbaja n.m. (pl. bəjbaje) insect | bəjbajət ʾəxrət tawre dung beetle

bəlād n.f. (A.) country

bəlbala n.m. chaos | wírre bəlbàla gawéy They were in chaos.

bəlbəlawa n.m. celebrations at the end of winter | xaðríwa bəlbəlàwa We would go around (performing) bəlbəlawa (i.e. children go around the village asking for gifts B7:7).

bəlbəllizək n.f. (K.) whirlwind, hurricane

bəldozer n.m. (pl. bəldozere) (A./E.) bulldozer

bəllorta n.f. (pl. bəlloryaθa) pipe; section of a reed | connected to the genitals of a baby in a cradle to carry away its urine

b-əlʾaxīr adv. (A.) in the end

bənduqqa n.m. (pl. bənduqqe) chestnut, chestnut tree

bənyana n.m. building | ʾáwwa ṃále ṭla‑bənyàna| That is sufficient (firing of the gypsum) for building (B5:184).

bəqqəm n.m. red powder (prepared from herbs) used to cure eye diseases

bəqra n.m. cattle (horses, mules, oxen, cows); herd of cattle | m‑lɛ́l mbàdla| xalwíwa tawə̀rta| y‑asqáwa bə̀qra| Early in the morning they would milk the cow and it would go up to (join) the herd (B5:172)

bərbərrane → bərra

bər-gare n.f. (pl. bər-garăwaθa) plateau

bərgawa n.m. inferior quality wool | qamáye ʾo-rešáya šaqlǝ̀xwale| ta‑jùlle.| ʾo-xèna,| y-amrǝ́xxa bǝrgàwa,| ʾo-t biš-daqìqa| First we took the best for clothes. The rest we called bərgawa (inferior quality wool), which was thinner. (B10:49)

bəṛ-gawṛa n.m. (pl. bəṛ-gawṛe) young sheep; young goat

beriya n.f. (pl. beriye, beriyaθa) (K.) milkmaid

beriyo n.f. type of dance

bərka n.f. (pl. bərkake) knee

bərke n.f. (A.) pool | ða‑bə́rkət mìya| a pool of water (A14:77)

bərmalta n.f. (pl. bərmalyaθa) (K.) long jacket worn over other clothes | šalla ʾu-bərmalta trousers and jacket

bə́rmaše adv. evening

bəṛ-naša n.m. (pl. bne-naše, bər-naše, bnonət naše) person, human | xa‑bəṛ‑náša lɛ̀la xzáya| They do not see any human (A14:41); ku‑brónət bə́ṛ‑naša ʾáθe l‑d‑áy jăzíra qamàye| Whichever person comes to the island first … (A14:46)

bəṛ‑našuθa ‘mankind’< bəṛ‑naša ‘man’

bərqa n.m. lightning; electricity | bə́rqe mxáya gu-šmàyyɛla| Lightning is striking in the sky; ʾɛ́-ga líθwa bǝ̀rqa| At that time there was no electricity (B10:45); ʾăbu‑bə̀rqa| electrician(s) (B10:50)

bəṛ-qatta n.f. (pl. bərqatte, bərqatyaθa) small white worm (found in butter and cheese)

bərqiya n.m. lightning | Qaṭína nðéle xo-bərqíyət šmàyya| Qaṭina jumped up under the lightning of the sky (A50:11).

bərra n.f. (pl. bərrane) group; flock; horde | hóle θéle Čùxo,| xa-bə́rra ʾə́rwe bàθre| Čuxo came, with a horde of sheep following him (A7:21); ʾən‑kúlla qəm‑maxíla bərrèy| If they have broken up all their group (B11:9); bərrane (groups), also bərbərrane, name of a game (B11:2ff.).

bərtamwaθa → ʾama

bərtaqala n.m. (pl. bərtaqale) orange

bərvana n.m. (pl. bərvane) apron (for cooking)

bəṛ‑zăra n.f. (pl. bər‑zăre) seed; offspring, children

bərt → brət

bərzoma n.m. (pl. bərzome) cool room for storage in the basement of a house | boyət bərzoma hatch giving access to storage room

bəṛ-ʿăqəl adj. invar. wise

be-saruber adj. invar. (K.) smashed, mutilated

bəska n.m. (pl. bəske) (K.) lock of hair; tress of hair | bəske rixe long locks (C2:2)

bəsma n.m. fragrance | bə́sma dɛ́rɛ gu‑pə̀rma| They put fragrance in a thurible.

bəspora n.m. (pl. bəspora) young child (under 10 years) | Băgiya m-bɛθa goṛa muqyamta max-bəspora Băgiya of a great family, brought up like a little child (C6:8).

bəspurta n.f. (pl. bəspuryaθa) young girl (under 10 years)

bəsqa n.m. (pl. bəsqe) small stone (in a river)

bəsra n.m. (pl. bəsre) meat; dewlap (of goat) | y‑oðíwa … bə́sre They would make meat dishes (B5:13).

bəṣla n.m. (pl. bəṣle) onion

bəṣliṣa n.m. (pl. bəṣliṣa) ray of light; small flame | xzéle xa‑bəṣlíṣa zòra| He saw a small ray of light (A14:24).

bəšra n.m. Gospel; good news

bəšwele n.f. small hole releasing a water jet from pipe (kotăla) that drives the blades of a water-mill

bəṭma n.f. (pl. bəṭmaθa) terebinth tree; the nut from such a tree

bəṭme n.pl. (sing. bəṭəmθa) terebinth nuts

bəθqa n.m. (pl. bəθqe) sweets, rice scattered over newly weds

bəxya n.m. weeping | ʾáwwa mò-qalət bə́xyɛle?| What sound of weeping is this? (A4:44); baxya bəxya marira She weeps a bitter weeping (C2:58)

bəxyona n.m. little weeping, weeping of a little child | bəxyóna lɛ́le dìyux| Weeping is not for you (A38:7)

bəzka n.m. (pl. bəzke) leap | šwírre xa-bə̀zka| He made a little leap.

bəzmara n.m. (pl. bəzmare) nail

biba n.m. (pl. bibe) pupil | bibət ʾɛna pupil of the eye

bibəlta n.f. (pl. bibəlyaθa) (small) pupil | bibəltət ʾɛna pupil of the eye

bibər n.f. pepper | bibər smoqta red pepper

bibla n.m. (pl. bible) camomile | yellow and white flower

bič̣a n.m. (pl. bič̣e) bastard, scoundrel

bič̣ta n.f. (pl. bič̣yaθa) bastard daughter, bitch

biš part. more, most; (not) at all (§14.8.1.) (1) more, most | With adjectives: ʾína mástət ʾə́rwe rába biš‑basimtɛ́la biš‑príštɛla mən‑d‑a‑t‑tàwre| But the yoghurt of sheep is much better and more choice than that of cattle. (B5:173); ʾaṣə́rta mɛθɛ́wala ða‑dúkθa bíš‑qurba t‑y‑awɛ́wa mìya táma| In the evening they would bring them to closer place closer where there was water (B5:160); ʾíθən … biš-xoš-gùṛe| There are better men (A26:79); ʾíθwa lìθwa| biš‑m‑álaha góṛa čú-mdi lìθwa| There was, there was not, there was nothing greater than God (A30:1); qu-qálbəx bɛ́θa biš-spày| Come let’s return home—(that is) better (A30:55); múr ʾɛ̀ni-mənnən| biš-šapìrtɛla| Say which of us (three) is most beautiful (A25:17); ʾáy biš-xámθɛla m-kùlla| She is more beautiful than all (= the most beautiful of all)’ (A25:26). Adjective omitted: bíš m‑áyya dúkθa ʾɛ̀ka xázəx?| Where could we find (something) better than this place? (A12:5). With adverbs: qəm-maxéla ʾáqla biš-xɛlàna| He struck her leg harder (A33:12); dráyɛle biš‑hódəx mə́nna díya xáčča xàmra| He put some wine further up from them (A12:49). With verbs: xáčča biš-šlèla| She became a little more calm (A4:17); bíš madqǝ́rre mən‑d‑ó déwa ṱ‑axǝ́lwa ʾǝ́rbe dìye| He (God) valued him more than the wolf that ate his sheep (A10:13). (2) (not) at all| intensifier of a negator: y‑amríwa ʾáw bíš la‑mzànzər| yáwəl ṭéma pàyəšwa| They said that it does not lose its taste at all. It keeps its taste (B10:76); ʾáp-xa lá-biš-ile-mṣaya mqarów-əlla dìya| Nobody was able to go near her at all (A4:6); b‑qɛ̀ṭa| bíš liθ-məṭràθa,| ʾu-bíš liθ-tàlga| In summer there are no rains at all and there is no snow at all. → zawda, zoda

bista (invar.) comforable, at east, familiar | ʾána bístɛwən b‑áwwa šùla| I am comfortable doing this job, I know how to do this job; ʾána bístɛwən b‑ṭràya| I know how to drive, ʾána bístɛwən mə̀nne| I am at ease with him; púš bìsta!| Feel at home!; ʾíθən nàše| ʾiðéy bìsta There are skilled people (B5:176).

biša n.m./adj. (pl. biše) bad | yala biša bad boy (C2:68)

bišta n.f. (pl. bišyaθa) bad woman; evil | šə́mša gànya| ʾu-bíšta là-ganya| The sun sets, but evil does not set (with it) (D2:5)

bišuθa n.f. evil, badness

bizər n.m. herb that is put in jajək

biz-zawda, bi-zawda → zawda, zoda

biz-zoda, bi-zoda → zawda, zoda

bla-jorta n.f. (pl. bla-joryaθa) bladder

bla-mandora n.m. shaft of a stone roller (mandorta)

bliga adj. (f. bligta, pl. blige) busy, occupied | m‑táma hòdəx| kúlla ʾan‑ʾárba yàrxe,| xámša yàrxe,| y‑áwɛ náše blíge mjămòye,| mjămóye qa‑sə̀twa| From this time onwards, throughout four or five months, people are busy gathering, gathering for winter (B5:107); har‑blígət b‑kàsux| You are always occupied with your stomach (A23:10); blígela b‑ġðàðe| The were preoccupied with one another (A4:50).

bluza n.f. (pl. bluzāt) (A./E.) blouse

b-nəsba (l-) part. (A.) with regard to; in accordance with

boč̣a n.m. (pl. boč̣e) seed; stone in a fruit | də́ryəlla bòč̣e| He sewed the seeds (A18:26).

boksa n.m. punch | maxə́nnux xa‑bòksa| I’ll punch you.

bola n.m. (pl. bole) seed head of millet (prage), sorghum (xroriya) or rice | Such heads do not have the long hairs characteristic of wheat and barley.

b-oma xena adv. the day before yesterday; the day after tomorrow

boni n.m. my little son | familiar form of broni.

boqa adj. (f. boqta, pl. boqe) recalcitrant (bull) | tawra boqa recalcitrant bull (that buts people)

boqča n.m. (pl. boqče) (K.) knapsack | made of finer fabric than parzūn.

boš adj. invar. (K.) empty, vain | qála qamáya zílle bòš| The first cry was in vain (A7:74)

boṭa n.m (pl. boṭe) large wooden channel made of willow (xorta) that carries water at high speed to drive water-mill

boṭla n.m. (pl. boṭle) bottle

boya n.m. (pl. boye, boyaye) hole | xá‑boyət xùwwe| a snake hole (A9:6); qam-tằrət| d-ó-boyət tèle| before the door of the fox’s hole (A20:6); boyət buma Hole of the Owl (a small cave in the rock near the village of Dure); bóyət xmàṭa| the eye of a needle (A11:12).

bra-ʾiða → brɛθaθa

bra-gðoða, b-ġðoða n.m. (pl. bra‑gðoðe, b-ġðoðe) hedgehog

bra-qala n.m.voice; echo

bra-qaple n.m./f. (pl. bra-qaple) baby; babe in arms

bra-qðala n.m. (pl. bra-qðale) collar: back of the neck

bra-qənna n.m. (pl. bra-qənne) egg that is placed under a chicken to stimulate it to lay more | also beta bra-qənna

bra-ṣəppa n.f. (pl. bra-ṣəppe) thimble

brata n.f. (pl. bnaθa) girl; daughter

braye bar axrăte n.pl. (K.) half brothers

brɛθaθa n.pl. (sing. bra-ʾiða f.) gloves

brət, bərt son of | Only in fixed expressions: b-šɛna, bərt-xaθa welcome, son of (my) sister (A52:26); brət ʾamti the son of my paternal aunt, my cousin. In expressions of abuse: kálba brət-kálba dog son of a dog (A6:12); kálbe bərt-kàlbe| dogs sons of dogs! (A7:15).

brika adj. (f. brikta, pl. brike) kneeling

brīn n.f. (pl. brinane) wound | ʾánna ma‑brinànela gu‑réšux?| What wounds are these on your head? (A29:6).

brindar adj. invar. injured | qəm-maxíli brìndar They injured me; mə́xyɛwən brìndar| I am injured; Rústam píšle brìndar| Rustam was injured (A28:28).

brixa adj. (f. brixta, pl. brixe) blessed | brixa! Congratulations! (general); brixe! Congratulations (on your new clothes)!; ʾéðux brìxa! Happy festival!; qedámtux brìxta| Good morning!; rámša brixà-llux| Good night; bríxta ḥammàmux| I hope you feel better after your wash; hóya brixtà-llux| May she be blessed to you (said as a blessing on the marriage of a man) (A25:69).

briza (f. brizta, pl. brize) adj. dry

brona n.m. (pl. bnone) son; young animal | brōn‑màlka| the son of the king (A18:17); lá bnòne| ʾə́zze maθòye| The goats were not producing young (A38:1).

bšila adj. (f. bšilta, pl. bšile) cooked; ripe | ʾənwe bšile ripe grapes

b-šrara adj. trustworthy → šrara

b-ṭali adj. ill → ṭali

bubra n.m. (pl. bubre) thorny pod | grows on plants such as lagna and ṣamərma.

bukina n.m. (pl. bukine) red anemone flower

bulbul n.f. (pl. bulbule, bulbulyaθa) nightingale | bulbúle jmáʾela l-qàle| Nightingales gather at his voice (A25:46)

bulta n.f. (pl. bulyaθa) small head of millet (prage )

buma n.f. (pl. bumaθa) owl

buqara n.m. (pl. buqare) question

buqta n.f. (pl. buqyaθa) doll

bura (i) n.m. (pl. burane) field cultivated without irrigation | The crops grown in such a field are said to be dema, e.g. xəṭṭe dema unirrigated wheat.

bura (ii) n.m. (pl. burane) pile, mound | xá‑burət kèpe| a pile of stones (A11:5)

buraxa n.m. (pl. buraxe) blessing; wedding ceremony

burəkθa n.f. (pl. burkaθa) blessing | After eating food a guest says to the host: ʾálaha dɛ́re burkáθa gu-bɛ̀θux| May God bestow blessings on your house.

buri n.m. (pl. băwari) (A.) metal pipe

burj, burja n.m. (A.) tower

burnuṭ n.f. (K.) snuff | wíðtənwalux bùrnuṭ!| I had made you (like) tobacco snuff! (A50:12).

burra n.m. (pl. burre) pot for preserving yoghurt (submerged in water to keep cool) or for storing date syrop (nepoxta) and yeast (xmira)

burrəš n.m. dish consisting of meat and grains | similar to čiče, a dish of meat, millet (prage) and yoghurt.

busama n.m. enjoyment | ʾó-məndit ʾàna xílli| ʾó busáma mubsǝ́mli tàma| là-ʾaθi mtanóye| What I ate and the enjoyment I had there could not be related (A2:8)

buse → base

bustana n.m. (pl. bustanane) garden, orchard

bušala n.m. stew

buṭa n.m. (pl. buṭe) penis

buxara, buxɛra n.m. (A.) steam | buxára máṭe l‑qarùθa,| páyəš ṭə́pye ṭə̀pye| The steam becomes cool and turns into drops.

buxɛri, buxɛriya n.m. (pl. buxɛriye) stove, smoke duct.

buxra n.m. (pl. buxre) firstborn son | buxrət bɛθa firstborn in the family

buxtən n.m. (K.) slander, false accusation | dráya búxtən l-xá l-d-o-xèna| (He was) slandering this one and that one (A48:5).

b-xamme adj. worried → xam

b-xaye adj. alive → xaye

byaṭa n.m. (pl. byaṭe) pickaxe

bzara n.f. (pl. bzare, bzaraθa) plough | ʾánna bzàre| these parts of the plough (A30:22)

bzúne adv. two years ago



/č/

čačma n.f. (pl. čačmaθa) (K.) bathroom, toilet

čadoda n.m. (pl. čadode) inviter; man who goes around villages to invite guests to a wedding → čyd

čadra n.m./f. (pl. čadre) (K.) tent | made of fabric (cf. k̭wina bedouin tent made of goat’s hair): Səttìye| qímtɛla čádra díya mxìθəlla| be-pálgət ʾAmedìa| Səttiye pitched her tent in the middle of Amedia (A25:78).

čakala n.m. (pl. čakale) (K.) pruning hook; tool used for pulling down fruit and nuts from trees

čakalta n.f. (pl. čakalyaθa) (K.) small pruning hook

čakčaka n.m. wooden wheel shaking and dispensing slowly wheat into a water-mill

čakke (i) n.pl. (K.) weapons | xoni b‑šaklile čakke The weapons suit my brother (C5:2)

čakke (ii) n.pl. (K.) clothes and jewels of women

čakuč n.m./f. (pl. čakuče) (K.) hammer

čakučta n.f. (pl. čakučyaθa) (K.) small hammer

čale n.f.
