(pl. čalăwaθa) (K.) large hole in ground, pit | ṣléla ʾáqla díya gu‑xa‑čàle| Her foot went down into a hole (A10:7); zadéle ṣàle| gu‑xa‑čále gòṛta| He threw him down into a deep pit (A22:40); ʾo-t-xápər čále ṭla-xàwre| b-gàne ṣále gáwa| He who digs a hole for his friends will fall in it himself (D2:17).

čallaq adj. invar. (K.) fast, agile

čalo → kalo

čamča n.f. (pl. čamče) (K.) spoon (made of wood); flat trowel

čamma n.f. (pl. čammane) (K.) large field near river; plantation

čangala n.f. fish-hook (connected to line)

čangəl n.f. (pl. čangale) (K.) fork

čanta n.f. (pl. čanaθa) (K.) shoulder bag

čăpər n.f. (pl. čăpɛre) (K.) ambush | ʾó‑naša hóle tíwa gu‑čằpər táma| That man was waiting in ambush there (A12:50).

čappa n.m. (pl. čappe) (K.) bend | čappa l-yamne a bend to the right; čappa l‑čappe a bend to the left; šaqíθa ʾi-xăðàwa| čàppa wéwa hátxa| lɛ́wa dǝ́rəst ràba| The stream twisted round, it was bendy like this, it was not straight (A8:13).

čappaya adj. (f. čappɛθa, pl. čappaye) left-handed

čappe buke (K.) clapping hands for the bride when she is taken around the village on the back of a mule | máxa čáppe bùke| They clap hands for the bride (B5:38)

čappe n.f. (K.) left (hand, side) | čappe ʾu-č̭ure zigzag; ʾáyya ʾúrxa kúlla čáppe ʾu-č̭ùrela| This path is very winding.

čaqmaq n.m. (pl. čaqmaqe) (T.) trigger of a gun

čara, čɛra, kyɛr n.m. (pl. čare, čɛre) (K.) solution; cure | qa-ṱ-oðíle xa-čàra| so that they cure him (A8:32); xa‑čára xazèna| qa‑t‑ʾáyya bràti| I should find a solution for this daughter of mine (A21:2); ʾáwəð xa-kyɛ́r ʾə̀lli| (If only) he would find me a solution (A31:3).

čarək n.m. (pl. čăwarək) (K.) quarter | ṭḷaθa čăwarək three quarters; sáʾət xa-w čàrək a quarter past one; saʾət xa-w čarək a quarter past one; čarək ṭḷa-ʾəṣra a quarter to ten.

čarməkθa n.f. (pl. čarməkyaθa) leather strap along which the spindle (kuša) is run to start it spinning

čaroxe, čeroxe n.pl. (sing. čaroxta) leather boots (worn in Spring)

čarxa n.m. (pl. čarxe) (K.) circuit; circuitous route, detour | ʾu‑zvírtɛla rēš-d-ó-ṭura rēš-d-ó-gəppa xa-čàrxa hátxa| She went round above the mountain, above the cave in a circuit, like this (A8:76); mxélux xa-čárxa hál zíllux kəs-bàxtux| You went on a circuitous route and went to your wife (A1:23).

čarxona n.m. (pl. čarxone) (K.) small turn | xa-čarxona črixwala She took a short turn around (A51:12).

čawərre adv. (K.) waiting (for arrival), expectation | tiwa wənwa nṭaraθa čawərrət beriyaθa I was sitting in vigil, waiting for the milkmaids (C2:16).

čay n.f. tea | mɛ́θili tre‑čày! Bring me two teas!; čay quwya, čay ranganta, čay mare‑ranga strong tea; čay zalalta weak tea; čáy lɛ́la šqílta rànga,| drí xačča‑xéna rànga gáwa| The tea is weak, make it a bit stronger; čay silani type of tea.

čayxana n.f. (pl. čayxane, čayxanwaθa) (K.) teashop

čayxanči n.m. (pl. čayxančiye) (K.) teashop owner

čeri (i) n.m. (pl. čeriyăwaθa) Autumn | čeri qamaya October; čeri xaraya November

čeri (ii) n.m. sash | xa-čeri b-Surma zqira a sash is woven by Surma (C1:19)

čeydən, čeydana n.f. (pl. čeydane) (K.) large teapot

čeypəs n.f. (pl. čeypase) (K.) small teapot

čezəkka n.m. (pl. čezəkke) (K.) spark

čəčča n.f. (pl. čəččăwaθa) (K.) breast; nipple; teat (of udder) | rešət čəčča nipple; čəččət tawərta teat of a cow; čəččət naθa lobe of the ear; čəččət balota tonsil

čəġa n.m. (K.) type of bird

čəkka n.m (pl. čəkke) (K.) joint (of bones); ankle bone | yále zóre mṭawóle b-čə̀kke The young children were playing with ankle bones (of sheep and goats) (A25:87).

čək̭k̭alle n.pl. (sing. čək̭k̭alta f.) (K.) slippers

čəklete n.pl. chocolates

čəldevana n.m. (K.) trigger in the trap known as ṱăp̭əkke, ṱăp̭əkθa

čələkka n.m. (pl. čələkke) (K.) small leaf stem; small twig

čəlləkθa n.f. (pl. čəlləkyaθa) (K.) earthenware pot (for milk or yoghurt) | xmaθa l‑yaṣila zinta. čəlləkθa m-ʾiða šqilta. The mother-in-law is standing by the corner. The pot (representing the household duties of the new bride) has been taken from her hand. (C1:10)

čəlloxe n.pl. (sing. čəlloxta) crispy pieces of baked bread remaining on the wall of the oven

čəlluri n.f. (pl. čəlluriyaθa) small lizard

čəngərra n.m. (pl. čəngərre) (K.) piece of fabric

čəngərta n.f. (pl. čəngəryaθa) (K.) small piece of fabric (put on mouth of pot containing jajək) (B14:1)

čərək, čŭruk interj. bang, twang | dǝ́ryəlla xá čǝ́rək ʾu‑mǝ̀xyəlla| He shot one, twang, and hit it (A12:32); har-wáða čŭ̀ruk| lan-mràʾa| čú-mdi lɛ̀le-θaya bíyi| It (the gun) just makes a bang, but I am not hurt, nothing happens to me (B9:18).

čərkənna (i) n.m. (pl. čərkənne) kernel (of an onion) | čərkənnət bəṣla kernel of an onion

čərkənna (ii) n.m. type of small sparrow (čučəkka)

čiče n.pl. dish made from meat, millet and yoghurt

čima → kima

čimanto n.f. cement

čiqa n.m. thick cane; bamboo

čiqəlka n.m. (pl. čiqəlke) young cock

čira adj. (f. čirta, pl. čire) annoyed | ṣlele m‑ərzala čira He got out of bed in a temper (C2:38)

čita n.m. (pl. čite) (K.) type of embroidered fabric

čiya adj. (f. čiθa, pl. čiye) tired

čol n.f. (K.) countryside, unsown land | plíṭɛle gu-čòl| He went out into the countryside (A8:90).

ču part. not any (§14.9.17.) | Negative determiner of a nominal: ʾu‑ṭlálux lan-šwíqa čù-məndi| and for you I shall not leave anything (A2:11); čù pəlxána la‑pálxət ʾáti| You shall do no work (A23:32); hon‑də́ryəlle gu‑xa‑čále ʾamúqta lá‑ʾaməṣ čù‑ga čú‑ga paləṭ| I have put him in a deep hole and he will never be able to come out (A22:41); la‑har‑ču‑dúkθa lìθwa| She was nowhere at all (to be found) (A27:26).

čučəkka n.m., čučəkθa n.f. (pl. čučəkke) sparrow | xá čučə́kka gu-ʾíða biš-spáyile mən-ʾə́ṣra gu-ʾilàna| One sparrow in the hand is better than ten in the tree (D2:50)

čuka n.m. (pl. čuke) chick | čukət qəqwanta the chick of a partridge

čukta n.f. (pl. čukyaθa) young chicken

čulla n.m. (pl. čulle) (K.) large broad mountain peak

čullənta n.m. (pl. čullənyaθa) (K.) small sharp mountain peak

čura, čurra n.m. (pl. čurre) angora goat | with long, silky hair known as marrəs; also known as čurrət marrəs or ʾərwət marrəs.

čurrəkθa n.f. (pl. čurrəkyaθa) female angora goat | čurrəkθət marrəs female long haired angora goat

čŭrup interj. thud | ṣə́lyɛle čŭ̀rup| He came down, thud (A8:40).

čuxa n.f. (K.) broadcloth, thick woolen fabric | A coat from this material was worn by men in winter to protect back when carrying loads and to protect body from knife wounds when engaging in warfare. The material was also used for the cloth that was put on the back of a mule (qurṭana).



/č̭/

č̭ənnara n.m. (pl. č̭ənnare) (K.) yoho

č̭ənnək̭ɛr-, č̭ənnək̭ar-prep. (K.) (with pronominal suffixes: č̭ənnək̭ɛre) around | θáyɛle xðárɛle č̭ənnək̭ɛ́rə d‑an‑nàše| He comes and rides around those people (A12:5); xăðíle č̭ənnək̭ɛ́re díye gǝ̀dda| They wind a thread around it (B11:18); zadáwale kúlla m‑gàre| č̭ənnək̭ɛ́rət swàna| l‑yámne čàppe| They would throw it all from the roof, around the eves, on the right and on the left (B5:195); ma‑t‑wɛ́wa ʾə́θye nàše| č̭ənnək̭ɛ́rət Mšìxa| … Mar‑Yuḥánna lá‑mṣele kút‑xa dréle qáwət míya b‑rèše| So many people came around Christ … that Saint John could not put a scoop of water over everybody (B6:10).

č̭uč̭ana n.m. (pl. č̭uč̭ane) magpie | makrəb č̭uč̭ane n.f. late snow falling at the beginning of the month of March (literally: the one that angers the magpies)

č̭ure | čappe ʾu-č̭ure zigzag | ʾáyya ʾúrxa kúlla čáppe ʾu-č̭ùrela| This path is very winding.


/č̣/

č̣anga n.m. (pl. č̣ange) (K.) leather gloves used to grasp thorny plants when harvesting

č̣aplapəske n.f. type of stew

č̣aple n.f. left (hand, side) | ʾan‑ṱ‑íla ʾíða č̣àple| ʾíla ba-ròža| The ones (mountains) on the left are (known as) ba‑roža (in the sun) (B3:1).

č̣apola n.m. (pl. č̣apole) slap

č̣appe n.pl. applause | mxaya č̣appe to clap hands in applause

č̣ara n.m. (pl. č̣are) (K.) type of black bird

č̣ena n.f. (pl. č̣ene) mosquito

č̣əlməsta n.f. (pl. č̣əlməsyaθa) small louse

č̣əmma (i) n.m. (pl. č̣əmmame) (K.) cloven hoof (of animal)

č̣əmma (ii) n.m. (pl. č̣əmme) (Ṭiy.) small amount | banəx kanune č̣əmme č̣əmme Let us build stoves (with) a little (fire) (C1:5)

č̣əč̣č̣a n.m. (pl. č̣əč̣č̣e) (K.) shoulder-blade

č̣ita n.f. butter made from yoghurt

č̣uwa adj. (f. č̣uta, pl. č̣uwe) smooth | tuθa č̣uwa mulberry tree with smooth bark

č̣uwana adj. (f. č̣uwanta, pl. č̣uwane) smooth | xa-kepa č̣uwana a smooth stone



/d/

D part. (realized phonetically as d, t, ṱ §4.4., §10.16.) subordinating particle. (1) annexation particle introducing nominal complements of nominals | brónət màlka the son of the king (A32:21); ṭəppəryáθət heywàne| the claws of animals (A19:2); málka d-áyya bàžər the king of this town (A32:5); bɛ́θa d-àw the house of that one (A8:24); ʾan-ʾə́rwe d-ɛ̀nila?| Whose sheep are those (A32:16); diy- when combined with pronominal suffixes: bábe díye his father (A32:31); gu‑máθa dìyən| in our village (B2:6); predicative: ʾáwwa bɛ́θa dìyəxile bráti?| Is this house yours, my daughter? (A40:13). (2) relative particle introducing clausal complements of nominals | ʾan‑suráye t‑wáwa gu‑Tùrkiya| zílla l‑ʾÌrən| The Christians who were in Turkey went to Iran (B2:8); ʾu‑ʾup-báxte dìye| ṱ-íle gwìrəlla| rába hawnàntɛla| Also his wife, whom he had married, was very clever (A17:21); ʾɛ́-šetət mɛ́θi qəm-yawə́lla xa-bróna zòra| In the year they would die he gave them a small son (A4:57); ʾo‑t‑̭íle wíra ʾáw xaràmɛle| The one who has entered is cursed (A23:27). (3) introducing nominal and clausal complements of adverbs and prepositions | dáx páyəš málka šáwpət bròni?| How will he become king in place of my son? (A8:4); qámət gǝ̀ppa| in front of the cave (A12:7); ʾax-d-àwwa| like him (A26:34); báθər d-ɛ̀-maθa| behind that village (A24:30); bēl‑d‑áyya l‑d‑àyya| between this and that (B5:115); mə́ṭye l‑d‑o‑nèra| They arrived at that river (A14:58); diy- when combined with pronominal suffixes | ʾax-díye like him (A4:3); bíye díye with him (A14:8); č̭ənnək̭ɛ́re díye around him (A8:71); clausal complements: mɛ́θən ʾax‑ṱ‑ila‑ʾànna míθe| I shall die like these people have died (A14:73); qam-ṱ-àθi| mpáləṭle mən-hàbsa| Before they return, release him from prison (A26:72); m‑bár t‑y‑óði núra gàwe,| xáyəm ràba| After they put fire in it, it heats up a lot (B6:48). (4) introducing clausal complements of verbs | ʾánna yắði ṱ-íle duglàna| They know that he is a liar (A48:3); bắyən ṱ-àzən| I want to go (A8:65); máṣəx ṱ‑àmrəx| We can say (B4:3). (5) introducing clausal complements of clauses | normally expressing purpose: ʾána paqðə̀nnɛxu| ṱ-azítu b-ʾúrxa maṭítu ʾə̀lla| I shall instruct you so that you go on the road and reach her (A8:27). → t-la

dăbanja n.f. (pl. dăbanje) (K.) pistol

dabaša n.m. (pl. dabaše) bee | ʾíθwa gu‑máθa doqíwa dabàše| ṭla‑dùša| Some people in the village used to keep bees for honey (B5:176).

dabašta n.f. (pl. dabašyaθa) beehive; family of bees within a hive | l‑Yawsəp zwinta b‑dabašta It has been bought by Yawsəp for a beehive (B8:29). A swarm of bees that leaves the hive is known as a šəlxa.

ḍabəṭ, ð̣abəṭ n.m. (pl. ḍubbāṭ, ð̣ubbāt) (A.) army officer

dabra n.m. supplies, sustenance | dabrət bɛθa household supplies

dabuqana n.m. parasitic plant growing in trees, from which a gluey substance is extracted to produced birdlime; birdlime extracted from this plant

dabušana n.m. glue. adj. sticky

dada (ʾƐn Nune), deda (Dure) n.f. sister or wife of an uncle (paternal or maternal)

dagala n.m./adj. (pl. dagale) liar

ḍăġat n.m. (A.) (blood)-pressure

dahlīz n.m. (pl. dahlize) (A.) corridor

dala n.m. (pl. dale) thicket, undergrowth

dalila adj. (f. dalilta, pl. dalile) thinly distributed with spaces in between | gəllále gu‑məššára dalìlela,| lɛ́la ʾamùre| The weeds in the rice paddy-field are thinly spaced, they are not densely spaced; ṭəlla dalilta light shade (with some sun shining through); káwsi píšle dalìla| My hair has become thin.

daliθa n.f. (pl. dalyaθa) vine | ṭarpət daliθa vine-leaves; xa-dalíθət xùwwe| wild vine (without fruit) (A26:91).

dalopa n.m. (pl. dalope) drip (leaking from roof); drizzle | qa‑t‑dalòpe| la‑ṣálɛ b‑sə̀twa| so that leaking drops did not seep through in the winter (B5:146); ʾəθyewəx kope kope qam‑məṭra ʾu‑qam dalope We have come bending down in rain and drizzle (C1:14).

dalupta n.f. (pl. dalupyaθa) small drip (leaking from roof)

dalya n.m. (pl. dalye) tendril of a vine | dálya dáwəq gújmət ʾə̀nwe| A tendril bears bunches of grapes.

dama n.m. backgammon | mṭáləx dàma| Let us play backgammon; kepət dama backgammon counter

ð̣ămān n.m. (A.) guarantee

dambus n.f. type of herb resembling tail of horse

dambusta n.f. (pl. dambusyaθa) small tail

dana n.f. (pl. danane, danaθa) time; point in time; period of time | mṭíθɛla dane-dìye| wírre kəs-màlka| His time came and he entered into the presence of the king (A1:14); dān‑dìye| ṭla‑pàya| It (the dough) is ready for baking (B5:16); dánɛla qarə́nna qálət ṭḷàθa| It is time for me to call the third cry (A8:59); xá‑saʾət qam‑dàna| an hour beforehand (B5:119); kəmà-dana pɛ́šət? How long will you stay? xə́lya ʾi-mjămə́xwa ràba,| ʾárba dàne| We would collect a lot of milk, four times (B10:21); har-dána b-danà y-oðíwala| They would make it from time to time (B10:22); har-d-ɛ-dána at that time (B15:64). Before a clause: mən-d-ɛ́-danət brèla| hál d-ɛ-dánət mṭéla l-yàla,| wéla bxàya| From the time she was born she started weeping, (and continued) until the time that she came to the boy (A25:4); ʾɛ-dánə ṱ-ìla ṛíše,| … ʾáwwa məskéna ràba pšímle| ʾu-ʾáy mšuyðə̀nna| When they woke up … he, poor man, became very sad and she became mad (A4:5).

danbus n.m. (pl. danbuse) (A.) pin

dandəkθa n.f. (pl. dandəkke, dandəkyaθa) seed | xa dandəkθət ṭlawxe a lentil seed, a single lentil; xa dandəkθət

danθa n.f. (pl. danyaθa) water jar | The water contained in such jars was kept cool by wrapping them in wet grass. These were used in Dure, which did not have water springs inside the village.

danwa n.m. (pl. danwe) tail

dapa n.m. (pl. dape) wooden board, plank; wooden beam used on a loom (xanuθa) for keeping the strands tight

daprana n.m. (pl. daprane) juniper bush, juniper shoot

dapranta n.f. (pl. dapranyaθa) small juniper tree

dapθa n.f. (pl. dapyaθa) small wooden board, strip; one of two leaves of a trap door in a partridge trap (suta)

daqiqa adj. (f. daqiqta, pl. daqiqe) fine; tiny | qamxa daqiqa finely ground flour; ṭmírtɛla ða-dúkθa daqìqta| She is buried in a tiny place (A38:10)

daqra n.m. (pl. daqre) long pole

dara n.m. (pl. dare) generation; century | dárət xámša Már-Gwirgis píšɛle bə̀nya| (The church of) Mar Gwirgis was built in the fifth century (B1:6).

dăraj n.m. (A.) degree | dắraj ḥărára díye its degree of heat, its temperature (B6:37)

dăraje n.f. (pl. dărajyaθa, dărayəj) flight of steps, staircase | xa xalqa mən-dăraje one step of a flight of steps.

dărava n.m. (pl. dărave) (K.) mud dam used to direct irrigation water in a field

daraya n.m. (pl. daraye) shooter | b-tope kəmɛwa daraya! What a skilled shooter he was! (C7:9)

darba n.m. (pl. darbe) (K./A.) blow (of weapon) | la-máxəx tre-dàrbe| We do not strike two blows (A50:14) → zarba

darda n.f. (K.) suffering, illness | ʾàna| dárdi lɛ́la d-àyya.| dárdi ʾíla t‑ʾá‑t gu-panjarìye.| My suffering is not from this (game), my suffering is from that one at the window (A26:66).

darga n.m. (pl. darge) (K.) main door (with two leaves) | Only build in large houses (qaṣre); ʾaqli l‑darga maxyanna I shall kick the door (C1:15)

dargušta n.f. (pl. dargušyaθa) (Urm.) cradle

darjăma n.f. (pl. darjăme) (K.) screen behind which hunters (shooting birds) hide

daṛmana n.f. (pl. daṛmane, daṛmanane) (K.) drug, medicine; chemical; polish (for shoes); gunpowder; substance | hàtxa wídlən bíye,| daṛmána dìyela| We have done such-and-such to him, its his comeuppance (A7:20); máxewa daṛmàna| l-ṣàwle| He used used to polish shoes (A16:1); mattíwa daṛmàna| They would plant gunpowder (B5:179); qrámtət šə́rma daṛmánət bušàla| The cover of the buttocks is the substance of the stew (i.e. the fat of the sheep’s tail) (D1:13).

darpoše n.f. (pl. darpošyaθa) (K.) pan for cooking

darqūl prep. (with pronominal suffixes: darqule) against | dárqūl d‑a‑məndìla| They are against that thing (A12:55); xákma dwáqa xáṣe dìye| ʾu-xákma darqúle dìye| Some supported him and others were against him (A7:20).

dars n.m. (A.) lesson

darta, dɛrta n.f. (pl. daryaθa) courtyard, residential enclosure; halo. (1) courtyard, residential enclosure | šqíləlla ṭása b-lɛ̀le| ʾu‑núbləlla zə́dyəlla gu-ða-dɛ̀rta| They took the bowl in the night, took it away and threw it into a house enclosure (A15:12); dártət ʾùmra| the churchyard (B1:12). (2) halo dartət yoma halo around the sun; dárta l-yòma,| ʾə́rwe gu-gòma.| dárta l-sèra,| ʾə́rwe l-ṭèra.| If the sun has a halo, the sheep will be in the basement stable. If the moon has a halo, the sheep will be in the noon sun. (D2:15).

dartət yoma, dart yoma adv. next day | dártət-yoma zílla wídla hàdəx| The next day she went and did the same (A18:3).

darya n.m. (K.) large number | xa‑dárya nàše| many people (B5:135); ʾu‑ʾíθwa náše xa‑dàrya| There were many people (B5:178)

darza n.m. (pl. darze) (K.) large tied bundle of grass or produce | cf. ṭaxa untied bundle

dasiya m. (pl. dasiye) (K.) awn, hair of head of corn

dasta n.f. (pl. dastaθa) (K.) bunch, handful | dastət warde a bunch of flowers; xa dastət xəṭṭe a bunch of wheat

dašdaše n.pl. long loose clothes (worn by men)

dašta n.f. (pl. daštaθa) (K.) plain; level ground | wíðəlwala ʾắra dàšta| ʾu-maṣíwa náše doqíwa ṭḷà| ʾarbà-reze xá-xa-gaye| They had made the ground level and the people could form three or four rows at once (B15:79).

daštaya n.m./adj. (pl. daštaye) dweller on the plain

dăvăqa n.m. (pl. dăvăqe) (K.) bite (from an animal) | kawə́dna mxéle dăvắqe bìyi| The mule bit me.

dawa n.m. (pl. dawe) gold; gold coin | ṭéni kúlla ʾíwa mən-dàwa| My load all consisted of gold (A7:11); ya-ʾàlaha,| yawə̀tli| ʾə́mma dàwe| Oh God, give me a hundred gold pieces (A6:1); ʾána xmáθi xá‑dawa zắra muttɛ́θəlli gu‑ʾíðət xóni ʾIshəq| My mother-in-law put a yellow gold coin for me in the hand of my brother Ishəq (B8:35).

dawba n.m. pure liquid honey (without pieces of honeycomb) | also dawbət duša

dawɛra, dawara n.m./f. (pl. dawɛre) mule | generic term used to refer to both male and female → kawədna (m.), koðənta (f.)

dawha n.m. gold

dawke | k̭otəl dawke n.m. (pl. k̭otəl dawke) (K.) pasty with yoghurt (B7:23)

dawla n.m. (pl. dawle) drum. (1) drum (musical instrument) | dawla‑w zorna drum and pipe; músqəlle dáwla-w zòrna-w| hósa ʾu‑gargàrta| They brought him up (with) drum and pipe, and with clamour and shouting (A4:25); sabóti mubèla,| píšla dàwla| My finger has swolen as large as a drum. (2) drum containing the wheat at the top of a water-mill | open box with a hole in the bottom through which wheat comes out onto the grindstone (B6:54).

dawlači n.m. (pl. dawlačiye) drummer

dawlatmand n.m./adj. (pl. dawlatmande) (Urm.) rich

dawqana n.m. (dawqane) setter of bones

dawra n.m. (pl. dawre) (1) wooden door bolt. (2) turn (in a game) | ʾap‑ʾáwwa pàrəq| dáwre dìye| Also his turn is over (B11:8).

dawrane n.pl. gums | dawranət kake gums of the teeth; dawrane ḷaye the upper gums; dawrane xtaye the lower gums

dawsa n.m. (pl. dawse) footprint | xzéli dáwsət déwa gu-tàlga| I saw the footprints of a wolf in the snow.

dawwe n.pl. yoghurt mixed with water

dax, daxi part., prep. how? how could it be? like, just as; when | (1) how? | dáx ʾúrxa muxzélux ʾə́lla lípla ʾàwwa šúla?| How did you show her the way to learn this work? (A21:34); dàx‑it?| How are you? (A22:16); hà bráti,| dàx‑it,| dàx‑lɛt?| My daughter, how are you? (said after long absence) (A21:27); dàxi?| How (could this be)? (A25:69); dàx-it mára?| What are you saying? (A7:14). (2) how could it be? | nàša| dàx la-pălǝ́nna?| Man, how could it be that I shall not divide them? (A1:13); mǝ́re dàxi?| He said ‘How could that be?’ (3) like, as | Before clause or noun (with pronominal suffixes: daxwaθe): dáx ṱ-in-muθɛ́θəlla ʾa‑béna xèta,| ʾay-béna ʾàna maθyánna| Just as I brought her before, so this time I shall bring her (A27:30); dax-ṱ-íwət ʾáti hátxa mṣuqàlta,| ʾap-ʾáw daxwàθax-ile| Just as you are pretty, so he is like you (A8:67); qa‑t-là-hawe sɛ́rga spáy dax-d-áw| so that there will not be another saddle as fine as it (A8:37). (4) when | dax‑ṱ‑ile xə́zyəlla θàya,| hádəx ṣràxa-w| xumθàne,| Čúxo rìqɛle,| plíṭɛle gu-màθa| When he saw them coming, shouting and angry, Čuxo ran out into the village (A7:16). (5) Idioms: dàx lítlux xáṭər| By all means (I’ll do as you say) (A21:11).

daxla n.m. (pl. daxle) (K./A.) corn plant | e.g. wheat (xəṭṭe), millet (prage), barley (saṛe), sesame (šišme)

dayəman, daʾəman adv. (A.) always

dbiša adj. (f. dbišta, pl. dbiše) stuck (together)

deda → dada

dekonta n.f. (K.) little mother | t-la-maxyáli dekònti| lest my mummy beat me (A34:3).

dēm, demi, dema adj. invar. unirrigated | zruta dēm unirrigated cultivation, xəṭṭe dema unirrigated wheat (as opposed to ʾavi irrigated).

dena → dɛna

deráb interj. woosh! (sound of sudden movement)

derubər n.m. (pl. derubɛre) wood, forest; vegetation | ʾán dɛrubɛ́re šuréla xá-bena xèta| The vegetation began again (to sing) (A51:10).

deθa n.f. (1) sweat. (2) resin, gum formed from the sap of the qaqna plant | This is softened in water then chewed; deθət qərda curative ointment produced from the black resin of the tragacanth shrub (qərda)

dewa n.m. (pl. dewe) wolf

dewərriš n.m. vagabond

dewta n.f. (pl. dewyaθa) female wolf

dɛda n.f. (pl. dɛdaθa) hawk

dɛna, dena n.m. (pl. dɛne, dene) debt | yáwən dèni| I shall pay off my debts (A1:8); zílli hiwíli dɛ̀ni| I went and paid off my debts (A1:11); tálga l-ṭùre| ʾu-dɛ́na l-gùre| As snow is to mountains, so a debt is to men (D2:25).

dɛnana, danana, denana adj. (f. dɛnanta, pl. dɛnane) owing a debt | yắðət b-gànux| ʾìqənwa,| danànənwa| You know, by your soul, I was in trouble. I was in debt (A1:10); šmáyya ʾíla denánta ṭla-ʾắra tə́rte qərṭále t-ʾə̀pra| Heaven owes the Earth two baskets of dust (D1:9)

dɛra n.m. (pl. dɛre) monastery

dɛrweša n.m. (pl. dɛrweše) vagabond

də-, de- part. particle expressing prominence (§15.1.5.2., §15.7.) | (1) With imperatives and deontic verbs: də-mjămə́xlən jarrèta| Let’s put together a food-box for ourselves (A30:41); də-šqúl ʾanna-zùze!| Take these coins! (A1:27); de-ʾə̀dyo,| qu-pɛ́gən kàde| Today, get up and bake kade cakes (A30:41); ʾána də‑ṱ‑amrə́nnox ʾó‑mdi‑t taxrə̀nne| I shall tell you what I remember (B15:1). (2) In deontic questions: de‑maxǝ̀xle?| Should we beat him? (A14:8); de-màṭo hóya?| How could that be? (A30:21). (3) With perfective verbs at boundaries and prominent points in narrative: de‑píšla ʾáp‑ay báxtə d‑àwwa dewə̀rrəš| Now, she became the wife of that vagabond (A12:38); de‑qíma mtúnyəlla qəṣṣə́tte kúlla ṭla‑d‑o‑sàwa| Now, he told all his story to the old man (A14:76); ʾu‑de‑b‑lɛ̀lela,| zílɛle zílɛle Now, while it was night, he went off (A22:38).

dəbba n.f. (pl. dəbbe, dəbbaθa) bear; the constellation ‘The Great Bear’

dəbbora n.m. (pl. dəbbore) hornet

dəbboriθa n.f. swarm of hornets

dəbburta n.f. (pl. dəbburyaθa) horsefly

dəgdin n.m. (pl. dəgdine) metal frame for cooking over a fire (with three legs); the three stars of the constellation Orion

dəkkana n.f. (pl. dəkkane, dəkkanane) (K./A.) shop

dəkkanči n.m. (pl. dəkkančiye) (K./A.) shopkeeper

dəlba n.m. (pl. dəlbe) plane tree

dəmma n.m. blood | ʾáwwa də́mma mattùle| He sheds this blood (A11:20); ʾáni zúzət bábe dìye,| dǝ̀mmɛla| This is the money of his father, it is his blood (money) (A15:16).

dəmmana adj. (f. dəmmanta, pl. dəmmane) bloody

dəmme n.pl. (sing. dəmmiθa) tears | də́mmət ʾɛ̀na| the tears of her eyes (A34:5); xa ṭəppət dəmma a tear drop

dəndəkθa n.f., dəndəkka n.m. (pl. dəndəkke, dəndəkyaθa) grain, small amount | xa dəndəkθət xəṭṭe a grain of wheat; xa dəndəkθət ṭlawxe a single red lentil; ʾap‑dəndə́kka baṣòra| just a tiny amount (A18:27); lɛn-zdáʾa ʾap-dəndə̀kθa| I am not afraid even a little (B9:17).

dənnəqθa → dəqqənθa

dəpna n.m. (pl. dəpne) (Urm.) side | qáyəθ b-o‑ṱ‑íle də̀pne| He knocked into the one next to him (A22:34)

Dəqlət n.m. Tigris

dəqna n.m. beard | mṭéle xa-náša sàwa,| dǝ̀qne| hal-ʾằra| mǝ̀ṭya| He came upon an old man, whose beard reached the ground (A24:7); dəqnət Nisan the beard of Nisan, a custom whereby on the first day of Nisan (April) a woman pulls up a plant with mud on its roots and sticks it to the roof of the house.

dəqqənθa, dənnəqθa n.f. (pl. dəqqənyaθa) chin

dəqša n.m. (pl. dəqše) butt, blow | táwra qəm-gamə́šle b-də̀qše| The ox gored him with butts.

dərədya n.m. (pl. dərədye) pile of snow that has fallen from a roof

dərvana n.m. (pl. dərvane) (K.) frying-pan

dəsqa n.m. (pl. dəsqe) (K.) (1) handle of a tool. (2) stem of fruit

dəxya adj. (f. dxiθa, pl. dəxye) pure (spiritually) | ləbba dəxya a pure heart

dəžmən n.m. (pl. dəžmə́nne) (K.) enemy | lišána də́žmən gàna| The tongue is its own enemy (D2:32); qáṭu‑w ʾaqúbra də́žmən t‑ġðàðela| A cat and a mouse are mutual enemies (A44:1).

dəžmənayuθa n.f. enmity, hostility | ʾána béni ʾu‑bénux dužmənayùθɛla| We are enemies.

didwa n.m. (pl. didwe, didwane) fly | ʾáyya dúkθa máre didwànela| This place is full of flies.

didwana adj. (f. didwanta, pl. didwane) full of flies | ʾáyya dúkθa didwàntɛla| This place is full of flies

diga n.m. (pl. dige) cock | qám t‑qáre ʾax-dìga| before it calls like a cock (A24:16)

dīn n.m. (A.) religion

dinamet n.m. (E.) dynamite

dipa adj. (f. dipta, pl. dipe) bent

diwən n.m./f. (pl. diwane) (K.) gathering of people; reception; audience chamber | díwən dwìqtɛla a gathering is being held

diwənxana n.f. (K.) reception room

diy– part. independent genitive particle (§7.3., §14.5.2.) → D

diya → hadiya

diyana n.f. (A.) religion

diyara n.pl. houses (A.) | xrīw-diyára twirílux bzàre!| You scoundrel (literally: one whose houses are destroyed, i.e. may you have your houses destroyed), you have broken the parts of the plough!

diyopa n.m. (pl. diyope) pleat

dmixa adj. (f. dmixta, pl. dmixe) asleep

dohuknaya n.m./adj. (pl. dohuknaye) man from Dohuk

dola n.m. (pl. dole) (K.) mountain pass

dolma n.f. (pl. dolme) (T.) dish of stuffed vine leaves; a stuffed vine leaf

dona n.m. animal fat, animal oil

donana adj. (f. donanta, pl. donane) fatty

dormadār adv. (K.) around | dormadā́r kúlla berəšyàθa| All around there were cushions (B10:80)

dorta n.f. (pl. doryaθa) round, cycle | ʾáwwəl dórta the first round (of sieving) (B10:13)

doša n.m. (pl. doše) balcony, low structure attached to outside of house for people to sit on; seats inside a booth (quprana) | generally used in the plural form doše.

došăka, došakka n.m. (pl. došăke, došakke) (K.) mattress

došəkθa n.f. (pl. došəkyaθa) (K.) cushion

dost n.m. (pl. doste) (K.) friend, mate | hà dostí!| Hey, my friend! (A1:18)

dostuθa n.f. friendship

drana n.m. (pl. dranane) lower arm | cf. ruša upper arm, arm in general

drangaya adj. (f. drangɛθa, pl. drangaye) (K.) late | ʾána drangàyɛwən| I am late.

draya n.m. (pl. draye) arm, cubit | ʾarbí dráye pàrča| forty yards of material (A28:10); kul səmbəlti xa draya Each (side) of my moustache is a cubit (A51:5)

drəst adj. (invar.) (K.) straight; right, correct | ʾo-tắra drə̀st-ile,| lɛ́le pč̣ìla| The door is straight, it is not crooked (A17:20); xelápa drə̀st-ile| The willow is straight; drə̀st-ila qə́ṣṣət| The story is true (A4:23); ʾə̀mma gắrəg háwa drə́st| They must be exactly a hundred (A6:1).

dudəkθa n.f. (pl. dudəkyaθa) (K.) pipe (musical instrument)

dudiya n.f. (pl. dudiyaθa) (K.) cradle | bríxta dudíya ṱ‑iwət ʾáti qíma gàwa!| Blessed be the cradle in which you grew up! (A21:41)

dudu n.f. type of game (B11:29)

dugla n.m. (pl. dugle) lie, falsehood; fiction

duglana n.m./adj. (pl. duglane) liar | rába rába duglàna-wewa| He was a great liar (A48:1); ʾáti duglàntət| You (fs.) are a liar (A25:20).

duka → dukθa

dukθa, duka (§10.9.) n.f. (pl. dukane) place, space. (1) place | mattíwala xa‑dúkθa šaxìnta| They would place them in a warm place (B5:12); bás šoqíwa dúkθət páləṭwa tə̀nna| They only left a place for the smoke to come out (B10:65); ʾáni kút‑xa b‑ða‑dùka| each had its place (B10:53); kú-dukə ṱ-íla mɛθə̀tlali.| Bring her to me wherever she is (A4:8); mšáxəlpu dukàne| Change places (A26:65). (2) space | xa‑dúkθət gə́ldət tàwrən híwəlle báne bɛ́θa| I have given him the space of an ox skin to build a house (A11:15); ʾíθwa dúkθa ta‑t‑kalèwa| There was space for him to stand (A22:30) (B5:66). (3) Idiom: y‑azíwa mšamšíwa bɛθ-qòra,| rə́ḥqa mən-an-dukàne| They would hold a ceremony in the cemetery—may (death) be far from these places! (formula used when referring to a cemetery or death) (B10:3).

dulāb n.m. (pl. dăwalīb) (A.) wardrobe

dulaba n.m. (pl. dulabe) (K./A.) wheel of water-mill

dulabča n.m. (pl. dulabče) (K.) small cupboard

duna n.m. (pl. dune) pen for sheltering sheep and goats in winter

dunye n.f. world, weather. (K./A.) (1) world | ʾáwwa plíṭɛle gu‑ða‑dúnye xèta| He came out into another world (A14:26); ʾálaha yállux b‑àyya dúnye| ʾu‑b‑ɛ‑xèta| May God grant you (bounty) in this world and the next (A21:44). (2) weather | dúnye hóla ràya| It is rainy; dúnye hóla ʾɛwànta| It is cloudy; dúnye hóla mgargòme| It is thundering; dúnye prèla| It became light. (3) Idioms: ʾáy šaqíθa bṱ-áza bṱ-áza nabláley ðá-gotət dùnye| The stream will flow along and take them somewhere (A8:11); har-máxəx b-dùnye| Let’s go just go away (A30:41); dùnye qəm‑čɛdíla| They invited many people (A12:23); šúprə dúnye hóle ʾəlla‑dìya| She was of a unique beauty (A13:11); šqéle b-dùnye| He ran off aimlessly; dùnyela!| That is life! (A40:13).

dūrbīn n.f. (K.) binoculars

durnaya n.m./adj. (pl. durnaye) man from Dure

dūs adj. (invar.) (K.) right; true; straight | b-álaha dū̀s-iwət!| Indeed you are right (A1:19); ʾína dū̀s galítu| Tell me the truth (A27:37); ʾurxa dūs a straight road; har-ʾáxtu kǝ́lye dū̀s| č̣alxítula m-ġðàðe| While standing erect, you shall tear her apart (A27:33); tèla| mríle ma‑dū̀s| The fox became truly ill (A32:32).

duša n.m. honey | šămət duša beeswax

duwana n.m. paste put in cakes made from flour, butter and salt (sometimes with the addition of honey and walnuts); oil (animal)

duxa n.m. (pl. duxe) dedicatory sacrifice (B5:70)

duxrana n.m. (pl. duxrane) memorial festival

duxtur n.m. (pl. duxture) (E.) doctor

duxwa n.m. dish made from yoghurt, barley and meat

duzuθa n.f. truth | yóma mən-duzúθa qìdle bɛ́θa| One day his house really burnt down (A48:5); xà-yoma,| har-mítle b-duzùθa| One day he really died (A27:42).

dwaqta n.f. (pl. dwaqyaθa) handle | dwaqtət sɛpa the handle of a sword

dwaṛa n.m. (pl. dwaṛe) rest area for sheep in the mountains (under the shade of trees)

dwara n.m. threshing of grains by animals on the threshing floor

dwiqa adj. (f. dwiqta, pl. dwiqe) seized, clasped; blocked (road) | ʾíðe dwìqta He is miserly.

dwira adj. (f. dwirta, pl. dwire) closed

dyapta n.f. (pl. dyapyaθa) a fold (in material or paper)


/ð/

ðawq n.m. (A.) taste, inclination

ðeta n.f. knowledge



/f/

fafon n.f. (K.) aluminium

fălăke n.pl. (K.) stones of a rapids in a river | néra hóle šwára fălằke| The river is flowing in rapids

falita n.m. (f. falitta) (A.) waster, spendthrift

fallāḥ n.m. (A.) peasant

fanūs n.m. (pl. fanuse) (A.) lamp

făqih n.m. (A.) jurist

făqira adj. (f. făqirta, pl. făqire) (A.) poor

farde n.pl. (K.) window blinds | máṣla fàrde!| Lower the blinds! (A39:19).

farquθa n.f. (A.) difference; division | mút farqùθɛla?| What is the difference? (A15:12); ʾáw‑ile xa‑dánət farqúθa bēl‑d‑áyya l‑d‑àyya| This is a time of division between this (season) and the other (B5:115)

farr adj. (invar.) (K.) important | ṣúpa b-sə́twa rába fàrr-ile gu-ʾƐ̄n-Núne| A stove in the winter is very important in ʾƐn-Nune.

farra n.f. (A.) circuit; gulp | mǝ́xyɛle xa‑fárra č̭ənnək̭ɛ́rə d‑o‑qàṣra| He made a circuit around the palace (A12:66); xa-fárra bəd‑šatə̀nne| I shall drink it with one gulp (Qaṭina).

farsaya n.m./adj. (pl. farsaye) Persian

făsaduθa n.f. (A.) mischief, trouble | ʾáwwa wídle făsadúθa bḗn ʾaturàye| ʾu-bḗn barzanàye| He made trouble between the Assyrians and the people of Barzan (B19:1).

faṣl n.m. (pl. fŭṣūl) (A.) season

fassada adj. (A.) corrupt, fraudulent

faṣuli n.m. (pl. faṣuliye) (A.) white bean

fatra n.f. (A.) short interval of time | zílela xa-fàtra| They went on awhile (A17:3)

făyað̣ān n.m. (A.) flood

fayda, payda n.f. (A.) benefit, use | lìθba fáyda| (A25:32), líba fàyda| (A18:4) It is no use; leš faydá‑lləx qáṭlət gànəx| It will no longer be of any use to you to kill yourself (A38:16); mùt paydɛ́wa?| What was the use of it? (B15:40).

feka, peka n.m. (pl. feke, peke) (A.) fruit | ʾítlən féka fə̀rya| We have abundant fruit (B5:222)

ferəssa n.m. (pl. ferəsse) (K./A.) hero, strongman | náše ferə́sse heroic people (A29:7) → pərsa

fədwa n.f. (A.) redemption | fə́dwa ʾə̀llux| (It was) a redemption for you (said when a catastrophe happens to others) (A23:16)

fəkra n.m. (pl. fəkre) (A.) thought | ʾaw-xoš-fə̀krɛle!| That is a good idea! (A39:11)

fəlfəl n.m. (pl. fəlfəle) (A.) pepper

fəlfəlta smoqta n.f. (A.) red pepper

fəllən, pəllən, flan pron. mod. so-and-so; such-and-such | hà-pəllən| lɛ̀kət zála?| Hey so-and-so, where are you going? (A1:11); ʾána síqli fǝ́llən dùkθa| I went up to such-and-such a place (A10:9); sí-mur ta-pə́llən wazī̀r| Go and tell such-and-such a minister (A4:38); só l-bɛ́θət flàn-naša| Go to the the house of such-and-such a man (A8:8); mót mára fə́llən ʾàti| What do you, so-and-so, say (B5:9).

fərya, friya pərya adj. (f. friθa, pl. fərye) (K.) much, abundant | ʾítlən féka fə̀rya| We have abundant fruit (B5:222); ʾăráθa pə̀ryewa| Plots of land were abundant (B10:54); qṭilela raba friye Very many were killed (C3:3)

fəstān n.f. (pl. fəstane) (A.) dress

fəstəq n.f. (pl. fəstəqe) (K./A.) pistachio

fətne n.pl. (A.) trouble | ṱ‑áwəð fə̀tne| He will make trouble (A29:11).

flan → fəllən

friya → fərya

fṭarta n.f. (pl. fṭaryaθa) breakfast



/g/

ga part. almost, about to; connective particle (§15.1.1.11., §18.1.6.). (1) almost, about to | Combined with verb: ga-ṱ‑àθən| I am about to come; ga-máṭya ṱ-axlàle| She is about to eat him (A18:26). (2) connective particle | Signalling temporal sequentiality: rắpili m‑an‑képe ṱ‑íla tàma,| ga‑maxzə́nnux ʾúrxa ṣàlət| Throw me the stones that are there, then I shall show you the way down (A14:70). Introducing a comment: lá-məre bắye xàθux.| mə́re bắye Zìne.| ga-ʾɛ́ni Zìne| ʾáxni lɛ̀ðəx.| He did not say ‘He loves your sister.’ He said ‘He loves Zine.’ Now, we do not know (by this statement) which Zine (was meant) (A26:61). At the beginning of direct speech, predominantly questions: ʾámər ga-k̭òra| ʾána mò yánnux?| He said ‘Now, blind man, what can I give you?’ (A26:57); mǝ́ra ga‑mo‑xǝ̀ðye b‑áwwa dúša?| They said ‘Why are we so happy about this honey?’ (A14:15).

ga, gaya n.f. (pl. gaye, gayaθa, gaθa) (K.) time, instance | málla Naṣrádin xá-ga băyéwa mbašə́lwa pàča| Once mullah Naṣradin wanted to cook pača (A5:1); xa‑xá‑ga (B6:16), xa-xa-gáye (B15:77), gá‑gaθa sometimes; b‑xšàwən| ʾáyya quṣàrta| hár gărəg-máṭe ʾəllì-xa-ga| I think this cooking pot should eventually belong to me (A5:2); tré‑gaye tré wíta ʾàrba| Two times two equals four; xámša gáye xámša wáyɛla ʾə́sri‑w xàmša| Five times five is twenty-five; raba gayaθa many times; ʾo-gáya qằmɛθa θélux l-kǝ́sli| The first time you came to me … (A1: 22). xa-ga xeta another time, again: xá-ga xéta plíṭṭɛla Lelìθa| Again Leliθa came out’ (A51:12); then: bắye qaṭǝ̀lwale.| xá‑ga xéta klèle| He wanted to kill him. Then he refrained (A10:3-4). ʾɛ-ga at that time, then | ʾɛ́‑ga zúze baṣòrewa.| At that time money was scarce (B5:5); kút‑dana ʾa‑ṣǝ́pra mìtle,| ʾɛ́‑ga ʾana‑mɛ̀θən| If ever that sparrow dies, then I shall die (A12:41); là‑palṭət,| hal‑t‑̭amrə́nnux plùṭgena| ʾɛ̀‑ga pálṭət| Do not come out, until when I say to you ‘Come out!’, at that time you should come out (A14:67). Governing a temporal clause: ʾɛ́‑gət damǝ̀xwa,| ṭḷaθà yomáθa| ʾu‑ṭḷaθà lɛlăwáθa háwe dmìxa| When he slept, he would be asleep for three days and three nights (A29:2). Expressing logical sequence: ʾɛ́-ga ʾáp-ana bắyən ʾàzən| So, I also want to go (A5:1). Governing a factual conditional (§19.5.8.): ʾɛ́-gət mən-d-ánna hàwe,| šúla bṱ-ázəl la-qàma!| If there are these (gold pieces), the job will go ahead! (A4:15).

gabbara, gebara n.m. (pl. gabbare, gebara) hero | náše gabbàre heroic people (A29:1); gabbare, gebare Orion (constellation): mbáqər kíma-w gabbàre| ask the Pleiades and Orion (A38:12).

gadoša adj. (f. gadošta, pl. gadoše) butting, aggressive (animal) → gamaša, gamoša

gaðilta n.f. (pl. gaðilyaθa) (1) plaited strap of a shoe | This passes through small holes (ʾɛnaθa) in the shoe. (2) plaited material on the top part of shoes know as lastike

gala n.m. (pl. gale) woolen rug

galaja n.m. (pl. galaje) prattler, somebody talking nonsense

galaveža, gulavež n.f. (K.) Sirius, Dog Star, morning star

galaya n.m. revealer | k̭urra xamra la-štile ... galaya sərre ʾile Boy, do not drink the wine. … It is the revealer of secrets (C2:10)

găliya, galliya, galli n.m. (pl. galliye) (K.) valley | b‑ṣlaya galli galli tope šišale ʾəlli While (I was) coming down the valley, he brandished his gun at me (C2:49).

gallək mod. (K.) multitude; all | Only in vocative expressions: hé gállək nàše,| ʾɛ́ni záwən ʾilàna?| Hey, everybody, who will buy the tree? (B5:42)

galθa n.f. | tawə́rta npílla l‑gàlθa| the cow allowed itself to be mounted by a bull (Betanure galθa stuffed fabric used for bedding)

gamaša adj. (f. gamašta, pl. gamaše) butting, aggressive (animal) | tawərta gamašta an aggressive cow

gambəl-ʾəxre n.m. dung beetle (literally: roller of dung)

gameša n.m. (pl. gameše) buffalo

gaməšta n.f. (pl. gaməšyaθa) female buffalo

gami n.f. (K./T.) boat

gamoša adj. (f. gamošta, pl. gamoše) butting, aggressive (animal) | táwra gamóša ʾi-máxe də̀qše| An aggressive ox butts.

gamura adj. (f. gamurta, pl. gamure) sour (e.g. apple that is not ripe, dry), pungent (taste remaining in mouth)

gana, jana n.f. (pl. ganaθa) soul, person; reflexive pronoun (§7.6., §14.6.). (1) soul, person | ʾən-lá‑ʾawðət b-xábra dìyi| gánux šaqlǝ̀nna| If you do not do as I tell you, I shall take away your life (A15:20); ha-gàni,| lɛ̀kət zála?| Hey, my soul, (respectful form of address) where are you going? (A15:6); háyyo ya‑gáni ṱ‑amrànnux| Come, my dear, let me tell you something (A22:36); də́ryəxxa gyánən gu‑bɛθɛ̀xu| We have placed our sould in your house (= We beseech you) (B5:4); gánux basìmta!| Well done! (A39:21); gyánən basìmta!| bravo! (B5:154); y‑aθɛ́wa m‑bár hàdəx| xámša ʾəštà ganáθa| Afterwards, five or six peoplewould come (A5:77). (2) reflexive pronoun | zdíθəlla gána dìya| kəsle-dìye| She threw herself down beside him (A37:18); bašlǝ́xla b-gànən| Let’s cook them by ourselves (A2:2); ʾáwwa ʾǝ̀rbi| m‑gáne díye θéle ríqle l‑ṭùra| This sheep of mine has come and run to the mountain of its own accord (A10:3); maxbánət gàne-wewa| He was a lover of himself (= selfish) (A3:1); Mắmo qímɛle rəš-gàne| Mămo stood up (A26:5); làn-ṛyaša b-gáni| I do not feel anything (is happening) to me (B9:19).

ganawa → genawa

găra, gəra n.m. (pl. gărare, gărɛre) (K.) hill

garaya n.m. (pl. garaye) barber

gardăna, gərdăna n.m. (pl. gərdăne) (K.) necklace | gərdăna šəklana a beautiful necklace

gare n.m. (pl. garăwaθa) roof | ʾən‑bábux ʾu‑yə́mmux gu‑bɛ̀θɛla,| lɛ́la šəklánta ṱ‑ásqət l‑gàre| If your father and mother are in the house, it is not pleasant for you to go up onto the roof (D2:11); l‑garăwàθa biš‑rába mṭalíwala| They played it most often on the roofs (B11:29); garət ʾɛna eyelid; š-gárət ʾɛ̀ni!| by all means!

garəbya n.m. North

gărəg part. (K./T.) particle expressing necessity (deontic and epistemic) | Deontic (must): gắrəg ʾàmrəx| We must say (A4:38); gắrəg ʾàθət| ‘You must come’ (A7:9). Deontic (supposed to): ʾáxtu mən-zoruθɛ́xu gắrəg pɛšítu tlíqe b-ʾámrət màlka| In your childhood, indeed, you were supposed to disappear by the command of the king (A8:88); Epistemic: gắrəg háwe làxxa,| qəm-xazə́nne qam-xámša daqìqe| He must be here, I saw him five minutes ago.

gărəkθa, gərəkθa n.f. (pl. gărəkyaθa) (K.) hillock, small hill; mound

gărən adj. invar. (K.) expensive

gargome n.pl. thunder | šmáyya hóla mxáya gargòme| The sky is thundering.

gariθa n.f. (pl. gariyaθa) small roof | e.g. over a porch (ṣopiθa)

garma, gɛrma, gyɛrma n.m. (pl. garme) bone | gɛrmət xaṣa backbone

garo n.f. (pl. garowaθa) rat

garoma n.m. (pl. garome) large stone rolling pin

garomta n.f. (pl. garomyaθa) small stone rolling pin

garosta n.f. (pl. garosyaθa) hand-mill; molar tooth

garra (i) n.m. (pl. garre) (K.) turn | mṭéle gárre dìye| His turn came (A1:7); ha-t-mṭéle gárra ʾə́lle dìye| until it was his turn (A17:31).

garra (ii) n.m. (pl. garre, garrɛre) (K.) pool in river created by constructing a dam

garšo n.f. (pl. garšowaθa) tool used to stir up the mud in the water when planting rice in the paddy fields

garuta, garruta n.f. (pl. garuyaθa, garruyaθa) small stack of twigs or leaves for animal fodder in winter, built against a tree

garuwa, garruwa n.m. (pl. garuwe, garruwe) stack of twigs and leaves for animal fodder in winter | garúwət ṭàrpa| a heap of leaves (A32:22)

garθa n.f. (pl. garaθa) large sledge for transporting sticks and fodder on snow

gasosa n.m. (pl. gasose) wild green bean | grows in pods (šənqe) in and uncultivated area (čol)

gaṣ n.m. (A.) meat cooked over a fire on a skewer

gawa gawa prep. through (§16.6.) | síqle gáwa-gawət ḥadìqa| He went up through the garden (A17:24); náša jawújwa gawe-gawe-dìye| palə́ṭwa m-d-ɛ́-paθa xèta| A person could walk through it (the river) and come out the other side (B3:9).

gawana, gewana n.m. (pl. gawanane, gewanane) boundary; strip between fields with no cultivation marking boundary | ʾo‑gawána bēl‑ʾắra| l‑ʾằra| The boundary area is between one plot of land and another (B5:131); píšla mxurdéθa m-kúlla gewàna| It was surrounded on every boundary (B1:15).

gawaya adj. (f. gawɛθa, pl. gawaye) inside; middle | ṣabota gawɛθa middle finger; mǝ́re ṭla-d-o-xóne gawàya| He said to his middle brother (i.e. middle of three) (A24:25); ʾo-gawáyə šqilíle zùze| The middle one (of the group of three people), who took the money (A15:16).

gawaya n.m. beggar → gewaya

gawaye, gawáy adv. inside

gawna n.m. (pl. gawne) colour

gawra adj. (f. and pl. gawre) (K.) grey, off-white

gawṛa, gyawṛa n.m. (pl. guṛe, guṛane) man; married man, husband; gentleman, courtier; valiant man | gáwṛi θèle| My husband has come back (A22:32); qə́ryəlle wăzir-díye ʾu-xákma guṛàne| He called his minister and a few courtiers (A4:40); bnáθət guṛàne| the daughters of gentlemen (A38:3); náše gùṛe| valiant men (A11:14); ʾíθən biš-gùṛe mə́nni| There are those who are better men than me (A26:79); ʾən‑ʾíle ʾúrza gáwṛa xoš‑qàyəm| If he is a brave man, let him get up (A29:27); ʾáwwɛle gáwṛa m-gùṛe| He is a man among men (= the best of men).

gawza n.m. (pl. gawze, gawzane) walnut; walnut tree | bàlki| képa qítle b-gàwza| npìlle-ʾăra gáwza| Perhaps the stone has hit the walnut, and the wallnut has fallen on the ground (= Perhaps I am in luck) (A1:5); gàwze| šmìṭe| cracked (i.e. shelled) walnuts (A25:48).

gawzana n.m. (pl. gawzane) walnut tree

gawzəlta n.f. (pl. gawzəlyaθa) small walnut tree

gayasa, geyasa n.m. penitent thief (at crucifixion); ceremony held on 2nd day of Easter | In this ceremony the priest blesses the congregation with a long pole bearing candles; yōm-gayàsa| the day of the gayasa ceremony (B10:2).

gaza n.m. (K.) three year old male sheep

gazənda n.m. (pl. gazənde) complaint; grumble | la‑ʾóðət mə́nni gazə̀nda| Do not blame me.

gazəndana n.m. (pl. gazəndane) whiner, grumbler

gazgoze pl. (sing. gazgozta) goose pimples

gazza n.m. tongs | gàzza| šaqlə́xwa lə́xma bìye| gu‑tanùra| With tongs we would pick up the bread in the oven (B10:98)

gðaðe → gədda

gðalta n.f. wrestling | gðaltət kore wrestling with one foot in a small hole (If your opponent pushes you over and your foot comes out of the hole, you have lost the game).

gðila (f. gðilta, pl. gðile) adj. frozen; braided, woven

gðila n.m. ice | míya mugðə̀lla,| píšla gðìla| The water has frozen, it has become ice.

gðoða → bra-ġðoða

geba n.m. (pl. gebane) side | mən‑kúl gebàne,| ʾíθ xa‑dàšta| On all sides there is a plain (B4:1); mən-d-ó-geba xèna| on the other hand (B15:11); kút-xa xíša l‑xà-gēb| Everybody went in one (= a different) direction (B1:8). m-gēb, gēb in place of, instead of: ʾáyya béna hár-kulla ṭlàlux ʾən-bắyət,| m-gēb-d-àni| This time everything is for you, if you want, in place of those (other coins) (A1:13); ʾálaha mxožə́bnəlla m-gēb-xà-dawa| God has reckoned this bag as corresponding to one gold coin (A6:10); gēb xaθi holi ʾana instead of my sister, it is me (C1:13); ʾap-àti| m-gḗb ṱ-aθǝ́twa mɛ́θətwali zùze,| šqíllux xa-šəndòxa| So you, instead of coming and bringing me money, took a stone (A1:25).

gebara → gabbara

genawa, ganawa n.m. (pl. genawe) thief (§2.5.2. iv) | ʾurxət genawe The Milky Way

genawta n.f. (pl. genawyaθa) thief (f.)

genawuθa n.f. theft, robbery; stealth | y‑áwəðwa genawùθa| ʾu‑qačaxùθa| He engaged in robbery and brigandry (A27:1); núbləlle b-genawùθa| He took it away in stealth.

gesa n.m. gypsum plaster | mšurɛ́lɛ bnáyəlla batèy| b‑képa ʾu‑gèsa| They began to build their houses with stone and gypsum plaster (B5:179)

gewaya, gawaya, guwaya n.m. (pl. gewaye, gawaye, guwaye) beggar

gežana adj. (f. gežanta, pl. gežane) (K.) dizzy

gezara n.m. (pl. gezare) carrot

gəbbo n.f. foam, froth

gədda n.m. (pl. gədde, gðaðe) string; thread | ma-yəmmi zulli gðaðe| Spin for me threads (A51:3)

gəddiša n.m. (pl. gəddiše) pile, pile of wood

gəddišta, gdišta n.f. (pl. gəddišyaθa) stook of corn | especially millet (prage), sorghum (xroriye) and sesame (šišme)

gədla m. (pl. gədle) wattle of intertwined twigs used to make a fence and other structures | mxéli gə́dla qam‑d‑áwwa bàqči| I have built a fence in front of my garden

gədša n.m. (pl. gədše) momentous event; catastrophe

gəðya n.m. (pl. gəðye) newborn male goat

gəgla n.m. (pl. gəgle) skein (of wool, thread) spun on a spool (msarbis)

gəhana n.m. Hell

gəlda n.m. (pl. gəlde) skin; carcass | xá‑gəldət tàwra| an ox skin (A11:10); mǝ́xyɛle ʾáqle díye l-ò-gəlda| He kicked the carcass (A27:43).

gəlla n.m. (pl. gəllale) plant; herb; grass | gəllət čay tea leaves

gəlya adj. (f. gliθa, pl. gəlye) open, exposed | ʾap‑ʾáxxa ʾisàra| réša har-gə̀lya| There was a rock here, the top of which was completely exposed (B9:3).

gəmbəlta n.f. (pl. gəmbəlyaθa) small ball | gəmbəltət ʾupra ball of earth; gəmbəltət barða hailstone

gəmgəmme n.pl. delicious foods | banəx kanune č̣əmme č̣əmme ʾu‑ʾəlla mbašləx gəmgəmme Let us build stoves (with) a little (fire) and on them we shall cook delicious foods (C1:5).

gəmra n.m. tanning

gəndore n.pl. (sing. gəndorta) (K.) melons

gəngəryasa n.f. (pl. gəngəryase) lime fruit, lime tree | ʾilanət gəngəryase lime tree

gənθa n.f. (pl. gənnane) (small) garden

gəppa n.m. (pl. gəppape) cave

gəppiθa n.f. (pl. gəppiyaθa, gəpyaθa) small cave

gəra → găra

gera n.m. (pl. gere) arrow; long thin rolling pin | qəšta-w gera bow and arrow

gərdăna → gardăna

gərðo n.f. dish consisting of yoghurt and cracked wheat

gərəkθa (i) n.f. (pl. gərəkyaθa) (K.) hand mill used to remove husks from rice

gərəkθa (ii) n.f. hillock → gărəkθa

gərgara n.m. (pl. gərgare) (K.) smooth steep slope

gərgəra n.m. type of grass with seed head that is fed to sheep; light snow falling in round grains like the seeds of this plant | dúnye hóla ráya gərgə̀ra| It is snowing in round grains.

gərgərta n.f. (pl. gərgəryaθa) wheel

gərkawe n.f. (K.) hunting of partridges | y‑azə́xwa gərkàwe| We used to go hunting partridges (B5:147)

gərra n.m. leprosy, psoriasis | kút-xa hóle zíla b-xá-gərrət yə̀mme| Every one went off empty handed (B1:23)

gərrəsta n.f. dandruff

gərse n.pl. crushed wheat | xa dəndəkθət gərsa a grain of crushed wheat

gərsəkka n.m. (pl. gərsəkke) (K.) wild pear

gərsəkθa n.f. (pl. gərsəkke, gərsəkyaθa) (K.) small wild pear

gərwe n.pl. (sing. gərwiθa, gruθa, gərwa f.) socks

gəšər n.m. (A.) husk

gesərra n.m. (K.) type large sparrow

gəšra n.m. (pl. gəšre) bridge

gəsta n.f. (pl. gəsyaθa) fleece of sheep

gəxka n.m. laughter; joke; fun | našət gəxka a man who is the butt of jokes; ʾay‑ṭawálta mṭalíwala qa‑gə̀xka| They play this game for fun (B12:2).

gəzra n.m. (pl. gəzre) mound, pile (of stones)

gəžže n.f. (K.) raised hand | neríya b-gə́žže lè-y-mayəθ| A male goat does not die (at the sight of) a raised hand (D2:12)

gilandi, gilanda n.m. (pl. gilandiye, gilande) (K.) scythe

gilasa n.m. (pl. gilase) cherry, cherry tree

gira n.m. limescale; tartar (on teeth) | képa dwíqle gírət mìya| The stone has become scaled from the water

giša n.m. (pl. giše) target

gisəkyaθa n.pl. (sing. gisəkθa) black pepper

gisəqθa, jisəqθa (pl. gisqaθa, jisqaθa) (K.) one- to two-year old female goat

gisqa n.m. (pl. gisqe) (K.) one- to two-year old male goat

gista n.f./adj. barren woman; wretched woman | ʾo gista xaθəx Oh your poor sister (C3:3)

glās n.m. (pl. glase) (K./E.) glass (for drinking)

glola n.m. circle. adj. (f. galolta, pl. galole) round

glop n.m. (pl. glope) lamp

gmira adj. (f. gmirta, pl. gmire) tanned (leather); compressed | ʾamṛa gmira compressed wool

gnaya n.m. (pl. gnaye) fault | lɛ́le gnàyi| It is not my fault; ʾína lɛ́wa mǝ́dre gnàyux| But again it was not your fault (A1:25).

gnayət yoma, gnay-yoma West | Combined with la side: hóle ʾə́θya Déwa Zàr| … m-la-gnay-yòma| Dewa Zar has come … from the West (A28:14).

gnɛθət yoma n.f. setting of the sun, dusk | gu-sáʾət ʾə́šta ʾaṣə́rta šáwwa gu-gnɛ́θət yòma,| hóle θéle Čùxo| At six or seven o’clock in the evening, at dusk, Čuxo came (A7:21).

gnuna n.m. (pl. gnune) band (tied at a wedding ceremony) | θáyɛle qàša| ʾu‑sáṛa gnùnɛle| The priest comes and ties the wedding band (B5:44)

goja n.m. (pl. goje) (K.) stock of tree; large root of a tree

gojiθa n.f. (pl. gojiyaθa) (K.) small stock of tree

goma n.m. (pl. gome, gomăwaθa) (K.) basement stable

gomiθa n.f. (pl. gomiyaθa) (K.) small stable

goṛa adj. (f. goṛta, pl. goṛe) big; great; old. (1) big (in size) | gilándi rába gòṛɛle| A scythe is very big (B5:143); ʾotáxe gòṛe hawéwa| Rooms were large (B10:51). (2) great (in power or importance) ʾíθwa lìθwa| biš‑m‑álaha góṛa čú-mdi lìθwa| There was, there was not, there was nothing greater than God (opening formula of stories) (A30:1); ʾeða goṛa the great festival = Easter. Used as nominal: góṛət ʾAmedìya| The chief of Amedia (A25:45). (3) old (person) | ʾána xa-náša gòṛɛwən,| wíra b-šə̀nne| I am an old man, advanced in years (A8:43); naša goṛa b-šənne an elderly person; goṛət ʾumra advanced in age; xóna ʾo‑góṛa the eldest brother (A12:17); Náze ʾɛ‑gòṛta| Naze, the eldest one (A25:16); kùllən,| mən‑yále zóre ʾu‑hal‑gòṛe| All of us, from young children to old people (B16:4).

goriya n.m. (K.) sacrifice (for redemption of s.o.) | hoyə́nwa gorìye| Let me be his redeemer, let me die instead of him. Used in devotional expressions in combination with names of saints: Mar‑Sàwa,| goríyət xɛ̀le| Saint Sawa, a sacrifice for his strength.

gorna n.f. (pl. gornaθa) baptismal font

goša n.m. (pl. goše) side (of a shape); corner

gota n.f. (pl. goyaθa, gotaθa) side | ʾasṛíwala b‑qɛ́sa ʾu‑m‑áy‑gota qɛ̀sa| ʾu‑m‑áy‑gota qɛ̀sa| They would bind them to a stick, with a stick this side and a stick that side (B7:16); holá-ʾəθye tìwe,| báxta tíwta l‑àyya-gotət més,| ʾu-gáwṛa tíwa l-ày-gota| They came and sat down, the wife sitting on this side of the table and the husband sitting on the other side (A4:57); ṱ-ázət zɛ́nət gótə d-o-xaràya| Go and stand by the side of the last one (A8:47); šqílɛle xa-šəndòxa| ṭrípəlle l‑gota-dìya| He took a smooth stone and threw it at her (A30:37); kúlla ṣalɛ́wa gota‑xtɛ̀θa| They would all fall down (B5:43); ṃaḷɛ́wa qərṭála m‑ay‑gṓt tərnèy| They would fill the pannier basket on both sides (B5:137); m-kúlla goyàθa| on all sides (A8:48); kízle mxàya| goyáθət sùsa,| súsa la‑jwìjle| He tried to strike the sides of the horse, but the horse did not move (A28:33).

gozăka n.m./f. (pl. gozăke) (K.) ankle | gozăkət ʾiða wrist

grawa n.m. (K.) off-white cotton fabric | used for lining clothes

grawəzna n.m. (pl. grawəzne) load of harvested rice carried on the back in a piece of cloth

griwa adj. (f. griwta, pl. griwe) ravenous, very hungry

gu- prep. (with pronominal suffixes: gawe) in; concerning; compared with; by (oath). (1) in | usually within an enclosed physical space: gu‑xa‑gəppìθa| in a cave (A15:1); gu-dudìya in the cradle (A15:8); ingressive: wìrela gu-bɛ́θa| They went into the house (A15:7); ʾǝ̀nwe ʾíθ gáwe| There are grapes in it (the orchard). (2) concerning | šmíle gu-d-o-Dàwəð:| ʾǝ́n ʾàmər| ṭúra mšanéle m-àxxa| mšanéle tămàha| The monk had heard concerning that David that if he says he will move a mountain from here, he will move it there (A16:3). (3) compared with | rába xá‑mdi prìšɛla júllux gu‑d‑ánna diyɛ́ni| Your clothes are something very special compared with ours (A35:10). (4) by | only in oaths: gu‑d‑ànna ʾɛ́ni bṱ‑áθən| (I promise) by these eyes of mine that I shall come (A22:20).

gubba n.m. (pl. gubbe) inner pocket

gubbān n.m. (A.) spirit-level | har-gubbā̀n-ix wíðəlle| We made it exactly according to a spirit-level (A17:20).

gučča n.m. (pl. gučče) (K.) fist | maxə́nnux xa-gùčča| I shall punch you.

guda n.m. (pl. gudane) wall | gúda máre naθyàθɛle| The wall has ears (A29:6).

guða n.m. (pl. guðe) skin bag (for churning or carrying liquids)

guðanta n.f. (guðanyaθa) small skin bag

gugiya n.m. (pl. gugiye) (K.) tassel

gugiθa n.f. (pl. gugiyaθa) (K.) small tree stump | ða‑gugíθa b‑šáwwa boyàye.| mòdile?| rèša.| A small stump of a tree with seven holes—What is it? A head (D1:17)

gujja n.m. (pl. gujje) (K.) three-year-old male sheep

gujma n.m. (pl. gujme) bunch (of grapes, nuts)

gulavež → galaveža

gulbare n.f. type of dance

gullira n.m. (pl. gullire) (K.) round oak apple gall | grows on the mɛša and p̣aṛma trees; used for tanning (gmara).

gulpa n.m. (pl. gulpane) wing | píšəlla xákma gulpàne| dáx d-an-t-ṭèra.| She had acquired some wings like those of a bird (A8:76).

gumarta n.f. piece of glowing charcoal

gumla n.m. (pl. gumle) camel

gunga m. (pl. gunge) (K.) chimney pipe

guniya n.f. (pl. guniyaθa) (K.) sack | made of flax, imported from towns. Sacks made in the villages out of animal hair are known as juwala.

gupta n.f. (pl. gupyaθa) cheese | gupta mṭumarta cheesed buried in ground to mature

gurba n.m. (pl. gurbe) torso (of an animal)

gurj adj. invar. (K.) tight; too short (rope)

guršeni | xəgga guršeni type of line dance

guṛuθa n.f. bravery | háwya bríxta guṛùθux| May your bravery be blessed (= bravo!) (A24:21).

gurya n.m. (pl. gurye) pup of dog

gurza n.f. (pl. gurzăwaθa) club

gušma n.m. (pl. gušme) fist | lá-maxət gúšma ʾurə̀dxa| Do not punch a needle (D2:59) → gučča

gusta n.f. (pl. gusyaθa) ball of dough

gutta n.f (pl. guttaθa) ball | guttət ʾaqla football

guwaya → gawaya

gwarta n.f. marriage | mò-hoyali gwárta-w?| What good would marriage be to me? (A16:5)

gwina n.m. (pl. gwinane) boundary, side (of field, paddy field basin) | marmíwa gwinánət məššàre| They would build up the sides of the paddy field basins.

gyatta n.f. finish at top of a wall on which the roof is laid; finishing at edge of woven material.

gzərta n.f. small pile


/ġ/

ġaba n.f. (A.) forest

ġaləbuθa n.f. (A.) achievement | w-àti| qa-dìyux| xa-ġaləbúθa gòṛtɛle| ʾən-bróni tàrəṣ| It would be a big achievement on your part if my son is cured (A8:36).

ġăzăliya n.f. (pl. ġăzăliyaθa) gazelle

ġðaðe pron. reciprocal pronoun (§14.6.) | bróni ʾu-brátux xə́zyela ġðàðe| My son and your daughter saw each other (A4:26); ʾu‑xíllən kúllən m‑ġðàðe| and we all ate together (A21:39); ʾu-ʾìtlən| ʾəštá-maθwaθa qúrba l-ġðàðela| We have six villages that are near to one another (B1:3); xa-xa-gáye ʾi-maxéwa tmanyà saʾə̀tte| bar-ġðáðe t‑là-klɛθa| Sometimes, they played for eight hours continuously without stopping (B15:77).



/h/

ha part. presentative particle | hàyyo!| hóla hà!| šqúlla yalə̀xθa| Come! Here it is! Take the handkerchief. (A4:18); ha-šqùl| Here, take (them) (A6:3).

habresəm, ʾabresəm n.m. (K./A.) silk

habriya n.m. (pl. habriye) (K.) festive headscarf | šəṭro marθət habriya the beautiful woman who possesses the headscarf (C2:1)

habsa n.m. (A.) prison

haða-huwa (A.) that is that, that is final

hadayya → hadiya

hade part. just now, hardly | yóma hádele zrìqa| The sun has just now risen (A26:37); yále zóre háde bǝ̀rye| young children just born (A8:10); ʾána hàden pláṭa| I am just now coming out (A23:11). hade m-hade as just now, once again: hade‑m‑háde píšlən xawràne| We became friends once again (B5:132); zìla| mtugə̀brəlla| háde m‑hàde‑w| They went and put it in order once again (A23:24).

hadəx adv. thus; like that; the same; so much. (1) thus, like that | dax-ṱ-ile xə́zyəlla θàya,| hádəx ṣràxa-w| xumθàne,| Čúxo rìqɛle| When he saw them coming, shouting like this and angry, Čuxo ran away (A7:16); páyəšwa ʾax‑xàlwa,| brìza hádəx| It would become like curds, dry, (it was) like that (B7:22). (2) the same | dártət-yoma zílla wídla hàdəx| The next day she went and did the same (A18:3); xàrθa,| pàlṭeti| ʾap‑ʾaṣə́rta hàdəx| Then, you go out, and in the evening (do) the same (A22:23); har-hádəx ʾŭ́mur Már Qiyòma| The age of Mar Qiyoma is the same (B1:7). (3) Making temporal intervals in narrative: šǝ́ryela gu-d-ɛ́ ʾotél ʾo-yòma-w| píšela hàdəx,| ʾaṣǝ́rta θìθɛla| bắyi ṱ-áxli xa-ràmša| They put up in the hotel that day and remained like that (until) the evening came and they wanted to eat dinner (A2:2); xa‑béna wítɛla hádəx b‑lɛ̀le| mə́xyɛle taq‑taq‑táq l‑tằra| Then, at night, there was a knock at the door (A23:26); bar‑hàdəx,| y‑aθɛ́wa mdarɛ̀wale| qa‑t‑lá‑hawa píše šə̀xte| Then they would come and winnow it (B5:86); hádəx ʾáp-ati ʾǝ̀θyət| Meanwhile you also came (A2:9). (4) so much | ʾo-xáwri hádəx gabbàra,| xázəx wírre gawàye| We saw my friend, who was such a huge man, go inside (B15:58); hàdəx-iwa xóš-naša| hàdəx‑iwa spày| He was such a good man, he was so good (A4:31).

hadiya, diya, hadayya (marginal) adv. now | hadíya ðíli ʾána manáy díyux mòdila| Now I know what you mean (A17:35); díya lɛ̀kət zála?| Now where are you going? (A1:12); ʾána m-díya m-bàθər| brátux băyə̀nna| I from now on love your daughter (A17:35); dìya| t-xzéle málka dúnye ráya pàṛe| zawn-šlàmɛle| Now that the king has seen it raining lambs, it is the time of peace (A1:26); ʾu-díya ṱ-àθyən| I shall be right back (A4:22); har-díya máṭyən ṱ-àθyən| I shall go right now and come back (A4:17); díya b‑dìya| (A30:28), di-b-dìya| right now (A30:35).

hădiya n.f. (pl. hădaya) (A.) gift

hāl n.f. (pl. hawāl) (A.) condition, situation | hā́l hawā́l ʾàtxɛla| The situation is like this (A8:35); hā́l ʾu-hawā́l hátxa xzèli| I saw such-and-such things (A4:7); hā́l‑u qǝ́ṣṣət hàtxɛla| The situation is like this (A12:42); ʾána háli m‑halɛ̀xu| I shall live like you (A14:97); líθ wíya čù‑məndi,| genáwe hàle?| Has anything happened? Thieves or the like? (A29:22); ṱ‑ázən máθyən xáčča štɛ̀θa,| màzza,| məndi-hàle| I shall go and bring some drink, nibbles, and the like (A17:25); míla l‑hàlux!| Confound you! (literally: Blue on your condition!) (A23:10).

hal, ha- prep. (§13.3.10., §19.3.9.) until, up to; before; until when. (1) until, up to | hal-ʾaṣǝ́rta plìxɛle| He worked until evening (A16:5); ʾo‑mənnɛ́xu t-dàqər| b-Mằmo,| m-áxxa hál qaṣrət-mìra| ṱ-oðə́xle də̀mma| Whoever of you touches Mămo, we shall scatter his blood from here until the palace (A26:68); yáʿni xamšá daqíqela hal‑ʾə̀ṣra| ʾáti ʾàθeti| after five or ten minutes you should come back (A22:22); hal-ʾìman ṱ-áwət hátxa mdagóle?| For how long will you lie like this? (A26:56). Before a prepositional phrase: wíyəx pláša m‑ʾaṣǝ́rta hal‑gu‑mbadlàθa| We fought from evening until morning (A12:19); hal‑gu‑réšət ṭúra up to the top of the mountain (A14:49). Combined with connective particle w: m-ó-yoma dwíqəlle Mắmo gu-hàbsa,| ʾu-hàl-ʾədyo| From that day he has held Mămo in prison, until today (A26:75); kùllən,| mən‑yále zóre ʾu‑hal‑gòṛe| all of us, from young children to old people (B16:4). Content clause as complement (often shortened to ha-): zílela hal-mǝ́ṭyela l-qàṣra| They went until they arrived at the palace (A24:49); kazíwa práməlla har-palṭìwa,| hál plíṭla hàtxa| They tried to cut them down, but they kept growing up, until they grew like this (A38:15); mxéla l‑ġðàðe| ha-t‑ṭḷáθna mìtla| They beat one another until the three of them died (A22:35). (2) before | ha-ṱ‑íle ʾə̀θya,| mpuláṭṭɛla fằqih| Before he came back, she took out the jurist (A22:39); pɛšáwa tàlga hal-qedámta| It would become ice before morning (B15:26). (3) until when | là‑palṭət,| hal‑ṱ‑amrə́nnux plùṭgena| ʾɛ̀‑ga pálṭət| Do not come out, until when I say to you ‘Come out!’, at that time you should come out (A14:67).

hala part. still (not) (§15.11.1.) | used before a negative copula or negative existential particle: ʾìna| núrət xàle| ṱ-íwa síqa l-tàma| gu‑zòma| hála lɛ̀le č̣ə́mya| The fire in the summer house of his maternal uncle, where he was making for, had still not gone out (A25:40); ʾáwwa nàša| hála lìtwale| This man still did not yet have (a son) (A8:5).

hălāl → ḥălāl

halbat part. (K./A.) of course

hălikoptər n.f. (E.) helicopter

hal-lɛle → har

halučakka n.m. (pl. halučakke) n.pl. (K.) black plum

haluka, halukka n.m. (pl. haluke, halukke) (K.) black plum; black plum tree

halurašša n.m. (pl. halurašše) (K.) black plum

halwasna n.m. (pl. halwasne) raspberry | It grows on a sunniθa tree

ham part. (K.) also; even; again. (1) also | ʾap‑m‑d‑áni y‑óði muràbba,| yáʿni ham‑mən‑sparə̀gle| They make jam also from these, that is also from quinces (B5:219). (2) even | in conditional constructions: hám‑ʾən yawə́tli zùze,| lè-y-aθən| Even if you give me money, I shall not come. (3) again | ham-zílɛle kə́sle dìye| He went again to him (A25:25); ham-mṣawòre ʾə́lle díye| He curses him again (A17:3).

hămanta, haymanta n.f. trust | ʾíða hămànta| a trusted hand (a deposit made by the groom’s family to the bride’s family as a token of securing the betrothal) (B5:5); hămántət bɛ̀θa| trust in the family (B5:44).

hambišaya n.m./f. (pl. hambišaye) giant

hamdān, ḥamdani n.m. (pl. hamdane) sheep with long hanging ears

hammaše, hammaša adv. (K.) always

ḥănăfiye n.f. (pl. ḥănăfiyāt) (A.) tap

hanawe n.pl. internal organs

handawaya n.m./adj. (pl. handawaye) Indian

hapupka n.m. (pl. hapupke) (K.) hoopoe bird

ḥaqiqi adj. invar. (A.) true

ḥaqq n.m. (A.) price; wage | kəmɛ́le ḥàqqe?| What is its price?| ʾáxni šáqləx ḥáqqət ʾəjàra mǝ́nne díye| We shall receive wages from him (A14:15); ʾu‑la-ḥáqqət kàrmi lɛle-yáwa| nor does he pay the price of the orchard (A17:30).

ḥaqqiθa n.f. (A.) cost, due (to be paid)

ḥaqquθa n.f. (A.) right; fee; what is lawful | ʾu-haqquθɛ́xu le-y-ṭàlqa| Your right will not be lost (A8:88); ʾína ʾítli ḥaqqùθi| but I (must) have my fee (A27:19); ṱ-ázən ṭắyən báθər ḥaqqùθa| ʾu-na-ḥaqqùθa| I shall go and search for what is lawful and what is unlawful (A15:5); xále díye t‑ḥaqqùθa| His real uncle (A23:28).

har part. (K.) always; again; still; as soon as; directly; just, only; the same; surely (§15.11.). (1) always, constantly | har-bxàya-wawa| They were constantly continued crying (A25:5); ʾu‑ʾáti har‑háwət baràye| ʾu‑sáprət ku‑t‑áθe làxxa| You be outside all the time and wait for whoever comes here (A22:23); har‑blígət b‑kàsux| You are always busy with your stomach (A23:10). (2) again | yómət ṭḷàθa| har‑ṣlèla| On the third day she went down again (A22:18). (3) still | Temporal persistence: ʾu-dəbbóre hár-hola qam-tắrət bòya| The hornets were still before the door of the hole (A20:9); har-xáθe ʾi-bằyela| He still loves his sister (A18:16); ʾáy har-là-yawəlla| It still does not give it back (A34:4); hal-lɛle < har-lɛle: hal-lɛ̀la gláya| She (the mother) still does not reveal (the truth) (A38:6). Logically unexpected: kəmə̀t ṱ-árqena| tópe har-ṭapyàli| However much I run, a gun will still reach me (B9:3). (4) as soon as | har-ðìlɛxu príqlən mən-ṭúra,| dɛ́rən tòpe,| kút-xa maxèla| xánjər dìye,| ʾo-ṱ-íle qáme díye qaṭə̀lle| As soon as you know that we have finished (coming over) the mountain, I shall fire a gun and everyone will strike with his dagger and kill the man in front of him (B19:6); har‑qítla bìyux,| qaṭlílux ṱ‑axlìlux| As soon as they hit you, they will kill you and eat you (A22:39). (5) directly | har‑ʾə́θyɛle mən‑ṭúra réša‑reša d‑o‑gàre| He came straight from the mountain onto the roof (A23:14). (6) just, only | har‑ʾàna hon‑zlíma| Only I am wronged (A13:5); lá har‑ʾáxni zlìme| Not only we are wronged (A13:16); har-ʾàwwɛle| He is alone (A17:16); har-ʾàti| you yourself (and nobody else) (A27:6); hár‑xa xále dìyele| It is his one and only uncle (A28:11). Narrowing the extent of an action: ʾína bróna lɛ̀la xíltəlle.| har-nobáltəlle muttɛ́θəlle mattòye.| She did not eat the boy. She just took him and put him down. (A19:7); ʾána har-ṣálən mðìta| mɛ́θən ʾixàla| ʾu-ʾàθena| I’ll just go down to the town to bring food and come back (A26:30). (7) the same | in combination with demonstratives: hàr ʾo-yóma on the same day (A25:4). (8) surely, indeed | ʾáxni har-xònən-it| You are indeed our brother (A39:12); ʾay-xá-yoma har-t-yằða| ṱ-íle míθa brònən| She will surely know one day that our son is dead (A4:39)

hăramāt → ḥarām

harmiya, hɛrmiya n.m. (pl. harmiye, hɛrmiye) (K.) pear | harmiyət čeri autumn pear; harmiyət qɛṭa summer pear

harmone, ʾarmone n.pl. (sing. harmonta, ʾarmonta) pomegranates | ʾilanət harmone pomegranate tree

harmonta, ʾarmonta n.f. pomegranate tree

harnuwa n.f. (pl. harnuwe) rabbit

harrəj n.m. (A.) bargain price

harun n.m. type of herb

hašya (i) n.m. (pl. hašye) woven lace | ʾašitnàye| qəm‑mpalṭíla ʾáwwa šálət qðàla,| hàšya| The people from Ashitha produced the neck shawl, (made of) lace (B10:50); zaqrə́xwa hàšye,| laqṭə̀xwa| We would weave works of lace and embroider them (B10:85); xmaṭət hašya needle for sewing lace.

hašya (ii) n.m. herb put in jajək and cheese (like chive)

hatta, hat part. even (A.) | hátta Gozáli b-gáne mšudrə́tle lɛ̀n θíθa| Even (when) you sent Gozali himself, I did not come (A8:94); hat‑yəmméy wírən ṭàlba| I entered attacking even their mother (A12:18); hátta mɛxólta b‑kàwe dárəx ʾəlle‑díye| We even give food to it through the window (A12:62).

hatxa, ʾatxa part. thus, like this, so, such | si-hátxa múrgən ṭla-màlka| Go, say thus to the king (A17:30); hàtxɛla qǝ́ṣṣət| The story is like this (A13:5); háyyo hátxa hátxa mə̀nnux!| Come on you so-and-so! (curse) (A28:21). Adverb: mjunəgníla hàtxa| She shook them like this (A4:15); wíðɛle hó hátxa ʾax‑də̀bba| He behaved just like a bear (B18:5). Governing a nominal: hátxa mǝ̀ndi| such a thing (A14:6); čú-bena lat-ṭlíbta hátxa məndiyáne díya hot-ṭlàba!| You have never requested such things are you are requesting now (A26:45). Governing an adjective: ʾíman ṱ-íle xə̀zyəlla,| hátxa šəṭránta-w šapìrta,| ʾay-ṣrìxla| When he saw her, so beautiful and good-looking, she screamed (A4:4). Expressing approximation: ʾaṣə̀rta| sáʾət ʾə́šta ʾàtxa| in the evening, around six o’clock (B15:43). End of discourse unit: xíšɛle l-bɛ̀θa| lɛ́le-hiwa ʾàtxa| He did not give (the money) and that was that (A1:9).

hatxane (pl. of hatxa) such things; approximately like this | ʾána gắrəg ʾámrən hatxàne| I must tell such things (A39:7); záwda mən‑ʾarbá‑mma šə̀nnele.| bálki bíš‑k̭em mən‑ʾəštà‑mma šə́nnela,| hàtxane| ṱ‑íle bənya tàma| It is older than four hunrdred years. Perhaps it is less that six hundred years ago, something like that, when it was built there (B6:31).

havrəkka n.m. (pl. havrəkke) (K.) rival, opponent | tre yalone havrəkke šarreley rəš-mamməkke two rival children are fighting on the breasts (C2:39).

hawa n.m. (K./A.) air

hawar, hawər n.m. (pl. haware) (K.) cry for help | haware! Help!; hàwarila| Help! (A32:21); hàwər-ila| What a calamity! (A7:10); píštɛla háwar gu‑màθa| There was a cry of alarm in the village (B5:162); draya hawar/hawər to call in anguish, call for help: šúryɛle mxáya gu-réše dráya hàwər| He began beating his head yelling in anguish (A7:10); ʾáp-xa la-mṣèle| θéle mṭéle hawàrən| Nobody could come to help us (B15:41).

hawd n.m. (pl. hawde) (A.) basin; flower-bed | qumte rixana t‑hawdi His figure was (that of) a basil in my flower-bed (C2:65)

hawga n.m. (pl. hawge) (K.) steam

hawna n.m. (pl. hawne) mind, intelligence | mɛθə̀nne háwni| I shall try to work it out (literally: I shall bring my intelligence) (A26:36).

hawnana, honana adj. (f. hawnanta, pl. hawnane) clever

hawše, ḥawše n.f. (pl. hawšaθa) (K./A.) sheep-fold, animal pen | constructed with wicker fencing (gədla), usually in the mountains, where the sheep spend the night: ʾíθ ḥáwše t‑ṭùra,| mturáṣta xa-dúkθa gu‑ṭùra,| képe y‑áwa zə̀dyəlla,| murə́xməlla qa‑t‑ʾə́rwe dàwṛi táma| There is a mountain sheep-fold, a place made in the mountains, in which they have removed the stones and which they have made suitable for the sheep to dwell in.

hayarta n.f. help

haymanuθa n.f. faith

hazər, haẓər, hað̣ər adj. invar. (K./A.) ready, prepared | hazər qa-štaya ready for drinking; ʾánna məndiyáne ṱ-it-ṭlábəlla kúlla hàzərila| All the things that you request are ready (A8:38); simàrxa| wíðtɛla gána hàzər| The simarxa bird prepared herself (A27:13).

he part. yes | maṣítu mšadrítula kə̀sli?| mǝ́ra hè| He said ‘Can you send her to me?’ They said ‘Yes’ (A4:13).

hedi hedi adv. (K./A.) slowly | ʾáy hédi-hedi qìmla| She got up slowly (A20:5); hédi hédi bašə́lwa ʾixàla| The food cooked slowly (B10:87)

hemza n.m. edible herb with pungent root and white sap

heš, həš, š part. still; (not) yet; (no) longer (§15.10.). (1) still | héš xúya xùyɛle| It is still very dark (A30:36); ʾáy heš-hóla gu-gòma| She is still in the basement stable (A18:22). As an intensifier of a comparative: heš-bìš qam-xóna díya qímtɛla| She rose still earlier than her brother (A8:69); b-qáryən ʾu-hèš-biš záwda| I shall call yet louder (A8:72). (2) heš + negator = not yet | heš-lɛ́le làxxa| He is not here yet; heš‑lɛ́le ʾə̀θya| He has not come yet; š‑lɛ́wa mšúrya xála gə̀lla| It had not yet started to eat grass (B5:175); qəm‑dári ʾan‑dáwwe heš‑t‑là bráza| They have poured out the dawwe while it is not yet dry (B14:1). (3) la + heš (generally contracted to leš, lɛš, laš, ləš) = no longer | léš-ʾaθəx hayorə̀xlux| We shall no longer come to help you (A48:6); leš faydáləx qáṭlət gànəx| It will no longer be of any use to you to kill yourself (A38:16); ʾáqlət susɛ́xu ʾən-píšla kèpa,| léš maṣítu jawjìtu| If the legs of your horses have become stone, you will no longer be able to move (A8:28); léš-ile gu-bɛ̀θa| He is no longer in the house; lɛ́š-in xzàya| I can no longer see (A24:2).

hewən n.m. (pl. hewane) (K.) season | ʾáyya ṱók̭e b-áwwa héwən, m-ɛ̀ka ṱók̭e díya?!| Is this a ṱok̭e bird in this season? Where has a ṱok̭e bird come from at this time? (A30:36); hewənət xzada the harvest season; qč̣ipewəx mqorəč̣pewəx| t-la-b-hewən ʾu-t-la măjalən| We are cut down and harvested not in the season nor in our time (for cutting) (A51:8); fa‑y‑áθe tàlga,| ʾu‑náše mšɛ́ri b‑hèwaney| maṣlɛ́wa karàθa| (When) the snow came, people would start bringing down loads (of leaves) as they needed them (literally: in their season) (B5:120); hèwənile| Is is time (to take the honeycomb from the hive) (B5:177); héwən-t gàre| the season of (sleeping on) the roof (B10:59).

heymanuθa n.f. faith

heywən, hɛwən, haywən, ḥeywən, ḥɛwən, ḥaywən n.m. (pl. heywane etc.) (K./A.) animal

hezara n.m. (pl. hezare) wooden beam used to lock a door

hezuke n.f. (K.) swing | y‑ázi y‑óði hèzuke| They go and swing (on a swing) (B6:6)

hɛrike n.pl. (K.) soft mud | made in preparation for cultivation of rice: tré‑yomaθa ṭḷàθa,| maštɛ̀wala| qá‑t xáčča pɛ́šawa rakìxta.| … ʾáwwa y‑amrə́xxe wáða hɛrìke| Three or four days beforehand, they would irrigate it so that it would become quite soft. … We call this making ‘soft mud beds’ (B5:76).

həlma n.m. (K.) breath | bắyən mə̀nnux| hə́lma t-yáwət b-rèši| I want you to blow on me (A25:12); hóla susăwàθa| jə̀mye b-réše díye| wáða hə̀lma| b-réše dìye| The horses were gathered over him, blowing onto him (A25:13).

hənd adv. a little (K.) | hə́nd ṃaḷèwa| It was just enough (B10:6). Before the 3fs. copula (hənṱ-ila) in temporal expressions: hənṱ-ila xə́zyəlla gane-díye tráb gu-ʾùrxa| All of a sudden (literally: it is a little) he found himself—bang—on a road (A8:40); hə́nṱ-ila ṱ-àθe| He will come very soon; hə́nṱ-ila rzígli m-šùla| I shall be finished with work very soon.

hənna n.m./f. (A.) thing; trifle, small amount. (1) thing | used as filler: ʾána háwən šḗx d-áyya hə̀nna| I am the sheikh of this thing (i.e. tribe) (A7:7). (2) trifle, small amount | used as a clausal conjunction: hə́n-ṱ-ile ṱ-àθe| He will come in a jiffy (= He is about to come); hə́n-ṱ-iwən t-rázgən| I shall finish in a jiffy (= I am about to finish); hə́n-ṱ-ile xə́zyəlla gane-díye tráb gu-ʾùrxa| In a trifle (= suddenly) he found himself on a road (A8:40).

həšše n.pl.tan. (K./A.) senses | hóle zíla m-hə́šše dìye| He has lost his senses; ʾáw l‑hə́šše dìyele| He is conscious.

həšyər adj. invar. (K.) careful | wi-hə̀šyər! Be careful!; háwət hə́šyər t‑là‑ʾaθi ʾə́llux| Be careful they do not accost you (A22:26); háwət hǝ́šyər ʾína ʾáyya sústa là marpǝ́tla| Be careful not to let that horse go (A12:29); daréle gu‑yáma hǝ̀šyər| He put it in the sea carefully (A12:30).

hič part. (K.) no, none (§14.9.18.) | ʾíθwa-w lìθwa| bíš m-álaha gòṛa| líθwa gòṛa| hič-nàša| There was and there was not, there was no man greater than God (opening formula of a story) (A8:2).

hiwi n.f (pl. hiwiye) (K.) hope | ʾitli hiwi ṱ-aθən I hope to come; ʾítli híwi ṱ‑áwət sáx ʾu-sălaməttùθa| I hope you will be fine and in good health; ʾo-t-páyəš b-híwi-t nàše| míθɛle mən-bərmàše| He who relies on other people is dead by the evening (D2:28); žɛ́re Fàrxo| ṱ-íwən ʾána b-hìwi díya| Poor (me), Farxo, who am waiting in hope for her (A25:18); ʾáyya muttáwtəlla híwət bàbi| She had abandoned hope regarding my father (B9:11); káze wáða hìwi mə́nne| ʾána xulàmux| He tried to beg him (saying) ‘I am your servant’ (A29:33).

ho part. presentative particle | hó ʾan‑ṭḷá gerə‑qǝ̀šta| Here are the three arrows of a bow (A12:46); ho‑θèli| Look I have come (A12:66); ho‑də́ryənna gáni ʾup-ʾána gu-mìya| See I threw myself into the water (B15:34).

hodəx adv. beyond; onwards | píðɛle hòdəx| He passed further on (A41:4); xáčča xéna biš-hódəx a little further on (A7:22); xáčča bìš hódəx mənna‑díya| a little further along from them (A12:47); m‑táma hódəx ṱ‑ázət máṭət xa‑nèra| From here onwards is the valley of the ants (A14:50); m‑táma hòdəx| ʾáxtu ʾu-gyanɛ̀xu| From then onwards you are by yourselves (A8:27); ʾána ʾáwwa ʾíle bɛ̀θi| m‑díya hòdəx| This is my house from now on (B5:41); l‑ay‑gōt‑hòdəx t‑šaqíθa| on the farther side of the channel (A9:1); ʾána bi-zóda m-hódəx là-maṣən ʾoðə́nnux| čù məndí| I cannot do anything more for you (A8:44). mod. yonder | m‑támma hódəx ṭùra ʾáθṛə d‑ánna dèwele| From here to yonder mountain is the land of the wolves (A14:48).

hogəčča n.m. (pl. hogəčče) (K.) three-year-old male sheep

hosa n.f. (K.) clamour, commotion | bréla hòsa| Panic broke out (C7:8); músqəlle dáwla-w zòrna-w| hósa ʾu‑gargàrta| They brought him up (with) drum and pipe, and with clamour and shouting (A4:25).

hosta, ʾosta n.m. (pl. hoste, ʾoste) (K./A.) craftsman; master craftsman

hotxa adv. aside | mɛ́θət tə́nna m‑ày‑gota,| ṱ‑ázi dabáše hòtxa| You put smoke on this side and the bees will go aside (B14:13).

huðala n.m. (pl. huðale) stack of bundles (darze) of grass

huðaya n.m./adj. (pl. huðaye) Jew; Jewish

huðayuθa n.f. Judaism

hudxa adv. beyond | ʾána m‑axxa‑húdxa lɛ̀‑y‑azən| I shall not go beyond here (A12:23)

hŭjūm n.m. (A.) attack

humna → mhumna

hurwa → ʾurwa

huta, ḥuta n.m. (pl. hute, ḥuta) whale | ʾáwwa náša hùtɛle| This man (eats like) a whale, he is greedy; šə́mša qəm-băléla ḥùta| a whale has swallowed the sun (i.e. it is eclipsed).

huwedi n.m. type of wheat


/ḥ/

ḥabba n.f. (A.) seed, grain

ḥabbəkθa n.f. (pl. ḥabbəkyaθa) grain, seed; tablet

ḥaddād n.m. (A.) blacksmith

ḥaddād‑xana n.f. blacksmith’s shop

ḥădiqa n.f. (pl. ḥădayəq) (A.) garden

ḥafla n.f. (A.) party

ḥajətta, hajətta, hajət n.f. pretext; tool, instrument | me-zome ṣlela b‑hajjəttət maše She came down from his summer pastures with the excuse of (fetching) black beans (C6:1); jawə́tta ʾíla hájət šùla| The chopper is a work tool.

ḥajj n.m. (A.) pilgrimage

ḥajjiyuθa n.f. pilgrimage | ʾən-lá zɛrǝ́nna Qŭ̀dus,| lɛ̀la qbílta ḥajjiyúθi| If I do not visit Jerusalem, my pilgrimage is not accepted (A2:1).

ḥăkīm, ḥăkima n.m. (K./A.) medical doctor

ḥălāl, hălāl adj. (A.) permitted | háwya halā̀l ṭlálux| Let her be permitted to you (A12:34); ʾu-hoya ḥalalta ṭlala and let it be permitted for her (C1:11).

ḥălăqa n.f. (A.) ring

ḥallaqa n.m. (A.) barber

ḥamās n.m (A.) enthusiasm, zeal

ḥamdani → hamdān

ḥammala n.m. (pl. ḥammale) (A.) porter

ḥammam n.m./f. (pl. ḥammame, ḥammamaθa) (A.) bath, bathroom | ʾaw‑l‑ḥàmmam sáxe| He washes in the bathroom (A21:17)

ḥărām, hărām adj. invar. (A.) forbidden | ḥărā́m‑ile gáwṛa ʾǝ̀lli| šúq mən‑dìyux| Any man is forbidden to me except you (A12:35); n.pl. hăramāt | ʾu‑zílle hăramā̀t| It was sold for nothing (A22:9).

ḥărara n.f. (A.) heat

ḥăras n.m. (A.) guard, watch

ḥarəs n.m. (pl. ḥurrās) (A.) guard

ḥarj n.m. (A.) predicament

ḥars n.m. (A.) guard

ḥasba l‑ʾŭṣūl (A.) according to principles, in order; as usual

ḥaṣəl n.m. (A.) | in phrase wa-l-ḥaṣəl (A.) and in sum.

ḥăšīm adj. invar. (A.) foolish, timid

ḥð̣ira adj. (f. ḥð̣irta, pl. ḥð̣ire) (A.) present, attending

ḥəmaya n.f. (A.) protection

ḥŭdūd n.m. (A.) border

ḥukma n.f. (A.) the government

ḥur adj. invar. (A.) pure | mə́šxa ḥùr| pure butter (B5:31)

ḥurriya, hurriya n.f. (A.) freedom

ḥuta → huta



/j/

jabla n.f. (A.) mud and straw mix acting as cement in the construction of houses

jadda n.m. (pl. jaddane) (A.) road

jăhannam n.m. (A.) hell

jajək n.m. (K./T.) yoghurt mixed with water (dawwe) and the herbs sərmo, hašya, purəpxina or bizər

jăkēt n.m., jăketa n.f. (pl. jăkete, jăketaθa) (E.) jacket
