jalda n.m. (pl. jalde) (A.) stroke (of a stick, whip) | qəm-maxèle| ʾəṣrà-jalde| He struck him ten strokes (A30:14).

jalde adv. (K.) quickly, early | y-awə́ðle jàlde| He does it quickly; lwíša júlle hátxa jálde jàlde| He put on his clothes very quickly (A4:55); šqilíle jal-jàlde| He quickly took them (A15:2); kut‑sámqa jàlde,| šaqlàla| She takes out whichever one (flat bread) is brown soonest (B5:102); kút maṭéwa qamáya jàldəlle| mɛθèwale| Whoever was the quickest and reached it first would bring it back (B5:154); ʾána θéli jàlde| I am early; qedamta jalde early in the morning. m-jalde recently; a long while ago | m-jàldela ʾə́θye They have come recently; ʾáyya lɛ̀wa rába m‑jálde,| bálki ṱ‑àwya| ʾə́mma‑w xámši šə́nne hàtxa| This was not very recently, perhaps it was something like a hundred and fifty years ago (B4:17); ʾaw‑bə́nyɛle m‑jálde ʾatìqa| It was built in very ancient times (B14:2).

jalduθa n.f. speed, quickness | b-jalduθa ‘quickly’

jal-jalde → jalde

jalla nune n.m./f. (pl. jalla nune) fish-eating bird | It has a long beak (naqruza rixa) and comes to the region in winter

jallada n.m. (pl. jallade) (A.) executioner | bába díya hóle mùtta| jallàde| Her father has appointed executioners (A25:32).

jalləkθa n.f. (pl. jalləkyaθa) rabbit trap

jallida n.m. (pl. jallide) (A.) icicle

jalṭa n.f. (A.) stroke, blood clot

jama n.m. (pl. jame) (A.) mosque

jaməkka n.m. (pl. jaməkke) (K.) twin | mḥuṣǝ́lla jamǝ̀kke| She gave birth to twins (A8:6)

jamm n.f. (pl. jammaθa) (A.) glass; green-house

jamme n.f. (K.) twin | xaθa jamme twin sister

jănaza n.f. (A.) coffin; burial | hadíya gáwṛəx píša jănàzɛle| Your husband is now dead (A10:13).

janga n.m./f. (K.) fight, contention | mare janga contentious, difficult person

jaqsi n.m. (pl. jaqsiye) (K.) craftsman | ʾu-síqɛle gu-d-ó sàrga| mtúrṣa l-an-jaqsìye| t-mðìta| He went up onto the saddle, which was made by the town craftsmen (A8:52); sɛ́pe díye … qəm‑nablále kəs-jàqši| She took his sword to a craftsman (A52:11)

jarāḥ n.m. (A.) wound, sore

jareta, jarreta n.f. (pl. jarreyaθa) (A.) food for journey or work, food bag | mattə́nnux jarréta lə́xma zeðàye| I shall provide you with a food-box of pitta breads (A30:5); də‑mjămə́xlən jarrèta| Let us put together a food bag for ourselves (A30:41).

jarge n.pl. (K.) inner organs (lungs, heart etc.) | ʾUsman mxurxile jarge He burnt the viscera of Usman (C7:10)

jarguma n.m. (pl. jargume) type of large dove

jariya n.f. (A.) maid-servant

jarra n.m. (pl. jarre) (K./A.) water jar, pot

jarriθa n.f. small water jar, pot

jaruṭa adj. (f. jaruṭṭa, pl. jaruṭe) slippery

jăwāb, jăwaba, jwaba n.m. (A.) reply; report; message | ṱ-awéləx jăwā́b ʾàti| You will have an answer (A8:74); ʾɛ́-ga xárθa θéle xa-jăwāb qa-màlka| Then, in the end, a report came to the king (A8:5); yíwɛle jăwába ṭla‑yàla| He conveyed a message to the young man (A21:33).

jawda n.m. (pl. jawde) water skin

jawətta n.f. (pl. jawəttaθa) wood chopper

jaxəšta n.f. (pl. jaxəšyaθa) (K.) young female mule

jaxša n.m. (pl. jaxše) (K.) young male mule

jăzira n.f. (A.) island

jeba, jɛba n.m. (pl. jebe, jebane) (A.) pocket

jəlja n.m. (pl. jəlje) slice of meat that is hung in the sun to dry | When such slices dry, they are called qadida and stored in a bag known as mziða.

jənjara, jəngara n.m. (K.) difficulty, hardship | npílewəx gu-jəngàra| We fell on hard times; jənjarət sətwa the hardship of the winter

jənna n.m. (pl. jənne) dirge

jənne n.pl. (K./A.) demons

jərziya n.m. (pl. jərziye) (E.) jersey; sweater

jēš n.m. (A.) army

jiðoqe n.pl. (K.) innards of an animal | eaten as a dish, stuffed and cooked

jigara, jigɛra n.m. (pl. jigare, jigɛre) (A./E.) cigarette

jəngara n.m. (K.) rust

jinika n.m. (pl. jinike) (K.) sideburn, side-whisker

jisəqθa (pl. jisqaθa) → gisəqθa

jmeta n.f. (pl. jmayaθa) gathering (of people)

jnanta n.f. (pl. jnanyaθa, jənne) dirge

jorta n.f. (pl. jore) urine

jubarrək n.f. (pl. jubarrəkke) (K.) mite that eats rice and flour

jŭda adj./adv. invar. (K.) separate | ʾáwwa glās máttule jŭ̀da| Put this glass aside; ʾánna məndiyáne jŭ̀dela| These things are different.

judala n.m. (A.) argument | ʾáni ʾu-qáša Sɛ́rgun wírra b-judàla| These people and the priest Sargun entered into an argument (B1:17).

julla n.m. cloth | hóle də́rya jùlla b-réša| He put a cloth over them (A25:48). julle n.pl. clothes | julle ṭiyariyana Ṭiyare style clothes (festive clothes worn by the groom at a wedding B10:33); kúlley júlle díye y‑áwa nčìle| All his clothes were ragged (B16:10); diya-mɛ́θu júlli malušùla| Now bring my clothes and put them on (me) (A4:20); xamšá-mma bnàθa| kúlla lwíše júllət ʾùrze| five hundred girls, all wearing men’s clothes (A25:76).

jullajena n.m. type of thorny shrub

julləkθa n.f. (pl. julləkyaθa) (K.) pail for milk or yoghurt

jundi n.m. (pl. jundiye) (A.) soldier

jurjēt n.m. (A.) type of velvet fabric | jurjēt zərqəf decorated fabric , jurjēt sada fabric without decorations

jutyara n.m. (pl. jutyare) (K.) farmer

juwala n.m./f. (pl. juwale) (K.) sack | local produce made of goat’s hair (seṛət ʾərwət kome), as opposed to the type of sack know as guniya, which is manufactured outside the villages

juwarre n.f. (pl. juwarriyaθa) (K.) nosebag

juwəlta n.f. (pl. juwəlyaθa) (K.) small sack

juwiθa n.f. (pl. juwiyaθa) (K.) pot that is buried in the ground to make jajək | It is covered with a fig leaf (ṭarpət tena) and a small piece of fabric (čəngərta).

jvoṭa adj. (f. jvoṭṭa, pl. jvoṭṭe) straight | kawsa jvoṭa straight hair (anton. kawsa kərtana curly hair), qɛse jvoṭe straight sticks

jwanna n.m. (jwanne) thorn; thorn tree | Also ʾilanət jwanne thorn tree. The thorns of this are used to make fences. This type of tree is decorated and auctioned at wedding celebrations to raise money for the married couple (B5:39).

jwanqa n.m. adj. (K.) young man; handsome | ʾa-parṣópa díyux hátxa jwànqa| This face of yours, which is so handsome (A8:41)

jwanqona n.m. (pl. jwanqone) young man

jwanquθa n.f. youth

jwina n.m. (pl. jwine) side (in a game, conflict)



/k/

ka- part. while (§19.3.14.) | dáx mṣéle ʾáyya bráta qəm‑ʾawə́dla b‑pəlxánət bɛ̀θa,| ʾu‑ká-t brátət màlka| ʾu‑lípta har‑dmàxa‑w xála| How could he have made this girl a hard-working housewife, while (she is) the daughter of the king and is used to only sleeping and eating (A21:32); mbúrxəllən l-ġðàðe| ka-xóna ʾu-xàθa,| lá ka-gáwṛa-w bàxta| They have wed us together while (we are) brother and sister, and not while (we are) husband and wife (A16:8).

kăbabe n.pl. (K./T.) kebabs

kăčăla adj. (f. kăčăle, pl. kăčăle) (K.) bald

kada n.m. (pl. kade) (K.) sweet pastry (made for festivals) (B6:51)

kăfiyya n.f. (pl. kăfiyyāt) (A.) handkerchief

kaka n.m. (pl. kake) tooth

kakta (pl. kakyaθa) small tooth (of a comb) | kakyaθət masərqa teeth of a carding comb

kalabča n.m. (pl. kalabče) (K./A.) handcuffs

kălăma n.m. (pl. kălăme) (K.) cabbage

kălama n.m./f. (pl. kălame) (K.) long thorn of parzena or jwanna tree | used for building fencing (syaʾa)

kalba n.m. (pl. kalwe, kalbe) dog | kálba brət-kálba dog son of a dog! (A6:12); kálbe bərt-kàlbe| dogs sons of dogs! (A7:15).

kaləbθa n.f. (pl. kaləbyaθa) bitch

kăləma n.f. (A.) word

kalle n.f. (K.) herd | kállət gamèše| a herd of buffaloes (A32:17)

kalləš, kălaša n.m./f. (pl. kălaše) (K.) corpse, carrion

kalo, kyalo, čalo n.f. (pl. kalowaθa) bride; doll

kaluθa n.f. bridehood

kalθa n.f. (pl. kalaθa) daughter-in-law

kămăra n.f. (kămăre) (K.) belt (worn by women)

kămaxa n.m. (pl. kămaxe) (K.) pelvis bone; haunch of an animal

kanaša n.m. (pl. kanaše) sweeper

kanda m. (pl. kande) (K.) cliff, crag, precipice | qaṣrux banyanne l‑kanda I shall build your palace on a cliff top (C3:10)

kanoša n.m. (pl. kanoše) broom

kanošta n.f. (pl. kanošyaθa) small broom, brush

kanun qamaya n.m. December

kanun xaraya n.m. January

kanuna n.m. (pl. kanune) stones used for cooking; fireplace, hearth | This is either open or enclosed by a clay cover to trap the heat. It is located in house or outhouse (ṣopiθa)

kăpăna n.m. (pl. kăpăne) (K.) thick woolen cloak of shepherd

kapora n.m./adj. (pl. kapore) infidel, scoundrel; cruel; awful (weather). 1. infidel, scoundrel | ʾáwwa kapòrɛle.| ʾána ʾəṣrà-jalde məxyə́lli.| He is a scoundrel. He beat me with ten strokes. (A30:15) 2. awful (weather) | ʾɛ́we ʾən-θéla m-la-Zàwa,| ṱ-áθe xa-yóma ṭàwa.| ʾən-ʾɛ́we θéla m-Xawòra,| ṱ-áθe xa-yóma kapòra.| If the clouds come from the side of the Zab (i.e. the East), a good day will come. If the clouds come from the Khabur (i.e. the West), an awful day will come (D2:16).

kār, kɛ̄r n.m./f. (K.) work, effect | ʾíθwa kə́ma gəllále palṭíwa mən‑d‑ò‑rəzza,| qá‑t la‑ʾoðíwa kɛ̄̀r| there were several plants that they took out of the rice, so that they did not have an effect (B5:78)

karafəs n.m. (A.) celery

karawəs n.m. celery

karaxa administrator of water channels (šaqyaθa). He redirected water channels when a field was sufficiently irrigated.

karaxa, karraxa n.m. (pl. karaxe) irrigation adminstrator | He was concerned principally with regulating the flow of water in water channels (šaqyaθa). → karxa

karaxuθa n.f. the profession of irrigation administrator

karba, kɛrba n.m. anger | ʾána-ži m-kɛ́rbi ʾǝ́θyən ʾá-kθɛθa múttənna rəš-núra ʾu-xìlənna| I, out of my anger, came and put the chicken on the fire and ate it (A2:11).

kareza n.m. (pl. kareze) (K.) deep channel for bringing subterranean water to the surface or conducting a spring from the hills to the plain

karma, kɛrma, kyɛrma n.m. (pl. karme, karmane) vineyard; orchard

karoba adj. (f. karobta, pl. karobe) angry (by nature)

karra n.m. (P.) hard butter (brought from towns)

karrəkka n.m. (pl. karrəkke) (K.) sheep shears

karrəkka adj. unripe (mulberry) | tuθe karrəkke unripe mulberries; tuθta karrəkθa an unripe mulberry

karta, kɛrta n.f. (pl. karaθa) (K.) load of wood (tied together with rope) | kút‑yum ʾazáwa l‑ṭúra maθyáwa ða‑kɛ́rta qɛ́sa l‑xáṣa dìya| Everyday she would go to the mountains and bring a load of wood on her back (A10:6); mattúla kàrte| He lays down his load (A15:3).

karxa n.m. (pl. karxe) basin in a paddy field | This word is not generally used in Barwar (where məššara is the normal term for this), but its derivative karaxa irrigation administrator is widely current.

kasa, kyasa n.f. (pl. kasaθa) stomach; belly | naša mare kyasa a plump person

kasa n.m. (pl. kase) chalice

kasana n.m./adj. (pl. kasane) glutton

kasɛθa, kəssɛθa n.f. lid, cover

kašira adj. (f. kaširta, pl. kašire) hard-working

kaska adj. (f. and pl. kaske) (K.) green

kasknaya adj. (f. kasknɛθa, pl. kasknaye) greenish

kasrāt n.pl. (A.) pleats (on clothes)

kašxa n.m. (K./A.) suit, smart clothes | ʾína huðáya lwíša kášxa-w júlle xàθe| Behold the Jew was wearing a smart suit and new clothes (A6:6)

kata n.m. (pl. kate) leaf sprouting on felled tree or severed branch

kătɛra n.m. (pl. kătɛre) middle of the back

k̭avərra n.m. (pl. k̭avərre) (K.) one- to two-year old male sheep

k̭avərta n.f. (pl. k̭avəryaθa) (K.) one- to two-year old female sheep

kawaza n.f. (pl. kawaze) earthenware pot for water | made of green clay

kawda n.f. (pl. kawdaθa) liver

kawe n.f. (pl. kawaθa) small window without glass; small aperture; small hole in the wall of a church in which burning wicks (punde) are placed | ʾíθwa xa‑kàwe| l‑gàre| There was a window in the roof (A10:4); kawət tăra a small hole in a door. In winter the breezes were stopped blowing through such windows in houses by placing a woolen cloth (jullət ʾamṛa) in the hole.

kawədna n.m. (pl. kawədne) male mule

k̭awəlla n.m. (pl. k̭awəlle) (K.) ruin | ma-píštət k̭awə̀lla!| How you have become a ruin! (A16:18).

kawša n.m. (pl. kawše) handle of a plough

kawsa n.m. hair

kawta n.m. (pl. kawte) (K.) flock (of sheep) | xa-káwtət ʾə̀rwe| a flock of sheep (A32:14).

kawuθra n.f. (pl. kawuθre, kawuθraθa) lunch; noon, early afternoon | b‑óma xéna ʾáθeti ṭla‑kawùθra| The day after tomorrow come to lunch (A22:14); kawúθrux brìxta| Good afternoon.

kaža n.m./f. (K.) pine tree

kaθawa n.m. (pl. kaθawe) writer

kaθawta n.f. (pl. kaθawyaθa) writer (f.)

kaθowa n.m. (pl. kaθowe) writer

kčixa adj. (f. kčixta, pl. kčixe) tired

kēk, keka n.m. (pl. keke) (E.) cake

k̭ēm mod. (K.) a few; small (in quantity) (§14.9.5.) | k̭ēm naše a few people; k̭ḕm baxtáθa a few women (B10:22); xa-k̭ḗm y-óði hàtxa| A few do this; gə́lla k̭ḕm hawéwa| Grass was scarce. With the comparative particle biš: bálki bíš‑k̭ēm mən‑ʾəštà‑mma šə́nnela| Perhaps it is less than six-hundred years old (B6:31).

kenapka n.m. (pl. kenapke) (K.) press-stud (to fasten clothes)

kenaya n.m. nature

kepa, kyepa n.m. (pl. kepe) stone | kepət dama backgammon counter; mšáni kèpux!| Move your counter!

kepana n.m. gravel

kepaye n.pl. (sing. kepaya) stuffed sheep’s stomachs

kerapso n.f. edible herb | pungent to the taste, eaten crushed and mixed with red sumac berries (smoqe)

kere n.pl. (sing. kera) (K.) wooden snow shoes

kerova n.m. (K.) snow storm, blizzard

kəzma n.m. (pl. kəzme) wooden prop supporting vine in a vineyard

kežurta n.f. (K.) fine pieces of wood put on roof | Roofs were constructed with several layers in the following order: qaryaθa (large beams), nire/qarše (slats), kežurta (fine wooden pieces), ṭarpa (leaves), jabla (cement), ʾupra (clay), ʾupra xwara (white clay), sərsərra (powdered white clay)

kɛ- part. (inflected with L-suffixes §8.20.4.) where? | kɛ́le? Where is he?; kɛ́lux? Where are you?; kɛ́lən? Where are we? etc. → ʾɛka.

kɛla n.m. (pl. kɛle) measure | b‑ó‑kɛla pɛ́šət kìla| You will be measured by the same measure (A41:6).

kɛlana n.m. (pl. kɛlane) measure

kɛmɛre n.f./adj.. white-striped (name of a nanny goat)

kɛra n.f. (K.) preparedness for a fight | ʾaw-wíðəlla kɛ́re dìye| He prepared himself for a fight (A18:17); wúdla kɛ̀rux!| Be prepared for a fight!

kɛrma → karma

kəčkaje n.pl. (K.) dried fruits (especially dried apples) | These were mainly eaten during Lent

kəčxa n.m. tiredness

kədbək n.m. (E.) kit bag

kēf n.f. (K./A.) pleasure, enjoyment | kèfuxila| It is up to you, do as you please; har-m-kèfəx?| Is that really your wish (B9:13); dáx‑ile kèfux?| How are you doing? (A22:12); ʾáwwa θéle kèfe| He became happy (A22:18); mábsəm ʾu-ṭáre kḕf| He will enjoy himself and have a good time (A2:8); málla múttəlle réše dmìxa,| ṭlìya,| kéfe basìmta| The mullah lay down his head, lay down and slept contented (A6:5); lɛ́la maxrówəlla kèfa| They do not disturb her (A21:9); dawə́qle xmára b‑íðe qa‑t‑lá‑ʾazəl kéfe dìye| He holds the ass by his hand so that it does not walk about freely; mqáwlət goràtle,| t‑yálla jùlla.| ʾən‑là,| har‑t‑yálla júlləx b‑kèfəx| If you promise to marry him, he will give back the clothes. If not, he will still give you the clothes, if you want them (A14:83); klɛ̀!| ʿala-kèfəx!| Wait! calm down! (A4:19).

kəlbəttən n.m. (pl. kəlbəttane) (K./A.) pincers

kəlkăla n.m. (K.) intense heat (of summer)

kəlša n.m. gypsum

kəlya adj. (f. kliθa, pl. kəlye) standing

kəma mod. adv. how many/much? some, several; so much/many; however much, as much as; when; as for (§14.9.9., §19.3.5.) (1) how many? how much? (interrogative) | ʾína kəmà-gaye zíllux ʾu-šqíllux ʾáyya?| How many times have you gone and taken it? (B15:90); ʾawwa ʾaskaríya dìye| ṭlà-kəma dánɛla?| For what time is this army of his for? Used independently: kəmà t-yátli?| How much will you give me? (A24:5). Used predicatively: sáʾət kəmɛ̀la?| The time is how much? (= What time is it?) (A26:27). Adverb: kəmà zonǝ́tle?| For how much will you buy him? (A24:23). (2) some, several | kə́ma gàye| several times (B9:18); y‑oráwa kə́ma yàrxe| Several months passed (B5:18). (3) so much, so many (exclamatory) | ʾána kəmà dána ṱ-in-mṣalóye ṭla-márya ʾàlaha| ta-t-yawə́lli ʾə̀mma dáwe| I was praying to the Lord God so many times to give me a hundred gold coins (A6:10); kəma‑basìmtɛla ʾixála!| The food is so delicious! (A21:31). Adverb: baxtáθa kə́ma zădíwa mən‑xuwwàwe!| The women feared snakes so much! (B5:78). Governing a clause (usually abbreviated to ma): ʾánna ma-ṱ-íla xmíle b-ġðàðe!| How happy they were together! (A4:50); ʾu‑ṭə̀lyela| ma‑t‑wáwa kčìxe| They slept, so tired were they (A14:43). (4) however much, as much as (governing a clause) | kəmə̀t ṱ-árqena| tópe har-ṭapyàli| However much I run, a gun will still reach me (B9:3); xúl kəma‑t-bằyət| Eat as much as you want (B15:56). (5) when | ma‑t‑wéwa brōn‑málka qə́ryəlle ʾo‑kθàwa,| mə́re spày!| When the son of the king had read the letter, he said ‘Good!’ (A11:18). (6) as for | kəmá ṱ-íle Rùstam,| ʾáw mbaqórəlle Tătár-i Slemán-i Sə̀ndi| As for Rustam, he asked for Tătar-i Sleman-i Səndi (A28:24).

kəmkəmma, kərkəmma n.m. (pl. kəmkəmme) large lizard

kəndala n.m (pl. kəndale) (K.) slope | ṣále kəndàla| He goes down the slope (A28:19); táwre masóqəlla b-o-kəndàla| He took the oxen up the slope (A30:9); ṱ-árqən b-o-kəndála hár qaṭlìli| If I run down the slope, they will kill me (B9:4).

kənθa n.f. (pl. kənnane) kidney

kəppa n.m. (pl. kəppe) (K./A.) ankle, anklebone

kəppəkθa n.f. (pl. kəppəkyaθa) (K./A.) arch on the bottom of the foot (between heel and toes)

kepta n.f. (pl. kepyaθa) small stone; bullet. (1) small stone | used to refer to the small stone that is heated in the fire and thrown in the snow as a game played in the celebrations at the end of the winter month of March). (2) bullet, lead head of the bullet cartridge | dréli tópe ʾu-képta la-qìtla| I fired the gun but the bullet did not hit (its mark); keptət pišanga head of the bullet cartridge.

kəpθa n.f. (kəpyaθa) arch on the bottom of the foot (between the heel and toes)

kərkəmma → kəmkəmma

kərkəroka n.m. (K.) adam’s apple, larynx | kərkərokət qðala the adam’s apple of the neck

kərra n.m./adj. (pl. kərre) (K.) sheep or goat with short ears, crop-eared

kərsəlle n.pl. dung of horses asses and mules (sing. kursəlta a piece of dung)

kərtana adj. (f. kərtanta, pl. kərtane) curly | kawsa kərtana (anton. kawsa jvoṭa straight hair).

kərya adj. (f. kriθa, pl. kərye) short

kəs– prep. (with pronominal suffixes: kəsle) at/to the home of (a person); to (object); with; next to. (1) at/to the home/presence of | čídət kəslɛ̀ni| You are invited to our home (A22:14). Frequently after verbs of movement: zílle kəs-màlka| He went to the king (A17:31); xa-yála hóle ʾə́θya táma kəslèy| a young man has come to their home (A17:21); θíθɛla koðə́nta kə̀sli| The mule came up to me (B5:132); ʾáni kə́lye kəs-bɛ̀θa| They all stayed at home (A39:12). (2) to (an object) after verbs of movement | ríqle kəs‑d‑à ʾilána| He ran to the tree (A14:27), qrúla qrúla kə́sle dìye| They came near to it (A14:42). (3) with | dmíxɛle kəs‑báxtət ʿAbda‑Raḥmā̀n‑bēk| He slept with the wife of ʿAbda-Raḥmān-bēk (A23:26). (4) next to, by | múttəlla kəs‑d‑ó Kărim‑addìn| He put it next to Karimaddin (A14:31); mattátla xa‑kawázət míya kəs‑réša‑w bàs| Put out for her a jar of water by her head (A21:7).

kəsənθa n.f. (pl. kəsənyaθa) (A.) jewel; treasure | max-kəsə́nθət dàwhɛla| She is like a golden jewel.

kəskənna n.m. yellow flower

kəsna n.m. (pl. kəsne) (A.) jewel; treasure

kəssɛθa → kasɛθa

kəštəvana n.m. (pl. kəštəvane) (K.) cross piece of wood in the frame of a bed (taxta) made of willow (xorta)

k̭ətta n.f. (pl. k̭ətte, k̭əttaθa) (K.) odd number | zawge ʾu-k̭ətte even and odd numbers. mod. odd | k̭ətte dukane in the odd place, in a few places; kúṱ-ila k̭ə́tte k̭ə́tte laqṭə̀tla| Whatever is separate (fruits) you pick.

kətwa bloka n.m. type of herb

kətwa n.m. (pl. kətwe) spike, thorn

kətwana adj. (f. kətwanta, pl. kətwane) spiky; thorny | gəlla kətwana thorny plant

kəxla n.m. kohl (for eyes)

kəxra n.m. grass fodder for animals

kəxwa n.m., kxuθa n.f. (pl. kəxwe) star | kǝ́xwət gu‑mbadlàθa| dawn star (A12:15). Mark on animal: ʾu-xá kə́xwa gu-be-ʾɛ́ne díye kòma| with a black star on its forehead (A8:62); xá‑ð̣abəṭ ʾəngləznáya ṱ‑ítwale ṭḷà kə́xwe| An English officer who had two stars (i.e. a captain) (B17:12); kxuθa goat with white mark on head.

kədde n.pl. (sing. kədda) snow shoes

kilo n.m. (pl. kiloye, kiloʾe) kilo

kilon n.f. (pl. kilone) (K.) metal lock (of a door)

kima, čima n.f. the Pleiades (constellation) | mbáqər kíma-w gabbàre| ask the Pleiades and Orion (A38:12); ṱ-asqa čima-w gabbare Pleiades and Orion will rise (C2:3).

kisa n.m. (pl. kise) large bag

kista n.f. (pl. kisyaθa) small bag

kiwara, kiwɛra n.m. thorny plant

kiyola n.m. (pl. kiyole) measure, quantity

kizəkka n.m. (pl. kizəkke) (K.) spark | b‑lɛ́le rúmxe díye hóla mxáya kizǝ̀kke| In the night his spear was giving off sparks (A12:9).

kizikizo n.f. edible herb

klama n.m. (pl. klame) wooden collar of ox; sacking tied over mouth of ox to prevent it from eating corn during threshing (dwara)

kliča adj. (f. kličta, pl. kliče) stripped, peeled; excoriated | šaqòla| kúlle klìča| a shank completely stripped of its meat (A30:30); ʾáyya dúkθe díye hátxa klíčta This part of him was scratched (B9:25).

klila n.m. (pl. klila) crown, coronet; coronet decorations on clothes | ma-yəmmux ʾazla klile Oh your mother spins crowns (A50:15)

kliθa n.f. (pl. kilyaθa) kidney

klōš n.m. wide skirt

kništa n.f. (pl. knišyaθa) synagogue

koč̭a, qoč̭a n.m./adj. (f. and pl. koč̭e) (K.) hornless (goat/sheep); type of wheat without hairs (dasiye)

kočari (pl. k̭očariye) (K.) nomadic pastoralist | They would take sheep and goats up to the summer pastures (zomăwaθa) in the summer and bring them down to the plains (dastaθa) in the winter.

kočarnaya n.m/adj. (pl. kočarnaye) (K.) nomad | kočɛrnáyət qurðàye| nomadic Kurds (B18:1)

koðənta n.f. (pl. koðənyaθa) female mule

koḥol n.m. (A./E.) alcohol

koləkθa n.f. (pl. koləkyaθa) (K.) chicken coop; wooden chamber of a patridge trap buried in the ground; shooting hut (used when hunting patridges)

koma adj. (f. komta, pl. kome) black | xáʾa lwíša kòma| somebody dressed in black (A12:5).

komaya n.m. negro

komnaya adj. (f. komnɛθa, pl. komnaye) blackish

kompaθuθa n.f. disgrace

kopa adj. (f. kopta, pl. kope) low | ʾəθyewəx kope kope qam‑məṭra ʾu‑qam dalope We have come bending down in rain and drizzle (C1:14). adv. below | náše ʾíwa kòpa| kùlla,| ʾu‑ʾáwwa gárewa ràma| The people were all below and he (the groom) was high up on the roof (B5:42)

kopana adj. (f. kopanta, pl. kopane) low

korašina n.m. wild plant

kore n.f. (pl. korăwaθa) (K.) hole (in the ground) | This is narrower than a čale. Cheese and jajək are buried in a kore. gðaltət kore, ṭawaltət kore wrestling of the hole, game of the hole. One of the wrestlers has a foot in a hole. If the opponent pushes him over and his foot comes out of the hole, he loses the game.

kosa adj. (pl. kose) beardless, immature | ʾən-lá doqə́tle də́qnux b-ìðux,| la-ʾámrət qa-xáwrux kòsa| If you cannot hold your own beard in your hand, do not call your friend beardless (D2:54).

kosiθa n.f. (pl. kosyaθa) hat (worn by men) | kosiθət parre hat with feathers

kosta n.f. (pl. kosyaθa) (K.) pen for young lambs in basement stable

kotăla m. (pl. kotăla) (K.) raised tank attached to a water-mill which fills with water from a channel and releases water flow at a high pressure to drive the mill. | This structure was necessary when the water did not come from a natural height and did not have natural pressure.

koxa n.m. (pl. koxe) (K.) hut

koza n.m. (pl. koze, kozăwaθa) (K.) sheltered place for pasturing in inclement weather in Winter and Spring

krehət, krēt adj. cs. (pl. krehətte, krete) (K./A.) bad | ʾƎ́šwuṭ rába krḕt‑iwa gu‑ʾàθṛa| (The month of) February was very bad in our land (B5:152); ʾap‑ʾƎ̀šwuṭ krèhət y‑áwe| (The month of) February is also bad (B5:197).

krēt → krehət

krəstyana n.m./adj. (pl. krəstyane) Christian

kriba adj. (f. kribta, pl. kribe) angry

krihe n.pl. (C.Syr.) suffering ones | rúšma t‑krìhe| the sign of the suffering ones (made to an infant at baptism) (B6:36)

ktana n.m. cotton

kuba n.m. (pl. kube) (A.) cup | kúbə čáy tea cups (A32:24)

kubbe n.pl. (sing. kubba) (A.) meat-balls

kuddina n.m. (pl. kuddine) (K.) cub (of animal)

kuddinta n.f. (pl. kuddinyaθa) (K.) female cub

kul, ku, kulla mod. every; all, all of (§14.9.2.). (1) every | kúl‑naša every person (B6:35); kúl‑məndi everything (B10:64); kúl‑xa suràya every Christian (B6:1); ku‑bɛ́θa every house (B7:7); kul-náše tre-ṭḷá-yomane šatìwa| Everybody would drink and eat for two or three days (B15:64). (2) all, all of | kúlla náše all the people (B10:88); míye díye kúlla all its water (B6:42); ʾáni kùlla all of them (B7:17); kúlla tunìθa all of the story (A29:12); kúlla Bɛ̀rwər all of Barwar (B10:100); ʾo‑bɛ́θa kúlla all of that family (B5:21); ʾixála kúlle all of the food (B6:5). Used independently: zadáwale kúlla m‑gàre| They throw all of it (the snow) from the room (B5:195); kúlla mṭéla tàma| They all arrived there (B2:8); l‑kúlla d‑ày| overall, in general (B5:115).

kuleča n.m. (pl. kuleče) (K.) small cake (made at festivals) (B6:52)

kulənga n.m. (pl. kulənge) (K.) pickaxe

kulfət, kulpət n.f. (pl. kulfatte, kulpatte) (K./A.) family; wife | ʾu‑náše xamɛ́wa kúlla kúlfət m‑ġðàðe| All the family lived together (B5:200); kulpət xətna the family of the groom; kulpatti my family, my wife; kúl kúlfət y‑azáwa l‑míθe dìye| Every family went to his (the head of the family’s) dead (B5:57).

kulla n.f. (A.) mosquito net

kullixa n.m. (pl. kullixe) (K.) hut

kulliya n.m. (pl. kulliye) (K.) head of maize (xəṭṭe romaye, xəṭṭe šemaye)

kumuθa n.f. blackness

kun part. deontic particle | kun ʾaθya t‑la xoraθa I hope she will come without her friends (C2:16)

kundarəs, kundɛrəs n.f. chain stitch

k̭unnəkθa n.f. (pl. k̭unnəkyaθa) (K.) woman’s headscarf

kupala n.f. (pl. kupale) (K.) shepherd’s stick; walking stick | ʾína kupáli píšla šmìṭṭa| My stick has broken (A37:17).

k̭uprana, quprana n.f. (pl. k̭upranane, qupranane) (K.) booth, wooden trellis affording cover | This stands separately in a field or is built over the roof of a porch (gariθət ṣopiθa)

kura n.m. (pl. kure) furnace, kiln

kuraxa n.m. (pl. kuraxe) shroud

kuraza n.m. (pl. kuraze) sermon, preaching

kurdaya → qurðaya

kurdəθ → qurdəθ

kurənja n.m. (pl. kurənje) (K.) long stick used for carding flax or wool

kurize n.pl. a type of millet (prage) that ripens slowly | prage kurize

kurra n.m. (pl. kurre) (K.) foal

kursa n.m. (pl. kursăwaθa) chair | málla hóle tíwa gu-kúrsa ṭlìle| The mullah sat in a chair and fell asleep (A2:3); kúrsət ṭaləbùθa| the betrothal chair (A32:11)

kursiya n.m. (pl. kursiye) chair

kurta n.m. (pl. kurte) (K.)vulture

kurtəxta n.f. (pl. kurtəxyaθa) lower back, pelvis | kupəšlux ʾəlli kurtəxyaθa You have gathered to me pelvises (of women) (A52:26).

kuša m. (pl. kuše) spindle | This hangs and pulls wool from the distaff (xarnɛsa). The wool is moistened. A large spindle (kuša goṛa) is used for making wool and a smalll spindle (kuša zora) for making thin threads. ʾazla-kuše dragonfly (spinner of spindles, so-called because it rotates around water)

kuspa dəbbe n.m. plant with large leaves | used for wrapping the filling of dolma

kuššət adv. every year

kut mod. each, every; whoever (§14.9.1.) (1) each, every | kut-yàrxa| each month (A24:5); kut‑ṭéna each load (B5:181); kút‑xa y‑azə́lwa bɛ̄θ‑dìye| Every person went to his home (B5:18); zonə́xwa kút‑xa xà| We would each buy one (B10:76); kút kəma‑šə̀nne| every few years (B10:59); kut-yom every day; kuššət (< kut-šat) every year. (2) whoever | kút mɛ̀θela| t-yánne zúze ràba| Whoever brings her, I shall give him a lot of money (A27:18).

kutəlθa f. (pl. kutlaθa) cutlet | kutlaθət bəsra meat cutlets, kutlaθət rəzza, kutlaθət gurgur, kutlaθət gəllale.

kutto name of spring in Ɛn Nune | There are two springs in Ɛn Nune, the other being ʾɛnət ʾumra near the church

kuvəkka n.m. (pl. kuvəkke) (K.) funnel

kuvi adj. invar. (K.) wild; shy (of company) | ʾaw‑yalúnka zòra| kùvi‑wewa| The young child was shy (B17:3).

kuza n.m. edible red herb

kwara, kwɛra n.m. (pl. kware, kwɛre) storage bin for corn | consisting of willow branches (xelape) covered with clay. It has a hole (ʾɛnta), plugged with a cloth, from which the wheat is taken.

kxila adj. (f. kxilta, pl. kxile) blackened with kohl

kxuθa → kəxwa

kyɛr → čara

kθawa n.m. (pl. kθawe) book; letter

kθawta n.f. writing

kθɛθa n.f. (pl. kθayaθa, kθaye) chicken | kθɛθət miya n.f. moorhen


/k̭/

k̭ăbani n.f. (pl. k̭ăbaniye) (K.) housewife, cook (woman) | k̭ăbanət bɛθa housekeeper, woman in charge of house

k̭ačune part. at least | k̭ačúne xá-gaya b-yárxa hàyyo| Come at least once a month.

k̭appurta n.f. (pl. k̭appuryaθa) (K.) waistcoat (worn by women)

k̭arra adj. (f. k̭arre, pl. k̭arre) (K.) deaf

k̭ašk̭a n.m. (K.) (§1.2.2.) wheat with husks

k̭awčo n.f. (pl. k̭awče) (K.) ladle | This is used for serving butter (məšxa) on the dish known as gərðo. It is deeper than the spoon known as barxošta.

k̭ɛw-, k̭aw- part. (combined with pronominal suffixes §8.20.3.) deontic particle | k̭ɛ́we May he be; k̭ɛ́wa May she be, etc.; k̭ɛ́wux làxxa| You stay here; k̭áwa ṭla-d-àni| May they get (what they deserve) (A15:18); ʾánna k̭áwa xàmmi| Let them be my concern (A29:61).

k̭əčče n.f. (pl. k̭əčyaθa) (K.) girl

k̭əččonta n.f. (pl. k̭əččonyaθa) little girl

k̭ərməkθa n.f. (pl. k̭ərməkyaθa, k̭ərme) worm

k̭olana n.m. (pl. k̭olane) (K.) road

k̭oma n.m. (pl. k̭ome) (K.) pile

k̭ora adj. (f. k̭ore, pl. k̭ore) (K.) blind | Dáwəð k̭òra| blind David (A16:2); ʾɛ́ne díye wíðəlla k̭òre| He made his eye blind (A16:2); ʾáp‑ʾana dàqrən| ʾax‑déwa k̭òra| I am worth the same as a blind wolf (A10:1); Idioms: k̭óre ʾàna| May I (f.) be blind (= Oh woe to me, poor me!) (A18:25); k̭óre brátət k̭òre| poor girl (literally: blind girl, daughter of a blind girl) (A52:5); má-lux k̭óra Xarə̀pša?| What is the matter with you poor soul, Xarəpša? (A31:9).

k̭otəl n.m. (K.) meat pasty | k̭ótəl dàwke pasty with yoghurt (B7:23)

k̭učke n.f. (K.) hearth; living room | mur-ṭla-Zìne| k̭účke mtagəbràla| Go down and tell Zine to prepare the living room (A26:46).

k̭ulčiva n.m. (pl. k̭ulčive) (K.) trigger for an animal trap | piece of wood holding the trap open

k̭ura n.m. (pl. k̭ure) (K.) two- to three-year old male goat

k̭urra n.m. (pl. k̭urre) boy | k̭urra xamra la-štile Boy, do not drink the wine (C2:10)

k̭wina n.m. (pl. k̭wine) (K.) tent | made of goat’s hair, used by bedouin Arabs (cf. čadra tent made of fabric): mə́xyela k̭winày| They pitched their tents (A29:40).



/l/

l- prep. (with pronominal suffixes: le, ʾəlle) (§13.3.12., §16.2.) to, for, upon, at, by: Admominal uses (1) Destination: si-dúṛ l-šòpux| Go back to your place (A15:20). (2) Objective without movement: ʾálaha šuxa-l-šə́mme God—praise be to his name (A6:10). (3) upon: hóle tíwa l-kèpa| He is sitting on a stone (A15:13); occasionally with the form ʾal-: ʾal‑ʾằra| on the ground (A21:5). (4) General spatial location: hóle ʾàrya| l-àyya góta| ʾu-ʾǝ̀zza| hóla l-àyya góta| There is lion on this side and a she-goat on the other side (A24:15); hóla spára l-kàwe| They are waiting at the window (A4:59). (5) Expression of the agent: šáwwaθna hóla xíle l‑dèwa| The seven of them have been eaten by wolves (A23:15). (6) Combined with other prepositions: ʾo-gáya qằmɛθa θélux l-kǝ́sli| The first time you came to me (A1:22). Use of l- + pronominal suffixes: (1) Inflection of past verbal base: qṭille He killed (him), zille He went. (2) Direct and indirect object: qaṭəlle He kills him; hawəlle He gives to him. (3) Possession: ʾitli kθawa I have a book. Use of ʾəll- + pronominal suffix: (1) Destination: ʾə́θyela mə́ṭye ʾə̀lle| They came up to him (A7:19); (2) Direction (without movement), beneficiary: ʾámər ʾə́lla dìya| He says to her (A16:7); wídla fṭárta ʾə̀lli| She made me breakfast (A21:38). (3) on (surface): mattí ʾíða ʾə̀lle| They place a hand on it (B5:100); qímle murə́sle hátxa míya ʾəllèy| He sprinkled water on them like this (B6:11). (4) over (abstract relation): hótu pšàma ʾə́lla díya| You are sad over it (A5:10). (5) direct object (bound to verb): múttətəlle You put him (A22:39); prìmənəlla I cut it (f.) (A22:9).

la n.f. (K.) side, direction | ṣə̀lyela| swánət ʾúmra la‑qámθa díya ràmta‑wawa| They (the sheep) went down over the eaves of the church, the front side of which was high (B18:6). Used mainly in adverbial expressions: la-qáma forwards; la-bára backwards; kú mənná ṱ‑íle pláṭa mən‑gawàye,| pláṭa la‑qam‑tằra| Each one who goes out from inside, going towards the outside (B11:8); y-azíwa la-zràqət yóma| They would go in the direction of the rising of the sun (A8:22); hóle ʾə́θya Déwa Zàr| … m-la-gnay-yòma| Dewa Zar has come … from the West (A28:14); ʾɛ́we ʾən-θéla m-la-Zàwa,| ṱ‑áθe xa-yóma ṭàwa| If the clouds come from the side of the Zab (i.e. the East), a good day will come (D2:16); hola θela m‑la‑Maye Look she has come from the direction of Maye (C2:46).

la part. no (variants laʾ, laʾa), not; neither/nor; asseverative particle. (1) no | mə́ra là| ʾáti ṣli-be-màlka| They said ‘No, you go down to the house of the king’ (A25:87); mə́re bráti lá là!| He said ‘My daughter, no, no!’ (A21:30); mǝ́re làʾ!| He said ‘No!’ (A1:6); ʾámər làʾa!| He says ‘No!’ (A21:42). (2) not | la‑ṣábrəx ṱ‑òrəx| We do not dare enter (A14:40); lə́mu la-qìmlux?| Why did you not stand? (A26:48); bróni là qəṭlúle!| Do not kill my son! (A33:6); ʾána lɛ̀‑gorən,| la-ʾàti gáwrət| I shall not marry, so long as you do not marry (A25:83); ʾáni maṣlə́xwa ʾə̀rxe,| ṭaxnə̀xwala,| là kúlla náše| bas‑ʾàxni| ‘We brought them down to the water-mill and ground them, not everybody, but we did (this) (B10:88). Negating an adjective: fə́lfəl … là-xšilta uncrushed pepper (B10:21). (3) la … la neither … nor | ʾána làn dmíxa,| là-b-lele,| là-b-yoma| I have not slept, neither at night nor during the day (A24:24); ʾána lànwa wíða| là xarbayúθa| là spayúθa ṭla‑čú‑naša| I have done neither evil nor good to anybody (A14:23); lá-băyəx la-mìya| ʾu-la-čù-məndi| We want neither water nor anything else (A39:12). (4) asseverative particle | la-hóle mìθa| He is indeed dead (A17:2); A: štélux čàyux?| B: la-štèli! A: Have you drunk your tea? B: Indeed I have drunk it!

lablabi n.m (A.) hyacynth bean

lagăna n.m. (pl. lagăne) brass container for food | séra píšle lagằna| The moon is full.

lagna n.m./f. (pl. lagne) thorny plant | blue in colour, producing seeds known as ṣəṣṣe in thorny pods (bubre, bar-xoxe), both the seeds and the root being edible.

lala adj. (f. and pl. lale) (K.) dumb

lama n.m. (pl. lame) lower jaw

laməkka n.m. (pl. laməkke) jaw of an animal

laməkθa n.f. (pl. laməkyaθa) jaw (of an animal)

lampa n.m. (pl. lampe) (E.) lamp | lámpət gúda … lámpət ʾìða| wall lamp … hand lamp (B10:83)

lana n.m. (A.) tune | ku‑zmarta lana gana Every song (has) a tune of its own (C1:13)

lappa n.m. (pl. lappape) palm (of hand), sole (of foot). (pl. lappe) wave

lappəkθa n.f. (pl. lappəkyaθa) paw (of small animal); foot/hand of small child

laqləq n.m. (pl. laqlaqe) (A.) stork

laqqa n.m. (pl. laqqe) bite | kálba mxéle láqqa bìyi| The dog snapped at me.

laqṭa n.m. bird feed of grains

lašša n.f. (pl. laššaθa) (K.) corpse, carcass (which is cut up) (gušma = body of living person, animal)

lastike n.pl. (sing. lastikta) rubber shoes

lata (i) n.f. (pl. lataθa) (mountain) path; furrow | síqli b‑áyya làta| I went up on this path; šəmša mxela gu-lata The sun has shone on the mountain path (C1:23); mxéle latàθa He made furrows (with a plough to mark the outline of the ploughing area) → lena

lata (ii) n.f. pl. (lataθa) flame

laṭṭa adj. (f. and pl. laṭṭe) (K.) shallow; flat | qəm-dɛrɛ́tuli ðá-duka làṭṭe| You threw me into a shallow place (A7:22); dréle ʾixála qa‑ṱ‑àxəl| gu‑ʾamána làṭṭa| He served food for him to eat in a shallow vessel (A45:1).

lăvăna n.m. (pl. lăvăne) (K.) cane pipe | used to convey steam to a condenser in the distilling of arak.

law part. conditional particle (A.) | only used in concessive constructions: wắ‑law ṱ‑ín ʾanna‑xámša šǝ́nne zíla b‑dùnye,| nǝ́mu lat‑ðàʾəlli?| Although I have been away in the world for these five years, do you not know me any more? (A12:65)

lawandiye n.pl. long sleeves

lawaša n.m. (pl. lawaše) large thin bread baked in an oven

lăwaza n.m. (pl. lăwaze) tune, music

lawlaba n.m. (pl. lawlabe) (K.) wooden stick at the two ends of the frame carrying the churn (guða); trigger of gun | l-ʾiðe drele lawlaba He put his hand on the trigger (C7:11)

lawn n.f. (ʾalwān) (A.) colour

lawora n.m. (pl. lawore) valley

lawurta n.f. (pl. lawuryaθa) small valley

lawusta n.f. (pl. lawusyaθa) jaw

laxoma adj. (f. laxomta, pl. laxome) pleasant, handsome; fitting | ṭla d‑aw dosta laxoma for that handsome friend of hers (C2:75)

laxxa adv. here | hóla làxxa| They are here (A14:100); mút ʾáti tíwta làxxa?| Why are you sitting here? (A25:58); háyyo làxxa!| Come here! (A13:6); ʾáyya xá-šeta hóla támma láxxa lɛ́la mbaqorə̀llux| It has been a year that they have been here without asking for you (A26:78).

laxxane adv. here, hereabouts | mắnile mǝ́ṣya zədyəlléy laxxàne?| Who could have thrown them here? (A8:15)

ḷaya → ʾəḷḷaya

layosa n.m. (pl. layose) jaw

lazəm part. (A.) particle expressing necessity (deontic and epistemic) | Deontic: lázəm ʾaxlə̀nne| I must eat him (A47:5). Epistemic: ʾánna madám-ṱ‑ila ʾátxa jwánqe w-átxa tàze,| lázəm ʾaw-xǝ́lmi pàləṭ| If they are so beautiful and so fine, that dream of mine must come true (A7:7); ʾu-xa-mašmóye‑wewa ʾəllɛ̀ni lázəm| Somebody must have been listening to us (A35:19).

lă-ʿamri interj. (A.) by my life, indeed

lăʿat part. (A.) so, in that case

leba n.m. (pl. lebe) trick, prank | záwnət lèbewa| It was the time of tricks (A1:24); lá‑băye ṱ‑awə́ðwa lèbe| He did not want to play tricks (A29:36).

lebana adj. (f. lebanta, pl. lebane) tricky | záwna lebàna-wewa| … wélux lebána ʾàx-zawna| The time was tricky … You became tricky like the time (A1:22).

lena n.m. (pl. lenane) furrow made by plough used as outline marks to guide the ploughing | mxaya lenane, draya lenane to mark furrows → lata

leta n.f. (pl. letaθa) ridge on a mountain side | letət kɛrma terraced vineyard built on mountain side

lɛle (past lɛwa) negative copula | ʾáwwa lɛ̀le kálba| He is not a dog (A11:20); lɛ̀wa yómət šábθa| It was not Saturday (A14:58). Used as tag in conversation to seek confirmation: ʾu-b-xšáwən mjárbət mɛθə́tle lɛ̀la?| I think you will try to bring her, is that not so? (A8:36).

lɛle n.m. (pl. lɛlăwaθa) night | pɛšíwa xá‑lɛle trè| They stayed for a night or two (B5:234); ʾɛ́-ga b-lɛ́le tíwəx kəs-xáli d-àni| That night we sat with my uncle and his family (B15:57); wítɛla b-lɛ̀le| maláxa mŭṛə́šle qa-ràbbǝn| In the night (literally: It became in the night) the angel woke the monk (A15:11); píšla b-lɛ̀le,| sìqɛle| l-gàre.| In the night (literally: It became in the night), he went up onto the roof (A25:52); mə́dre ʾi‑zamŕwa‑w šatɛ̀wa| hál y‑oráwa gu‑lɛ̀le| They again sang and drank until it was night (literally: until it passed into night) (B5:18); m-lɛle early morning, before dawn; ʾədlɛle tonight.

lɛša n.m. dough | ʾíman‑t qámxa lɛšíle lɛ̀ša| when they knead flour into a dough (B6:45)

ləbba n.m. (pl. ləbbe) heart; kernel of fruit or berry | Idioms: yawa ləbba l- to console (after death), to encourage: híwɛle lə́bba ṭla-gyáne dìye| He took heart (A8:58). ləbbi zille l‑d‑ɛ qumta I fainted at the sight of that figure (C2:55). bəd‑lə́bba gu‑bɛ́θət bába dìyɛla| She thinks that she is in her father’s house (A21:18). gu-lə́bbe díye mtuxmə̀nne| I thought to himself (A39:5). lə́bbe biyáxu tlìqetu| He thinks you are lost (A14:85). dwiqále b‑lə̀bbe| He kept it in mind. ʾáyya quṣárta ràba šapirta,| rába zála ləbbì-ʾəlla| This cooking pot is very nice, I like it a lot (A5:2); hóle zála lə̀bbi| ṱ-ásqət ṣɛ́dət ʾə́rbət wàla| I would like you to go up and hunt for wild sheep (A26:44). lə́bbi basìma| I am happy. ʾáwwa náša lə́bbe pqìle| The heart of that burst (= He was terrified) (A32:2). qìdle lə́bbi,| xóni zòra-wewa| My heart yearned (for him), he was my young brother (A34:24); mən-lə́bbe díye qìða,| dɛ́re xɛ̀la,| načə̀lle ʾo-šəryóxa| Out of his fervour, he applied force and pulled the tether apart (A28:20). xílli lə̀bbux| My dear, you are dear to me (A39:12). ʾána hóle píša lə̀bbi| I am angry. t‑la‑páyəš lə́bbən b‑ġðàðe| so that we do not feel anger at each other (B5:10); ṭḷàθna| xonăwáθət Qára Tèždin| mopíšəlle ləbbèy| The three brothers of Qara Teždin became angry (A26:71). ʾánna píšla gu-lə́bbe díye kùlla| All these (words) weighed on his heart (A38:13). ʾáyya lɛ̀ða,| lə́bba ṣə̀pya žáre| She did not know, she was innocent, poor thing (A14:99). hátxa baṣlóṣe gu-lǝ́bbət nàša| (They) glow in the heart of man (= they captivate one’s heart) (A8:16). m-kúlla lə́bbi bắyən ʾána qaṭlìtuli| With all my heart I want you to kill me (B9:14).

ləbbana adj. (f. ləbbanta, pl. ləbbane) brave, courageous | kálba gu-tắrət màre| ləbbàna y-áwe| A dog at the door of his owner is brave (D2:64)

ləbna n.m. (pl. ləbne) mud brick

ləhefa n.m. (pl. ləhefe) (K./A.) duvet

ləmu → nəmu

lənga adj. (f. and pl. lənge) (K.) crippled in the leg; lame

ləngo adv. (K.) limping | xáθi θèli| ʾítle ṭḷáθa ʾaqlàθa,| lə́ngo lə̀ngo| hal-tàmma| Sister, I came here, while it (my horse) had three legs, limping up to here (A18:20).

ləva n.f. (K.) lamb’s wool

ləxma n.m. (pl. ləxme) bread; loaf of bread | lə́xma šaxína daṛmánət náša kpìna| Hot bread is the medicine of a hungry man (D2:69). šáqla xa‑lǝ̀xma| She would buy a loaf of bread (A10:6); ʾína xáze ʾə́sri ʾə́č̣č̣a lə̀xme| He saw that there were twenty-nine loaves of bread (A17:12); lə́xmən xaràmile| Our bread is outlawed (i.e. we are unpopular); ləxmət maθ-Maryam, ləxmət maθ-Maryam St. Mary’s bread (name of herb).

ləxxawa n.m. (pl. ləxxawe) bit (of horse), harness

ləʾannahu part. (A.) because

lifəkka n.m. (pl. lifəkke) (K.) flannel

limandus n.f. lemon juice

lina n.m. (pl. line) large conical-shaped pot

linta n.f. (pl. linyaθa) small conical-shaped pot (for water)

lipa adj. (f. lipta, pl. lipe) learned, educated | náše lípe learned people (A8:35)

lišana n.m. (pl. lišane) tongue; language | lišana ʾarabaya the Arabic language; qəm-maxɛ́le lišanèy| They licked him (A18:31); npílle lišána b-sɛ̀pa| The sword started to talk (A52:22).

liθ part. (variants: liθən, liθena, liθga, liθgən, liθgena. past: liθwa) negative existential particle (§8.20.1., §15.3.8., §17.3.) (1) Used without suffixes | líθ čù‑məndi| There is nothing (A21:5); líθ ʾáp‑xa gu‑bɛ̀θa?| Is there nobody in the house? (A22:32); čú-qala líθən mənnèy| There is no sound of them (A18:15); ʾɛ́-ga líθwa bǝ̀rqa| At that time there was not electricity (B10:45); líθwa qá‑t mbaqríwa bràta| It was not the practice to ask the girl (B5:2). Used interrogatively to draw attention to a particular point: ʾo‑šúla ʾáwwa y‑amrə́xwale qə̀rṭa líθən?| We called this job trimming, you see (B5:141). (2) With L-suffixes expressing possession: ʾána zúza lìtli| I do not have money. (A22:19); lítle la-bába la-yə́mma la-ʾàp-xa| He does not have a father, a mother or anybody (A17:17); lìθwale quṣə̀rta| He did not have a cooking-pot (A5:1); lítla xàm| That’s fine, no problem.

lo part. or, either | Zìne nábləx kəs-Mắmo| lo-Mằmo nábləx kəs-Zíne?| Should we take Zine to Mămo or Mămo to Zine? (A26:2); xázəx mhayríli lo-làʾa| Let us see whether they will help me or not (A48:2); lo-ṱ-axláli dǝ̀bba| lo-palṭèna| Either the bear will eat me or I shall get out (A20:11).

lok̭anta n.f. (pl. lok̭anyaθa) (T.) restaurant

lota n.f. (pl. loyaθa, lotaθa) cheek; chewing gum

lubya n.m. (pl. lubye) bean growing in pods (šənqe)

lujna n.f. (A.) committee

lula → nula

lulta → nulta

lutka n.f. (pl. lutke) boat

luwwəš n.m. edible herb | used to make dolma

lwišta n.f. (pl. lwišyaθa) clothing

l‑xərxəθ → xərxəθ

lxima adj. (f. lximta, pl. lxime) fit; well built | xzi-kəmɛ́le lxìma!| Look how fit he is! (A15:13)



/m/

ma part. pron. what? (§7.5., §14.9.13.)| xúwwe mà ṱ-áwəð b-an-álpa dáwe?| What will the snake do with those thousand gold coins? (A1:8); xáθi mà-ləx?| Sister, what is the matter with you? (A34:12); mà‑lux zə́dya?| Why are you afraid? (A11:6); má-lux mə́nne ʾàti?| What business is it of yours? (A32:3); ʾána má-li mə̀nnux?| What have I to do with you? (A32:22); má-ləx bráta ṱ‑it‑hátxa bxàya| What is the matter with you girl that you are weeping so much? (A34:20); sállət míya yắðət mɛ̀la?| (< mà-ila) Do you know what a basket of water is? (A16:10). Modifier of a noun: ʾánna ma‑brinànela gu‑réšux| What wounds are these on your head? (A29:6). Exclamatory modifier of a noun: ʾu-Bə́lbəl Hazár yăðátla ma-báxta xàmθɛla| You know what a beautiful woman Bəlbəl Hazar is (A8:65). Expressing an exclamatory proposition: ma-píštət k̭awə̀lla!| How you have become a ruin! (A18:16). With remonstrating force in negated questions ma-lat-ðáya b-gánəx qàrθɛla?| Don’t you know yourself that it is cold?! (A20:1). Before imperatives: ma-yəmmi pɛli zwaðe Mother, bake me supplies! (A50:9). Before a repeated noun to express a more general class (§14.11.): jawə́tta ṭla‑pràma| ʾanna qɛ́se ma‑qɛ̀se| A chopper was for chopping wood and the like (B5:141).

madala n.m. (pl. madale) millipede

madam part. if, so long as | introduces factual conditions (§19.5.7.): mádam hàtxɛla| ṱ-ázən ṭắyən báθər ḥaqqùθa| ʾu-na-ḥaqqùθa| If (the world) is like that, I shall go and search for what is lawful and what is unlawful (A15:5).

madanus n.m. (K.) parsley

maðbəḥ n.f. (A.) altar

madəbxa n.m. altar

madənxa n.m. East; sunrise | jálde qam-mxɛ́θət madə̀nxa| early before sunrise (A8:51); qímɛle jálde madə́nxa t-la-mxàya| He rose early while the dawn was not breaking (= before dawn broke) (A8:51); txúme díye ʾìla| mən-madə̀nxa| Zàwa,| ʾu-mən-màrwa| ʾìla| Xawòra| Its borders are, on the East, the Zab and, on the West, the Khabur (B1:4).

madfaʿ n.m. (A.) artillery

mað̣ira n.m. dish made of dawwe and rice

magəlta n.f. (pl. magəlyaθa) small sickle

magla n.m. (pl. magle) sickle

magreta n.f. (pl. magreyaθa) shaving knife | măkinət magreta razor

magriyana n.m. (pl. magriyane) barber

maġara n.m. (A.) cavern, subterranean cave

măḥalle n.f. (A.) neighbourhood; place; shop | ʾap‑a‑măḥálle tlixàle| and he destroyed the district (A29:53); ʾɛ́kɛle măḥálle dìye?| Where is his shop? (A16:3).

măjāl n.m. (A.) space, period | măjā́l xa-ʾə́šta šáwwa yòme| ṱ‑axlǝ́nne xáčča bǝ̀sra| (Give me) the space of six or seven days, so that I can eat some meat (A24:48); qč̣ipewəx mqorəč̣pewəx| t-la-b-hewən ʾu-t-la măjalən| We are cut down and harvested not in the season nor in our time (for cutting) (A51:8).

majbur adj. invar. (A.) obliged; forced | páyəš májbur béna xaráya šàte| In the end it will be forced to drink (A12:47); píšɛle májbur ṣə̀lyɛle| He had to dismount (A28:33); ʾáti májbur t‑yàtli rǝ́sqi| You will be obliged to give me my sustenance (A10:3).

majburuθa n.f. necessity

majma n.m. (pl. majme) (A.) tray | ʾáy šwíqtəlwa májma tàma| She had left a tray there (A4:53).

majo n.f. (pl. majowaθa) wide bowl for kneading dried yoghurt cakes (qaške)

majwajta n.f. (pl. majwajyaθa) a movement

makəčxana adj. (f. makəčxanta, pl. makəčxane) tiring

măkina n.f. (pl. măkine, măkayən) (A.) machine | măkinət xyaṭa sewing machine

makrəb č̭uč̭ane n.f. late snow falling at the beginning March | Literally: the one that angers the magpies

makšūf adj. invar. (A.) uncovered

makuk n.m. (pl. makuke) (K.) shuttle on loom

māl n.m./f. (A.) wealth

malapa n.m. (pl. malape) sheet | hóla ʾarbí malàpe| There are forty sheets (A24:17)

malaxa n.m. (pl. malaxe) angel

maləkθa n.f. (pl. maləkyaθa) queen | ṱ-óya malə́kθa b-šópi ʾíman-t-ʾána mɛ̀θən| She will be queen in my place when I die (A4:39).

malgori n.m. (K.) assistant of a shepherd

malka n.m. (pl. malke) king | qɛsət malka wood of the king, a type of wood from which spoons were made (B10:100); ʾilanət malka the tree from which such wood is taken.

malkuθa n.f. (pl. malkuwaθa) kingdom; kingship | mən-ə̀dyo| malkùθa| m-bnónux qằṭa| From today the kingship will be cut off from your sons (A8:96).

malla n.m. (K./A.) mullah

mallaka n.m. (pl. mallake) (A.) land owner

ṃaḷyana adj. (f. ṃaḷyanta, pl. ṃaḷyane) sufficient | ṃaḷyànɛle That is enough; ṃaḷyànɛle ʾixálux? Do you have enough food?

malyəzana adj. (f. malyəzanta, pl. malyəzane) hasty | lá-hawət malyəzàna!| Do not be hasty (A8:43)

mama n.m. (pl. mamăwaθa) (K.) paternal uncle | bronət mama (first) cousin

mama interj. mother

mamačučək, mawačučək n.m. (K.) edible herb sweet to the taste

mămaðta n.f. baptism

mamðana n.m. baptist | mar Yoḥanna mamðana St. John the Baptist

maməkka n.m. (pl. maməkke) breast of young woman | tre yalone havrəkke šarreley rəš-mamməkke two rival children are fighting on the breasts (C2:39)

mamodiθa n.f. baptism

mana n.m. (pl. mane) vessel, plate

manay, manaya n.f. (K./A.) meaning | hadíya ðíli ʾána manáy díyux mòdila| Now I know what you mean (A17:35).

mandorta n.m. (pl. mandoryaθa) roller for flattening roof

măni pron. who? (less frequently used than ʾɛni) | mằniwət?| Who are you? (A23:26); ʾánna tre-yále mắnile mǝ́ṣya dəryǝ́lla gu-šaqìθa?| Who could have put these two children in the stream? (A8:15).

manqal n.m. (A.) griddle

manquš n.m. (pl. manquše) fire steel, metal instrument for striking fire on flint

manṭăqa n.f. (A.) region

manṭo n.m. type of fabric

manzəl n.f. (pl. manzale) (K./A.) room | manzəl tawa sitting room

mapšəmana n.m. (pl. mapšəmane, f. mapšəmanta) trouble-maker. adj. miserable, sad | xa-qə́ṣṣət rába mapšəmàntɛla| It is a very sad story (A4:31).

măqamta n.f. raising | măqámtət ʾə̀rbe the raising of sheep

maqara n.m. (pl. maqare) gouge, chisel

maqaṣta n.f. (A.) scissors, shears

maqərxana n.m. (pl. maqərxane) (1) brush for whitewashing | hóle maqróxe gudáne b-maqərxàna| He is whitewashing the wools with a brush. (2) metal-polisher | kut-šayə́šla šə́rme lɛ́le makərxàna| Everybody who shakes his buttocks is not a metal-polisher (D2:75).

maqhərana, maqḥərana adj. (f. maqhəranta, pl. maqhərane) (K.) sad

maqle n.f. (pl. maqlăwaθa) (K./A.) cooking pot | made of red clay

maqlūb adj. invar. (A.) reversed | nále l‑koðənyaθéy mə́xyəlla bə̀‑l‑maqlūb| They put on the shoes of their mules back to front (B4:13)

maqora, meqora n.m. (pl. maqore, meqore) hole cut out of middle of stew to hold syrop (napoxta, nepoxta) | ʾó‑t mɛθéwa bušàla| be‑pálge díye y‑awə́ðwale maqòra y‑amrə́xle| Whoever brought stew would make what we call a ‘hole’ in the middle of it (B5:67). Normally the hole was filled with syrop (napoxta, nepoxta).

maqrəṭana n.m. (pl. maqrəṭane) cutter (of hair) | maqrəṭanət kawsa barber

maqriyana n.m. (pl. maqriyane) teacher

maqul adj. invar. (A.) acceptable, respectable; fine | wéləx hawnànta,| b-ʾiqárət ṣáwθa basìmta,| ʾu-màqul| You have been clever, with the gift of sweet and fine words (A40:16)

mara n.m. (pl. marăwaθa, marwaθa) master, owner | marət bɛθa householder, landlord; kɛ̀le mára d-áyya?| Where is the owner of this (ring)? (A4:19); t-lá marăwàθɛle ʾo-márga| ṱ-it-súsux də́ryəlle tàma?| Is the meadow in which you have put your horse without owners? (A25:60). Pl. parents | ʾánna tre-yále qəm-xazǝ̀nna| t-la marwàθa| I have found these two children, without parents (A8:16); sáʾət ṭḷàθa| qèdamta| măṛəšíwalən marăwàθən| At three o’clock in the morning our parents used to wake us (B15:2); t-la-rzáyət marăwáθa dìya| without the consent of her parents.

măra, marra n.m. (pl. măre, marre) illness

maṛa, mɛra n.m. (pl. maṛe, mɛra) (§1.2.3.) metal spade | maṛət kɛrma spade for vineyards, maṛət ʾaqara spade for working on farmland

mărād n.m. (A.) desire | mărádət lə̀bbux| maməṭyànnux| I shall make you attain your heart’s desire (A33:10).

mărana adj. (f. măranta, pl. mărane) ill

mararta n.f. gall bladder

marč̣a-xuwwe, marč̣a-xuwwawe, marč̣a-xuwwaθa n.f. (pl. same) chameleon | Literally: crusher of snakes

marda adj. (f. and pl. marde) (K.) generous

marduθa n.f. education

mare cst. (§10.17.5.)| Element in compounds expressing property: mare bena tolerant; mare janga contentious; mare ʾarxe hospitable; dukθa raba mare baqta a place full of gnats.

marəgla n.m. (pl. marəgle) brass pan for heating water

marɛθa n.f. rennet

marga, mɛrga n.m. (pl. marge, mɛrge, margane, mɛrgane) meadow

margəlta n.f. (pl. margəlyaθa) small pan for heating water

margəšta n.f. (pl. magrəšyaθa) small meadow

marimana n.m. (pl. marimane) lever | especially lever of a water mill (ʾərxe) raised in order to control the turning of the millstone → marmana

marira adj. (f. marirta, pl. marire) bitter

măṛiya n.m. (pl. măṛiye) pasture place | maṛiyət ʾərbe pasture ground of sheep

măṛiyana n.m. grazer, pasturer | măṛiyanət ʾərwe pasturer of small cattle

markaz n.m. (A.) centre

markən n.m. (pl. markane) storage pot

marmana n.m. (pl. marmane) lever → marimana

marmar n.f. (K./A.) marble | mármar mšuwìθa| dressed marble (A40:8)

marquṣta n.f. (pl. marqoṣe, marquṣyaθa) yellow narcissus flower | grows mainly among rocks

marquza n.m. (pl. marquze) yellow narcissus flower = marquṣta

marrəs n.m. (K.) wool of the long haired angora goat (čura, čurra) | ʾərwət marrəs goat with such hair

marta n.f. saying | ʾáyya mártət ʾamàre| This is what they say (literally: This is the saying of the sayers) (A32:24)

marta, marθa n.f. (pl. marwaθa) mistress, lady | marθət bɛθa mistress of the house; Mat Maryam (< Mart) St. Mary. In attributive expressions: šəṭro marθət habriya the beautiful woman who possesses the headscarf (C2:1).

maruta n.f. (pl. maruyaθa) fur (of animal)

maṛuθa n.f. (pl. maṛuwaθa) wooden shovel for moving snow

marya n.m. The Lord | márya ʾálaha Lord God; yá‑marya ʾàlaha| O Lord God (A10:3).

maryana n.m. (f. maryanta, pl. maryane) repairer of clothes | maryanət ṣawle cobbler

marza n.m. (pl. marzane) (K.) border; edge; bank; shore | marzət nera the bank of a river; l‑márzət yàma| the shore of the sea (A12:27); t‑yatwanwa l-marzət gəšra I would sit on the edge of the bridge (C3:2)

marzaban–, marzavan- prep. (K.) around | kúlla maθwáθə ṱ-íla marzabánət ʾƐ̄n‑Nùne| all the villages that were around Ɛn Nune (B15:61).

marzaq n.m. (pl. marzaqe) wooden stick covered in wool used to stick bread to the oven

marziwa n.m. (pl. marziwe) (K.) gutter

măsafa n.f. (A.) distance

măsaḥa n.f. (A.) area

mašana n.f. (pl. mašane) (K.) beam connecting yoke to the main body of the plough

măṣayəf n.pl. (A.) summer pastures

masaθa n.pl. balance (for weighing); the constellation Libra

maše n.pl. black beans | xa dandəkθət maše a single bean; šənqət maše bean pod

masərqa n.m. (pl. masərqe) large comb for carding wool

masəxθa n.f. (pl. masəxyaθa) metal poker for fire; branding iron; frying pan

mašhūr adj. invar. (A.) famous

maši adj. invar. (A.) walking, on foot | mášila zála dǝ̀bba| The bear was walking (A27:13)

masina n.f. (pl. masine) earthenware pot with spout

mašina n.f. (E.) machine; train

maṣīr n.m. (A.) fate, outcome

măṣixət šərmət kθayaθa n.m. little finger | Literally: the tester of the behind of chickens, i.e. the finger that one inserts into a chicken to test whether it is bearing an egg→ m-ṣyx III.

maška n.m. (K.) skin (of sheep)

maṣraf n.m. (A.) expense

masrəqta, masrəqθa n.f. (pl. masrəqyaθa) comb (for hair); comb for filtering the water passing through a pipe leading to a water-mill | la-ṣále b-čú masrə̀qθa| He cannot be combed down with any comb (D2:76);

masrəqθonta n.f. little comb | hállila masrəqθònti| Give me my little comb (A34:3)

massa n.m. (pl. masse) ox goad; pole

masta n.f. (K.) yoghurt

mašura n.m. (p. mašure) stepping stone

maṣyana adj. (f. maṣyanta, pl. maṣyane)capable

ma-t → kəma

mata n.f. (pl. mayaθa, mataθa) grape | hálli ða‑máta mən‑d‑aw‑gùjma| Give me a grape from that bunch

maṭʿam n.m. (A.) restaurant

maṭlab n.m. (pl. măṭaləb) (A.) request

maṭo part. how? how could it? (1) how? | máṭo mṭèlux?| How have you come? (A18:18); de-màṭo hóya?| How could that be? (A30:21); ʾána máṭo mṣárən ṭla‑yə̀mme| yə́mme díye yə̀mmi‑wawa?| How can I curse his mother, since his mother was my mother? (A32:31); màṭowət? How are you? (2) How could it be? | quṣárta màṭo mabə́rya?!| How can it be that a cooking pot has given birth?! (A5:6)

maṭoya adj. ripening quickly | prage maṭoye a type of millet that ripens quickly

maṭuθa n.f. quick ripening plant | prage maṭuθa quick ripening millet.

mawačučək →mamačučək

mawəlka n.m. (K.) type of small sledge hammer with fine head | smaller than a murja

mawjūd adj. invar. (A.) existing, available

mawmiθa n.f. (pl. mawmaθa) oath | méli rába mawmàθa| I swore many oaths

mawṭan n.m. (A.) country, land

mawʿəd n.m. (A.) appointment

mawθa, moθa n.m. death

mawθana n.m. plague

max prep. (with pronominal suffixes: maxwaθe, ʾax-diye) (§13.3.13., §19.3.4.) like, as | Before a noun or clause: ʾína plíṭɛle max-tàla| He came out like a fox (A17:35); xa-pàṛa| wiðále gáne max-qə̀šta| A lamb made itself like a bow (A25:28); max-d-áy like that one (A4:16), max-d-ó-t Lelìθa| like that of Leliθa (A52:15); max-ṱ-íla brátux mšuyðànta,| ʾap-àw,| ʾən-lá-ʾazən mšàyðən| Just as your daughter has gone mad, he also, if I do not go back, will go mad (A4:27); máme díye t-wéwa max-qṭàləlle| His uncle who had almost killed him (A25:70).

maxbana n.m. (pl. maxbane) lover | maxbánət gàne-wewa| He was a lover of himself (= selfish) (A3:1).

maxðiyana adj. (f. maxðiyanta, pl. maxðiyane)cheerful, causing joy

maxətwa n.m. (pl. maxətwe) awl (with wooden handle)

maxfurta n.f. (pl. maxfure) carpet

maxjəlana adj. (f. maxjəlanta, pl. maxjəlane) terrifying | wéle xa-xábra maxjəlàna| It was a terrifying piece of news (B1:13).

maxkɛθa n.f. speech | la-mháymnət kul-maxkɛ́θa basìmta| Do not believe every sweet speech (A49:6).

maxlana n.m. (pl. maxlane) feeder

maxmore n.pl. jewels | xo-qðala maxmore on her neck are jewels (C6:4)

maxyana n.m. player (of an instrument) | maxyánət šabíba pipe-player (A7:6)

maydani n.m. type of red fabric | ṣudrət maydani

mayl n.m. (pl. mayle) (E.) mile

maymun n.m. (pl. maymune) (K./A.) monkey

mayoya n.m. (pl. mayoye) long wooden rod runnning the length of the frame carryng the churn (guða) → lawlaba.

mayoθa adj. mortal

mayuθa n.f. crown (anatomical) | mayuθət reša crown of the head

ma-yxaləf (A.) That is fine

măzada n.m. (pl. măzade) (A.) auction | dɛrɛ́wa măzàde| They would hold auctions (B8:38)

ma-zāl (A.) it is inevitable | ma-zāl qaṣe‑llèy| He must break them (A30:11)

mazaxa n.m. (A.) area below the millstones in a water-mill onto which the flour falls

mazdiyana adj. (f. mazdiyanta, pl. mazdiyane) frightening | xzéli xa‑xə̀lma| rába mazdiyàna| I had a very frightening dream (A11:6)

mazra n.m. (K.) field

mazreta n.f. yoyo

mazyatta n.f. increase, bidding | mšɛrìwa … mazyàtta| They would start the bidding (B5:8)

mazza n.m. (pl. mazze) (K.) snack before meal

maʾarwa, marwa n.m. West | txúme díye ʾìla| mən-madə̀nxa| Zàwa,| ʾu‑mən-màrwa| ʾìla| Xawòra| Its borders are, on the East, the Zab and, on the West, the Khabur (B1:4)

maʾayša n.f. (A.) livelihood, earnings | mút maʾáyša muttàli?| What earnings did I make? (A23:40)

maʿjūn n.m. (A.) paste

maʿmal n.m. (A.) factory

maθa n.f. (pl. maθwaθa) village | maθət ʾƐ̄n-Nune the village of ʾƐn-Nune (B1:9); rešət maθa the head of the village; ʾíθwalən šawwá ʾabòne| gu‑máθa dìyən| We had seven bishops in our village (B2:6).

maθyana n.m. collector (of taxes) | maθyánət xárje-w bárjət boṭanàye| the collector of taxes and the like of the people of Botan (A26:34).

m-bădal → bădal

mbadla n.f. (pl. mbadlaθa) adv. morning | m-lɛle mbadla early morning; mbadla jalde early in the morning; rázgi mbádla dàna| They finish (eating) in the early morning (B5:36). mbadlaθa dawn: gu‑mbadláθa mxɛ́θət yóma ʾó‑naša tlìqɛle| At dawn, the break of day, the man disappeared (A12:10).

mbaqrana adj. (f. mbaqranta, pl. mbaqrane) inquiring, inquisitive | wí mbaqràna,| ṱ-áwət yaðùwa| If you are inquisitive, you shall be knowledgeable (D2:11)

mbašlana n.m. (pl. mbašlane) cook

mbaxlana, baxlana adj. (f. mbaxlanta, pl. mbaxlane) envious

mčakčəkana n.m./adj. (f. mčakčəkanta, pl. mčakčəkane) garrulous

mčarčərana n.m./adj. (f. mčarčəranta, pl. mčarčərane) garrulous

mdabqana n.m. glue

mðita n.f. (pl. mðinaθa) town

mədrasa n.m./f. (pl. mədrase) school

mədre part. (K.) again | mǝ́dre xzéle xǝ̀lma| He had a dream again (A1:9); ʾína lɛ́wa mǝ́dre gnàyux| But again it was not your fault (A1:25).

məjja n.m. yoghurt paste made by dissolving dried yoghurt cakes (qaške)

məjjəd part. (K.) really | b-álaha xónən‑it mə̀jjəd| By God, you are really our brother (A39:8); ʾáyya bèna| ʾǝ́n ʾamrǝ̀nnux| pălǝ́tla pálga mǝ̀jjəd?| This time, if I tell you, will you really divide them in half? (A1:12).

məlga n.m. wool plucked from sheepskin

məlka n.m. (pl. məlke) (A.) property | mə́lkət gáne dìyela| They were his property (B4:2).

məllatayuθa n.f. nationalism

məllət n.f. (K./A.) community, nation | mə́llət kúlla sqìdla| The whole community is fed up (A32:9); mə́llət ʾaθoràye| the Assyrian nation (B6:21).

məlməlawa n.m. celebrations at the end of winter | custom practised at the end of the month of February, in which a bonfire is made and children go around the village asking for small gifts, also know as bəlbəlawa.

məlxa n.f. salt

məlxana adj. (f. məlxana, pl. məlxana) salty

məlxawa n.m. (pl. məlxawe) winnowing fork | made of wood, including the teeth

ṃəḷya adj. (f. ṃḷiθa, pl. ṃəḷye) full | ṃǝ́ḷya dùša| full of honey (A14:14); díwən-t málka hóle ṃḷíθa náše ràbe| The audience chamber of the king is full of many people (A17:31); ða‑ʾilàna| hóla rš‑rúše dìye| ṃḷíθɛla mən‑rǝ́jbət ʾằra| a tree is on his shoulder, full of wildlife (A12:3); dúnye qímla ṃə̀ḷye it is raining torrentially.

məlθa n.f. (pl. məlyaθa) twine made of gut (miroṭe)

mən, m- prep. (rare variant: mənnət; with pronominal suffixes: mənne) (§13.3.14., §16.5.) from, with: (1) Separation or removal: šqíləlla mən-d-ɛ-dɛ̀rta| They took it from that enclosure (A15:12); nìxlən m‑Čúxo| We are relieved of Čuxo (A7:19). (2) Source or origin: ʾən-kyálo m-gu-màθa,| čɛrxìwala máθa| xáṣə dawɛ̀re| If the bride was from the village, they would take her round the village on the back of mules (B10:34). (3) Temporal starting point: ʾu-hóla mšuyðánta mən-d-ó-yoma ṱ-íla xzíθəlle ʾàw| She has been mad from the day that she saw him (A4:12). (4) Partitive: šqíltɛla mən‑dàwe| She took some of the gold coins (A10:7). (5) Comparison: ʾína mástət ʾə́rwe rába biš‑basimtɛ́la biš‑príštɛla mən‑d‑a‑t‑tàwre| But the yoghurt of sheep is much better and more choice than that of cattle (B5:173). (6) Cause: ʾána-ži m-kɛ́rbi ʾǝ́θyən ʾá-kθɛθa múttənna rəš-núra ʾu-xìlənna| I, out of my anger, came and put the chicken on the fire and ate it (A2:11). (7) Material: məlxáwa ʾíwa mtúrṣa m‑qɛ̀sa| The winnowing fork was made from wood (B5:87). (8) Stative spatial location: ʾasṛíwala b‑qɛ́sa ʾu‑m‑áy‑gota qɛ̀sa| ʾu‑m‑áy‑gota qɛ̀sa| They would bind them to a stick, with a stick this side and a stick that side (B7:16). (9) Comitative: mən-xuráne díye píšɛle gu-ṭúra xá-yoma yóme trè| With his friends he remained in the mountains one or two days (A4:2). (10) Combined with other prepositions: ʾu-ṭríðəlle m-gu-bɛ̀θa| He drove him from the house (A16:11); xa‑qála ʾáθe m‑qam‑tắrət bɛ̀θa| A voice came from before the house (A22:29); ʾázən šáqlən zùzi| m-rəš-ʾɛ̀na| I shall go to take my money from on top of the spring (A15:2).

məndi, mdi n.m. (pl. məndiyane) thing | ʾána ʾáxxa nšéli xa‑mə̀ndi| I have forgotten something here (B5:35); ʾáθət ʾána mbàšlən mə́ndi| Come and I shall cook something (A22:14); rába mə́ndi ṭemàna a lot of valuable stuff (A7:9); ʾíθwale mə́ndi ràba| He had a lot (A26:63); ʾu‑xáčča ṭína məndì| and a little mud or the like (B5:190); ʾaw-lá-ʾaxəl čú-mdi He would eat nothing (A2:4); ʾáp-xa mənnɛ́xu lɛ́le l‑zmárta xa-mə̀ndi?| Is anyone of you for a song or something? (A35:7)

mənta n.f. favour | hon‑ṭyána mə́nta mə̀nnux| / ʾána ṭɛnánət mə̀ntɛwən| You have done me a favour (I am much obliged to you).

mənya n.m. stone weight on a balance (masaθa)

mənyana n.m. (pl. mənyane) number

meqora → maqora

merəkka n.m. (K.) game played with stones | the object of this is to hit a small stone as far as possible with a broad stone

mɛrsər n.m. (K.) head of household

mərtoxa n.m. (Urm.) filling made of wheat flour mixed with butter | the more usual term used in Barwar is duwana.

mərwəš n.m. type of wheat

mərya adj. (f. mriθa, pl. mərye) ill

mēs, mēz n.m. (pl. mezăwaθa, mezăwāt) (K.) table

mɛša n.f. (pl. mɛše) type of oak tree | produces ʾapṣe (gallnuts) and baluṭe (acorns); also known as ʾilanət ʾapṣe gallnut tree. It is related to the trees known as p̣aṛma and zədyana.

mɛṣa-ʾəzze, mɛṣantət ʾəzze n.f. (pl. mɛṣa-ʾəzze, mɛṣanət ʾəzze) lizard | Literally: goat-sucker.

məskena n.m./adj. (f. məskənta, pl. məskene) wretched, poor | b-núrət rašíye y-áqði məskène| By the fire of wicked people the poor burn (D2:73)

məšməšša n.m. (pl. məšməšše) (K./A.) apricot

məšna n.f. (pl. məšnaθa, məšne) whetstone for sharpening blades | məšna ʾu-baṭila a whetstone and horn (of butter for lubrication)

məššara n.f. (pl. məššare) section of a paddy field, paddy field basin

məssukta n.f. (pl. məssukyaθa) craw, gizzard (of a bird)

məṣṭaqa n.m. (pl. məṣṭaqe) shelf in a chicken-coop (qare) on which chickens sit

məšṭaxa n.m. (pl. məšṭaxe) area where fruit and vegetables were spread out to dry

məstik n.m. (pl. məstike) mosquito net (supported by one pole or by four poles)

məšwanəkke n.f. (pl. məšwanəkke) beehive | referring properly to the cover of the cylindrical baskets (sălămeše) in which the bees are kept.

məšxa n.m. vegetable oil; clarified butter (from yoghurt or milk) | mə́šxa ḥùr| (B5:31), mə́šxa hòr (B16:12) pure butter; máxa xa‑mə́šxa gu‑be‑ʾéne dìye| (The priest and deacon) put some oil on his forehead (B6:36)

məšxana n.m. paste made from oil. adj. (f. məšxanta, pl. məšxane) oily

metər n.m. (pl. metre) metre

məṭra n.f. (pl. məṭraθa) rain | ṣléla mə̀ṭra| Rain fell (A11:18); mə̀ṭrɛla| It is rainy; mə́ṭra mṭárɛla ràba| There is a lot of rain; məṭra xɛlanta heavy rain.

məttəlθa n.f., mətla n.m. (pl. mətle) story, folktale; riddle, maxim | ʾaw‑mút mə̀tlɛle?| What is (the meaning of) the riddle? (D1:14); mátli mə̀tle| They tell witty sayings.

mətxa n.m. (pl. mətxe) period (of time) | gu-mə́txət xa-daqìqa| wéla lháya ʾan-qɛ̀se| Within the space of one minute those pieces of wood ignited (B15:24)

məṭya adj. (f. mṭiθa, pl. məṭye) ripe

mevan n.m. (pl. mevane) (K.) guest | pɛšənwa mevan diya (If only) I could become her guest (C2:1)

mewa n.m. (K.) fruit

mɛxolta n.f. (pl. mɛxolyaθa) food; nourishment

məxra n.m. (pl. məxre, məxrare) small water channel carrying water across field boundaries (gevanane)

meydān n.m. (pl. meydane) (A.) flat area, plain | ṣadra meydān t‑Barčalla Her chest (is like) the plain of Barčalla (C2:44).

məžməža n.m. (K.) light snow

məžməžoke n.pl. (K.) dried mulberries

məzzana adj. (f. məzzanta, pl. məzzane) hairy | xawxa məzzana hairy peach

məzze pl. (sing. məsta f.) hair | zínna mə́zzət rèši| My hair stood on end (out of fear); kut-mǝ̀sta| xa-zága dáryət bìya| Put a bell on every hair (A27:8).

məʾajbana adj. (f. məʾajbanta, pl. məʾajbane) amazing | xa-mə́ndi məʾajbàna!| (It was) something amazing! (A4:56).

mgamprana n.m. (pl. mgamprane) arrogant person

mgawarta n.f. burp

mhɛmənana, mhamənana n.m. believer | mhamənána b-ʾalàha| a believer in God (A16:3).

mhumna, humna adj. (f. mhumanta, pl. mhumne) faithful, trustworthy

mila n.m.. blue/green colour | mə́xyəxəlla máθən kúlla l-míla-w l-kóma We have covered all our village with blue and black (A4:32); míla b-rešɛ̀xu!| Confound you! (literally: Blue on your head!) (A7:14); míla l‑hàlux!| Confound you! (literally: Blue on your condition!) (A23:10). adj. (pl. mile, no f. form used) blue/green; xa rapə yawne mile A flock of blue doves (C2:35).

milana adj. (f. milanta, pl. milane) blue/green

milannaya adj. (f. milannɛθa, pl. milannaye) bluish; greenish

milanuθa n.f. blueness; greenness; greens, vegetables

mira n.m. (pl. mire) lord, prince

mirata n.m. property without heirs | bɛ́θa d-áwwa náša píšle miràta| The house of this man has no heirs

mir-e-mən interj. (K.) my lord!

miroṭa n.m. (pl. miroṭe) small intestine, gut | ʾipyáθa mən‑miròṭela| The straps (of the plough) are made of gut

miruθa n.f. (K.) nobility, the office of a lord

miya n.pl.tan. water | miya qarire cold water; míya hóla rθàxa| The water is boiling; šalqo t-miya chicken-pox.

miyana adj. (f. miyanta, pl. miyane) watery, wet

miyora n.m. (pl. miyore) intestine

miθa adj. (f. miθta, pl. miθe) dead

miθəkka n.m. a child dressed up in white clothes who is taken around houses of the village at Christmas, or a model of a child dressed and carried in this way (B16:13ff.)

mjunəgra adj. (f. mjungarta, pl. mjunəgre) rusty

mkase qərṭale n.f. late snow falling at the end of March | Literally: the coverer of panniers

m-lɛle adv. early morning, before dawn

mnaxa n.m. rest; deceased, late | mnáxət bábi my father, may he rest in peace; my late father (B3:4)

mnujra fashioned, worked | kepa mnujra dressed stone; ʾi-banɛ́wa báte b-képa mnùjra,| mnújra bəd‑ʾìða| They would build houses with dressed stone, dressed by hand.

mo, mu, modi, maw, mawdi part. pron. (§7.5., §14.9.12., §17.1.4., §17.7.13., §19.1.2.4., §19.2.2.) what; why?; how could it be? how (exclamatory). (1) what | Interrogative: mò‑băyət?| What do you want? (A13:13); mòdi wídle?| What did he do? (A25:19); mú bṱ-àwe?!| What will it be? (= That is fine, OK) (A18:33); mo‑ʾìba?! What is there in it?! (= That is fine, OK) (A13:1); màw-lux?| What is the matter with you? (A31:9); mút qála dìyi?| What is my voice? (A25:44). Indirect question: xáze mòdila qə́ṣṣət| He sees what the problem is (A22:43); làn‑ðaʾa mo‑qaríwale| I do not know what they call him (A12:20); ṱ-ázən xázən mòdi píše ʾan‑náše| I shall go to see what has become of those people (A18:12). Modifier of a noun: ʾáwwa mò-tăhər nášɛle?| What kind of man is he? (A25:31); ʾáyya mòdi mðítɛla?| What town is this? (A26:26). Exclamatory: ʾína mù‑brata!| But what a girl! (A13:11). Head of a relative clause: mšaróyela kθàwa| bɛθwáθət nàše| ʾu‑mo‑ṱ‑itlèy| They start registering the houses of people and what they have (B1:16). (2) why? | mu-ṣṭímlux bɛ̀θi?| Why have you ruined me? (literally: Why have you destroyed my house?) (A15:14); mút ʾáti tíwta làxxa?| Why are you sitting here? (A25:58); módit ʾə̀θya?| Why have you come? (A17:31). (3) how could it be? | questioning possibility of sth., mainly with short forms mu-, mut: ʾánna šáwwa yamàθa| ʾana mù pɛðǝ́nna?| How could I cross these seven seas? (A12:26); mùt hole-pč̣íla?| How could it be that it is crooked? (A17:20); mut‑yằðən ʾɛ́kɛla?| How shall I know where she is? (A14:98). (4) how (exclamatory) | Before a verb: téla mo-ṭréle ʾə̀lla!| How the fox ran to it! (A49:4).

modi → mo

moja n.m. (pl. moje) (K.) calf

mojənta n.f. (pl. mojənyaθa) heifer

mola n.m. (pl. mole) partitioned storage area in a goma (basement stable)

moṣulnaya n.m. (pl. moṣulnaye) man from Mosul

moxa n.m. brain

moza n.m. must (unfermented juice) of grapes; residue of grapes after distillation of arak

mozina (m.) (K.) foal

mozinta (f.) (K.) foal

moʿəd n.m. (A.) appointment | ṭḷáθna hon‑yíwtəlla mòʿəd| I have made an appointment with the three of them (A22:21)

mp̣aṛəmyana, p̣aṛəmyana adj. (f. mp̣aṛəmyanta, pl. mp̣aṛəmyane) knowledgeable, wise

mqawăla n.f. (A.) contract

mqurəmṭa adj. (f. mqurmaṭṭa, pl. mqurəmṭe) wrinkled

mrariya n.f. (K./A.) marble | gudane bani kepa xwara mrariya They will build the walls white stone and marble. (C3:9)

mraxmana adj. (f. mraxmanta, pl. mraxmane) merciful

mreriya n.m. (pl. mreriye) bangle, decoration | qðalə kyalo mreriye On the neck of the bride there are bangles (C5:10)

mriya adj. (f. mrita, pl. mriye) ill

mrupya adj. (f. mrupɛθa, pl. mrupye) free, untethered | heywáne mrùpyewa gu‑góma| The animals were untethered in the basement stable.

m-săbab → sab, săbab

msapyanuθa n.f. (pl. msapyanuyaθa) tradition

msarbəs n.m. (pl. msarbise) wooden instrument on which balls of wool are wound → srbs

msɛθa n.f. washing | ʾitla msɛθa She is having a menstrual period (literally: She has washing, i.e. washing of the soiled clothes).

mṣapyana n.m. (pl. mṣapyane) strainer

mṣoθa n.f. extract from ʾatko (piece of the stomach of a young goat) used as rennet (marɛθa) for cheese

mšadrana n.m. (pl. mšadrane) sender

mšanyana n.m. (pl. mšanyane) nomad

mšarbəṭana → šarbəṭana

mšaxəlpana n.m. (pl. mšaxəlpane) somebody who keeps changing his mind

mṣɛθa n.f. ability | mattìwa| ṱ‑ámrəx xá xámša dinàre| ʾən‑hàtxa mə́ndi| yáʿni ʾax‑mṣɛ̀θa| They would deposit let us say a sum of five dinars, or thereabouts, according to their ability (to pay) (B5:6)

mšixaya n.m./adj. (f. mšixɛθa, pl. mšixaye) Christian

mšurəšya adj. (f. mšuršɛθa, pl. mšurəšye) sloping; tilting | garíθa mšuršɛ̀θɛla| The roof (of the outhouse) is sloping.

mšuṭra adj. (f. mšuṭarta, pl. mšuṭre) spoilt (child)

mšuθna adj. (f. mšuθanta, pl. mšuθne) feverish; afflicted with fever

mtagbarta n.f. maintenance

mtagbərana n.m. (pl. mtagbərane) regulator

mtanaxta n.f. (pl. mtanaxyaθa) sigh

mtanyana n.m. (pl. mtanyane) teller | mtanyanət tunayaθa storyteller

mtarəksana n.m. small wooden poker | cf. badoda long wooden poker, maṣəxθa metal poker

mṭarṭəmana n.m. (pl. mṭarṭəmane) grumbler

mṭawalta → ṭawalta

mu, mut → mo

mubyana n.m. (pl. mubyane) swelling (on skin)

mučəkθa n.f. (pl. mučəkyaθa) dry measure in the form of a small bowl (used by the owner of water-mill to measure out his share of the flour for his fee)

mudda n.f. (A.) period

mugədla adj. (f. mugðalta, pl. mugədle) frozen | miya mugədle frozen water

muhəmma n.f. (A.) important matter, duty

muḥkəm adj. invar. (A.) solid, strong

mujarrad adv. (A.) only | bas-mjárrad mṣawθàwa| She was just talking (A19:9)

mujawharāt n.pl. (A.) jewelry

muka n.m. (pl. muke) wooden post hammered into the ground to make a wattle fence

munað̣ð̣əm n.m. (A.) regulator, governor

mŭnawăra n.f. (A.) manoeuvre

muntăð̣am adj. invar. (A.) controlled

mŭqabəl prep. (A.) opposite

muqaṭăʿa n.f. (A.) territory, province

mur n.f. (pl. muraθa) (K./A.) stamp, seal | məxyále mur-dìye| He put his stamp (on it).

murabba n.m. (pl. murabbe) (A.) jam

murč̣anus n.f. mashed potato → mrč̣.

murja n.m. (pl. murje) type of sledge hammer | used for breaking stones and hewing rock, larger than a mawəlka which is used for the same purpose.

murza n.f. (pl. murzăwaθa) iron ball and chain (weapon)

musarde n.m. festival commemorating the baptism of Christ (100 days after Easter)

mušəlmana n.m./adj. (pl. mušəlmane) Muslim

mušəlmanuθa n.f. Islam

muškəla n.f. (pl. măšakəl) (A.) problem

muštărək adj. invar. (A.) participating

muxtăləf adj. invar. (A.) different

muxtər n.m. (A.) village head

muʿalləm n.m. (A.) teacher

mwafăqa n.f. (A.) agreement

mxamyana n.m. (pl. mxamyane) guard

mxallana n.m. (pl. mxallane) cleaning cloth

mxilta n.f. (pl. mxilyaθa) sieve with small holes (for flour)

mzabnana n.m. (pl. mzabnane) seller

mziða n.m. (pl. miziðe) bag for storing grain (made of sheepskin)

mθallaθ n.m. (pl. mθallăθāt) (A.) triangle



/n/

nabuwa n.m. (pl. nabuwe) large spring of water

nač̣əpta n.f. (pl. nač̣əpyaθa) drop (of liquid)

naðorta n.f. (pl. naðoryaθa) pipe running out from a spring (ʾɛna) or an irrigation channel (šaqiθa)

năfăr n.m. (pl. năfăre) (A.) person, individual | After numerals: ʾəč̣č̣ì nắfăre| ninety people (B2:10).

nafšə‑šay (A.) the same thing

naftang n.m. (pl. naftange) (K.) waist | ʾaqláθe díye píše kèpa| hál naftánge dìye| His legs had turned to stone up to his waist (A8:58).

nagəstən adv. (K.) suddenly

nagoza n.m. (pl. nagoze) bite | mxáyəlle xa-nagòza| He bit it (B15:55).

na-ḥaqquθa n.f. (A.) what is not lawful | ṱ-ázən ṭắyən báθər ḥaqqùθa| ʾu-na-ḥaqqùθa| I shall go and search for what is lawful and what is unlawful (A15:5)

nahira n.m. lamp oil | used in the lamps of churches (nuṭa being used in house lamps); nahirət šəšme sesame oil for lamps, nahirət gawze walnut oil for lamps, nahirət bəṭme terebinth oil for lamps

naḥiya n.f. (A.) district

najara, najjara n.m (pl. najare, najjare) (A.) carpenter

najaruθa n.f. carpentry

najīb adj. (A.) good, diligent

nala n.m. (pl. nale) horse-shoe

nalbanda m. (pl. nalbande) (K.) farrier

nama n.f. (pl. name) ostrich

na‑mumkən adj. invar. (K./A.) impossible | ʾo‑t‑là páləx| na‑múmkən ṱ‑áxəl gu‑bɛ̀θi| Whoever does not work cannot eat in my house (A21:40).

na-paləx adj. (invar.) lazy

napaxta n.f. a large hollow measure for corn in the form of open oblong wooden box

napoxta, nepoxta n.f. raisin or date syrop | In the Barwar region it was always made of raisins.

naqiða adj. thin, fine | qɛsa naqiða thin wood; zolale naqiðe fine tendrils

naqoša n.m. (pl. naqoše) (Urm.) bell

naqro n.f. (pl. naqrowaθa) woodpecker

naqruza n.m. (pl. naqruze) beak (of birds); proboscis (of flies, wasps, bees, etc.) | č̣éne šádli naqruzéy gu‑gə́ldət heywàne| Mosquitoes stick their proboscis into the skin of animals.

naqta n.f. (pl. naqyaθa) young female goat | the male equivalent is gəðya

nara → nera

năra (i) n.m. (pl. năre) axe

năra (ii) n.m. roar | ʾay-wàðtɛla| năra-nắra dìya| She was roaring (A27:14).

narduma n.m. (pl. nardume) nose (of animal)

nardumana adj. (f. nardumanta, pl. nardumane) miserable, discontent | báxti nardumàntɛla,| lá-băya ʾàrxe| My wife is miserable, she does not want guests.

năreθa n.f. (pl. năreyaθa) small axe; piece in shape of an axe at the end of the rotating shaft that fits into the upper grindstone of a water-mill

narṭuma n.m. snout (of an animal) | narṭúmə sùsa| the snout of the horse (A12:65)

nasarta n.f. (pl. nasaryaθa) saw | nasartət ʾiða hand saw; nasartət dape large saw used by two people for cutting planks (dape) from logs.

năṣiyət n.f. (A.) advice | xa-năṣíyət t-yánna ṭlàlux| I’ll give you some advice (A24:9).

naša n.m. (pl. naše) man, person; family relative | bəṛ-naša human being; málla mǝ́re náša šùqla!| The mullah said ‘Man, give me a break!’ (A2:6); nášət kyàlo| the family of the bride (B5:36); xa-nàši| a relative of mine (A18:16).

našuθa n.f. humanity | ʾáyya bráta hon‑ʾə́θya nablə̀nna| ʾən‑b‑našùθa,| ʾən‑b‑xɛ̀la| I have come to take this girl, either humanely or by force (A29:65).

naṭora n.m. (pl. naṭore) guard

naveže n.f. (K.) ablution (for prayer) | lázəm ʾáθe ʾáwəð navèže| He must come to make ablutions (A25:33).

nawa m. (pl. nawe) nit (in hair)

nawaga n.m. (pl. nawage) (K.) grandson, grandchild

nawagta n.f. (pl. nawagyaθa) (K.) granddaughter

nawba n.f. (pl. nawbe) (A.) turn; guard duty | nawbət miya turn for a field to receive irrigation water, determined by the irrigation manager (karaxa); so-dúqu nàwba| Go and keep guard (A18:3).

nawbadār n.m. (pl. nawbadare) (K./A.) night guard

nawərčəkka, nawərčika, nawčərka n.m. (pl. nawərčəkke, nawərčike, nawčərke) (K.) great-great-grandson

nawəgga n.m. (pl. nawəgge) (K.) great-grandson

nawəgta n.f. (pl. nawəgyaθa) (K.) great-granddaughter
