nawəlka n.m. (pl. nawəlke), nawəlta n.f. (pl. nawəlyaθa) bar used to stretch and tease strands of wool by turning

nawəlta → nawəlka

nawčərka → nawərčəkka

nawərčəkta, nawərčəkθa n.f. (pl. nawərčəkyaθa) great-great-granddaughter

nawra n.m. (pl. nawre) mirror

nawžina n.m. (pl. nawžine) (K.) foal of a horse

naxira n.m. (pl. naxire) nose; projecting structure with a small orifice on the tower of a church

naxopa adj. (f. naxopta, pl. naxope) shy

naxraya n.m./adj. (f. naxrɛθa, naxraye) foreigner, stranger; foreign, strange

nazik adj. (pl. năwazik) (K.) delicate | Nàze,| ʾáti gánəx nàzik-iwət| Naze, you yourself are delicate (A25:18); ʾə́rwe năwazìk‑ila| Sheep are delicate (B10:56).

naθa n.f. (pl. naθyaθa) ear, handle | gúda máre naθyàθɛle| The wall has ears (D2:43); náθux lè-y-yatla| l-hàtxa náše mṣáwθi| Do not give your ear to such people speaking (A26:67); zdímla naθyáθi b-qálət tòpe| My ears were deafened by a gushot; naθyaθət nunta the gills of a fish, naθyaθət tope the sights of a gun (diagonal pieces attached to the barrel joined by a strip of animal hair).

nčila adj. (f. nčilta, pl. nčile) ragged, scruffy | y‑oðə́xwale júlle nčìle We made for him ragged clothes (B16:10)

neṛa n.m. sight, vision | rába píšle zắbun néṛət ʾɛ̀ne,| b-xɛ̀lɛle dyála| His sight has become very weak, he can hardly see.

nera, nara n.m. (pl. nerăwaθa) river

neriya n.m. (pl. neriye) (K.) male goat four years old and upwards

nɛka n.m. (pl. nɛke) thigh

nəčča n.m. (pl. nəčče) small piece of meat

nəhaya n.f. (A.) end

nəmra (i) n.m. (pl. nəmre) tiger

nəmra (ii) n.f. (A.) number

nəmu, ləmu part. asseverative particle; why?; remonstrating particle (§17.9.1.). (1) asseverative particle | In the context of negative questions: nə́mu la‑mə́ri‑llux dàyəṛ,| míθa dàyəṛ?| Did I not tell you that he would return (= indeed I told you …), that the dead would return? (A22:39); nə́mu la-ʾawðə́xle ʾáwwa ṭùra| dărajyàθa,| daràje,| ṱ-ásqəx l-áwwa ṭùra?| Should we not make steps for this mountain (= indeed let us make …), so that we can go up the mountain? (A17:4); lə́mu lá-ʾasqən ʾàna?| Should I not go? (= indeed I should go) (A39:10). (2) why? | lə́mu la-qìmlux?| Why did you not get up? (A26:48). (3) remonstrating particle | In a positive question: nə́mu ʾáyya bə́rke d-ɛ̀nila| ṱ-it-ʾáti sxáya gàwa?| Whose is this pool in which you are swimming? (surely it is mine not yours) (A25:61).

nənxa n.m. mint | mtăməzə́xwa ʾamáne b-qə́ṭma‑w nə̀nxa| We used to clean vessels with ash and mint.

nəqda n.m. money | ʾo‑yóma qăṭíwa nə̀qda| On that day they would decide on money (B5:8).

nəqša n.m. (pl. nəqše) embroidery, decorations | y‑oðíwa nə̀qše gáwa| t‑ʾámṛa kòma| They made embroideries in them (the rugs) of black wool (B10:79)

nəsyana n.m. experience

nəṣyət, nəṣyətta n.f. (pl. nəṣyətte) (A.) advice; admonishment

nəšma n.m./f. soul | tá-t šaqlíle nəšmèy| so that they could take away their soul (A4:59); píšle nə̀šma| It became a living being (A18:29); kú nə̀šma| t-màṭya| rəš-gə́šrət Dalàle| ʾɛ-nə́šma bəd-pɛ̀ša| prìmta,| qṭìlta| Any soul that comes onto the bridge of Dalale—that soul will be slaughtered, killed (C8:5).

nəšra n.m. (pl. nəšre) eagle

nəšwa n.m. bird trap | nəšwət qəqwane traps for partridges, consisting of loops (xarbuqyaθa) of horse hair suspended on pruning hooks (čakalyaθa) that are stuck in the ground; nəšwət čučəkke traps for small birds, consisting of loops of horse hair hung up intertwined with a bunch of millet heads (dastət bole); mattoye nəšwe to lay bird traps.

nəṭṭəpta n.f. (pl. nəṭṭəpyaθa) drop

nəxla n.m. sieved grain; flour that falls through a fine sieve (mxilta) | nəxlət qɛsa sawdust, shavings

nəxsa n.m. rebuke

nəzla n.m. puss

nimana adj. (f. nimanta, pl. nimane) damp | bɛθa nimana a damp house; julla nimana a damp cloth; hawa nimana humid air; ʾăra nimanta damp ground

nira n.m. (pl. nire) yoke of a plough; small wooden strip made of juniper laid across beams in a roof (syn. qarša)

nišan n.m. (K.) target

nišanqa n.m. (pl. nišanqe) (K.) sign, symbol, symbolic act, token | wíðɛle ʾa‑dúkθa nišànqa| He made a sign in that place (A11:10); mattíwa nišànqe| They (the family of the groom) would deposit tokens (of betrothal, usually in the form of a deposit of money) (B5:5).

nisən n.m. April

nita n.f. (pl. nitaθa) dawning of the day, all night celebrations during a wedding | munéla nìta| Dawn has broken; qaṭlə́xla nìta| We shall continue our celebrations until dawn.

niwa n.m. (pl. niwe) canine tooth

nixa adj. (f. nixta, pl. nixe) slow; inactive; extinct, obliterated; deceased | nixa nixa slowly, gently: zíla níxa níxa wíra gu‑d‑a‑màθɛle| He went along slowly and entered the village (A14:58); pálxi plìxe,| y-áxli nìxe| Those who have worked hard work but those who are inactive eat (D2:33); tré-mənna tlíxela nìxela| Two of them (the churces) are destroyed and obliterated (B1:5); ʾána ṣalə́nwa m‑d‑ó‑nixət xòni| I used to go down with my late brother (B5:212).

niza n.m. (pl. nize) (K.) bayonet

nohra, nora n.m. light | ʾálaha maníxle gu-nóhra ʾu-pardɛ̀sa| May God grant him rest in light and paradise (said after the death of somebody); šabθət nora The Saturday of Light. This is the Saturday before Easter, so named since the angels went down to the grave of Jesus and bathed it in light.

noš– | b-noš– adv. (Urm.) by oneself | xà b-nošéy| by themselves (B15:75)

nqira adj. (f. nqirta, pl. nqire) carved; dressed (stone) | képe nqìre| dressed stones (B15:22)

nṭarta n.f. guard; vigil; waiting | tiwa wənwa nṭaraθa I was sitting in vigil (C2:16)

nuhara n.m. (pl. nuhare) explanation, clarification

nula, lula n.m. (pl. nule, lule) (K.) young ox

nulta, lulta n.f. (pl. nulyaθa, lulyaθa) (K.) young cow

nune n.pl. (sing. nunta) fish; smooth skinned like a fish (name of nanny goat) | ʾə́zza ʾɛ-Nùne the nanny goat called Nune (C7:3)

nuniθa n.f. fish

nura n.m. fire; Hell fire | qa-mó gắrəg ʾázəl kúlla páxri gu-nùra?| Why should all my body go to Hell fire (A16:2)

nuta n.f. edible herb | small form of nuwa, consists of a single leaf (ṭaya), which is bitter to the taste; nuta balle type of herb

nuṭa n.m. oil, petroleum

nuwa n.m. edible herb | large form of a nuta, consisting of several leaves (ṭaye)

nuwala n.m. (pl. nuwale) water channel

nxəpθa n.f. shame | be-nxəpθa shameless

nxiluθa n.f. mischief

nxilθa n.f. mischievous trick | mtuxmǝ́nne ṱ-áwəð nxìlθa| He (the fox) thought of doing a mischievous trick (A49:2).

nyasa n.m. (pl. nyase) (K.) acquaintance (among the Kurds)

nyasta n.f. (pl. nyasyaθa)(K.) acquaintance (among the Kurds)



/p/

pača n.m. (T.) dish consisting of the head and legs of an animal

pačča n.m. (pl. pačče) handful with two hands | štáyɛle b‑pàčča| He is drinking with his hands

paččəkθa n.f. (pl. paččəkyaθa) small handful with one hand

pala (i) n.m. (pl. pale) workman

pala (ii) n.m. fate, fortune | qəm-daryáli pàla| She presented my fortune to me; dréla xa-pàla| She made a prediction of her fortune (A38:2) → pela

pălakka n.m. (pl. pălakke) (A.) celestial sphere, star | marmanne qam‑pălakke I shall raise it (the churn) up to the stars (C5:2)

palaxa n.m./adj. (pl. palaxe) worker; hard-working

palga n.m. (pl. palge) half; middle. (1) half | xa-w palge one and a half; hálli xa‑lə́xma-w pàlge| Give me one and a half loaves of bread; xa‑kista-w palge one and a half bags; ʾánna ʾálpa dáwe pălǝ̀tla,| pálga ṭlàli| pálga ṭlàlux?| Will you divide those thousand gold pieces, half for me and half for you? (A1:6); ʾap‑an-zúze kúlla ṱ-in šqìləlla| pălǝ́nna pàlge| I’ll divide into halves also all the money that I took (A1:17); pálgət ʾùrxɛwəx| We are halfway (on our journey). (2) middle | ʾu‑b-pálgət bɛ́θa wídla nùra| She made a fire in the middle of the house (A19:4); palgət yoma midday; kepət palga middle stone (at the top of a door stone). be-palga adv. in the middle | ʾo-yála zóra hóla múttəlle be‑pàlga| They put the little boy in the middle (A4:58); n.m. middle section | ʾap-aqlə‑d-àw,| hál be-palge-díye píša kèpa| Its leg, up to its middle had become stone (A8:30).

palkon n.m. (A.) balcony

palla n.m. (pl. palle) (K.) ember of burning wood | y‑oðə́xwa nùra,| ʾáwwəl ma‑t‑ràxəθ,| garšə́xla qɛ̀se,| pɛ́šiwa pàlle| We made a fire. As soon as it boiled, we pulled away the wood and it became embers. (B10:87)

palləkθa n.f. (pl. palləkyaθa) (K.) small piece of burning coal, ember

paloxaya n.m. (pl. paloxaye) labourer | ʾu-plúx mən-d-ànna paloxáye| Work with these labourers (A24:5).

palpule n.pl. (sing. palpule) boot, large shoe | kul səmbəlti xa draya, kul zargulti palpulti Each (side) of my moustache is a cubit, and each shoe of mine and each boot of mine (is a cubit) (A51:5).

pampule n.pl. (sing. pampulta) large shoes

pandana adj. cunning | θéle téla pandàna| The cunning fox came (A49:2).

pande adv. slowly | lá‑juj pàndux| Don’t be slow.

panjana n.m. (pl. panjane) (K./A.) glass; cup | qáṭu wìrtɛla,| npílta gu-d-án panjàne| mqurə̀dxela| ʾánna ṛìšela| A cat came in, fell into the glasses, they shattered and they woke up (A4:53).

panjăra, panjara, panjɛra, panjăriya, panjăriye n.f. (pl. panjăriyaθa) (K.) window

panya n.m. (pl. panye) shadow | ʾaṣərta yoma gnele panya ṭalana rpele In the evening the sun set and cast a shadow on the shadow side of the mountain (C2:5)

papa n.m. pope

papaya n.m./adj. (pl. papaye) Catholic

p-ape prep. beyond | hóla p‑ápe šawwà yamáθa| She is beyond seven seas (A12:21); qímtɛla musáqtəlle bróna dìya| p‑ápe xa-gằra,| prìmtəlle| She went and took up her young cub the other side of a hill and slaughtered it (A33:13).

papuka n.m. (f. papukta, pl. papuke) miserable waif (with no family)

paqərta n.f. (pl. paqəryaθa) tonsil

paqota n.f. dish consisting of wheat dumplings and meat

paṛa (i) n.m. (pl. paṛe) male lamb

paṛa (ii) n.m. (pl. paṛe) odd number | zawge ʾu-paṛe even and odd numbers

para (i) n.m. fine dust | qaríwtux ʾúpra-w pàra| Your companion is earth and fine dust (A38:9)

para, pɛra (ii) n.m. (pl. pare, pɛre) coin; silver disk decoration on the tita (string of decorative disks worn by women on the forehead)

păra n.m. first rain in autumn | tiwle păra The first rain has settled (and the ground is muddy)

parča n.m. (pl. parče) (K.) piece of woven cloth; patch

parda n.m. (pl. parde) (K.) curtain; cloth blind

pardɛsa n.m. paradise | xzéli b-xǝ̀lmi| ʾìna| ʾána zíla l-pardɛ̀sa| l-á-dunye xèta| I dreamt that I went to Paradise to the next life (A2:7); ʾálaha maníxle gu-nóhra ʾu-pardɛ̀sa| May God grant him rest in light and paradise (said after the death of somebody); (gu-)pardɛ́sa bábux ʾu-yə̀mmux May your father and mother be in paradise (said in thanks to somebody’s good wishes).

p̣aṛəmyana → mp̣aṛəmyana

parəšta n.f. (pl. parəšyaθa) small flat stone

parəxtət lɛle n.f. (pl. parxaθət lɛle) bat

parma n.m. (pl. parme) blade

parma adj. m. (f. parəmta, pl. parme) cutting | skinta parəmtɛla the knife cuts well (it is sharp)

paṛma n.m. (pl. paṛme) type of oak | producing a sweet edible fruit called baluṭe (sing. baluṭa)

parmanta n.f. (pl. parmanyaθa) cutting tool

p̣aṛmɛθa n.f. knowledge, wisdom

p̣aṛmyana →mp̣aṛmyana

paroxa adj. (pl. paroxta, pl. paroxe) flying, able to fly | ṭɛ́ra paròxɛle| a bird is a flying creature

parpiṭe n.pl. brushwood taken from bushes (ṭarraše)

parra n.m. (pl. parre, parrane) (K.) feather; fin on water-wheel

parranta n.f. (pl. parranyaθa) comb of a bird

parša n.m. (pl. parše) large flat stone | e.g. for flattening dough

parṣopa n.m. physiognomy, face; personality | ʾa-parṣópa díyux hátxa jwànqa| This face of yours, which is so handsome (A8:41)

parsuwa n.m. (pl. parsuwe) (K.) rib

parta n.f. husks of rice left after rice is hulled and ground; remains left in sieve after sieving; scraps of wool left on floor after carding | partət kawsa dandruff

partəkka n.m. (pl. partəkke) loose wisp of wool/hair (falling on ground after carding) | ʾámṛe díye partə̀kkɛle| Its wool is full of loose wisps; káwse díye píšle partə̀kke| His hair has become dishevelled.

paruða adj. (pl. paruðta, pl. paruðe) coarse | qamxa paruða coarse flour, as opposed to qamxa daqiqa finely ground flour.

paṛuna m. (pl. paṛune) sheepskin bag for clothes

parušta ‘smooth pebble’ (D.A.: parrçÊÊšyā́θa) K: parrušta

parušta, parrušta n.f. (pl. parušyaθa, parrušyaθa) smooth pebble

paruxa adj. flying, able to fly | ṭɛ́ra parùxɛle| A bird is able to fly.

parwana n.m. (pl. parwane) (K.) propeller | mìya| mazəvríle xa‑parwàna| The water drives round a propeller (of a water mill) (B6:53)

parxa lɛle, parxa b‑lɛle, parxət lɛle n.f. (pl. parxa lɛle) bat | Literally: night-flyer → parəxtət lɛle, parxantət lɛle

parxantət lɛle n.f. (pl. parxanyaθət lɛle) bat

parxe n.pl. peeling skin | šanə parxe chicken-pox (literally: honeycomb of peeling skin)

parxoniθa n.f. (pl. parxonyaθa) butterfly

parxoniθət lɛle n.f. (pl. parxonyaθət lɛle) bat

parzəkka, parzəkθa n.f. (pl. parzəkyaθa) spot on skin

parzena n.m. thorn tree | its long thorns (known as kălame) are used for making fences.

parzūn, parzuna n.m. (pl. parzune) (K.) woolen knapsack worn by women | used for carrying everyday items and by bride to carry dowry

paṛθa n.f. (pl. paṛaθa) female newborn sheep

pasuta n.f. (pl. pasuwe, pasuyaθa) pace | bēl‑šə́dla l‑šə̀dla| gắrəg mátteti xa‑xamšá ʾaqlàθa,| xamšá pasùwe| Between the saplings you must leave about five steps, five paces (B5:103).

pašxa rase n.f. late snow in the month of April | Literally: splitter of rasa grass

pătate n.pl. potatoes

patəsqa n.m. (K.) type of fabric (white)

patlo n.f. (hot) whirlwind

patorta n.f. (pl. patoryaθa) mushroom

paṭiroke n.f. edible herb | resembling hemza with tendrils (zolale) running along the ground and a pungent root

paṭoša n.m. (pl. paṭoše) patch; mark | ʾən‑ʾárdət ṣawə́lta xrùle,| maxə́lla paṭòša| If the bottom of a shoe is damaged, they put patch on it; paṭošət ṭina muddy mark (on clothes)

paṭoxa n.m. (pl. paṭoxe) flattened piece of cattle dung used for fuel

paθa n.f. (pl. paθwaθa) face; front; upper surface; side (of river). (1) face | mxúlla páθe dìye| He washed his face (A14:27); ʾáp-xa mən-díyən lɛ́le mə́ṣya kə́lya gu-páθe dìye| None of us can face him; díya gu-pàθux| mdàgəl| He will now lie to your face (A6:11); rəḥqa mən-paθa Let it be far from the face (said after mentioning something untoward or unpleasant); xabūš paθa cheek-bone (literally: apple of the face); kōm-paθa black-faced, disgraced, xwār-paθa white-faced, innocent; šaqlanət paθwaθa two-faced, deceitful. (2) front | paθət guda front of wall facing outwards (as opposed to băṭăna inside of wall), outside row of stones; kepət paθa stones of the facing (small white stones used to cover outer wall of house B5:180). (3) upper surface | paθət miya surface of water; paθət ṣawle top of shoes; paθət mēz table-cloth; l‑páθa d‑o‑gúpta dɛréwa matúwwa ṭàrpe| Over the surface of the cheese they would put leaves (B5:169). (4) side (of river) | l-a‑páθa xétət nèra| on the other side of the river (A14:50).

paθora n.m. (pl. paθore), paθorta n.f. (pl. paθoryaθa) banquet, meal on special occasion

pawxa n.m. (pl. pawxe) wind, air | ṱ-óyən … waðǝ́llux pàwxa| I shall give you air (to keep cool) (A27:38)

paxa adj. (f. paxta, pl. paxe) insipid; boring

paxalta n.f. forgiveness; sorry! | sí-ṭlub paxálta mǝ́nne dìye| Go and ask forgiveness from him (A1:10); paxàlta,| lá-mṣən ʾáθən ʾə̀dyo| Sorry, I cannot come today.

paxra n.m. (pl. paxre) body

payda → fayda

payoxa adj. (f. payoxta, pl. payoxe) cool

p̭azesor n.pl. (K.) large sheep with red ears | p̭azesór b-ʾəlyàθa,| hátxa b-qanàne| red eared sheep with fat tails and horns like this (A7:22); xa-ʾərbət pazesor a red eared sheep

pažgir n.f. (pl. pažgire) (K.) towel

pč̣ila adj. bendy, crooked | ʾurxa pč̣ilta winding road; ʾáwwa tărɛ́xu pč̣ìlɛle| This door of yours is crooked (A17:20); tú pč̣ìla,| mṣáwəθ dū̀z| Sit crooked, but tell the truth (D2:60).

pek n.m. measure of whiskey

peka → feka

pela (i) n.m. (pl. pele) radish

pela (ii) n.m. fate, fortune | tálga lá mattúle pèle| The snow will not put aside its fate (D2:45), i.e. a person cannot change his character.

p̣ena n.f. (pl. p̣ena, p̣enane) (K.) kick | mxaya p̣ena to kick: qəm‑maxyála ðà‑p̣ena| She gave me a kick (B5:132); b‑ðá‑ʾaqla díya p̣éna qəm‑maxyáli ʾàxxa| With one of its legs it kicked me here (A5:132); p̣enàne maxyátli!| You kick me! (A27:41).

periya n.f. (pl. periyaθa) (K.) beautiful girl | periyət yama mermaid

peruzana n.m. (pl. peruzane) (K.) gift given on the birth of child

petəxt n.m. (P.) capital city

pɛra → para (ii)

pəčča n.m. (pl. pəčče, pəččače) (K.) piece (of meat) | qəm-awə́dla tre-pə̀čče| He cut her into two pieces (A51:18).

pəčkana adj. (f. pəčkanta, pl. pəčkane) (K.) insignificant; useless

pəddoma n.m. (pl. pəddome) cloth stopper of a vessel | used to stop mouth of a kwara (storage basket), a mziða (storage bag) or a guða (skin)

pəllən → fəllən

pəlxana (pl. pəlxanane) n.m. work; job; cultivation | ʾàw zílɛwa l‑pəlxàna| He had gone to work (A21:5); lípla pəlxàna| She has learnt how to work (A21:32); ʾáp‑ʾana ṱ‑ázən pàlxən| xa‑pəlxána ta‑t‑lɛ̀pena| I also shall go and work, so that I can learn (how to do) a job (A23:1); kúlla pəlxàna,| pəlxánət bɛ́θa hóle b‑qðàli| All the work, the work of the house is my duty (A21:27); ʾína xabúše biš‑senàyiwa| pəlxanèy| but the cultivation of apples was easier (B5:75). b-pəlxana busy, hard-working: ʾána b-pəlxànən| I am hard-working (A21:27); bráti wéla b‑pəlxàna| My daughter has become hard-working (A21:32).

pənxa n.m. (pl. pənxe) millstone, grinding wheel | pənxa ḷaya upper millstone; pənxa xtaya lower millstone; mattíwa … pə́nxət ʾə̀rxe.| ʾíθwa ʾo-t‑kyépa ʾáw ʾo-t‑xə̀ṭṭe,| y‑oðíwa qàmxa,| ʾína ʾáw t-rə̀zza| ʾíwa t‑qɛ̀sa| They would install a grinding wheel of a water-mill. There was a stone, which was for wheat, with which they made flour, but the one for rice was of wood (B5:90); mattále xa‑pə̀nxət| šáwwi šawwá pə́rse rəš-ṣádre dìye| She put a millstone (capable of being lifted only by) seventy-seven heroic men onto his chest (A50:7).

p̣əqqa n.m. (pl. p̣əqqaqe) crack, split | p̣əqqət ʾaqla arch of sole of foot

pəqqa, pəqqe n.f. (pl. pəqqe, pəqqaθa, pəqqaqe) frog

pəqqəške n.f. pəqqəškaθa (K.) blister; bubble

pəqqəšta n.f. (pl. pəqqəšyaθa) blister, bubble

pəqxa n.m. (pl. pəqxe) blossom

pərc̭e n.pl. (K.) hair

pərč̭əmta n.f. (pl. pərc̭əmyaθa) (K.) forelock; front of hair | pálgət pərč̭ə́mte dìye| xríxla qam-yòma| Half of his forelock was singed by the sun (A50:11); xá pərč̭ǝ́mta dìye| … t‑dáwa-w xa-t-sèma| one forelock of his … was of gold and one was of silver (sign of beauty) (A8:6).

pərma n.m. (pl. pərme) thurible

p̭ərruš adj. invar. (K.) treacherous, unfaithful | m-o-kalbət p̭ərruš wele ṣlele rəš-kalləš klele xəmyanət Dalle bxele On account of that dog which was treacherous, which went down and stood over carrion, the father-in-law of Dalle wept (C8:9).

pərsa n.m. (pl. pərse) hero, warrior | mattále xa‑pə̀nxət| šáwwi šawwá pə́rse rəš-ṣádre dìye| She put a millstone (capable of being lifted only by) seventy-seven heroic men onto his chest (A50:7) → ferəssa.

pərsange n.pl. game in which players compete in the throwing of heavy stones

pərṣət n.f. (pl. pərṣətte) (A.) opportunity, chance | lítlux pyáša pə̀rṣət.| dìya qaṭlə́xlux.| You have no chance (of escape). We shall kill you now. (A26:76)

pəršunya n.m. (pl. pəršunye) difference

pərtəkta n.f. (pl. pərtəkyaθa) small splinter (of wood)

pərṭena, pərṭana n.m. (pl. pərṭene, pərṭana) flea

pərtika n.m. (pl. pərtike) splinter (of wood)

pərtoxa n.m. (pl. pərtoxe) crumb

pərya → fərya

pəška n.m. (pl. pəške) small piece (of meat)

pəškəlle n.pl. (sing. pəškəlta) (K.) droppings of goats or sheep that have not been broken up by trampling | cf. purta

pəškoža n.f. (pl. pəškože) (K.) bud; tassel, decorative stud, bead | xanjar t‑xoni pəškože The dagger of my brother has (golden) decorations (C5:3).

pəšmanta n.f. sorrow | qəm-ʾaryála pəšmànta| Sorrow seized her (A49:5).

pəšpəšyaθa n.pl. (sing. pəšpəšta) the first flakes of snowing that fall in a snow storm | ráya pəšpəšyàθa| the first flakes of snow are falling.

pəṣla n.m. type; form | liθ bəṛ-náša hátxa b-aw-pə̀ṣla díyux| There is nobody with such a (beautiful) figure as yours (A8:41); ʾu‑b‑ó pəṣlà| ʾi‑mtarṣíwa gùpta| In this way they used to make cheese (B5:171).

pəθwana n.m. (pl. pəθwane) stride, wide step | pəθwane zɛdi l-xure His strides exceed (in size those) of his friends (Qaṭina).

pəθya adj. (f. pθiθa, pl. pəθye) wide

pəθyo interj. achoo! (noise of sneeze) | wíðɛle pə̀θyo!| He went ‘achoo!’ (A4:60).

pəxla n.m. (pl. pəxle) young sheep or calf that has not yet been castrated

pilawe n.pl. (sing. pilawta) (K.) plastic shoes | ʾu-piláwe píšla šmìṭe| My shoes have become broken (A37:17).

pipa n.m. (pl. pipe) cage for partridge chicks made from a gourd

pista n.f. (pl. pisyaθa) leather bag ( for carrying jajək and yoghurt)

pišanga, pušanga n.m (pl. pišange, pušange) (K.) bullet, bullet cartridge | keptət pišanga the lead head of the bullet; masoqe pišanga gu-tope to load a gun; kú pušánga ṱ-íx mattóyəlle gu-d-ay-tòpe| čŭ̀ruk-ile pláṭa| Every bullet that we put in this gun comes out with a bang (B9:21).

pištamasi n.m. (K.) long chine of meat on the back of sheep in the shape of a fish

pixa adj. (f. pixta, pl. pixe) cool | b‑yárxət ʾə̀ṣra| xadə̀ssər| y‑óya pìxta dúnye| In October or November the weather is cool (B5:177).

plaša n.m. (pl. plaše) fighting; war | wéle pláša bēn‑ʾáskar‑t málkət ʾÌrən| ʾu‑ʾàw| There was a war between him and the army of the king of Iran (A11:16); qám‑plaša qamàya| before the First World War (B17:1).

plima adj. (f. plimta, pl. plime) crooked

pode pl.tan. puss from nose

poləθ n.m. (K./A.) steel

polise n.pl. (K./A./E.) police

posa (pl. pose) dry cow dung

poše n.f. goat having a white spot on the head | guði t‑ʾəzzi d‑ɛ‑poše My churn from my goat called ‘white spotted’ (C5:3).

pošiya n.f. (pl. pošiyaθa) (K.) festive headscarf (worn by women)

poza n.m. (pl. pozaze) (K.) snout, nostrils (of a sheep)

pozəkke, pozəkθa n.f. (pl. pozəkyaθa) (K.) nozzle

poθa n.f. root of madder used to dye clothes and colour eggs red at Easter

pqiθa n.f. (pl. pəqyaθa) blister, wart

prage n.pl. pearl millet | xa dandəkθət prage a single millet seed; prage maṭoye a type of millet that ripens quickly; prage kurize a type of millet that ripens slowly

praġe, praxe, prɛxe n.pl. (T.) stuffed vine leaves

prāq interj. bang

praqta n.f. (pl. praqyaθa) end

prasa n.m. (pl. prase) cloth spread on floor on which food is laid

prasta n.f. (pl. prasyaθa) goat’s skin spread on the floor

praza n.f. (pl. prazane) stubble field

prɛxe → praġe

prəzla n.m. iron | xa‑prǝ̀zla| a piece of iron (A14:12); šíšət prə̀zla| iron bars (A19:4)

prisa adj. (f. prista, pl. prise) spread out; famous

prista n.f. spread, covering for floor (such as rug or carpet)

priša adj. (f. prišta, pl. priše) different; special; various. (1) different | zrútət xə́ṭṭe prìštɛla| The cultivation of wheat is different (B5:94); pálṭi wɛ̀rde,| bɛ́hɛr y‑áwɛ príše prìše| Flowers come out, in Spring there are lots of different kinds (B5:176). (2) special, choice | rába xá‑mdi prìšɛla júllux gu-d-ánna diyɛ́ni| Your clothes are something very special compared with ours (A35:10); ʾína mástət ʾə́rwe rába biš‑basimtɛ́la biš‑príštɛla mən‑d‑a‑t‑tàwre| But the yoghurt of sheep is much better and more choice than that of cattle (B5:173). (3) various | Placed before the nominal: priše məndiyane various things.

prišayiθ adv. specifically, especially

prora adj. (f. prorta, pl. prore) open (space), spacious | dukθa prorta an open place, ʾurxa prorta an open road; ʾíθ dùkθa,| pròrtɛla,| máṣi mṭàli gáwa| There is a place that is open, in which they can play (B11:30).

psasa n.m. permission

pšima adj. (f. pšimta, pl. pšime) sad, regretful (of mistake)

pšiqa adj. (f. pšiqta, pl. pšiqe) explicit, specific

pšiṭa adj. (f. pšiṭṭa, pl. pšiṭe) simple, uncomplicated, sincere | rába pšìṭṭɛwa xayúθa díyən gu-maθwáθa| Our life in the villages was very simple (B15:12); ʾáti náša pšìṭɛwət| You are a fine person.

pṣixa adj. (f. pṣixta, pl. pṣixe) glad, happy

pṭoxa adj. (f. pṭoxta, pl. pṭoxe) broad, flat | parša pṭoxa a flat stone; bəṛ-gare pṭoxta a flat plateau

pθana n.m. (pl. pθane) pair, team (of draught animals); plough | pθánət tàwre| a pair of oxen (B5:73).

pθila n.m. (pl. pθile) twisted thread | xaθux patla pθile Your sister twists twisted threads (A50:15).

pθilta n.f. (pl. pθilyaθa) wick | šráya ʾítle pθíltət ktàna| A lamp has a wick of cotton.

pukta n.f. hiccups | qəm-doqáli pùkta| I had a bout of hiccups.

pumma n.m. (pl. pummăwaθa) mouth (of body or vessel); end of a spade | pumma pṭoxa wide end (of a spade)

punda n.f. (pl. punde, pundaθa) thick wick (burnt in church ceremonies) | mălə́xwa pundàθa| We would light wicks.

puqdana n.m. (pl. puqdane) command

puq‑əlli game of hide-and-seek | Literally meaning: Come to me! → ṭŭši‑ṭŭšo, ṭappu (B11:12ff.)

Purāt n.m. Euphrates

purəpxina n.m. purslane | herb that is put in jajək

purta n.f. sheep’s dung that has been broken up (mpurtəxa) by the trampling of their feet

purya n.m. light | hóle xa‑púrya láxxa zòra| There is a small chink of light here (A14:25).

puryana adj. (f. puryanta, pl. puryane) full of light, lightsome

pušiθa n.f. (pl. pušiyaθa) smelly fart made without noise

puwa n.m. hay from millet (prage)

puwuš n.m. hay from fibres of rice plant

pxiša n.m. paste made of flour and oil | also known as duwana



/q/

qa- prep. (with pronominal suffixes: qa-diye, qale) (§16.4., §19.3.11.) to, for; so that. (1) Recipient, objective or beneficiary: mə́re qa‑yə́mme dìye| ‘He said to his mother’ (A21:10); ʾáp-awwa šaqə́lla ðá-kista qa-d-ày,| yawə́lla qa-d-ày| He takes a purse for her and gives it to her (A4:22); qa-mo? qa-modi? why? (2) Destination: núbləlla qa-bráte dìye| He took them to his daughter (A17:13). (3) Temporal objective: qa-ṭḷà-yarxe| for three months (A17:22). (4) Object marker: băyéwa qa-ʾalàha| ‘He loved God’ (A16:10). (5) Before a clause expressing purpose or result: ṣráxɛle qa‑t‑šằma| brátət màlka| He is shouting so that the daughter of the king hears (A21:16); qímle b-zdáya m-bróne dìye| qa-t-là-ʾamər| He was afraid of his son and (as a result) did not tell (= He was afraid to tell his son) (A8:17).

qaba n.m. (pl. qabe) (K.) waistcoat | Xasắdo t‑šáwwa qábe ʾaw‑bə̀ṣlɛle| Xasădo who has seven gowns is an onion (D1:15).

qabūl adj. (invar.) (A.) acceptable | ʾap-ʾáyya qabū̀l-ila| That is acceptable (A6:8).

qăbux interj. battle cry | ʾáni qári qắbux l‑ġðàðe| They challenged one another to fight (A29:59).

qačamiθa n.f. waste grains falling from a water-mill | These are swept up and given to animals to eat.

qačax n.m. (pl. qačaxe) (K.) brigand

qačaxuθa n.f. brigandry

qăda n.m./f. (pl. qădaθa) (K./A.) calamity, trouble | tắra dwìra| qắda wìra| If the door is closed, trouble passes by (D2:47).

qadalta n.f. (pl. qadalyaθa) earthenware pot | xa‑qadáltə dàwe| a pot of gold (A10:7)

qadaša n.m. (pl. qadaše) goat with a dewlap

qadax n.m. (pl. qadaxe) (K.) stick, pole

qaddiša n.m. (pl. qaddiše) saint

qaddišta n.f. (pl. qaddišyaθa) saint (f.)

qadida n.m. (pl. qadide) dried salted meat (usually lamb) | This is dried on the bone by hanging

qădīm adj. (A.) old, ancient

qaḍiya, qaẓiya n.f. (A.) situation, affair | hátxɛla qaḍìya| The situation is like this (A21:8).

qadra, qădər n.m. (A.) amount; respect. (1) amount | yăðíwa mo‑qádra dɛrɛ̀wa| They knew what quantity to put on (B5:191); yáwa nišánqa ma‑qádrɛla mkawòre,| ma-qádrɛla qwìθa| It gives a sign as to how much (arak) is distilling, how strong it is; pšúṭla ʾàqlux| qắdər bărə̀kθux| Stretch your legs according to your cloth (D1:6). (2) respect | qəm‑dawǝ́qle qádra dìya| He showed them respect (A12:37).

qaḥbuθa n.f. (A.) whoredom

qăhər n.m. (A.) sadness | θéle qằhər‑ʾəlle| Sadness came upon him (A14:87).

qahwayi adj. invar. brown

qala n.m. (pl. qale) voice; utterance; song; sound. (1) voice | qále díye rába basìmɛwa| His voice was very beautiful (A25:43); léš‑maṣe-náša palə́ṭle qále dìye| A person can no longer utter his voice (B15:39); ʾímə ṱ-íle zmàra,| bulbúle jmáʾela l-qàle| When he sings, nightingales gather at his voice (A25:46). (2) utterance, shout | ṣríxɛle xa‑qála ràba xɛlána| He shouted a mighty shout (A11:3). (3) song | zmírre xa-qála b-súse dìye| He sang a song to his horse (A25:55). (4) sound | qálət maymùne| the sound of monkeys (A14:43); qalət tope gunshot; ʾáwwa mò-qalət bə́xyɛle?| What sound of weeping is this? (A4:44); ʾímət ʾàθya,| mzàngər zága,| ʾáxni šămə́xle qále ṱ‑árqəx mṭàšəx| When it (the cat) comes, the bell will sound, we shall hear its sound and run and hide (A44:2).

qăla, qalla n.f. (A.) citadel

qălama n.m. (pl. qălame) (A.) pen; protruding branch of a tree | qălamət xurta the protruding branches of willow; qălamət prəzla chisel

qalaša n.m. (pl. qalaše) (K.) corpse | ṭɛ́re xáləlla qalášət gùṛe| Birds are eating the corpses of men (B9:32).

qaləpθa n.f. peal; rind

qăləs adj. invar. (K.) miserly

qalɛθa n.f. (pl. qalayaθa) cell | qaddištət qalayaθa the Saint of the Cells (name of a church in Walto B9:30)

qaləb n.m. (pl. qalibe) (A.) mold

qalma n.f. (pl. qalme) louse

qalpa n.m. peal; bark; shell | xá-qapla qɛ̀se| t‑lá-hawa b-qàlpe| a bundle of pieces of wood that are without bark (A30:6); qalpət nune scales of a fish

qalta, qalθa n.f. (qalaθa, qalyaθa) basket (made of palm leaves) | This was made in the towns rather than the villages

qalula adj. (f. qalulta, pl. qalule) light, quick | xánči ṱ-amrə́nna qalùlta| qa-t-pàrqa| I’ll tell it (the story) to you quickly so that it will finish (A4:5).

qalunka n.m. (p. qalunke) (K.) pipe | garə́šwa tŭ́tun qalùnke| He used to smoke pipe tobacco (A10:9).

qalwa n.m. (pl. qalwe) wooden mold in which fabric is pressed

qalya n.m. (K./A.) meat roasted in fat and preserved for winter

qam prep. (with pronominal suffixes: qame) (§13.3.16.) before (spatial and temporal); in (adversity), from (adversity); on account of (adversity); instead of. (1) before (spatial) | qam-ʾɛ́nux| before your eyes (A15:15). Obstacle: muttɛ́θətwa qámi xa-ṭúrət skinyàθa| You had placed before me a mountain of knives (A24:33), hálli xá-məndi ṱ‑àxlən| t‑lá-pɛšən kə́twa qam-ʾàqlux| Give me something to eat so that I am not a thorn in your foot (A26:57). Duty: ʾána ʾíθ šùla qámi| I have a job to do (A24:45). Outside: qam-tăra outside the door (of the house), qámət gǝ̀ppa| outside the cave (A12:7). After verbs of movement: ṱ-azítu qam-d-o-gə̀ppa| You should go to the cave (A8:28), zíla, zíla zìla,| qam‑xákma ṭuràne| rába ràme| He went a long way (and came) to some very high mountains (A14:66). At the disposal of, for the benefit of: ʾáyya dəkkána qàməx| This shop is for you (to choose from as you wish) (A22:20); ʾáni daríwala qam-qənyàne| They would put them out for the animals (to eat) (B15:50). Leading animals: xa‑šăvána … y‑azǝ́lwa qam‑ʾǝ̀rwe| A shepherd used to go to look after sheep (A10:1), qu‑sí qam‑ʾǝ̀rwe!| Go and look after the sheep! (A10:5). In charge of: ṭaxána qam-ðà-ʾarxe| a miller in charge of a water-mill (A32:1). (2) before (temporal) | with a nominal: qám šáwwi tmáni šə̀nne seventy or eighty years ago (B5:179); qam-dàna| beforehand (A4:30); qam-mxɛ́θət madə̀nxa| before the rise of dawn (A8:51); ʾáw qam‑mə̀nnux hóle ʾə́θya láxxa| He has come back here before you (A22:39). With a clause complement: qam-ṱ-àθi| mpáləṭle mən-hàbsa| Before they return, release him from prison (A26:72). (3) in (adversity) | ʾup‑ʾàni| náše ʾi-xawšìwala| mattíwale gu-gòme| qá-t barzìwa,| qa-t-là-hawiwa qam-mə́ṭra| People would store these (pieces of wood) and put them in the basement to dry, so that they would not be in the rain (B15:19); ʾəθyewəx kope kope qam‑məṭra ʾu‑qam dalope We have come bending down in rain and drizzle (C1:14); maqðánnux qam‑šmàyya| I shall burn you in the sun (A12:31). (4) from (adversity) | In contexts expressing escaping from or sheltering from: ríqən qam-màmi| I have run away from my paternal uncle (A25:42); lɛ́ka b-šárṭət qam-ʾiθàθi?| Where can you escape from my hands? (A28:21); mṭášət qam-Lelìθa| Hide from Leliθa (A51:6); mṭošéle qam-tàlga| He sheltered from the snow (A28:3). (5) on account of (adversity) | ʾáskar kúlla mìtla| qam-qàle| All the army died on account of his voice (A52:13); šəlmanā̀t| dìpla| qam-xɛ̀la| The bars have bent due to the force (put on them) (A52:9); kšíple bɛ́θa qam‑tàlga| The house collapsed on account of the snow; tréle qam-mə̀ṭra| He was soaked on account of the rain. (6) instead of | ʾɛ́-ga qam-lámpa ʾíθwa šràʾa| At that time instead of an (electric) lamp there was an (oil) lamp (A33:1).

qama qama prep. in front of | With actions involving movement: ʾə́θyela tré malàxe,| pyáða qama-qámət čádra d-ò-malka| Two angels came, passing in front of the tent of the king (A4:2).

qamaya adj. (f. qamɛθa, pl. qamaye) first | yóma qamàya on the first day (A25:14); har-ʾánna qamàyela| They are the same as the ones before them (A27:27).

qamaye adv. at first | qamáye xírta b-áqlət súsa dìya| At first she looked at the legs of her horse (A8:72); ku‑brónət bə́ṛ‑naša ʾáθe l‑d‑áy jăzíra qamàye,| ʾáwwa ṱ‑áwe málka diyɛ̀xu| Whichever person comes to the island first, he will be your king (A14:46); y-azə́xwa kalə́xwa m-qamàye| We went and stood at the front (in the first row of the congregation) (B15:82); bǝ́nta qamàye for the first time (B5:1).

qamčiya n.m. (pl. qamčiye) (K.) leather whip | imported to the villages from towns

qa-mó adv. why?

qamoθ- prep. in front of | only used in expressions of meeting: xúwwe plíṭɛle l-qamòθe| The snake came out to meet him (A1:18); yáwəx xàbra| ta-t-pálṭi l‑qamòθən| We give word for them to come out to meet us (A4:30).

qamṣa n.m. (pl. qamṣe) grasshopper

qam-tăra adv. outside

qamxa n.m. flour | maṣlɛ́wala ʾə̀rxe,| ṭaxnìwala,| pɛ́ši qàmxa| They would take it (the wheat xəṭṭe) down to the water-mill and grind it and it would become flour (B5:15).

qamθa (1) adv. formerly | qàmθa| y‑aθéwa tálga ràba| Formerly a lot of snow would fall (B5:146). (2) prep. in front of | l-qámθe dìye| ʾíθ xa-čòl| Before it lies barren countryside (A8:21); m‑qámθa díya ṭùrɛle| In front of it there is a mountain (B4:1). Frequently used in expressions of meeting: ríqa qímle plíṭle qámθət bróne dìye| He ran out to meet his son (A14:95), ṣlí qamθə-d-áwwa nàša| Go down to meet this man (A15:6); pálṭən qámθux qam-tằra| I’ll come outside to meet you.

qana n.f. (pl. qanane) horn; horn container used to carry grease (məšxa) for applying to the whetsone (məšna); peak of a mountain | lá-mɛθət m‑an‑t‑qanàne| Do not bring those (sheep) with horns (A7:24); parxəx l‑qanət ʾAvraza Let us fly up to the peak of Avraza (C2:83).

qănăpa, qănăfa n.f. (pl. qănăpe, qănăfe, qănăpāt) (A.) armchair, sofa, couch

qanaθe n.pl. metal finger covers worn by harvesters

qanṭopa, qanṭepa n.m. (pl. qanṭope, qanṭepe) bunch | qanṭopət ʾənwe bunch of grapes

qanθa n.f. wild grass eaten by sheep

qăpaxta n.f. (pl. qăpaxyaθa) (K./T.) lid, cover

qapəlta n.f. embrace | xə́ṭṭe m-sənnòrta,| yála m-qapə̀lta| Wheat (is seen to be good) from when it is a shoot. A child (is seen to be good) from the time of (his mother’s) embrace. (D2:36)

qăpəx n.f. (pl. qăpəxyaθa) (K./T.) lid, cover | ta-ṱ-óðən qắpəx ʾàp ṭla-réšəx| until I make a lid also for your head (A20:3).

qapla n.m. (pl. qaple) armful; bundle carried in arms; arms | jămíwale y‑oðíwale qàpla| They gathered it (the rice hay) and made it into an armful (B5:84); xá-qapla qɛ̀se| a bundle of pieces of wood (A30:6); qápli hóle ṃḷàya| My arms are full (B15:89); qəm-šaqlánne gu-qàpli| I took him in my arms (B9:25); mə́xyəlle qáple bìye| dwìqəlle| He put out his hands and caught him (A29:31).

qapyo n.f. (pl. qapyowaθa) blockage; twigs and grass blocking flow of a water channel

qaqna n.f. (pl. qaqne) thorny plant | This is yellow in colour and grows in the mountains. When the sap sets it produces a gum known as deθa, which is softened in water and then chewed.

qăra n.m. (pl. qăre) pumpkin; gourd

qărăbalux n.f. (K.) din, noise

qărăčaya n.m. (K.) gypsy

qărama n.f. edible herb | fed to sheep to make them give more milk

qărana adj. (f. qăranta, pl. qărane) big; fully grown

qărār n.m. (A.) decision

qaraṣta, qarraṣta n.f. (pl. qaraṣyaθa, qarraṣyaθa) crowbar

qăratiθa, qarratiθa n.f. (pl. qăratyaθa) pieces of rasa grass fed to young lambs in a pen (kosta)

qarawət n.f. (pl. qarawətte) (A.) bed

qare n.f. (pl. qareyaθa) (K.) chicken coop | téla qəm-doqìle| mə́re ku‑mə́ndit băyítu wúðu bìyi,| bás gu-qáre t‑kθayáθa là dɛrɛ́tuli!| They caught the fox and it said ‘Do with me what you will, but do not put me in the chicken coop’.

qarəkke n.f. (pl. qarəkyaθa) (K.) crow

qarəkθonta n.f. (K.) little crow | qarə́kke qarəkθònti| O crow, my little crow (A34:3)

qarɛθa n.f. (pl. qarayaθa) reader

qăreθa n.f. (pl. qăreyaθa, qăraθa) vessel (for water and storage) made from a gourd

qareže n.pl. sweepings, rubbish

qarira adj. (f. qarirta, pl. qarire) cold, cool

qariwa n.m. (pl. qariwe) close friend; best man (at a wedding), godfather | qariwi my friend (said by a Christian to a Jew or vice versa).

qariwta n.f. (pl. qariwyaθa) bridesmaid; female companion of bride and groom at a wedding

qariθa n.f. (pl. qariyaθa) beam

qarmana n.m./adj. winner

qaroya n.m. (pl. qaroye) reader

qarqupθa n.f. (pl. qarqupyaθa) skull | qarqúpθe sapìqtɛla| His head is empty (he is a fool)

qarṣa → ʾaxəl qarṣa

qarša n.m. (pl. qarše) small wooden strip made of juniper laid across beams in a roof | kú ṱ‑íle ṣláya xo‑qárše ʾǝ̀ltəx,| pyáša dàwa| Everything that fell down under the beams became gold (A10:11). → syn. nira

qaruṭa adj. (f. qaruṭṭa, pl. qaruṭe) tough (food) | ʾə́nwə baṣírana qarùṭela| The baṣirana grapes are tough.

qaruθa n.f. coolness | buxára máṭe l‑qarùθa,| páyəš ṭə́pye ṭə̀pye| The steam becomes cool and turns into drops.

qarwən n.f. (pl. qarwane) (K./A.) caravan, convoy (of mules) that transports merchandise | y‑azíwa qàrwən| They would go in a convoy (B5:124)

qaryana n.m. (pl. qaryane) reader

qarθa n.f. cold | qàrθɛla| It is cold; t-lá-hoya qàrθa-ʾəlləx| so that you are not cold (A20:2).

qăsăla n.m. (pl. qăsăle) (K.) stem of corn plant

qăṣāṣ n.m. (A.) revenge, vendetta

qaṣore → qaṣra

qaṣra n.m. (pl. qaṣre) palace; large house (consisting of two storeys and made of dressed stones) | bráte díye muttúla qáṣre ʾu-qaṣòre| His daughter established villas and palaces (A40:7).

qaṣxane n.f. (pl. qaṣxane, qaṣxanwaθa, qaṣxanyaθa) brass cooking pot | used to warm milk to make yoghurt

qaṣxanta n.f. (pl. qaṣxanyaθa) small pan

qaša n.m. (pl. qaše) priest

qaška n.m. (pl. qaške) (K.) (§1.2.2.) dried cake of yoghurt (B6:42ff.)

qatta n.f. (pl. qattaθa) stick; handle of a knife, hilt of sword; sheath of a sword | qattət xanjare komta The handle of his dagger was black (C2:55); qəm‑maxéle bə-b-qàtta| He struck it (the sword) together with the sheath (A52:18).

qatxa n.m. (pl. qatxe) (A.) cup, goblet | ʾɛnile gawṛa m-guṛe … šatele qatxət šteli? Who is the man amongst men … who could drink the glass I have drunk?(A50:3)

qaṭ n.m. (pl. qaṭ) (K.) suit (of clothes); storey (of building

qaṭa n.m. (pl. qaṭe) cat, tomcat

qăṭifa n.f. (A.) velvet

qaṭira n.m. (pl. qaṭire) wooden beam joining oxen together

qaṭita n.f. (pl. qaṭiyaθa) walking-stick

qaṭiya m. (pl. qaṭiye) stick, goad; whip

qaṭlana n.m./adj. (f. qaṭlanta, pl. qaṭlane) murderer, murderous

qaṭola n.m. (pl. qaṭole) murderer

qaṭota n.f. (1) break in an irrigation channel (šaqiθa) to stop or redirect the flow of water | prí míya b‑qaṭòta!| Cut off the water flow! (2) cutting down of leaves; leaves that have been cut down (and gathered for fodder) | lítli qaṭóta ʾə̀ššeta| I do not have any gathered leaves this year. (3) dirt left in a sieve after sieving | cf. qəmmoṭa

qaṭra n.m. (pl. qaṭre) rock, boulder

qaṭu, qaṭuθa n.f. (pl. qaṭwaθa) (§10.9.) female cat; spiky type of oak gall

qaṭwa n.m (pl. qaṭwe) large wooden needle

qawa n.m. coffee

qawači n.m. (pl. qawačiye) (K.) man serving coffee

qawadən n.f. (pl. qawadane) (K.) coffee pot

qăwanīn n.pl. (A.) laws

qawda, qoda n.m. (pl. qawde, qode) shackle, bond | zaqra-qode spider (literally: weaver of shackles §2.4.2., §10.17.1.)

qawla n.m. (pl. qawle) word; promise; condition | ʾàwwɛle qawla-díyi| This is my word (A8:79); dwíqla xa-qáwla m‑an‑qurðàye| She extracted a promise from the Kurds (B9:12); b‑ó-qawla b-ṣályən mənnɛ̀xu| t-lá ʾamrítu púš qurðɛ̀θa| I shall go down with you on this condition that you do not say ‘Become a Kurd’ (B9:12).

qawmi adj. (A.) national

qawra n.f. (pl. qawre, qawraθa, qorăwaθa) grave

qawurma n.m. (T.) fried meat dish

qawwa n.m. (pl. qawwe) scoop, jug | tiwta b-qwaya b-qawwa She is sitting scooping with a scoop (C2:8).

qayəmθa n.f. (pl. qayəmyaθa) monument; statue

qayiš, qayiša n.m./f. (pl. qayiše) (K.) man’s belt made of leather → šəbbaqa

qaysi, qaysiya n.f. (K.) dried apricots

qaza n.m (pl. qaze) (K.) goose

qazba n.m. (pl. qazbe) (K.) date | ʾilanət qazbe date palm tree

qazd n.m. purpose, direction (K./A.) | yắðət módi-wawa qázde dìye?| Do you know what his intention was? (A17:16); wíðɛle qázd d‑ò‑bɛθa| He made his way towards that house (A14:75).

qazəd, qazədda n.m. (pl. qazədde) (K./A.) messenger; goal, objective | qímla kθúla xa‑kθàwa,| mšudə́rra bəd‑qàzəd She wrote a letter and sent it by a messenger (A11:17); ʾázən ʾóðən qázəd d-àwwa gə́ppa| ṱ‑áwðən qázədde dìye| I shall go and make for that cave. I shall make for it (A39:3).

qazi n.m. (A.) judge

qaʾəd n.m. (A.) leader

qbila adj. (f. qbilta, pl. qbile) accepted | ʾən-lá zɛrǝ́nna Qŭ̀dus,| lɛ̀la qbílta ḥajjiyúθi| If I do not visit Jerusalem, my pilgrimage is not accepted (A2:1).

qðala n.m. (pl. qðale) neck | pəlxánət bɛ́θa hóle b‑qðàli| The housework is my responsibility (A21:27); xṭíθi b-qðalɛ̀xu| bnóni qam-ʾɛ́ni là qaṭlítula| I implore you (literally: my sin be on your neck), do not kill my children before my eyes (B9:13)

qðilta n.f. (pl. qðilyaθa) key

qedamta n.f. (pl. qedamyaθa) morning | mən-sab-ʾɛ́-ʾotəx t-là-hawe gáwa ṣópa,| yáʿni pɛšáwa tàlga hal-qedámta| Since a room that did not have a stove in it would become icy by the morning (B15:26); hal-qedámta šə́nθe la-θèla| Right up to the morning he did not sleep (A6:4). qèdamtɛla,| wíðtəlle ʾixàla| (When) it was morning, she made him food (A24:4); wítɛla qedámta sáʾət ʾárpa b-lɛ̀le,| ṛìšɛle| màlka| (When) the morning came, four o’clock in the morning, the king woke up (A17:27). Used adverbially: in the morning | qédamta y‑ázi náše l‑ʾùmra| In the morning people go to church (B6:23); ʾu-qímli qedàmta,| la-xəzyàli| I got up in the morning and did not find her (A26:10-11); qedamta jalde early in the morning.

qeṭana n.m. woven silk lace | used to bind together pieces of fabric in clothing.

qɛma n.m. (pl. qɛme) stand, stake; tree supporting pile of leaves (garuta)

qɛsa m. (pl. qɛse) wood; piece of wood | maṛúθa mturáṣtɛwa m‑qɛ̀sa| The snow shovel was made of wood (B5:196); xákma qɛ̀se| several pieces of wood (A48:2); hóle síqa l‑qɛ̀se| He has come to (fetch) wood (A22:25); xa‑qɛ́sa rìxa| a long piece of wood (A22:26); qəm‑maxèle| … ʾəṣrá-qɛse gu-xáṣe dìye| He struck him ten strokes of a stick on his back (A30:14); ʾítle xa-yalə́xta mnuqàšta| l-bábe zqírta b-qɛ̀se| He had an embroidered handkerchief, which was woven by his father on the wood (of the loom) (A37:11); qɛsət malka type of wood used for making spoons; qɛsət xu‑rušane crutch.

qɛṭa n.m. (pl. qɛṭe) Summer

qəbla n.m. (pl. qəble) gift dedicated to the church at festivals (usually sheep or goat); meal in church dedicated to the memory of the dead | šawwí-qəble qbìlɛle He made seventy donations (A52:2)

qəčča n.m. (pl. qəčče) (K.) short rope tethering an animal to a stake | This is shorter than a xawəlta

qəččiθa n.f. (pl. qəččiyaθa) small piece of rope

qəfla → qəpla

qəlle n.f. (pl. qəllaθa) hawk

qəllora n.m. (pl. qəllore) (K.) large loaf made from flour of maize (xəṭṭə romaye), sorghum (xroriya) or prage (millet); head of maize

qəm- part. preverbal particle | forms past perfective of qaṭəl and qaṭəlwa with pronominal suffixes: qəm-qaṭəlle, qəm-qaṭəlwa (§8.6.3.)

qəmina adj. (f. qəminta, pl. qəmine) miserly

qəmmota n.f. dirt and stones remaining in a sieve after sieving

qənna n.f. (pl. qənne, qənnane, qənnaθa) nest

qənne n.pl. (sing. qənθa) walnut kernel

qənyane n.pl. (sing. qənyana) domesticated animals; cattle | ʾítli bas-xà qənyána| I have only one animal.

qənθa → qənne

qəpla, qəfla n.m. (pl. qəple, qəfle) (A.) metal lock

qəppo n.f. (K.) foam, froth | smóqe dɛrə́xwalɛ gu-mìye,| marəθə̀xwalɛ.| y‑áwe qə́ppo b-rèša.| We would put sumac berries in water and boil them. There was a froth on top. (B10:15)

qəqwana n.m. (pl. qəqwane) partridge | tré qəqwáne b-xà-kepa maxèwa| He would kill two birds with one stone (A8:35).

qəqwanta n.f. (pl. qəqwanyaθa) female partridge

qərda n.m. tragacanth shrub | deθət qərda curative ointment produced from the black resin of this plant

qərrušta, qrušta n.f. (pl. qrušyaθa) crust (of yoghurt, milk) | ʾo‑xə̀lya| dáwuqwa qrùšta| The milk would set (form yoghurt) with a crust (B5:165); qrúšte‑diye rába basimtɛ̀wa.| Its crust was delicious (B5:165); ʾu-màsta| ʾáxlət mə́nna qrúšta díya t‑la-xàrwa| You should eat the yoghurt without the crust being spoilt (A30:5).

qərša (i) n.m. (pl. qərše) covering; lid; crust (of yoghurt)

qərša (ii) n.m. stalks and remnants of leaves; refuse

qərṭa n.m. trimming (of trees) | y‑azə́xwa qə̀rṭa| We would go and trim (trees) (B5:140); qə́rṭət ʾə̀rwe| trimming (of trees to feed) small cattle (B5:206).

qərṭala n.f. (pl. qərṭale) pannier bag on the back of an animal | This was made of cane (čiqa thick cane and zala thin cane); mkase qərṭale n.f. late snow falling at the end of March (literally: the coverer of panniers).

qərṭalta n.f. (pl. qərṭalyaθa) small pannier bag

qərya adj. (f. qriθa, pl. qərye) educated | yə́mmi lɛ́wa qrìθa| My mother was not educated (B8:15).

qəsm n.m. (pl. qəsme) (A.) part | ʾawðánna trè‑qəsme| I shall make it into two parts (A21:28); ʾan-míya pɛ́ši trè-qəsme| The water will become (divided into) two parts (A24:14).

qəsmətta n.f. (K./A.) luck; fate | xázəx qəsmǝ̀ttila,| bálki qàrmən| Let’s see (whether) I am lucky, perhaps I shall win (A1:4).

qəṣqəṣta n.f. fine crushed rice

qəssa part. (A.) almost | qə́ssa pìdla| They have almost passed (A32:23).

qəṣṣət, qəṣṣətta n.f. (A.) story; affair | mòdila qə́ṣṣət?| What has happened? (A4:11); mǝ́re mòdila qə́ṣṣət díya?| mǝ́ra b-álaha qə́ṣṣət díya hàtxɛla| He said ‘What is her story? (= What has happened to her)’ She said ‘Well, her story is like this.’ (A4:14); mparqànnux m‑áyya qǝ́ṣṣət| I shall rid you of this business (A14:1).

qəšta n.f. (pl. qəštaθa) bow; sling | qəštət marən rainbow; qəšta-w gera bow and arrow.

qəštaniθa n.f. | qəštaniθət marən rainbow

qəšya adj. (f. qšiθa, pl. qəšye) hard; thick (liquid) | míya píšla qə̀šye| The water has become thick; ʾay-gə́rðo ʾa-qšìθa,| ta-duxràne,| ʾína bušála t-ʾoðə́xwala ṭlàlən,| xánči miyànta,| la-ràba| The gərðo, which is thick, is for church memorial festivals. But the stew, which we made for ourselves, was somewhat watery, though not too much (B10:17).

qəṭla n.m. killing, murder | ʾáwwa záwna t-xzélux dúnye ráya dèwe| ʾíwa záwnət qǝ́ṭla-w dǝ́mma-w pràma| This time when you saw it raining wolves, it was a time of killing, blood and slaughter (A1:24).

qəṭma n.m. ash | ʾáyya məškə́nta píštɛla mxàya| dráya qə́ṭma gu‑réša dìya| The poor woman began to beat (herself) and put ash on her head (A14:22); qə́ṭma b‑rèšux!| Confound you! (A23:8); qəṭma b-qaṣraθa (putting) ash on cooking pots to clean them

qəṭra n.m. (pl. qəṭre) arch; door arch; stone door frame | kepət qəṭra keystone of arch

qəṭrana adj. (f. qəṭranta, pl. qəṭrane) hunchbacked

qəṭṭa n.m. (pl. qəṭṭaṭe) piece | kúlla wíðəlla qəṭṭàṭe| He broke them all into pieces (A30:22); qəṭṭaṭət lina šmiṭa shards of a broken pot.

qəθra n.m. (pl. qəθre) knot | qəθrət šeta annual growth ring of tree.

qəθθurta n.f. (pl. qəθθuryaθa) knapsack (consisting of tied cloth) | synon. boqča

qima n.f (A.) value

qira n.f. (A.) tar

qirθa adj. f. barren | generally applied to animals, ʾəzza qirθa a barren goat, tawərta qirθa a barren cow, etc. baxta qirθa a barren women is unusual and a euphemism such as baxta t‑lɛ maθya yale a woman who does not bear children is preferred.

qixa adj. (f. qixta, pl. qixe) faded

qiya adj. m. (f. qiθa, pl. qiye) blunt | magla qiya a blunt sickle, skinta qiθa a blunt knife

qmaṭa n.m. (pl. qmaṭe) rope used for tightening | e.g. the two shafts of a stone roller (mandorta)

qmiṭa adj. (f. qmiṭṭa, pl. qmiṭe) tied up | qmiṭa b‑ġðaðe tied together

qoč̭a → koč̭a

qodəšta n.f. (pl. qodəšyaθa) small bunch of grapes | section of a gujma (large bunch)

qola n.m. (pl. qole) metal springed trap (for animals)

qolaxine n.pl. (sing. qolaxina m.) (K.) pelvis bones of an animal, above the rump (kamaxe)

qoma n.m. (pl. qome) pile | ʾu‑ʾan‑baxtàθa| kapšìwale,| napṣíwale gu‑d‑a‑npàṣta| ʾu‑mattíwale l‑qóma báθər xàṣey| The women would gather it (the rice hay) and shake it with the shaking (just mentioned) and put it into a pile behind their back (B5:85).

qonəx, qunəx, qunaxa n.m. (pl. qonaxe, qunaxe) (K./T.) stage of journey; guesthouse; feast. (1) stage of journey, milestone | qunáxət ṭḷáθa yomáθa qəm-azə́lla b-xamšà daqíqe| He travelled a stage of three days (journey) in five minutes (A8:39); ʾáp‑ʾaw qúnəx ṭḷáθa mǝ́ṭye l‑qàṣra| and on the third day’s stage (of the journey) they arrived at the palace (A12:11); ʾɛ́kɛle qonàxux?| Where is your destination? (2) guesthouse | xa‑qúnəx wíðəlle tàza| He made a beautiful guesthouse (A12:22). (3) feast, banquent | wúð qunáxa gòṛa| Make a big feast (A8:89).

qopa adj. (f. and pl. qope) (K.) hunchbacked

qoqa n.m. (pl. qoqe) water pot

qoqta n.f. (pl. qoqyaθa) small water pot

qoṱiya n.f./m. (pl. qotiye) (K.) small box; mirror | qoṱiyət burnuṭ snuff box

qramta n.f. cover | qrámtət šə́rma darmánət bušàla| The cover of the buttocks is the substance of the stew (D1:13).

qraqəpta n.f. (pl. qraqəpyaθa) small turtle

qraqipa n.m. (pl. qraqipe) turtle

qrəmṭa m. (pl. qrəmṭe) wrinkle | npílla qrə́mṭe gu‑pàθe| His face has wrinkles

qrixa adj. (f. qrixta, pl. qrixe) white-haired; whitewashed

qrušta → qərrušta

qudme adv. (Urm.) tomorrow; yesterday

qudša n.m. holiness | róxət qúdša The Holy Spirit (B6:8)

quja n.m. (pl. quje) (K.) marten | hunted for their fur

qujta n.f. (pl. qujyaθa) female marten

qulaya n.m. (pl. qulaye) clod of earth

qulba n.m. (pl. qulbe) (A.) bracelet

qulčiva n.m. (K.) trigger in the bird trap known as ṱăp̭əkke, ṱăp̭əkθa

qulənga n.m (pl. qulənge) (K.) crane (bird)

qulqulta n.f. (pl. qulqulyaθa) rods in wooden door lock | These are raised by the key to release the bolt

qulta n.f. (pl. qulyaθa, qultaθa) metal springed trap (for an animals) | This was mostly used to catch foxes and rabbits

qumārči n.m. (pl. qumārčiye) (K./A.) gambler

qŭmāš n.m. (pl. qŭmāšāt) (A.) fabric

qumma n.m. (pl. qumme) peak (of a mountain)

qumta n.f. (pl. qumyaθa) stature, figure; height (of a man), mound of snow | qumta zala t-gu-Nērwa Her figure is (that of) a reed in Nerwa (C2:43); θéle tálga b-qumyàθa| The snow came in mounds (= a great quantity of snow fell); gu-réšət ʾAmedíya y-aθéwa tálga qúmtət bəṛ-nàša| At the top of Amedia snow used to fall to the height of a man (A25:41); síqɛwa tálga qúrbət tre-qumyàθa| The snow had almost reached twice the height of a man (B15:38).

quna n.f. (pl. qune) (K.) buttocks | ʾo-t-dáwəq nùne| tárya qùne| One who catches fishes gets his buttocks wet (D2:26).

qunaxa → qonəx

qundăre n.pl. (sing. qundarta) (K./T.) leather shoes with heals

qundaxa n.m (pl. qundaxe) (K.) (wooden) butt of a rifle; bullet of a gun

qunəx → qonəx

qunjəlta n.f. (pl. qunjəlyaθa) (K.) corner | zílla dwíqla náwba l-ăyàʾha qunjə́lta t-hódəx,| ʾáyya gu-d-ɛ-qunjə́lta xèta| They went and kept a guard in that far corner, and one in that other corner (A18:3).

qunjiθa n.f. (pl. qunjiyaθa) corner; end | qunjiyáθe dìye| d‑áy mandòrta| y‑áwa bə̀zye| The ends of the roller are bored (with holes) (B5:193).

qunya n.m. (pl. qunye) hole; well | qəm‑darə́tli gu‑d‑áwwa qùnya| You have put me in this hole (A14:23); Qučanəs qunye qunye, Mar Šəmʾon t-kulla dunye Qučanəs of wells, wells, Mar Shimon (patriarch) of the whole world (C1:18).

qupa n.m. (pl. qupe) wicker basket used for storage

qupiθa n.f. (pl. qupyaθa) small basket

quppe n.f. (pl. quppaθa, quppeyaθa) brooding-hen

quprana → k̭uprana

quraṣina n.m. (pl. quraṣine) nettle

qurba n.m. adv. adj. vicinity; near, nearby; approximately. (1) vicinity | mǝ́ṭyela l-qúrbət qáṣrət màlka| They came to the vicinity of the palace of the king (A24:24). Used adverbially: mṭíθɛla qúrbət qàṣra| He came to the vicinity of the palace (A27:31); ʾə́θyɛle qùrba| He came up close (A4:55); θéle qùrbi| He came near to me; qùrbɛwa d-ɛ-xayúθə díyən| ṱ‑i-xăyə́xwala gu-maθwàθa| It was similar to the life that we lived in the villages (B15:9); ʾan‑ṱ‑ìla qúrbi qúrbi| those who are very near me (B11:24). (2) Attributive adjective (§14.7.): nearby qaṣra qurba a nearby palace, maθa qurba a nearby village. (3) approximately, about | ʾína palṭíwa qúrbət tre-ṭḷáθa ʾálpe nàše| About two thousand people would go out (B15:62), ʾáni qúrbət ʾə́ṣra trésər šənnèwa| They were about ten or twelve years old (B15:32), qúrbət trè-metre| around two metres (B15:31).

qurbana n.m. holy communion; host | y-oðíwa qurbàna| They would take communion; gu‑d‑ɛ‑dána mšɛríwa wáða rázət qurbàna| Then they began to perform the communion ceremony (B5:56); qurbánux brìxa!| Blessed communion (said at a saint’s festival); qurbána mattíwa gu‑pummèy| They would put the communion host in their mouth (B16:16).

qurðaya, qurdaya n.m./adj. Kurd, Kurdish | lišana kurdaya Kurdish language.

qurdəθ, kurdəθ adv. in Kurdish | kùrdəθ‑ila| It is Kurdish (A12:15)

qurmuz n.m. red, scarlet; wool dyed red

qurniθa n.f. (pl. qurniyaθa) corner | line spiqe l‑qurniθa The wine jars are empty in the corner (C2:27).

qurrabaška n.m. (pl. qurrabaške) (K.) badger

qurša n.m. frozen snow | tálga lɛ́le šmàṭa,| píšle qùrša| The snow does not break, it has become frozen; qəm-daríle rəš-qùrša| They have neglected him (literally: they have put him on the ice).

qurṣəlta n.f. (pl. qurṣəlyaθa) elbow; square (instrument used in carpentary); bend in chimney pipe on the roof (to prevent rain and snow from entering chimney)

qurta n.m. (pl. qurte) (K.) vulture

qurṭana n.m. (pl. qurṭane) blanket put on the back of an animal made of compacted wool | a softer blanket known as sarpəšta was put under this

qurʾən n.m. Qur’an

quṣarta n.f. (pl. quṣraθa, quṣariyaθa) cooking pot | quṣárta xsípla l‑pùmma| bráta plíṭla l-yə̀mma| A pot has been turned upside down—the girl has come to resemble her mother (D2:35); xošébə bnàθa| qə́ṭma b‑quṣràθa| On Girls’ Sunday there was (washing) ash in the cooking pots (i.e. the people fasted and washed their pots rather than using them for cooking) (B7:5).

quṣriya n.m. (pl. quṣriye) pot for collecting urine and excrement of baby under a cot

quṭa n.m. (pl. quṭe) virgina

qutana n.f. (pl. qutane) shirt | qutáne blèla| His shirt was worn out (A37:13)

quṭna kəri n.m. tough plaster containing straw | applied as first coating on wall

qutna n.m. (pl. qutne) woman’s vest

qutta adj. (f. qutte, pl. qutte) (K.) with a short tail or lacking a tail

qutta n.m. (pl. qutte) (K.) dwarf

quwāt n.pl. (A.) forces

quwwət n.f. (K./A.) force, strength | ʾána hon-muθɛ́θa ʾáyya qùwwət láxxa| I have brought this (military) force here (A25:84).

quwya adj. (f. qwiθa, pl. quwye) strong, hard, tough | xá-dukθa ṱ‑íwa qwìθa| A place that was hard (i.e. had solid foundations) (B15:16); réše qùwyɛle| He is stubborn; ṭríθa qùwya| She rode hard (A8:70).

quwyana adj. (f. quwyanta, pl. quwyane) hard, tough

qyamta n.f. resurrection; Easter, Easter vigil | šábθa ʾaṣə̀rta| mrazgíwa gyána qa‑t‑ṣálɛ qyàmta| On Saturday evening they prepared themselves to go down (to church) for the Easter (vigil) (B5:53); dánət plíṭla qyàmta| The time when the resurrection has come out (point in Easter vigil when Christ’s resurrection is celebrated) (B5:54); qyámtət màrən| qímle màrən| The resurrection of our Lord. Our Lord has risen. (Easter blessing by priest to worshippers) (B5:55); bàθər qyámta| after Easter (B10:2).



/r/

raʾsan adv. (A.) immediately, directly

raba mod. much, a lot, many; very (§14.9.3.). (1) much, a lot, many | rába tàlga much snow (B10:47); ʾan‑yomáθa ṱ‑awéwa ràba séra| the days when there was a lot of moonlight (B11:3); šúla ràba a lot of work (B5:19); zúze ràba| a lot of money (A27:18); líθwa šuláne ràba| There were not many jobs (B11:17). Used independently: ṭla-d-áy dráyɛla xàčča| ṭla-d-áw ràba| For herself she pours out a little and for him a lot (A17:25). Intensifier of a verb: ʾáti ràba băyánnux| I love you a lot (A22:19); ràba xðéle b‑d‑a‑bràta| ‘He was very happy with the girl’ (A14:96). (2) very | xa-yála rába šapìra| a very handsome youth (A25:58); ʾó‑lɛša páyəš raqíqa ràba| The dough becomes very fine (B6:46); basíma ràba (May you be) very well (= Thank you very much). adj. big, abundant, numerous, many | ʾə́θyele xa‑máymun ràba| A big monkey came (A14:45); píšla máθa ràbθa| It has become a big village (B10:94); ʾíθwa qáṣre ràbe| There were big villas (B10:52); məndiyáne rábe many things (A27:17); rábe gúṛe y‑awðìwala| Many men (were needed to) make it (B10:79); heywáne ràbe-wawa| The animals were numerous (A27:36). Used independenly: lɛ́ðiwa ràbe| Fárxo màṭole| Many people did not know what Farxo was like (A25:78).

rabbana n.m. (pl. rabbane) monk

rabbanta n.f. (pl. rabbanyaθa) nun

rabbanta n.f. type of black bird with red breast

rabbən n.m. (pl. rabbane) monk

răbəṭ n.m. (A.) rivet | qəm-awə́dle rằbəṭ.| ʾánna t-maxɛ́-răbəṭ,| rắbəṭ, rắbəṭ kúlla maxèle| sɛ́pe díye ta-t-la-gàrəš| He riveted it. (He was one) of those people who did riveting. He riveted all his sword so that he could not draw it (A52:11).

rabi n.m. (pl. rabiye) teacher

răhan n.m. (A.) pledge, bet | də̀ryəlla| ʾar-rằhan| They made a bet (B19:4)

raḥat, rahat adj. invar. (K./A.) comfortable, at ease, content | ʾə́θyət ràḥat,| ʾən-là?| Have you had a comfortable journey? (A17:6); kúlla heywáne píšla ràḥat| All the animals were content (A46:4); bàbi| ràhat!| My dear, be quiet, calm down (C7:6).

rakawa n.m. (pl. rakawe) rider

rakixa adj. (f. rakixta, pl. rakixe) soft

rakka n.m (pl. rakke) (K.) cage

rama adj. (f. ramta, pl. rame) high | xá‑dukθa ràmta| a high place (A14:87). adv. above | bíš y‑awéwa ráḥat ràma| It was more comfortable above (B5:204); ʾu‑ʾáwwa gárewa ràma| He was high up on the roof (B5:42).

ramana adj. (f. ramanta, pl. ramane) high | xa-ṭúra ramàna| a high mountain (A8:21); ṣáwle … ramàne| high(-heeled) shoes (B10:41)

ramša n.f. (pl. ramšaθa) evening | ramšɛ́xu ṭàwa!| / ramšɛ́xu brìxta!| Good evening! ṣloθət ramša evening prayer; xa-ramša evening meal.

ramuθa n.f. height | xamší-metre ramùθe| Its height was fifty metres (A25:54).

randuš n.f. (pl. randušyaθa, randuše) plane (of carpenter)

ranga n.m. (pl. range) colour | čay mare‑ranga strong tea; range-range multicoloured; rangət ʾumra place near church in Ɛn Nune where people hold social gathering

rangana adj. (f. ranganta, pl. rangane) colourful | čay ranganta strong tea

rangaya adj. (f. rangɛθa, pl. rangaye) colourful

rap interj. swoosh (sound of sudden movement)

rapa (i) n.m. (pl. rape) (K./A.) flock (of birds) | rápət qəqwàne| a flock of partridges (B5:148); barbiye rape rape The bridesmaids are in flocks and flocks (B8:23).

rapa (ii) n.m. (pl. rape) gate of animal pen

rapəkθa n.f. (pl. rapəkyaθa) cup measure for grain

rapiθa n.f. (pl. rapiyaθa) small gate of animal pen

rapopta n.f. rash on skin

răqaba n.f. (A.) observation point

raqaða n.m./adj. (pl. raqaðe) dancer | rába raqáðetu You are good dancers (A51:19).

raqiqa adj. (f. raqiqta, pl. raqiqe) thin | šála raqìqa| a thin veil (B10:32).

raqqa n.m. (pl. raqqe) flat bread

rasa n.m. (pl. rase, rasane) tall thick grass used as animal fodder | šəprət rasa plot of land on which rasa grass is grown; pašxa rase (f.) late snow in the month of Nisan (literally: breaker of rasa grass); ʾo‑t‑y‑awéla ʾə́rwət xwàre,| yáwilɛ ràsa| A person who has sheep gives them rasa grass (B5:123).

rasən adv. (A.) directly

rasmi adj. invar. (A.) official

răṣāṣ n.m. (A.) lead

rašən n.f. (E.) ration; consignment of produce

rašiya n.m./adj. (pl. rašiye) wicked person; evil | b-núrət rašíye y-áqði məskène| By the fire of wicked people the poor burn (D2:73).

rašmevi n.m. (K.) type of grape that ripens quickly | ʾənwət rašmevi

rašwa n.f. (A.) bribe

raθa n.f. (pl. raθa, raθe, raθyaθa) lung | raθət yamne ʾu‑raθət čappe the right lung and the left lung

răwatəb n.pl. (A.) pay, salary

rawaya n.m. (pl. rawaye) drunkard

rawðana n.m. (pl. rawðane) earthquake | ʾắra mxéla rawðàna| The earth quaked.

rawəkke n.f. little rawe

rawiya n.m. (pl. rawiye) large leather water bottle

rawola n.m. (pl. rawole) ravine, small valley

rawulta n.f. (pl. rawulyaθa) small ravine

raxaša n.m. (pl. raxaše) walker

raxmana adj. (f. raxmanta, pl. raxmane) merciful

raxme n.pl. mercy, compassion (sing. raxma act of mercy) | ṣléla ráxme gu-lǝ́bbə d-án polìse| The policemen felt compassion in their hearts (A8:11); b-raxme! Bless you! (said to somebody who sneezes); yá-babət ràxme| O father of mercies (addressing God) (A31:6); wúdli xa-ráxma mən-d-àwwa náša| Perform an act of mercy for me with this man (A31:6).

raxoša n.m. (pl. raxoše) (1) crutch, stilt. (2) large mixing tool shaped like a crutch

raxšana n.m. (pl. raxšane) walker

ray n.f. (K./A.) opinion | ráyux mòdila?| What is your opinion? (A27:7).

raza n.m. (pl. raze) mass (in church) | y-awə́xwa mašmòye| ʾu‑xzàya‑w| qàše-w| wáða ràze| We used to listen and see the priests performing the mass (B15:3).

razi adj. (invar.) (K./A.) pleased, happy, agreeable | razítu ʾə̀n‑la?| Do you agree or not? (B5:2); ʾən-hóya rázi šə́nna díya pălàla,| … maqimə̀xle| If she is agreeable to sharing her years, … we shall resurrect him (A4:46); ràzi díye| his pleasure (A8:57).

razwana ‘guard of orchard (machine)’ Kurd. r̭ezvan m.

razwana n.m. (pl. razwane) (K.) machine to frighten away birds in a vineyard or orchard | This makes a banging noise. It operates by water from an irrigation channel filling a tray. When the water evaporates the arm of the machine rises and hits a tin, which makes a noise.

rečəl n.m. dairy products

rēš-, rəš-, rš-, š- prep. (with pronominal suffixes: reše) (§13.3.19.) upon | rēš‑bə́rka dìya| on her knees (B5:175), hóla rəš-ṭùra| She is on a mountain (A20:2), də́ryəlla š‑qaràwət| They put her on the bed (A21:7), múttəlla rš-d-àn bəsmáre| He placed them on the nails (A17:28); l-xóðe rəš-ʾɛ̀na| He is alone by the well (A28:11). After verbs of movement: zílle rəš-ʾɛ̀na| He went to the spring (A15:2); zílta š‑tanùra| She has gone to the oven (A38:4); ʾánna ríqela síqela rəš‑d‑ay‑ʾilána mə‑zdùθa| They ran and climbed the tree out of fear (A13:11); wítɛla b-réši ʾup‑ʾàyya| This also happened to me (B15:85). Idioms: rəš‑réši by all means (expressing assent), ʾáhlan wa‑sáhlan rəš‑rèši| You are very welcome (A22:24); b-šɛ̀na,| š-rèši| A hearty goodbye (A8:50). Combined with b-: b-réša over them (A25:48); mút ṱ-áwəð b-rèše?| What will he do to him? (A30:27).

reša adv. above; directly | ʾáw xá-reša m-táma qú-si l-bɛ̀θa.| He—directly from there get up and go home! (narrative imperatives §15.7.) (A1:19); ṱ-ázəx xa-rèša| We shall go immediately (B9:15).

reša n.m. (pl. reše, rešăwaθa) head; top; beginning. (1) head (of body)| dríθa xə̀ppo b-réša| She had put a veil on her head; ʾu‑mútte párre gu‑rèša| They have put feathers on their head (B5:47); ʾáyya-ži šōp-rèšux-ila| That is the place of your head (A24:51). Referring by synecdoche to whole person: réšux ṱ-áwe basìma| May you (literally: your head) be healthy (said to a person who has been recently bereaved). In oath: b‑rèšux| mó ʾamràna?| By your head, what should I say? (A26:33). (2) head (of animals) | mə́ṭyɛle xa-káwtət ʾə̀rwe,| ʾíbe tre-ṭḷáθa ʾálpa rēš-ʾə̀rwe| He came to a flock of sheep, in which there were two or three thousand head of sheep (A32:14). (3) head person, leader (pl. rešane) | rešət maθa village leader. (4) head (of an instrument) (pl. rešaθa) | rešət maṛa the head of spade. (5) head (of vegetables) | xá-reša tùma| a head of garlic (B10:19). (6) round (of cheese) | Produced by draining in a muslin bag: šqílli mə́nni qə́ṭṭa m-réšət gùpta| I took with me a piece from the round of cheese. (7) top, peak, tip (pl. rešăwaθa) | ʾilanɛni t‑xabušta m‑reša‑w šətta mnoqašta Our apple tree is decorated from top to bottom (B8:29); hóla gu-réšət xa-ṭúra ramàna| She is on the top of a high mountain (A8:21); xazdə́xwa gəllále gu-rešăwaθa bélən bḗl Turkàye| We would would harvest herbs on the (mountain) tops between us and the Turks; réšə lišáne the tip of his tongue (A45:1). (8) beginning | Temporal: rešət ṣawma the beginning of the fast. Spatial: málka tíwa gu-rèšət máθa| The king lived at the top (i.e. beginning) of the village (A25:1). (9) Idioms: reša xtaya upside down; downhill | réša xtáya kúlle mǝ̀lxɛle| Down hill it is all salt (A24:12); ṣlíθɛla reša-xtàya| She went down head first (A8:76); léwət ʾàti| ʾɛ-bráta ṱ‑in-ʾána wíðəlla gáni k̭óra b-rèšəx| Are you not the girl on account of whom I made myself blind (A16:7); twíra twíra réše díye m‑rēš‑d‑àyya‑wawa| It was because of her that his head was all broken (A29:29); b‑rèšux| (I swear) by your head (that I am telling the truth) (A22:39).

reša reša prep. over, across | with actions involving movement: har‑ʾə́θyɛle mən‑ṭúra réša‑reša d‑o‑gàre| He came straight from the mountain across that roof (A23:14); b‑xə́lmi zála reša‑réša ða‑yáma rába gòṛta,| yáma xwàrta| In my dream I went across a great sea, a white sea (A11:7); m-ɛ́ka mɛθə́nne bəzmàre| ʾu-nasàrta,| ta-ṱ-oðə́nne gə̀šra| šàwər réše réše| From where should I bring you nails and a saw to make him a bridge across which he could jump? (A17:9).

rešaya adj. (f. rešɛθa, pl. rešaye) first class, excellent, special | zamára rešàya-wewa| He was a first class singer (A7:6); píšle rešáya gu-máθa ʾàwwa| He became a leading figure in the village (A39:22); qamáye ʾo-rešáya šaqlǝ̀xwale| ta-jùlle| First we took the best (of the spun wool) for clothes (B1:49); xa-bɛ́θa rába góṛa rešàya| a large luxurious house.

rexana, rixana n.m. (pl. rexane, rixana) basil; odiferous herb; perfume | qumta rixana balla Her figure is (that of) an erect odiferous basil (C2:44).

reza n.m. (pl. reze) (K.) row | kút y-azə́lwa zayə̀nwa,| píše xá ʾarb-ə́mma xamš-ə́mma náše réza rèza| Everybody who went would stand, about four or five hundred people, in rows (A8:31); hóla dwíqe kúlla rèza| They were all standing in a row (A25:29).

rəð̣ya, rəḍya adj. (f. rð̣iθa, pl. rəð̣ye) (A.) content, satisfied

rəḥqa n.m. adv./adj. distance; distant. (1) distance | xá‑bena xzéle m‑rə́ḥqa xá‑mdi xwàra| He suddenly saw in the distance something white (A14:28). Used adverbially: muttɛ́θəlle rə̀ḥqa| mən-màθa| She put him down far away from the village (A19:3); rǝ̀ḥqɛle qáṣra| The palace is in the distance/is distant (A24:48). (2) Attributive adjective: distant, far (§14.7.) | qaṣra rəḥqa a distant palace; maθa rəḥqa a distant village. (3) Idioms: y‑azíwa mšamšíwa bɛθ-qòra,| rə́ḥqa mən-an-dukàne| They would hold a ceremony in the cemetery—may (death) be far from these places! (formula used when referring to a cemetery or death) (B10:3); šáwpe rə́ḥqa m‑áxxa jyára də̀mma| Pardon me (literally: may its place be far from here)—he was urinating blood (A18:24).

rəjba m. (pl. rəjbe) crawling creature, reptile | rǝ́jbət ʾằra| wildlife (A12:36).

rəmya adj. (f. rmiθa, pl. rəmye) woeful; accursed | rəmyàθa hawetúwa!| May you be cursed! (A26:27)

rənga n.m. ringing sound

rəpya adj. (f. rpiθa, pl. rəpye) lazy

rəpθa n.f. (pl. rpaθa) throb, pulse

rəqða n.m. (pl. rəqðe) dance, dancing

rəqqi n.f. (K.) stubbornness | dwíqla rə̀qqi| She insisted (A5:7); ʾáni har-doqíwa rə́qqi ṱ-azìwa| They still insisted on going (A8:26); bas-ta-rə́qqi b‑yawə́nnəx qa-xa-náša špíla gu-tanùra| but out of stubbornness (= against your will), I am going to give you to a paralysed man (living) in an oven (house) (A40:3).

rəqqiyana adj. (f. rəqqiyanta, pl. rəqqiyane) stubborn, obstinate

rəsqa, rəzqa n.m. (pl. ʾarzāq) (A.) sustenance

rəšta n.f. (pl. rəšyaθa) head of a slaughtered animal | rəšta‑w ʾaqle dish consisting of the cooked head and limbs of an animal

rəzda n.f. (pl. rəzde) scree, row of rock debris on the side of a mountain

rəzya n.m. dye produced from walnut peal

rəzyana adj. (f. rəzyanta, pl. rəzye) dark in colour (especially colour of walnut peal)

rəzza n.m. (pl. rəzzane) rice | rə́zza smòqa| red rice (cooked with tomatoes) (B5:48); rə́zza y‑awéwa ʾo-t‑ṭḷàθa| The rice was the third one (in the degree of fineness, i.e. after the third sieving) (B10:13).

rixa n.m. (pl. rixe) smell | míxɛle ʾína ríxət xàmra| He sniffed and smelt the odour of wine (A12:50); kálba šqílle rìxa| t-xa-kàlləš| The dog smelt a carcass (C8:5); har-ʾásqən gu-qáṣrət bàbi,| har‑šáqlən rìxa mə́nne| I shall just go up to my father’s palace, I shall just have a quick look (literally: I shall take a smell of it) (A18:16); šawqíwale l‑šə̀mša| barə́zwa ta‑t‑là‑yawəlwa ríxa| They left it in the sun to dry, so that it would not give off a smell (B7:20).

rixa adj. (f. rixta, pl. rixe) long

rixana → rexana

riyaḍa n.f. (A.) sport

rkawta n.f. riding; copulation

rkewa n.m. (pl. rkewe) stirrup

rmɛθa n.f. (pl. rmayaθa) udder

roma n.m. (pl. rome) hill

romta n.f. (pl. romyaθa) small hill | xzeli zina rəš-romta I saw a person standing on the hill (C2:55)

roxa n.f. spirit | ya-ʾàlaha| hal-róxa qa-d-ánna náše ṱ-ila píše kèpa| Oh God, give spirit to these people who have become stone (A8:82); ṣléle róxət qúdša mən‑šmáyya The Holy Spirit descended from Heaven (B6:8).

rpapa n.m. (pl. rpape) blink, wink | rpapət ʾɛna blinking of the eyes; b-xá rpápa mṭéle tàma| He arrived there in a blink (of the eye).

rpoxa adj. (f. rpoxta, pl. rpoxe) loose | šəbbaqa rpoxa a loose belt (anton. xloṣa tight)

rubar n.m./f. (pl. rubare) (K.) river | rubarət ʾAmediya the river of Amedia (C2:41)

rŭbaʿ n.m. (A.) quarter

rumxa n.f. (pl. rumxaθa, rumxe) spear | məxyále rúmxe díye gu-ṣádrət ʾáwwa Tắtar-i Slemán-i Sə̀ndi| He drove his spear into the chest of Tătar-i Sleman-i Səndi (A28:36).

ruqta n.f. spittle

ruša n.m. (pl.rušane) shoulder; arm; upper arm | cf. drana lower arm

rušma n.m. (pl. rušme) sign | ʾoðíle rúšma ʾax‑ṣlìwa| They make for him a sign like a cross (B6:36).

rušta n.f. (pl. rušyaθa) small flat spade (with a head resembling a shoulder blade) | used, for example, for flattening paddy field basins (məššare)

ruta n.f. (pl. rutaθa) Friday

rutba n.f. (A.) rank

rzaya n.m. will, consent | ʾu-čú bəṛ-náša la-máṭe-lla ʾə́lla b-rzáyət gána-diya ṱ-àθya| Nobody can reach her, but rather she comes of her own will (A8:65); t-la-rzáyət marăwáθa dìya| without the consent of her parents.



/ṛ/

ṛiṛe pl. tan. slobber, drivel

ṛiya n.m. (pl. ṛiye) (Ṭiy.) shepherd


/s/

sab, săbab, m-săbab part. because | ʾắraq mpalṭə̀xla| m‑yabìše,| sab‑ɛ́‑ga xúrme lìθwa táma| They would produce arak from raisins, because at that time there were no dates there (B5:12); šábθa ʾaṣə̀rta| mrazgíwa gyána qa‑t‑ṣálɛ qyàmta,| sab‑qyámta b‑lɛ̀le ʾiyáwa| On Saturday evening they prepared themselves to go down (to church) for the Easter (vigil), because Easter was at night (B5:53); ʾámər ṭla‑mòdi bráti?| mə́ra sắbab ʾáwwa yàla| ʾo‑t‑la‑pàləx| lè y‑áxəl| He said ‘Why, daughter?’ She said ‘Because this young man (has made a rule that) whoever does not work will not eat (A21:29); m-sắbab ʾup-yárxət šáwwa-w tmànya,| m-bar-sáʾat ʾə̀č̣č̣a b-lɛ́le,| mšắre xánči qàrθa wáya| This was because even in July and August, after nine o’clock at night, it started to get rather cold (B15:27).

sadana n.m. (pl. sadane) anvil

sadda n.m. (pl. sadde) dammed section of paddy field consisting of a row of basins (məššare)

saðuθa → sahðuθa

saġðana, saxðana n.m. (pl. saġðane, saxðane) worshipper | saġðánət sănằme worshipper of idols (B6:28)

sahaða n.m. (pl. sahaðe) witness

sahða, saða n.m. (pl. sahðe) witness; martyr

sahðuθa, saðuθa n.f. evidence; martyrdom | qa-t-yáwi sahðùθa| in order to give evidence (B1:18).

saka n.m (pl. sake) mountain ridge

sala n.m. (pl. sale) storage basket | used for dairy products, which are kept cool by flow of air

sălămaške, sŭlamməš, sălamməš, sallamḗš n.f. (pl. šălămaške) (K.) beehive; cylindrical compartment of beehive (made of basket)

sălamət n.f. safety; good health (K./A.) | ʾáxxa biš-sălàmət-ila| It is safer here (A30:51).

sălaməttuθa n.f. safety; good health (K./A.) | ʾítli híwi ṱ‑áwət sáx ʾu‑sălaməttùθa| I hope you will fine and in good health

saləkke n.f. (pl. saləkyaθa) small basket of beehive

saliqa n.m. tune | ṱ-ázi xa‑fàtra,| ʾal-salíqə zòrna| They went off for a while according to the tune of the pipe (A25:27); máxe zórna xa‑salíqa xèna| He plays another tune on the pipe (A25:27).

salla n.f. (pl. sallaθa) basket | sallət čamča basket for storing spoons hanging on the wall

salθa n.f. (pl. sallaθa) basket | made of willow (xelapa) and mulberry (tuθa) twigs, chiefly used to refer to (1) small baskets used to keep bees in a beehive and (2) large baskets used to catch fish in a river.

sama n.m. portion, share | ʾána sámi t‑yánne ṭlalɛ̀xu| I shall give you my share (A21:29); sama zoda the majority (n.), mostly (adv.): ʾína sáma zóda ʾiyɛ́wala qaràwət| Most people, however, had a bed (B5:204); ʾima‑t‑y‑aθéwa tàlga| sáma zóda b‑yárxət trè‑ʾəsər| yárxət xà| when it snowed, mainly in December and January (B5:196).

samma, sama n.m. poison, venom | Zìne| maštáli sàmma| Zine will give me poison to drink (A26:85).

sammana adj. (f. sammanta, pl. sammane) poisonous

samuna n.m. (pl. samune) loaf of bread

samxa n.m. (pl. samxe) large post around which vine grows | used mainly for vines planted in farmland (ʾaqara)

săna n.m. (pl. săne) (A.) labourer, builder

sănam n.m (pl. sănăme) (A.) idol | saġðánət sănằme worshipper of idols (B6:28)

sănayi, senayi adj. (K.) easy | lɛ́la senáyi xzàyəlle| It is not easy to see him; máṣe náša ṱ‑ásəq l‑gáre b‑sănàyi| A person can easily go onto the roof (B18:2).

sănayuθa n.f. easiness

sanda n.m. (pl. sande) (A.) support; prop | xoθe maxi stune ʾu‑ʾap‑sanda Under it they will build pillars and a support (C3:10).

sanduqa, ṣanduqa n.m. (pl. sanduqe, ṣanduqe) (A.) box

sanoya n.m. (pl. sanoye) poker for a fire

santən n.m. satin | k̭unnəkyáθǝ sàntǝn| head-scarves of satin (B10:42)

santiya n.m. (pl. santiye) centimetre | ʾi‑maxəlmíwa ʾúpra taqríban xamšì santíye| They made the (layer of) mud about fifty centimetres thick.

sapiqa adj. (f. sapiqta, pl. sapiqe) empty; not busy; riderless (horse). (1) empty | xǝ́zye ʾína qáṣra sapìqa| They found that the palace was empty (A12:34); ʾắra ʾiyáwa sapìqta| The ground was (left) empty (without cultivation) (B5:76). (2) unoccupied, not busy | ʾɛ́‑ga y‑áwa bíš sapìqe,| lá y‑awéwa šúla ràba| Then at that time (in the Autumn) they were more free and there was not much work (B5:19). (3) riderless (horse) | xə́zyəlle sùsa| ʾína sapìqa| They saw that the horse was without a rider (A29:29).

sapoya n.m. bite, mouthful | xá sapóya ṱ-axlə̀nne| I shall eat it with one bite (Qaṭina).

saqawa n.m. water-giver | saqáwa d‑ánna susăwàθa| This water-giver of the horses (A12:59).

saqðana adj. (f. saqðanta, pl. saqðane) tedious, exasperating | sə́twa saqðànɛle| Winter is harsh.

saqqaṭ adj. (f. saqqaṭ, pl. saqqaṭe) crippled

saṛa → seṛa

sarada n.m. (pl. sarade) (K./A.) sieve with large holes (for corn)

sar-amoða n.m. the first child to be baptized

sarapsɛra, sarbsara n.m. (pl. sarapsɛre) (K.) chain or rope for leading horse

sarastuθa n.m. (K./P.) honesty, frankness

sar-bar n.m. (pl. sar-barre) front row | mgabyanni m‑gu‑sar-barre I would choose for myself (one of them) from the first rows (C2:63)

sar-bari n.m. my first born child

sarbsara → sarapsɛra

sardəb n.m. (A.) basement

sardər n.m. (K.) lintel | sardər tăra the lintel of a door (on the outside of the house)

saṛe n.pl. barley | xa dəndəkθət saṛe a grain of barley

sarəṭlana n.m. (pl. sarəṭlana) crab, lobster

sarga, sɛrga n.m. (pl. sarge, sɛrge) saddle | zwína sɛ́rga qam-sùsa| He has bought the saddle before the horse (D2:14)

sar-gera n.m. (K.) leading ox on the threshing floor | sar‑gèra,| yáʿni ʾáwən majújwala ʾan‑tàwre| The leader, that is it would make the (other) oxen walk around (B5:84).

šărīf adj. invar. (A.) honourable, noble | ʾáti rába šărīf-nàšət| You are a very honourable person (A26:5).

sariqana n.m. (pl. sariqane) rake | hóle sráqa kolána b-sariqàna| He is raking the street with a rake.

sark̭ola adj. (f. sark̭ole, pl. sark̭ole) (K.) having a bare head

sarmajanke, sarmažanke n.f. (pl. sarmajanke, sarmažanke) (K.) small hook of wood connecting the yoke to the beam (mašana) of the plough

sarmor, sarmora (f. sarmore, pl. sarmore) adj. (K.) sealed; unbreached

sarpəšta n.f. (pl. sarpəšyaθa) soft woolen blanket put on back of pack animal under the outer cover known as qurṭana

sarqafliya n.f. (K.) deposit (on purchase)

sarqənna n.m. (K.) firstborn

šarre n.f. (pl. šarrăwaθa) (K.) battle; war | tre yalone havrəkke šarreley rəš-mamməkke two rival children are fighting on the breasts (C2:39)

saršoye n.f. (K.) place for washing oneself; large basin for washing dishes | usually in an outhouse (ṣopiθa)

saṭana n.m. (pl. saṭane) devil, demon | saṭána qpìxəlle| The devil has possessed him; tíwɛle l-súsət saṭàna| He has become arrogant (literally: He is sitting on the horse of the devil); saṭàne ʾítlən| We have demons (A22:26); bəjbajət saṭana snail; betət saṭana snail shell.

saṭanta n.f. (pl. saṭanyaθa) demon, evil spirit

saṭla n.f. (pl. ṣaṭlaθa) brass pail | used by milkmaids of sheep: sáṭlət màsta| bucket of yoghurt (A11:4)

sawa n.m. (pl. sawăwaθa) old (man); grandfather; ancestor | naša sawa old man; sáwən Tóma grandfather Toma (A50:1); sawət sawən our ancestors; sawăwáθən t-qámθa kúlla tàmɛwa mŭmə́ðe| All our ancestors of former ages were baptized there (B3:21).

sawta n.f. (pl. sawyaθa) old woman

sawunka n.m. (pl. sawunke) old man

sāx adj. (f. sāx, pl. saxe) (K.) healthy, alive | la-šawqítuley sàxe| Do not leave them alive (A8:8).

saxara n.m. (pl. saxare) large brass dish | used for gərðo stew

saxðana → saġðana

saxlam adj. invar. (K.) fit, healthy

saxora n.m. (pl. saxore) sty, inflammation in the eye | plíṭle saxóra gu-ʾɛ́ne dìye| He a sty formed in his eye.

sayəssa n.m. (pl. sayəsse) (K.) three-year old male goat
