saʾatta n.f. (pl. saʾattaθa) (K./A.) watch

saʾət, saʾta, saʾatta, saʾa n.m./f. (pl. saʾatte) (K./A.) hour | sáʾət kəmɛ̀la?| What time is it?; sáʾət ʾàrbɛla| It is four o’clock; sáʾət ʾə́ṣra b-lɛ̀le| ten o’clock at night; sáʾət ʾə́šta mbàdla| at six in the morning (A6:5); xá‑saʾət xèna| (after) another hour (A9:5); pálgə sàʾa| half an hour (B6:15).

saθra n.m. herb put in yoghurt

sebuθa n.f. old age

sela n.m. (K.) concave metal iron griddle for making bread

sela n.m. (A.) stream, river | gəšrə Zaxo ramana selət xoθe milana The high bridge of Zakho, the river under it is blue (with grief) (C8:7)

sema n.m. silver

semalta n.f. (pl. semalyaθa) ladder

senayi → sănayi

senike, senəkke n.f. (pl. senike) (K./A.) metal plate

seniya, ṣiniye, ṣiniya n.f. (pl. seniye) (K./A.) metal tray, metal plate

sentimeter n.m. (pl. sentimetre) (E.) centimetre | ṭḷáθi sèntimetre ríxa| thirty centimetres long (B6:55).

sera n.m. moon | sera hadele traṣa the moon is new, sera pišle lăgăna the moon is full (literally: has become a bowl), šəmšət sera moonlight; sera poriyana a bright moon; ʾan‑yomáθa ṱ‑awéwa ràba séra| qùwya| days when the moon was very bright (B11:3).

seṛa, saṛa n.m. goat’s hair

serane n.f. (K.) picnic

serani adj. | xawxa serani white peach

sere n.pl. (A.) magic | xáʾa ṱóṱo sère| an old woman of magic (A27:18)

sɛpa n.m. (pl. sɛpe) sword | mxìli xa‑sɛ́pa xéna| Strike me another blow of the sword (A51:18).

sɛrga → sarga

səgola n.m. (Urm.) dear person | səgoli my dear; ʾazíza səgóli xòna| my dear brother (A40:1).

səjən n.m. (A.) prison

səkra n.m. (pl. səkre) dam | hóle dwáqa sə́kra gu-nèra| A dam is blocking the river.

səkθa n.f. (pl. səkke, səkkake) peg, stake; ploughshare | ʾó-t šawə́rra šáwwa sə̀kke,| ða-qɛ́θa gu-be-tə̀kke| He who jumps seven stakes, (one) will hit him in his waist (D2:1).

səllər n.f. frost | ʾaqára hóle dwíqa sə̀llər| The farm land is hard with frost.

səlqa n.m. chard

səmbele n.pl. moustache | səmbelət šəbbəltət saṛe the hairs of a head of barley. Sing. səmbəlta one side of a moustache: kul səmbəlti xa draya Each (side) of my moustache is a cubit (A51:5)

səmma n.m., səmθa n.f. (pl. səmmame) (K.) hoof of animal

səmmala n.f. (pl. səmmale) small bundle of grass or produce | Four or five səmmale make up a darza large bundle. They are collected in the left hand (cf. C.Syr. semmālā ‘left’) with the sickle (magla) being held in the right.

səmmala adv. (C.Syr.) left, to the left

səmmora n.m. (pl. səmmore) squirrel

səmθa → səmma

səmya adj. (f. smiθa, pl. səmye) blind

səndana n.m. (pl. səndane) large pot for jajək

sənjane n.f. type of dance

sənjəq, sənjaqa (pl. sənjaqe) crotchet-hook

sənnək n.f. (collective) insects that eat wheat | qəm-axlála xə́ṭṭe sə̀nnək| The wheat has been eaten by sənnək insects; sənnəkθa a single one of these insects.

sənnorta n.f. (pl. sənnoryaθa) shoot (of corn) | xə́ṭṭe m-sənnòrta,| yála m-qapə̀lta| Wheat (is seen to be good) from when it is a shoot. A child (is seen to be good) from the time of (his mother’s) embrace (D2:36).

səpθa n.f. (pl. səppaθa, səpwaθa) lip | səppaθət swana the lips of the eaves (of a house)

sərda n.m. stalks (remaining after leaves are eaten by animals) | synon. səryoqe

sərke n.pl. herb put in jajək (similar to mint)

sərmo n.f. herb put in jajək and cheese (like chive)

sərr n.m. (pl. ʾasrār) (A.) secret

sərra n.f. (K.) turn (in a queue) | mṭéla sə́rrə d‑áw ṭla‑t‑šàqəl| His turn came to take (supplies) (B17:11); náše hóla zíne sə̀rra| The people are standing (waiting their) turn (B17:10).

sərri adj. invar. (A.) secret

sərsərra n.m. layer of fine white powder put on roof | This is made by sieving white clay (ʾupra xwara)

šərwala n.m. (pl. šərwale) trousers made from cloth

sərya adj. (f. sriθa, pl. sərye) bad | šeta sriθa t‑lɛla dwiqta daliθa the bad year in which the vine did not yield (fruit) (C2:27).

səryoqe n.pl. (sing. səryoqa) stalks of leaves remaining after leaves are eaten by animals → srq

səttināt n.pl. (A.) the (19)60s

sətwa n.m. (pl. sətwe) Winter

seylo n.m. (E.) silo

səbba n.m. hair of crotch

simarxa, simɛrxa n.m. (pl. simarxe) giant mythological bird | cf. A24, A27

sisisambər n.m. mythical plant | cf. A50

sivanoka n.f. (pl. sivanoke) (K.) type of small sparrow

sixurra n.m. (pl. sixurre) (K.) porcupine

skinta n.f. (pl. skinyaθa) knife

skita adj. (f. skitta, pl. skite) (A.) quiet, silent

skolaya n.m. (pl. skolaye) student

slemanaya n.m. (pl. slemanaye) man from Suleimaniyya

smiqa adj. (f. smiqta, pl. smiqe) red, reddened; red hot

smoqa adj. (f. smoqta, pl. smoqe) red; brown | šuréle zmírre b-súsa smòqa| He started to sing to a brown horse (A25:11).

smoqe n.pl. red sumac berries | ʾilanət smoqe sumac tree, with bunches (qanṭope) of red berries

smoqnaya adj. (f. smoqnɛθa, pl. smoqnaye) reddish

smoquθa n.f. redness

sniqa adj. (f. sniqta, pl. sniqe) needy

sniquθa n.f. need

snoniθa n.f. (pl. snoniyaθa) swallow | with a black body and a white breast

solho n.f. (A.) peace, truce, reconciliation | wídlɛ sòlho| They made peace → ṣoloh

sona n.f. (pl. sonaθa) type of duck

sorəkke n.f. (pl. sorəkyaθa) (K.) hollowed out open wooden pipe bringing water from a water channel (šaqiθa); gutter of roof; drain pipe

sorəkθa n.f. (pl. sorəkyaθa) (K.) lip in the ridge of the lower grindstone of a water-mill where sesame oil pours off

sparəgla n.m. (pl. sparəgle) quince

spay adj. invar. (K.) good, well. (1) good | hálli xa‑súsa spày| Give me a good horse (A12:62); bábux spày‑našɛle,| xàwrən‑ile| Your father is a good man, he is our friend (A14:61). (2) well | ʾɛ́ne dìye| píšela spày| His eyes became well (A24:21); dàx-it?| spày-in| How are you? I am well. adv. well | qa-t‑xáyən spáy ʾàxxa| so that I can live well here (A3:3); qəm-awə́dle rába spày| He did it very well.

spayuθa n.f. goodness; favour | ʾána spayùθən wáða| I have done good (A14:34); wúð ða-spayúθa mə̀nni| Do me a favour (A7:17).

spena n.f. (pl. spene, spenane, spenaθa) (K.) wedge | ṣṭíple qɛ́sa b-spèna| He split the wood in the middle with a wedge; naqrə́tla spèna| You knock in the wedge.

spərto n.f. alcoholic spirit

spiqa adj. (f. spiqta, pl. spiqe) empty

spisa adj. (f. spista, pl. spise) rotten, worn out | píšɛle màjbur| hà-ṱ-ile| ríxa ʾǝ́θya mǝ́nne díye spìsa| He remained like that, of necessity, until a rotten smell came from him (A27:43).

squpθa n.f. (pl. squpyaθa) lintel

stăkana n.m. (pl. stăkane) (K.) glass (for drink)

stanga n.m. (pl. stange) (K.) narrow mountain path

stavla, stawla n.m. (pl. stavle, stawle) (K.) wooden frame for carrying loads on pack animal | Each animal had four of these: stavlət qɛse type used for carrying wood; stavlət kepe reinforced type used for carrying stones.

stərra n.m. (pl. stərre) storeroom for food | contains bags made of dried skins (guðe)

stuna n.m. (pl. stunane) (K.) post; pole; pillar

stunta n.f. (pl. stunyaθa) small post

sula n.m. dung, manure

sulamməš → sălămaške

sulaqa n.m. ascension | ʾeðət sulaqa Festival of Ascension (40th day after Easter)

suləkθa n.f. small pipe | e.g. a pipe used to carry sesame oil running off millstones.

sulina n.m. (pl. suline) clay pipe section (several of which are joined together to form a pipe); interlocking section of church roof

sulta n.f. (pl. sulyaθa) dunghill | mən-málka ṣála l-sùlta,| mən-súlta ṣála màlke| From being king people descend to the dung heap and from the dung heap people rise to be kings (A40:13).

sunniθa n.f. (pl. sunniyaθa) thorny bush bearing raspberries (halwasne)

suraya n.m./adj. (pl. suraye) Christian

surayuθa n.f. Christianity

surəθ n.f. Assyrian language

surgada n.m. calendar

susa n.m. (pl. susăwaθa, suse) horse

susta n.f. (pl. susyaθa) mare | sustət ʾabona ladybird

suta n.f. (pl. sutaθa) trap for partridges (qəqwane) | consisting of trap doors over walls made of stone

swana n.m. (pl. swanane) overhaning edge of a roof, eaves of roof | swanáne palṭíwa m‑gùda| qa‑t‑lá‑miya ṣále gu‑gùda| The eaves protruded from the wall, so that the water would not run down the wall (B5:191)

swariya n.m. (pl. swariye) (K.) horseman

swata n.f. surfeit; satiety | ʾu-bxíθa hál swáta dìya| She wept until she was sated (A8:71)

swire n.f. (pl. swiriyaθa) (K.) stream, small tributary of a river

syamta n.f. ordination

syaʾa n.m. (pl. syaʾane) fence



/ṣ/

ṣabota n.f. (pl. ṣabaθa, ṣaboyaθa) finger | ṣabotət ʾisəqθa ring finger; ṣabota goṛta thumb; ṣabota zurta little finger; ṣabota gawɛθa middle finger.

ṣabun n.m. soap | ṣabun t‑raggye type of soap made out of gallnuts (apṣe); ṣabunət ʾaqla kneecap

ṣad- part. (inflected with L-suffixes §8.20.5.) afraid | ṣadli I am afraid; ṣadlux You (ms.) are afraid; ṣadlən We are afraid; ṣadwale He was afraid; nášət máθa ṣàdwala mənnéy| The people of the village were afraid of them (B18:3); ma‑t‑ṣàdwalən| How we were afraid (B8:19).

ṣăda n.m. (A.) echo

ṣadra n.m. chest, breast; front; middle | xpáqəlle gu-ṣádra dìya| She is hugging him to her breast (A4:58); l-ṣadrət gəppa wirwala| She entered the front of the cave (A51:12); tərte yawne šukraye tiwe ṣadrə be‑ḷaye Two white doves sitting in the middle of the upper room (C2:29).

ṣala m. (pl. ṣale) goatskin or lambskin (spread on floor to sit on)

ṣalila adj. (f. ṣalilta, pl. ṣalile) sober

ṣalma n.m. (pl. ṣalme) small bush with small leaves and small sweet red berries; the berries of this bush

ṣamərma n.f. (pl. ṣamərma) thorn-bush with small edible berries | It is gathered in mountains and used as fodder for animals in winter.

ṣanətta n.f. (A./K.) skill, craftsmanship

ṣanita n.f. (A.) product, job; skill | ʾáwwa šəbbáqa ṣanìtɛla,| ṣanítət xanăwàθɛle| This belt is manufactured, it is a product of looms; lípwalən ṣanìta| We learnt a skill; ʾáyya xoš‑ṣanìtɛla!| That is a good plan! (A44:3).

ṣapra n.m. morning | only in: ṣloθət ṣapra morning prayer

ṣarupa adj. (f. ṣarupta, pl. ṣarupe) smarting (food), spicy

ṣarupuθa n.f. spiciness

ṣawade n.pl. domesticated animals (usually sheep and goats)

ṣawaya n.m. (pl. ṣawaye) dyer

ṣawle n.m. (sing. ṣawəlta) leather shoes

ṣawma n.m. (pl. ṣawme) fast | rēš‑ṣàwma| the beginning of the fast (of Lent) (B5:156)

ṣawməkka n.m. a man dressed up in sheep skins who goes around the houses of the village at the beginning of the fast of Lent requesting gifts, or a model figure so dressed and carried around the village (B5:156ff., B16:7ff)

ṣawoya n.m. (pl. ṣawoye) painter

ṣawyana n.m. (pl. ṣawyane) painter

ṣawθa n.f. (pl. ṣawaθa) speech; sound | ṣáwθa lɛ̀le mṣawóθe mə́nna díya| He did not speak to her at all (A21:18); ṣawθət ʾaθuθa the sound of a letter; wéləx hawnànta,| b-ʾiqárət ṣáwθa basìmta,| ʾu-màqul| You have been clever, with the honour of sweet and fine words (A40:16); múrra ṣáwθa xà‑gaya xéta| Repeat what you said again (A25:61); ʾáyya ṣáwθi dū̀s‑ila| What I say is true (A40:4).

ṣewa n.m. thirst

ṣɛda n.m. hunt | bắyən pálṭən ṣɛ̀da| I want to go out hunting (A4:1).

ṣədfa n.m. (A.) chance | b-ṣǝ̀dfa (A8:14) by chance

ṣəmawla n.f. (pl. ṣəmawle) brown squirrel

ṣəmmaðra n.m. (pl. ṣəmmaðre) violet | xwarθi ṱ‑azəx ṣəmmaðre My friend, let us go (and collect) violets (C2:14).

ṣəmṭa n.m. type of cement | It consists of jabla and stones.

ṣəppa n.f. (pl. ṣəppaθa) finger; rod protruding from a stone wheel of a roller (mandorta) → ṣabota

ṣəpra n.f./m., ṣəppərθa n.f. (pl. ṣəpre) sparrow

ṣəpya adj. (f. ṣpiθa, pl. ṣəpye) pure

ṣəqla n.m. decoration; decorative occasion | y‑oðíwale xa‑ṣə̀qla| They made it a decorative occasion (B5:72).

ṣəṣra n.f. (pl. ṣəṣraθa, ṣəṣre) cockroach

ṣəṣṣe n.pl. seeds of the lagna plant | These grow in thorny pods. They are eaten as a snack.

ṣəṭpa n.m. (pl. ṣəṭpe) crack

ṣəxwa n.m (pl. ṣəxwe) clear sky | ṣə̀xwɛla| It is clear (A34:5); hóle sxáya b-ṣə̀xwe| He is swimming breast-stroke.

ṣiniye, ṣiniya →seniya

ṣiṭa n.m. (pl. ṣiṭe) span

ṣiwən n.m. (pl. ṣiwane) border

ṣiya adj. (f. ṣiθa, pl. ṣiye) thirsty | ṣíya míya thirsty for water (A14:27)

ṣlawa n.m. tether to tie an animal to a post

ṣlawiθa n.f. small tether

ṣləmθa n.f. (pl. ṣləmyaθa) form, appearance | ṣləmθət paθa facial expression; ṣləmθéy náše gabbàre| their appearance (was that of) warriors (A8:54).

ṣliwa n.m. (pl. ṣliwe, ṣliwane) cross | y‑oðáwa ṣlíwa l‑tằra| She would make (the sign of) the cross (B5:41); y‑oðáwa ṣlíwa mə̀šxa| She (the bride) makes (the sign of) the cross in oil (B5:40).

ṣliwana n.m. (pl. ṣliwane) knot; drawing of a cross | wúdli hàtxa| ṣliwána b‑tắrət bɛ̀θa| Draw a cross for me like this on the door of the house (B8:32).

ṣloθa n.f. (pl. ṣloyaθa, ṣlăwaθa) prayer | ṣloθət ramša evening prayer; ṣlăwaθət xɛle prayers for his strength, blessing prefixed to names of saints: ṣlăwaθət xɛle Mar-Sawa the Blessed St. Sawa.

ṣoloh n.m. (A.) truce, peace | wídle ṣóloh mə́nne dìye| He made a truce with him (A29:62).

ṣopiθa n.f. (pl. ṣopiyaθa) outhouse, shed | This contains the oven (tanura), the grindstone (xašolta), the cooking stones (kanuna) and the wash place (saršoye)

ṣoṣinta n.f. (pl. ṣoṣine) azerole tree; azerole fruit (edible red berry) | ʾilanət ṣoṣine

ṣoṣiθa n.f. (pl. ṣoṣiyaθa) plait, lock of hair | príməlla ṣoṣiyàθa| they cut their locks (A31:10)

ṣṭipa adj. (f. ṣtipta, pl. ṣtipe) split, cracked

ṣŭbuġ n.m. (A.) paint | kúlla mðíta mə́xyəlla ṣŭ̀buġ| They painted the whole town (A4:34)

ṣudra n.f. (pl. ṣudraθa) shirt, blouse | ṣudrət lawindiye shirt with long sleeves; ṣudrət xoθa blouse worn under other clothes; ṣudrət jurjēt velvet blouse

ṣūf n.m. (A.) wool

ṣup̭a, ṣop̭a n.f. (pl. ṣup̭ăwaθa, ṣup̭e, ṣop̭aθa) (K.) stove

ṣuwarta n.f. (pl. ṣuwaryaθa) wide mountain pass

ṣuwya adj. (f. ṣwiθa, pl. ṣuwye) hard



/š/

šāb n.m./adj. (A.) young, young man

šăbăka n.f. (A.) net

šab n.m. (A.) alum

šabuða n.m. (pl. šabuðe) rod; skewer | šabuðət ʾərxe driving rod in water mill that is turned by the propellors, made of willow (xelapa) soaked in grease (tarba); y‑oðíwa … bə́sre‑u … šabùðe| They would make meat dishes and kebabs (B5:13).

šabuqa n.m. (pl. šabuqe) rod | bəska šabuqe t‑dawa Her locks are rods of gold (C2:78).

šabuqta n.f. (šabuqytaθa) rod, shaft; shuttle (on a loom) | šabuqtət dudiya wooden bar on the side of a cradle (to which the swaddling bands are tied); šabuqtət tope metal rod for cleaning the muzzle of a gun

šabθa n.f. (pl. šabbaθa) Saturday; week

šaðaya n.m. (pl. šaðaye) carder (of wool) | referring to a person doing the carding or the instrument used for carding

šadda n.m. (pl. šadde) spool | for thread made of cotton (ktana) or gut (gədde)

šadəsta n.f. (pl. šadəsyaθa) pre-wedding party (to which close family and friends are invited)

šadlaxana n.f. party, festivity

šaharta n.f. prayer vigil (at Christmas and Easter) | y‑awðíwa gáwe díye šahàrta| They would hold vigil in it (the church) (B2:5); sáma zóda náše y‑ázi šahàrta| Most people went to the vigil (B5:53); šahárta qa‑t‑qyàmta pálṭa| the vigil until the resurrection comes out (at Easter) (B5:54).

šaka n.m. (pl. šake) shoot of a wine | grows from the tendrils (dalye)

šakka n.m. (pl. šakke) (K.) two-year-old male sheep (gelding)

šakroke n.f. bush with thorny pods

šala, šāl n.m. (pl. šale) (A.) shawl, kerchief; sash wrapped around waist | šalət xaṣa back/waist kerchief; šalət qðala neck kerchief; šalət turma type of wide waist sash worn by men (in which a sword is held)

šalgəmme n.pl. (sing. šalgəmta f.) turnips, swedes

šalila n.m. (pl. šalile) large basket | used for transporting straw from the threshing floor (bədra) to the storage bin (zənja): xánjər l-gótət xáwrux gu-šalílət tùna| A dagger in the side of your friend (as if) into a basket of straw (D2:41), said when you do not care for your friend.

šalla n.m. (K.) woolen trousers; suit of clothes; type of fabric made from wool | šalla ʾu-bərmalta trousers and jacket; jullət šalla clothes made of šalla fabric

šallala n.m. (pl. šallale) (A.) waterfall

šalqo n.f. smallpox | šalqo t-miya chickenpox

šăma n.f. wax | šămət duša beeswax

šama n.m. (pl. šame) (A.) mole (on skin)

šămala n.f (pl. šămale) (K.) candle | plíṭla šămála šắve lhàya| She came out glowing like a night candle (A38:14).

šamaša, šumaša n.m. (pl. šamaše, šumaše) deacon

šambəs adj. invar. recalcitrant, frisky (mule) | ʾáyya koðə́nta šàmbusila| This mule is frisky.

šamina adj. (f. šaminta, pl. šamine) fertile | Bɛ́rwər ʾíla xa-ʾàθṛa| šamìnɛle| Barwar is a land which is fertile (B1:5).

šamšuma n.m. (pl. šamšume) large waterfall

šana n.m. (pl. šanane) (K.) honeycomb | šanə parxe chickenpox (literally: honeycomb of peeling skin; šanət zarəqte section from a wasps’ nest. This is put in the cage of partridge chicks (pipa), since it contains worms, which the chicks feed on.

šangabí n.m. (K.) weeping willow | ṭúrxət šangabí ʾi-ṣáli l-ằra| The branches of the weeping willow hang down to the ground.

šapira adj. (f. šapirta, pl. šapire) beautiful, pleasant | ʾa‑zúrta ràba šapírtɛwa| The young one was very beautiful (A14:82).

šapna n.f. (pl. šapnaθa) instrument for smoothing ground after ploughing and sowing | This was made of oak twigs (taqanət p̣aṛma). It was connected by ropes to the beam that holds the oxen together (qaṭira); maxe šapna He uses the šapna.

šapra n.m. (pl. šapre) (A.) large knife

šăqa n.m. (A.) joking, fun

šaqa n.m. (pl. šaqe) lower leg; legging (covering lower leg)

šaqiθa n.f. (pl. šaqiyaθa, šaqyaθa) irrigation channel; groove; scar. (1) irrigation channel | l‑ay‑gōt‑hòdəx t‑šaqíθa| the farther side of the channel (A9:1). (2) groove | šaqyaθa xriṭe gu‑xṣipta grooves carved into wooden door lock, for rods (qulqulyaθa) that release and lock the bolt (dawra). (3) scar | xírre gu‑réšət Zàlo| ʾíθwa šaqyàθa| brinàne,| gòṛe rába| He looked at the head of Zāl (and saw) that there were scars, enormous wounds (A29:3).

šaqla n.m. (pl. šaqle) supporting pole | Such poles are attached to a bier (tirta) and have pieces of cloth (julle) tied between them. They are also used to support the roof of booths (k̭uprane).

šaqlanət paθwaθa n.m., adj. two-faced, deceitful | Literally: one who assumes faces.

šaqola n.m. (pl. šaqole) lower leg; plumb line (used in building)

šaqqa n.m. game played with a bat and ball (B11:10ff.)

šaqqana n.m. (pl. šaqqane) slap, blow | ʾárya mə́xyəlle šaqqána l‑ʾəqər‑náθət dèwa| The lion clouted the wolf on the root of his ear (A42:2).

šarafta, šarapθa n.f. (pl. šaraftyaθa) rope made of flax | Used to hang the shafts (mayoye) of the churn (guða) on the frame.

šarba n.f. (pl. šarbe, šarbaθa) earthenware jug | synon. kawaza

šarbəṭana, šarəbṭana, mšarbəṭana n.m. (pl. šarbəṭane) cane, pliant wooden stick for driving animals | usually made of sticks from the pomegranate tree (harmonta); mǝ́xyəlla ṭḷá šarbəṭáne xéne t-qɛ̀se| He hit her with three other wooden canes (A24:53)

šăre n.pl. wet cattle dung

šarəz adj. (invar.) (K.) familiar, knowledgeable (regarding of area) | ʾaw šárəz-ile b-ùrxa| He is familiar with the road; ʾáy šárəz-ila b‑ùrxa| She is familiar with the road.

šarīr n.m. (A.) evil

šarira adj. (f. šarirta, pl. šarire) true, truthful; honourable | ʾárxən šarìra| Our honourable guest (A26:30).

šărīṭ n.m. (A.) tape (recording)

šarniye, šɛrniye n.pl. (sing. šarnita) sweets

šarpa n.m. wrap worn around the neck, extending over front of body | usually with tastles (gugiye)

šaršura n.m. (pl. šaršure) small waterfall

šarṭ, šărəṭ n.f. (pl. šăraṭe, šŭrūṭ) (K./A.) condition; agreement; test, ordeal, challenge; court case; judgement, sentence; court; custom (1) condition | ʾaláha hole-mìra| t-yawə̀llux| b-šàrṭ| kú‑mdit yawə̀llux| ta-šwáwux t-yáwəl trè| God has said that he will give to you on condition that everything he gives to you he will give to your neighbour twofold (A3:4); šŭrūṭ‑díyi mkumlìlux?| Have you fulfilled my conditions? (A12:16); ha-t‑dóqət šárṭ mən‑d‑ò| nàša| until you agree on conditions with that man (A12:42). (2) agreement | wídle šàrṭ| ta-máxa l-ġðàðe| He made an agreement that they would strike each other (in a contest) (A52:15). (3) test, ordeal, challenge | ʾən-šắrəṭ díyi qəm-yăðə̀tla,| xo-b-gawrànnux| If you know (the answer to) my test, I shall indeed marry you (A25:62). (4) court case | ʾitléy šăráṭe ṱ-amríla qa-màlka| They have cases (to present) to the king (A17:31). (5) judgement, sentence | šárṭ qázi t-yawə́lla ṭlàlux| The judge will make a sentence in your favour (A6:7). (6) court (proceedings) | wírela šarṭ-qàzi| They entered the court of the judge (A6:9). (7) custom | w‑áxni lìθ gu‑šắrəṭ dìyən| bràta| krəstyànta| gáwra mušəlmàna| But it is not our custom that a Christian girl marries a Muslim (B4:9).

šaruθa n.f. (pl. šaruyaθa) lunch

šarθa n.f. (pl. šaryaθa) navel

šaša n.m. (pl. šaše) comb of a bird | ʾáwwa mo-ṭɛ́rɛle b-šàša| What bird is this with a comb? (D1:7)

šašta n.f. (pl. šašyaθa) turban

šata n.f. plaster | píšli bēl-šáta l-šəndùxta| I have come between the plaster and the polishing stone (D2:24), i.e. I am done for.

šaṭər adj. invar. beautiful, handsome | xa-bróna šàṭər| a handsome son (A8:22)

šatɛθa n.f. (pl. šatayaθa) big drinker (f.)

šaṭṭa n.m. (A.) river

šatyana n.m. (pl. šatyane) big drinker

šăvana n.m. (pl. šăvane) (K.) shepherd | dóqəx šăvàna| We hire a shepherd (B5:109).

šăve n.f. (K.) night | plíṭla šămála šắve lhàya| She came out glowing like a night candle (A38:14).

šawba n.m. (šawbe) headcold, influenza | ṭə́pyɛn šàwba I have caught a cold

šawbana adj. (f. šawbanta, pl. šawbane) suffering from a headcold

šawpa n.m. (pl. šawpe) footprint; place | ʾánna ʾíla šáwpət ʾaqlaθèy| These are their footprints; bróna díye šáqəl šáwpe dìye| bar-d-àw| His son will take his place after him (A8:2); (b-)šawp-, (b-)šop- adv. in place of, instead of | hálli bə́sra šópət lə̀xma| Give me meat instead of bread; dáx páyəš málka šáwpət bròni?| How will he become king in place of my son? (A8:4); pɛ́ša ʾáy ʾàxxa,| b-šópət brònən| Let her stay here in place of our son (A4:39); de‑puš‑šòpux!| Stay where you are! (A14:20); xə́ṭṭe … šōp‑rə̀zza| wheat sown after the harvest of rice (B5:95); šlàma-llux| sáwi šópət bàbi| Greetings to you, my old man, (you have) a place (like that of) my father (in my respect) (A24:8)

šawwa num. (f. ʾəšwa) seven| ʾurzət šawwa the seventh man; baxtət ʾəšwa the seventh woman; šawwa xaθwaθa Seven Sisters (=the Pleiades constellation)

šawwaθn– num. seven of | base for pronominal suffixes: šawwaθnən the seven of us; šawwaθnɛxu the seven of you; šawwaθnéy the seven of them

šawwi num. seventy

šaxina adj. (f. šaxinta, pl. šaxine) hot; warm | lə́xma šaxína darmánət náša kpìna| Hot bread is the medicine of a hungry man (D2:69)

šaxinuθa n.f. heat, warmth

šaxxa adj. (f. šaxxe, pl. šaxxe) (K.) stupid

šăyana n.m. (pl. šăyane) plasterer

šazada n.m. (pl. šazade) (P.) prince | wírtɛla hátxa ʾína hóle xa-šazáda dmíxa kə́sla dìya!| She came in like this and there was a prince lying with her! (A4:51)

šazatta n.f. (P.) princess

šaʿb n.m. (A.) people

šaθa n.f. fever | b-xšáwən šáθa doqàli| I think I have caught a fever.

šaθana adj. (f. šaθanta, pl. šaθane) feverish

šeða (i) n.m. (pl. šeðe) almond, almond tree

šeða (ii) n.m. (pl. šeðe) demon

šeðana adj. (f. šeðanta, pl. šeðane) mad

šekăro! interj. call to stop an animal | hó šekằro!| Wo there! (A22:25).

šekər n.f. sugar

šenəkka n.m (pl. šenəkke) a bird of prey

šera (i) n.m. (pl. šere, šerane, šerăwaθa, šəryăwaθa) saint’s festival

šera (ii) n.m. (pl. šere) (A.) poem; verse | qímən molə́xmənna ʾánna šére bud-dìye| I composed these verses about him (C4:3)

šeta n.f. (pl. šənne) year | kul šeta, kuššət every year; ʾəššeta this year; šetət wirra last year; šetə ṱ-ila b-θaya next year; xa naša wira b-šənne an old person; ʾáyya xá-šeta hóla támma láxxa lɛ́la mbaqorə̀llux| It has been a year that they have been here without asking for you (A26:78)

šēx n.m. (pl. šexiye) Arab elder, sheikh

šexani | xəgga šexani type of dance performed with a line of people in a row with linked arms

šɛna n.m. peace | b‑šɛ̀na θélux!| Welcome; b-šɛ́na b-ṭawàθa!| Welcome and greetings!; púš b-šɛ̀na!| Goodbye! xoš‑ʾáθya b‑šɛ̀na| She is welcome (A21:10). adj. invar. tame, domesticated; at ease | dawɛ́ra rába šɛ̀nɛle| A mule is very tame (B5:132); tawə́rta šɛ̀nɛla| The cow is domesticated (B5:175); ʾu‑brōn‑díye hádəx píša šɛ̀na mə́nne díye| His son had become at ease with him (B17:5).

šɛnaya adj. (f. šɛnɛθa, pl. šɛnaye) tame

šɛpanta n.f. (pl. šɛpanyaθa) rubber, eraser

šəbbaqa n.m. (pl. šəbbaqe) belt (leather or woven) | worn by men and women

šəbbəlta n.f. (pl. šəblaθa, šəble) head of wheat or barley | bréla xə̀ṭṭe,| dwíqla šəblàθa| The wheat grew and bore heads.

šəbbərθa, šəbbərta n.f. (pl. šəbbəryaθa) bracelet

šəbbət n.m. (K./A.) dill

šədda n.f. (pl. šəddaθa) demon | šə́ddət Mar-ʾOdíšo ṱ-áθya ʾəllɛ̀xu| The demon of Lord Jesus will come to you (said to a child as a warning); qəm-maxyála šə̀dda| A demon has hit her, qəm-qapxála šə̀dda| A demon has possessed her (said of a woman who is afraid or acts emotionally).

šəddəlta n.f. (pl. šəddəlyaθa, šədle) lullaby

šədla (i) n.m. (pl. šədle) lullaby

šədla (ii) n.m. (pl. šədle) seedling; sapling

šəftiya n.m. (pl. šəftiye) (K.) water melon

šəkkuθa n.f. (A.) doubt, suspcion | kəmət jawja b‑ʾašəquθa naše nabli šəkkuθa Whenever she moves coquettishly, people become suspicious (C2:73)

šəkla n.m. (pl. šəkle) form, appearance; picture, image | yə́mmi ðítəlla b‑šə́klɛ Bedwàye wɛ́wa| My mother knew that they were from Bedu by their appearance (B9:5); xírre qəm-xazéle šə́kle díye tàma| He looked and saw his own image there (A46:4); šqílli šə́kla dìya| I took a picture of it (B3:21); ʾən-bắyət šə̀kla,| ʾíttən šə́klət vìdeo| If you want a picture, we have a video film (B15:93).

šəklana adj. (f. šəklanta, pl. šəklane) beautiful; pleasant | mən-yóma qamáyə brèla,| ʾatxa-jwànqe-wɛwa,| ʾatxa-spáy ʾátxa šəkláne ʾu‑xǝ̀lye| From the first day (after) they were born, they were so beautiful, so fine, so bonny and sweet (A8:6); rába šəklánta ʾiyáwa basìmta| It (the occasion) was very beautiful and pleasant (B5:55); ṣáwθa gu-púmmət màrɛla šəklánta| A word is beautiful in the mouth of its master (= It is easier said than done) (A26:40); ʾən‑bábux ʾu‑yə́mmux gu‑bɛ̀θɛla,| lɛ́la šəklánta ṱ‑ásqət l‑gàre| If your father and mother are in the house, it is not pleasant for you to go up onto the roof (D2:7).

šəkloka n.m. (pl. šəkloke) loose stitch used to join pieces of fabric together in a preliminary fashion before they are sewed with the final stiching

šəkwane (sing. šəkwana m., šəkwanta f.) ants | šəkwanət qurðaye red biting ants

šəkθa n.f. (pl. šəkkaθa, škaθa, šəkke) testicle | The plural form šəkke is restricted to the insect name taqla šəkke spider (literally: weigher of testicles).

šəllela n.m. (pl. šəllele) (K.) waterfall

šəlloxta n.f. (pl. šəlloxyaθa) shed skin of a snake; husk of grain | ʾɛ‑šəllóxte díye šaqlə̀xwala| We would remove that husk (B16:30).

šəlmana n.f. (pl. šəlmanāt) (A.) iron bar

šəlxa n.m. (pl. šəlxe) swarm (of bees) | dabaše šəlxa mubrela The bees have made a swarm.

šəlya adj. (f. šliθa, pl. šəlye) calm, silent

šəlya m. (pl. šəlye) poisonous snake, viper

šəmma n.m. (pl. šəmmane) name | ʾáw múttəlle šə́mme díye Mar‑Sàwa| They named it (the church) St. Sawa (B6:30); ʾáti šǝ́mmux zìlɛle| You are famous (A12:10); ʾƐ̄́n Núne b-šə̀mmɛwa Ɛn Nune was famous; šǝ́myəx b‑šămáθə šǝ̀mmux| We have heard about you (A12:12); ʾálaha šuxa-l-šə́mme God, praise be to his name (A6:10); yalúnka zòra‑wewa b‑šə́mma| ʾína ʾáp‑aw ferə̀ssa‑wewa| He was a young child in name (only), but (in fact) he also was a great warrior (A29:25).

šəmmaxta n.f. palate

šəmme n.f. sky | marginal, the normal form is šmayya

šəmməšta n.f. bark from juniper (daprana) or vine (daliθa) used as tinder

šəmra n.m. soot | síqɛle xákma mən-d-ò-šəmra,| wírɛle gu-naxírət xa‑m‑malàxe| Some of the soot went up and entered the nose of one of the angels (A4:60).

šəmša n.f. sun | šə́mša gnèla| The sun set; šə́mša xrùle| The sun was eclipsed; šə́mša qəm-băléla ḥùta| A whale has swallowed the sun (i.e. it is eclipsed); šəmšət sera moonlight; mattíle qam‑šə̀mša,| ʾi‑bàrəz| They put it in the sun and it dries (B6:43); ʾáwwa málla ṱ‑axǝ́lla kθɛ̀θa| ʾána bṱ-ázən gu-šǝ̀mša| This mullah will eat the chicken and I shall go without food (A2:4).

šəmšaya adj. (f. šəmšɛθa, pl. šəmšaye) sunny

šəndoxa n.m. (pl. šəndoxe) large smooth stone | dɛréle ʾo-šəndòxa| b‑xùwwe| qá-t qaṭǝ̀lle xúwwe| He threw the stone at the snake, to kill the snake (A1:15).

šənduxta n.f. (pl. šənduxyaθa) small smooth stone | used for smoothing plaster; píšli bēl-šáta l-šəndùxta| I have come between the plaster and the polishing stone (D2:24), i.e. I am done for.

šənqa n.m. (pl. šənqe) pod containing seeds (boč̣e) | This is a component of vegetables such as maše, faṣuliye, lubye, gasose.

šənxurri adj. invar. grey

šənθa n.f. sleep | šənθux θàyɛla? Are you sleepy?; ʾɛ́ka ṱ-áθya šə̀nθe?!| hal-qedámta šə́nθe la-θèla| How could he sleep!? Right up to the early morning he did not sleep. (A6:3); qəm-ganwàle šə́nθa,| ṭlìle| Sleep stole him away and he slept (A26:19).

šəppola n.m. (pl. šəppole) edge of clothing | šəppolət ṣudra the edge of the shirt.

šəpra n.m. (pl. šəprane) area of land | šəprət rasa an area of land on which rasa grass grows

šəqqana n.m. slap | qəm‑maxə́nne xa‑šəqqàna| I slapped him (synon. zərana)

šəqraqa m./f. (pl. šəqraqe) small green bird that eats bees

šərma n.f. (pl. šərmaθa) buttocks | The plural is used to refer to the two halves of the buttocks). maqðə́xwa šə́rmət ʾÙšwuṭ| We used to burn the buttocks of February (festivity at the end of winter in which a bonfire is lit → məlməlawa); šərmət qamṣa back of grasshopper fed to chick partridges when kept in a cage (→ pipa); qrámtət šə́rma darmánət bušàla| The cover of the buttocks is the substance of the stew (i.e. the fat of the sheep’s tail) (D1:13).

šəryoxa n.m. (pl. šəryoxe) shoe-lace, cord | used to to tie up sheepskin boots (zargule) and the mouth of leather storage bags (mziðe); šəryóxa báθər mzìða| (There is) a chord behind the bag (said of a man who is the puppet of his master) (D2:18). Also used to tie the collar of oxen that are pulling the plough.

šəšxana n.m. (K.) old type of rifle (loaded from the barrel)

šətrənje n.pl. chess | šúryela mṭawóle b-šətrənjàne| They started playing chess (A26:63)

šəṭrana, šṭrana adj. handsome, beautiful | ʾítli ðá bratət-màma,| hádəx‑ila šṭrànta| max-d-àwwa yóma| I have a cousin, who is as beautiful as this sun (A7:17); y‑awə́ðwala šṭràne| He used to make them (the spoons) beautiful (B10:100); ṭliba lɛle šəṭrana Her betrothed is not handsome (C2:57); šəṭrantux ʾɛna zroqe Your sweetheart— her eyes are blue (C2:33).

šəṭro n.f. beautiful woman | šəṭro marθət habriya the beautiful woman who possesses the headscarf (C2:1); šətro šuṭarta lali Beautiful one, sweet-heart of mine (C2:7).

šətta n.f. (pl. šəttaθa) bottom | šəttət linta the bottom of a jar; šə́ttət màθa-wewa tíwa ʾo-xóna făqíra| The poor brother lived at the bottom of the village (A25:1); maṣǝ́lyannux šǝ́ttət yamàθa| I shall take you down to the bottom of the seas (A12:28); ʾilanɛni t‑xabušta m‑reša‑w šətta mnoqašta Our apple tree is decorated from top to bottom (B8:29); qəm-daryále gu-xa-gunìya| šə́tta díya nčìlta| She put it in a sack the bottom of which was torn (A34:17).

šətya n.m. warp | → maštoye to arrange threads on warp beam

šəxda n.m. good news

šəxna (pl. šəxne) inflammation, boil | šəxna gu-kasa stomach ulcer

šəxra n.m. charcoal; soot

šəxta n.m. (pl. šəxte) dirt, impurity | šəxtət naθyaθa ear wax; bar‑hàdəx,| y‑aθɛ́wa mdarɛ̀wale| qa‑t‑lá‑hawa píše šə̀xte| Then they would come and winnow it, so that impurities did not remain (B5:86); mítla m-šǝ̀xta| She has died with dirt (= she is terribly dirty) (A27:24).

šəxtana adj. (f. šəxtanta, pl. šəxtane) dirty

šəxxaṭa n.m. (pl. šəxxaṭe) (A.) match

šəxxore (sing. šəxxorta) charcoal | sing. šəxxorta a piece of charcoal

šəlpa n.m. blade

šima n.m. catastrophe | hay šima-lən a catastrophe has come upon us (A51:8)

šima adj. (f. šimta, pl. šime) huge; numerous | θélən b-áwwa ṭúra šìma| We came to this huge mountain (A17:10); ʾan-ʾə́rwe šìme| those numerous sheep (A32:16)

šipa (i) n.m. (pl. šipe) volley | šipət topaθa a volley of rifles

šipa (ii) adj. (f. šipta, pl. šipe) worn down, erased

šira n.m. (K.) milk; sap (of tree), resin (of plants); paint | ṣawe šira guda He paints the wall.

šiša (i) n.m. (pl. šiše) iron bar, iron tip | šišət qɛsa the iron tip of a wooden stick; šíšət bə̀sra| meat kebabs (B10:6).

šiša (ii) | xəgga šiša type of dance performed with a line of people in a row with linked arms

šišəlta n.f. (pl. šišlaθa, šišilyaθa) chain worn around neck; row of terraced stones | Such stone terraces were built to prevent subsidence of earth in the foundation of a house and as a boundary marker on land; cf. zənjir chain for securing sth.

šišmanta n.f. sesame grass | used as kindling for a fire and also for stopping up holes in a wicker screen (B10:65)

šišme n.pl. sesame

škăra, ʾəškăra adj. invar. (K.) clear, revealed; actual, real | xǝ́zwa škằra wéwa| It was a clear vision (A2:6); mṣáwəθ škằra!| Speak clearly!; gu‑lə́bbət gàne márəlla| lɛ́le‑marəlla škằra| He says it to himself, he does not say it openly; lɛ̀le xə́lma,| škằrɛla| It is not a dream, it is real (A4:8); mə́ndi ṭə́šwa bət-páyəš škằra| any hidden thing will be uncovered (A38:15).

škira adj. (f. škirta, pl. škire) thanked | škíra ʾaláha díya bsìmla| Thank God she has now recovered (A4:26); škíra šǝ́mmux ya‑ʾàlaha| Praise be your name, oh God (A9:4).

šlada n.f. (pl. šlade, šladaθa) corpse

šlama n.m. peace; greeting | šlama-llux greetings to you; də́ryəlle šláma l‑xa‑báxta tàma| He greeted a woman there (B17:2).

šliθa n.f. membrane of new-born calf that is ejected from the body by a cow when giving birth; sloughed skin of a snake

šmayya n.f. sky, heaven | šmáyya ʾíla denánta ṭla-ʾắra tə́rte qərṭále t‑ʾə̀pra| Heaven owes the Earth two baskets of dust (the graves of Noah and Elijah) (D2:9); síqle l-šmàyya| He went up to heaven (A1:27).

šmɛθa n.f. (pl. šămaθa) report, rumour | šǝ́myəx b‑šămáθə šǝ̀mmux| We have heard about you (A12:12).

šop- → šawpa

šor adj. invar. (K.) loose, haning down

šoramiṭa n.m. (pl. šoramiṭe) giant | hóle xa-šoramíṭa m-áxxa l-tămàha| dmíxa kə́sla dìya| A giant from here to there (in size) is lying with her (A4:52).

šorba n.f. (K./A.) stew (with beans) | rə́zza‑w šòrba rice and stew (B5:63)

šošanθa n.f. (pl. šošanne) lily

šotapaʾiθ adv. socially

špila adj. (f. špilta, pl. špile) paralysed

špina adj. (f. špinta, pl. špine) level (ground)

šraʾa, šraya n.f. (pl. šraʾaθa, šrayaθa) oil-lamp | də-yamyannux b‑ʾayya šraya I swear to you by this lamp (C2:81)

šrape n.pl. sleet | hóla ráya dúnye šràpe| It is sleeting

šrara n.m. truthfulness | ʾáw b-šràrɛle| He is truthful

štɛθa n.f. (pl. štayaθa) drink | štɛθa‑w xalta food and drink.

štiqa adj. (f. štiqta, pl. štiqe) silent | štìqe!| Be quiet (pl.)!

šṭixa adj. (f. šṭixta, pl. šṭixe) flat

šṭrana → šəṭrana

šubaða n.m. slavery

šukraya adj. (f. šukrɛθa, pl. šukraye) white | tərte yawne šukraye tiwe ṣadrə be‑ḷaye Two white doves sitting in the middle of the upper room (C2:29).

šula n.m. (pl. šule, šulane) job, profession, business; affair, thing | ʾɛ́‑gət mən-d-ánna hàwe,| šúla bṱ-ázəl la-qàma!| If there are these (gold pieces), the job will go ahead! (A4:15); wíðta šùlɛla ṱóṱo| The old woman made (good) business (A4:22); ʾítli šùla| I have something to do (A4:22); ʾítli xáčča šùla mǝ́nnux| I have some business with you (A16:4); ʾáti lítləx šùla| It is not your business (A5:2); mur-ʾána šə́mmi Čùxole| ʾu-lìtlux šúla| Say ‘My name is Čuxo’ and you will have no trouble (A7:18); ʾɛ‑dánə ṱ‑íle wíðəlle ʾáwwa šùla| When he did this thing … (A29:48)

šulxaya adj. (f. šulxɛθa, m.pl. šulxaye, fpl. šluxayaθa) naked, bare, bare-backed (animal) | dráya képe ʾáxni sxàya| šluxayàθa| He threw stones when we (women) were swimming in the nude (A25:20); koðə́nta b‑ìðiyawa| šulxɛ̀θa| The mule was in my hand, (while it was) bare-backed (B5:130).

šumana adj. (f. šumanta, pl. šumane) badly behaved, naughty

šumuθa n.f. bad behaviour, naughtiness | ʾáw hóle wáða šumùθa| He is behaving badly

šupra n.m. beauty

šup̣šup̣ina n.f. (pl. šup̣šup̣ine) type of dove (grey in colour)

šuq mən except → šwq

šuqa n.m. (pl. šuqane) market | gắrəg ʾázət šùqa| You must go to the market (A40:6)

šura n.m. (pl. šure, šurane) fortification wall; protective fence | šúrə d-o-qàṣra| the wall of the palace (A25:53).

šuraye adv. in the beginning, first of all | šùraye| y‑azǝ̀xwa| … l‑bɛ̄θ‑be‑kyàlo| First of all we would go … to the house of the bride’s family (B5:1).

šurela n.m. (pl. šurele) party of close family after wedding

šuša n.m. (pl. šuše) (K.) glass; bottle | šušət panjăriya window pane; xa‑šùša| a piece of glass (B11:20)

šut part. deontic particle (§15.1.1.5.) | ʾən-maṣya šut-ʾoðala If she can, let her do it (C1:11); šút la‑ʾàθe!| Let him not come!

šuta n.f. (šutăwaθa, šute) yoyo (B11:17ff.)

šuxa n.m. praise | ʾálaha šuxa-l-šə́mme God, praise be to his name (A6:10)

šuxlapa n.m. (pl. šuxlape) change

šuxra n.m. commandeering, commissioning | y‑aθéwa šùxra| It would come by commissioned transport (B5:126).

šwalta n.f. edible herb that produces glue; the glue extracted from this herb | It turns yellow when cooked in rice

šwanəkke n.f. (pl. šwanəkke) small booth covering beehives

šwassər num. seventeen

swata n.f. satiety, surfeit | yəmma baxya swata Let her mother have a surfeit of weeping (C1:23)

šwawa n.m. (pl. šwawe) neighbour | zílɛwa be‑šwàwe| He had gone to the neighbour’s house (A22:32).

šwawta, šwota n.f. (pl. šwawyaθa) neighbour (f.)

šwixa adj. (f. šwixta, pl. šwixe) stupid

šwiθa n.f. (pl. šəwyaθa, šwiyaθa ) bed; bedding | qedámta xzíθəlla gyána gu-šwiyáθət gyàna| In the morning she found herself in her own bed (A4:14); šəwyáθa sằfări travelling beds (A8:51).

šxinta (i) n.f. sanctuary, altar

šxinta (ii) n.f. fever



/t/

t → D

ta → ṭla

tăballa, teballa n.m. (pl. tăballe, teballe) (K.) marble (glass ball)

tabura n.f. (pl. tabure) (K./A.) squadron, battalion | ʾu-ʾanna jwanqe tabure and these young men are in squadrons (C1:21)

tabura adj. (f. taburta, pl. tabure) modest, submissive | la duqrula qalulta kriθa, xliθa, taburta Do not consider her to be small short, sweet and submissive (C2:74).

tabūt n.f. (pl. tabute) (A.) coffin

tabziya n.m. (pl. tabziye) (A./K.) rosary | xməryáθə tabzìye| beads of rosaries (A25:34)

tábzune adv. three years ago | rarely used

tafša n.m. (pl. tafše) small stone put in cement (jabla)

tagbarta n.f. administration | ʾáxni xoθ-tagbártət màlkəx| We are under the administration of the king (A8:80).

tagbir n.f. (pl. tagbire) plan | qímla wídla tàgbir| They made a plan (A26:1)

taḥela n.m. (K.) spleen

tăhər, tăhəra, tɛra n.m. (pl. tăhɛre, tɛre) (K.) type; kind | xa‑tắhər t‑šəkwána a type of ant; kùt-tăhər t‑bắyitu| every kind you want (A7:23); kúl xa‑tắhər mə́ndi ʾítle gàwa| He had every kind of thing in it (the shop) (A22:18); mò-tăhər nášɛle?| What kind of person is he? (A25:31).

taḥqīq n.m. (A.) investigation

tajammuʿ n.m. (A.) gathering, group

tajər n.m. (A.) merchant

tajəruθa n.f. trade; trade delegation, merchants | sáwi y-awúðwa təjarùθa| mən-ʾAšìθa| My grandfather would conduct trade with Ashitha (B3:4); zíltənwa tajərúθa tàma| I went on business there (A35:9); tajərúθət bàbux| kút‑ṭla šə́nne xa‑béna y‑áθya làxxa| The merchants of your father come here every three years (A14:61).

tala → tela

taləmθa n.f. (pl. taləmyaθa) small water pot

talən n.m. (K.) plunder, robbery | mə́xyət tàlən| bážər dìyən| You have plundered our town (A52:14).

talga n.m. snow; ice | ráya tàlga| It is snowing; θéle tálga xa-θɛ̀θa| It snowed heavily (A25:41); ʾu-míya ṣáli bíye díye páyəš tàlga| The water flows down it and becomes ice (B19:3).

tali n.f. (K./A.) end, fate | ʾáyya táli dìyila| This is the end of me (A8:58).

talila adj. (f. talilta, pl. talile) wet; fresh | julla talila a wet cloth; dánət talìla y‑áwe,| y‑áwe dwìqa| When it (the pile of leaves) is fresh, it is compact (B5:119).

taliluθa n.f. wetness

talma n.m. (pl. talme, talmane) water pot

táltalune adv. four years ago | rarely used

tama adv. there | Used to refer anaphorically to a location out of sight of speech situation: bálki lá-hawe tàma| Perhaps he will not be there (A1:10); sab‑ɛ́‑ga xúrme lìθwa táma| since at that time there were no dates there (in Barwar) (B5:12); táxtɛla mútte hàtxa| ta‑ṣáli tàma| They have put a board like this in order to go down there (A22:10). Repeated to express movement: ʾan-tre-maláxe … θéla pyáða táma tàma| Those two angels … came passing by (A4:44); ʾáw brōn-málka θéle jwája tam-tàma| The son of the king came walking along there (A8:14). Temporal sense in expression m‑tama hodəx from then onwards, afterwards: xárθa m-táma hòdəx,| xɛ̀ri| ʾína bɛ́θe díye kúlle qìða| Then, afterwards they look and see that all his house had burnt down (A48:7).

tămaha adv. over there (in sight) | dǝ́ryəlla gu-qaṣxàne| ʾu-múttəlla tămàha| He put them (the bones) in the pan and put it aside (A2:5); hóle xa-šoramíṭa m-áxxa l-tămàha| dmíxa kə́sla dìya| A giant from here to there (in size) is lying with her (A4:52).

tămaʾha adv. far over there (in sight) | ʾu-xá-kepa muttɛ́θəlle tămàʾha| She put a stone far away over there (A25:17); tu‑tămàʾha!| Sit way over there! (A25:17).

tambəl adj. (invar.) (K.) lazy

tăməz adj. invar. (K.) clean; clear | ʾíθ dukáne tắməz y‑áwa ṭla‑zrùta| There are places that are clear for sowing (B5:94).

tăməzuθa n.f. cleanliness

tamma adv. here | ʾáyya xá-šeta hóla támma láxxa lɛ́la mbaqorə̀llux| It has been a year that they have been here without asking for you (A26:78); ʾu‑táwra píšle mangóle ʾáxxa l‑tàmma| The ox began to limp back and forth (A22:3); qedámta qímtɛla bràta-w| mxŭláltəlla ʾay-dùkθa| ʾáxxa-w tàmma| In the morning the girl got up and cleaned the place, and so forth (A17:27)/

tamuz n.m. July

tăna adj. invar. (K.) calm | lə́bbi píšle tằna| I was relieved

taniθa n.f. (pl. tanyaθa) line (for hanging things) | This was used to hang washing or to hang pieces of meat to dry

tannəkka n.m. (pl. tannəkke) (K.) tin; gallon | ṭḷà tannə́kke míya| three gallons of water (B5:211)

tanura n.m. (pl. tanure) oven (for baking bread); section of women’s blouse (ṣudra) that covers the legs

tanurta n.f. (pl. tanuryaθa) small oven

taqa n.m. (pl. taqe, taqane) branch; strand (of wool) | ʾáyya tunìθən| mšaxlǝ́ppa mən-d-áwwa tàqa,| ṱ-áza l-xa-táqa xèna hadíya| Now, our story will change from this branch and go to another branch (A8:20); y-oðǝ́xwa ṭḷáθa táqe naqìðe We would make three thin strands (of wool by spinning) (B10:46)

taqla-šəkke n.f. (pl. taqla-šəkke) spider (§10.17.1.)

taqlīm n.m. (A.) pruning

taqriban adv. (A.) approximately

taqṣīr-ḥāl n.m. (A.) straitening of circumstances, impoverishment

taqta n.f. (pl. taqyaθa) twig, sprig | taqyáθət tŭ̀tun| (young) tobacco sprigs (B7:13)

tăra, tarra n.m. (pl. tăre, tărane) door; leaf of large door (darga); beginning | dárga ʾítle tré tăràne| A darga has two leaves; ʾu‑náše mapəlxìwala| hal‑tắrət sə̀twa| People would use it until the beginning of winter (B5:171).

tărare, tărɛre n.f. (pl. tărare, tărɛre) (K.) small aluminium cup, small bowl

tarba n.m. grease

tarəkka n.m. (pl. tarəkke) (K.) corpse | ʾawə́dla tarə̀kka šáwpa díya| He made her into a corpse (A30:33).

tarəqta n.f. (pl. tarəqyaθa) button | tráqəlle b‑tarə̀qta| He is buttoning it up.

tăreθa n.f. (pl. tărayaθa) small door or opening in fence or hedge; oesophagus; small mountain pass

tarḥīl n.m. (A.) evacuation

tar-ʾIšo n.m. a type of edible plant that grows in water | similar to kerapso

tarīx n.m. (A.) history

tarjəmən n.m. (pl. tarjəmane) (A.) interpreter, translator

tasma n.m. (pl. tasme) lace, tie | tásmə sàwle| shoe-laces (A11:12)

tašʿiθa n.f. history

tašʿiθanaya adj. (f. tašʿiθanɛθa, pl. tašʿiθanaye) historical

tata n.f. (pl. tataθa) crest (of bird), cock’s comb | tatət parre comb of feathers; tatət bəsra comb of skin

taṭʿīm n.m. (A.) grafting

tawba, toba n.f. (tawbaθa) repentance; submission | ha-ṱ‑íla wíðta tóba l‑iθáθe dìye| until she submitted to him (A12:31).

tawərta n.f. (pl. tawraθa, tawriyaθa) cow | tawərti ʾa-Ġazale my cow called Ġazale.

tawqīʿ n.m. (A.) signature

tawra n.m. (pl. tawre) ox | tawri ʾo-Xammo my ox called Xammo

tawta n.f. (pl. tawyaθa) sitting, social gathering

tawuna adj. (f. tawunta, pl. tawune) lukewarm | miya tawune lukewarm water

tawuzra n.f. edible herb with wide leaves | It is boiled and mixed with sumac berries (smoqe)

taxe n.f. (pl. taxaθa) (K.) neighbourhood; district | šmili xa qalət zəmra l-a-taxət baθər ʾumra I heard the sound of song in the neighbourhood beyond the church (C2:6)

taxərta n.f. (pl. taxraθa) small pitta bread cooked on the side of oven | a larger form of this is called zeðaya

taxmanta n.f. (pl. taxmanyaθa) thought, idea | háyyo xázəx mhàyərri| bəd‑taxmàntux| Come, let’s see whether you can help me with any ideas (A21:2).

taxta n.f. (pl. taxtaθa) (K.) board; wooden bed; throne. (1) board | mátti táxta hàtxa| … ta‑ṣáli gu‑gòma| They would lay down a board like this … in order to go down into the basement stable (A22:10). (2) wooden bed | damxə́xwa b‑gáre b‑qɛ̀ṭa.| … kút‑xa‑w táxte dìye,| táxtət qɛ̀sa| We would sleep on the roof in summer … everybody (would go up) with his bed, with his wooden bed (B10:58). (3) throne | brōn‑málka tíwɛle l‑d‑a‑tàxta| The son of the king sat on the throne (A14:43).

tayəmna n.m. South

taza adj. cs. (pl. taze) (K.) good, fine, beautiful | xáyūθ‑diye rába tàzɛyawa| His life was very good (B5:132); xmárte díye msúrgəlla-w wíðəlla tàza| He had saddled his donkey and made it smart (A6:6); barə́zwa tàza| It became thoroughly dry (B5:88).

tazi n.f. (K./A.) mourning | hadíya gu‑bɛ́θən tàzila| Now our house is in mourning; bássa wuð-tàzi| Do not mourn any more! (A26:88).

taʾla → tela

tela, tala, taʾla n.m. (pl. tele) fox

televəzyōn n.m. television

telkefnaya n.m./adj. man from Telkepe

telta n.f. (pl. telyaθa) vixen, female fox

tena n.f. tenta/tənta n.f. (pl. tene) fig; fig tree | xəzyali l‑ʾaqrət tena I saw her by the trunk of the fig tree (C2:24); ṭarpət tena fig leaves (put over pots of jajək)

təðya | xuwwe təðya type of long snake

təksa m. (pl. təkse) sting (of a bee) | dabáša máxe tə̀ksa| A bee stings.

təkθa n.f. (pl. təkke, təkkake) trouser cord

təlpa, təlpapa n.m. (pl. təlpape) eyelash

təltassər num. thirteen

təmməl adv. yesterday; tomorrow | təmməl b‑lɛle last night

təngər adv. limping | hóle θéle téla tə́ngər tə̀ngər| Then the fox came, limping (A35:18)

tənna n.m. smoke | gu‑yáma plíṭle xa‑tǝ̀nna| A plume of smoke came out of the sea (A13:10)

təpna n.m. mould

təqna n.m. (K.) grime | gáwət ṭína ʾu‑tǝ̀qna| in the mud and grime (A27:28)

təqsa sting (of a bee, wasp etc.)

tərða n.m. thick bush, vegetation

tərwəθ– num. two of | base for pronominal suffixes: tərwəθnən the two of us; tərwəθnɛxu the two of you; tərwəθnéy the two of them.

tərya adj. (f. triθa, pl. tərye) wet | julla tərya a wet cloth

təxrunya n.m. (pl. təxrunye) memory, memorial | ʾáxči ʾána təxrúnya dìyi| xə́zyɛn núne zòre| I have seen, as far as I remember, only small fish (B3:8); xa‑təxrúnya d‑ó qadìša| a memorial of the saint (B5:69).

təxruθa n.f. memory | kúlla xaràye,| təxrùθi,| plìlɛni| In the end, I remember, we all separated (B8:9).

tfaqta n.f. meeting

tiraka n.m. (pl. tirake) (K.) wooden rod | used as a spool for thread; used with metal tips as a component of a partridge trap (suta ↓) holding up the trap doors (dapyaθa).

tirta n.f. (pl. tiryaθa) bier, stretcher for carrying a corpse | It consists of two carrying poles (šaqle) between which are tied pieces of cloth (julle).

tita n.f. (pl. titiye, tite) silver tassel decorating head of a woman; small chain hanging from belt or bracelet

tiwa sitting; inhabited | maθwaθa tiwe inhabited villages

tiya n.m. (pl. tiyaye) (K.) mountain peak

t-la part. without | With nominal complement: t-la-zùze| without money (A24:23); t‑lá mìya| without water (B5:14); t-lá d-o-náša without that man; t-la‑díyi without me. With an infinitive: zeðàye| ʾáxlət mə́nna t‑là-qṣaya| You should eat the pittas without breaking them. (A30:5); ʾáni xə́ṭṭe huwèdi sáma zóda| ʾi‑zăríla t‑là maštóye| The huwedi wheat they generally sow without irrigating (B5:94); qímɛle jálde madə́nxa t-la-mxàya| He rose early while the dawn was not breaking (= before dawn broke) (A8:51); qəm‑dári ʾan‑dáwwe heš‑t‑là bráza| They have poured out the dawwe without it yet being dry (B14:1).

tmanəssər, tmanessər num. eighteen

tmani num. eighty

tmanya num. (f. tmane) eight | ʾurzət tmanya the eighth man; baxtət tmane the eighth woman.

tmanyaθn– num. eight of | base for pronominal suffixes: tmanyaθnən the eight of us; tmanyaθnɛxu the eight of you; tmanyaθnéy the eight of them

to imper. pl. (Urm.) come! | hár-to bàθri| Still come after me = Follow me further (A32:19).

tola n.m. (K.) revenge | ṱ-ázən šáqlən tólət bàbi| I shall go to take revenge for my father (A28:8); šqílla toléy xa-b-ʾə̀ṣra| They took their revenge ten times over (B3:14).

tope n.f. (pl. topaθa) (K.) gun, rifle | dɛríwa topàθa| They would fire guns (B10:34); ʾaw‑mə́xyəlla tópe gu‑ṣádrət ʾàxa| He shot his gun at the chest of the agha.

toqe | ʾəzza toqe mottled coloured goat

tos n.f. (K.) dust | ʾánna xéne kúlla hóla tíwta tos-ʾə̀lla Dust had settled on all the others (A8:56)

totənta n.f. (pl. totənyaθa) type of small sparrow

totike n.f. type of dance

tpina adj. (f. tpinta, pl. tpine) mouldy

trab interj. thud | ʾu-Gozáli tíwɛle tràb xaṣ-súsa| Gozali sat—thud—on the back of the horse (A8:39).

trapθa n.f. blinking | trapθət ʾɛne blinking of the eyes; qəm‑awə́dle b‑trápθət ʾɛ̀ne| He did it before you could bat an eyelid.

traθn– num. two of | base for pronominal suffixes: traθnən the two of us; traθnɛxu the two of you; traθnéy the two of them.

tre, treʾe num. (f. tərte, tətte) two | ʾína qəm-xazə́nnəx ʾáti rába hawnànta,| biš-mə́nni xa-tə̀rte| I see that you are very clever, twice as much as me (A40:16); yómət trè on the second day (A21:14); ʾu‑də‑trè| and secondly, and moreover (B5:3).

trəssər, tressər num. twelve

ṭrisa adj. (f. ṭrista, pl. ṭrise) fat, obese

troṣa n.m. truth. adv. in truth, indeed

trup interj. thud

trušeba n.m. Monday

tulla n.m. (pl. tulle) (K.) hound

tulləkθa n.f. (pl. tulləkyaθa) (K.) small hound

tuma n.m. garlic

tumbana n.m. trousers

tuna n.m. straw from wheat (xəṭṭe)

tuniθa n.f. (pl. tuniyaθa) story

tura n.m. (pl. ture) pliable twig | used for weaving baskets

turkaya n.m./adj. (pl. turkaye) Turk, Turkish

tŭtun, tuttun n.f. (K.) tobacco

tŭtur, tuttur n.f. (pl. tŭtur, tuttur) caterpillar | tŭtur ṱ‑abresəm silk worm (which feeds on the mulberry tree tuθa)

tuθa n.m. (pl. tuθe, tuθane) mulberry tree | Types of tree include: tuθa qazbi large white berry, tuθa turka small yellow mulberry, tuθa č̣uwa smooth mulberry, tuθət burane field mulberry, tuθət ʾərxe mill mulberry.

tuθta n.f. (pl. tuθe, tuθyaθa) mulberry fruit | Types of berry include: tuθe xware white mulberries and tuθe kome black mulberries. The latter type is also know as tuθə šemaye or tuθə šemi Syrian mulberries. tuθe karrəkke unripe mulberries; tuθta karrəkθa an unripe mulberry.

twina adj. (f. twinta, pl. twine) numb

txo- prep. under (archaic form of xo- only found in proverbs) | ʾíði txo‑kèpɛla| My hand is under a stone (D2:20); míya txo-tùna| (He is like) water under straw (D2:42).

txuma n.m. (pl. txume) boundary



/ṱ/

ṱ → D

ṱolaza n.m./adj. (pl. ṱolaze) (K.) self-indulging, libertine

ṱanga n.m. (pl. ṱange) (K.) saddle-girth, strap used to secure the cloth (qurṭana) on the back of an animal | This was threaded through a metal ring.

ṱăp̭əkke, ṱăp̭əkθa n.f. (pl. ṱăp̭əkke, ṱăp̭əkyaθa) (K.) trap for small birds; lid

ṱar adj. (f. ṱarre, pl. ṱarre) (K.) fresh, young | guṛe ṱarre young men (C2:63)

ṱaražoke n.f. (pl. ṱaražokăwaθa) (K.) small green bird | It builds its nests in the eaves of houses

ṱarra adj. (f. ṱarre, pl. ṱarre) (K.) fresh | xánči halúke ṱàrre| some fresh plums (B8:19)

ṱok̭e n.f. (pl. ṱok̭aθa) small bird with a distinctive song |

ṱoṱo n.f. (pl. ṱoṱaθa) old woman; grandmother | ʾítlən ða-ṱóṱo y-óða xə̀rše| We have an old woman who does magic (A4:13); ṱoṱi my grandmother; kɛ̀la ṱóṱo?| Where is grandma? (A7:24).

ṱurk̭a n.m. (pl. ṱurk̭e) (K.) pollarded mulberry tree | It is treated in this way in order that it produces twigs and wood for construction rather than fruit

ṱušṱirta n.f. (pl. ṱušṱiryaθa) (K.) two- to three-year old female goat


/ṭ/

ṭabăqa n.f. (A.) layer

ṭabʿan adv. (A.) of course

ṭabbaxta n.f. (ṭabbaxyaθa) (A.) cook (f.)

ṭabbəx n.m. August

ṭabəq, ṭabaq n.m. (pl. ṭabăqe, ṭabaqe) (A.) floor, storey | músqəlla gu‑ṭábaq t-ṭḷàθa| He took her up to the third floor (A4:37); ṭabaq ḷaya upper room; ʾáwwa mən-tre-ṭabàqewa bɛ́θe díye| His house consisted of two storeys (B15:20).

ṭabli n.f. (pl. ṭabliyāt) (A.) small table, side table

ṭabuwana n.f. (pl. ṭabuwane) tick

ṭalana n.m. side of mountains in Barwar that remains in the shade at sunrise | guði t‑ʾəzzi d‑ɛ‑poše gu‑ṭalana mxarpoše My churn (made) from my goat called ‘white spotted,’ which looked for food on the shady mountain (C5:3).

ṭaləb prep. (with pronominal suffixes: ṭalbe) towards; against (agressively) | ṱ‑ázən ṣálən ṭáləb Yuwánəs ʾaramnàya| I shall go down to fight Yuwanəs the Armenian (A52:10); ʾáwwa síqa ṭálba dìya| He went up towards her (A12:33); wárɛle Barzǝ́kko ṭáləb d‑ày| Barzəkko went in against her (attacking her) (A12:7); zílle xa‑béna ʾárya θéle ṭálbe dìye| A lion once attacked him (A11:1).

ṭaləbuθa n.f. betrothal | kúrsət ṭaləbùθa| the betrothal chair (A32:11)

ṭali n.m. (pl. ṭaliye) viral illness | b-ṭali ill (with disease) | brōn-málka píšle b-ṭàli| The son of the king became ill (A8:32).

ṭalobaya n.m. (pl. ṭalobaye) a person who performs ṭalobe (requesting of the hand of a girl in marriage)

ṭămaše n.pl. (K.) joking, fun

ṭamta n.f. (Urm.) breakfast

ṭana (i) n.m. allusion; indirect criticism | mxaya ṭane l- to make critical innuendoes against

ṭana (ii) → ṭena

ṭapaya n.m. (pl. ṭapaye) slope (of a mountain)

ṭapɛθa n.f. (pl. ṭapayaθa) small slope (of a hill)

ṭapoya n.m. kindling (for fire)

ṭappu game of hide-and-seek (B11:12ff.) → ṭŭši‑ṭŭšo, puq-əlli

ṭapṭapa n.m. (pl. ṭapṭape) small round unleavened bread on a griddle (sela) | ʾáw ṭapṭàpɛle| He is (like) unleavened bread (i.e. he lacks something).

ṭapθa n.f. (pl. ṭapyaθa) drop (of liquid)

ṭarəpθa n.f. (pl. ṭarpe, ṭarpaθa, ṭarəpyaθa) leaf

ṭarma n.f. (pl. ṭarmaθa) porch, balcony; shelter (under a rock) | ṱ‑awrəx xo-ṭármət ʾisàra| Let’s shelter under the rock.

ṭarpa n.m. leaves; gathering of leaves (for winter) | ʾo‑t‑hawéle ʾə̀rwe| y‑áwe xzida ṭàrpa| A person who has sheep would have harvested leaves (B5:108); hóle zíla ṭàrpa| He has gone to collect leaves.

ṭarpana n.m. (pl. ṭarpane) scythe

ṭarpe → ṭarəpθa

ṭarraša n.m., ṭarrašta n.f. (pl. ṭarraše) bush, shrub

ṭarxa n.m. (pl. ṭarxe) new shoot in a plant or tree | ʾilána hóle mṭaróxe ṭàrxe| The tree is putting out shoots.

ṭaryanta n.f. (pl. ṭaryanyaθa) flat bread basket | woven out of willow fronds (xelape)

ṭasa n.f. (pl. ṭase) (A.) small drinking bowl | xa-ṭásət dàwa| a golden bowl (A15:11); xa-ṭásət mìya| a bowl of water (A26:42).

ṭašta, ṭašte n.f. (pl. ṭaštaθa, ṭašyaθa) (K.) brass bowl (for kneading dough)

ṭaṭiya n.f. (pl. ṭaṭiyaθa) mat made of compressed wool

ṭawa adj. (f. ṭawa, pl. ṭawe) good | ʾáwwa náša sáwa rába ṭàwa-wewa| This old man was very good (A15:19); ramšɛ́xu ṭàwa| Good evening (ramša f.), ʾɛ́we ʾən-θéla m-la-Zàwa,| ṱ-áθe xa-yóma ṭàwa.| ʾən-ʾɛ́we θéla m-Xawòra,| ṱ-áθe xa-yóma kapòra.| If the clouds come from the side of the Zab (i.e. the East), a good day will come. If the clouds come from the Khabur (i.e. the West), an awful day will come. (D2:16); nə́mu ʾánna là-biš ṭáwe m-áwwa Gozáli xóni!| Surely they are not better than Gozali, my brother! (A8:72); ʾay m‑kulley buš ṭawa She is the best of all (C2:42).

ṭawalta, ṭuwalta, mṭawalta n.f. (pl. ṭawalyaθa, ṭuwalyaθa) game | lá‑kulla danáne kúlla ṭawalyáθa ṱ‑aθíwa mṭawòle| Not all games would be played at all times (B11:1).

ṭawaθa n.pl. blessings, greetings | b-šɛ́na b-ṭawàθa!| Welcome and greetings!

ṭawpana n.m. flood, deluge | dúnye hóla ráya ṭawpàna| There is heavy rain.

ṭaxa n.m. (pl. ṭaxe) pile, untied bundle (of grass and leaves) | This was compressed with stones in order to faciliate it being carried as a bundle: ʾan‑xéne ʾiyáwa báθre báθre wáða ṭàxe| zóre qa‑t máṣi mjămɛ̀wala| The others were following behind him making small piles, so that they could gather them up (B5:118). Cf. darza tied bundle.

ṭaxana, ṭaxxana n.m. (pl. ṭaxane, ṭaxxane) miller

ṭaxanɛθa, ṭaxxanɛθa n.f. (pl. ṭaxanyaθa, ṭaxxanyaθa) miller woman | ṭaxxána brōn‑ṭaxxanɛ̀θa| a miller the son of a miller woman (A32:27)

ṭaxime n.pl. furniture

ṭaxin n.f. sesame oil

ṭaxsa, ṭuxsa n.m. ceremony; rite; way | l‑d‑áw ṭùxsa| in this way (B6:11)

ṭaya n.m. (pl. ṭayane) leaf (of a plant); leafy branch (of a tree)

ṭayana n.m. (pl. ṭayane) porter

ṭayyara n.f. (pl. ṭayyarāt) (A.) airplane

ṭefi, ṭepi adj. (invar.) | ʾənwa ṭefi/ṭepi (pl. ʾənwe ṭefi/ṭepi) type of long grape | regarded as fine quality: xoš-ʾáwər ʾu-ʾáxəl ʾu-šáte gu-pərdɛ̀sa-w| ʾiθ-táma ʾǝ́nwa ṭèpi| ʾu-ḥuriyā̀t| Let him enter, eat and drink in Paradise. There are there fine grapes and houris (A2:8)

ṭema n.m. taste; value

ṭemana adj. (f. ṭemanta, pl. ṭemane) valulable; tasty | képe ṭemàne precious stones (A14:29)

ṭena, ṭana n.m. (pl. ṭene) load (on the back of an animal)

ṭera n.m. noon, noonday sun | dān ṭera noontime, dárta l-yòma,| ʾə́rwe gu-gòma.| dárta l-sèra,| ʾə́rwe l-ṭèra| If the sun has a halo, the sheep will be in the basement stable. If the moon has a halo, the sheep will be in the noonday sun. (D2:15)

ṭɛnana n.m. (pl. ṭɛnane) bearer | ʾána ṭɛnánət mə̀ntɛwən| You have done me a favour (I am much obliged to you).

ṭɛra, ṭara n.m. (pl. ṭɛre) bird | ṭɛ́ra t-málka Šlèmun| hoopoe bird (D1:7)

ṭəfl n.m. (A.) child

ṭəlla n.f. shade | ṭəlla ʾamurta deep shade, ṭəlla dalilta light shade (with some sun shining through)

ṭəllaniθa n.f. shade

ṭəlma n.m., ṭləmθa n.f. (pl. ṭəlme) large thin flat bread made on a griddle (sela)| thinner than zeðaye

ṭəppa → ṭəpθa

ṭəpra n.f. (pl. ṭəpraθa, ṭəppəryaθa) fingernail, toenail; claw (of bird, animal) | hóle qráṭa ṭəpràθe| He is biting his nails; ṭəppəryáθət heywàne| animal claws (A19:2).

ṭəpθa n.f., ṭəppiθa n.f., ṭəppa n.m. (pl. ṭəppe, ṭəppape) drop; dew; dot | lítlən ʾap-ṭə̀ppa| We do not have a single drop; xa‑ṭəppíθa míya lìθ| There was not a drop of water (A14:24); xa ṭəppət dəmma a tear drop; ʾən‑qɛ́ra dúnye qedàmta,| gə́lla dáwəq ṭə̀pθa| If it is cold in the early morning, a plant has dew on it.

ṭəšwa n.m. (pl. ṭəšwe) something hidden, secret | mə́ndi ṭə́šwa bət-páyəš škằra| any hidden thing will be uncovered (A38:15)

ṭima n.m. value | mare ṭima expensive

ṭina n.m. (pl. ṭinane) mud | ʾáni qámθa báte bə́nye b‑képa‑w ṭìna| In the old days houses were built with stone and mud (B5:179)

ṭina adj. (f. ṭinta, pl. ṭine) loaded | baxta ṭinta a pregnant woman; guði ... măyale ʾɛ‑baxta ṭinta My churn ... which that pregnant woman churns (C5:4)

ṭəpša n.m. (pl. ṭəpše) spot


ṭiyariyana adj. (f. ṭiyariyanta, pl. ṭiyariyane) relating to Ṭiyare | júlle ṭiyariyàne lóšiwa| They used to wear Ṭiyare clothes (B8:22).

ṭiza n.m. (pl. ṭize) bottom, fundament | xá ʾaxwáθi mìra| dráya šlámi ʾə̀llux| ʾu-ʾáti tíwa l-ṭìzux!| A prince like me greets you and you are sitting on your bum! (A26:48)

ṭla-, ta- prep. (with pronominal suffixes: ṭlale) to, for. (1) Recipient, objective or beneficiary: híwəlla quṣárta ta-màlla| They gave the pot to the mullah (A5:8); wídla ʾixàla| ṭla‑yàla| She made food for the young man (A21:22). ṭla-mo, ta-mo, ṭla-modi, ta-modi why?: ṭla-mò wídlux hátxa bíyi?| Why (literally: for what) have you done this to me? (A15:14). (2) Destination: dǝ́ṛṛa ta-ʾaθrɛ̀y| They returned to their land (A4:27). (3) Temporal objective: ʾawwa ʾaskaríya dìye| ṭlà-kəma dánɛla?| For how long is this army of his? (A17:22). (4) Object marker: ʾáwwa qṭìlle ṭla‑ʾárya| He killed the lion (A11:1).

ṭlaba n.m. (pl. ṭlabe) request | t-yawəllux kulla ṭlabe He will give you all requests (C4:5).

ṭlawxe n.pl. lentils (red or green) | xa dandəkθət ṭlawxe a lentil seed

ṭḷaθa, ṭḷa num. (f. ṭəḷḷəθ) three | ʾurzət ṭḷaθa the third man; baxtət ṭəḷḷəθ the third woman

ṭḷaθi num. thirty

ṭḷaθn– num. three of | base for pronominal suffixes: ṭḷaθnən the three of us; ṭḷaθnɛxu the three of you; ṭḷaθnéy the three of them; ṭḷáθna t‑bnóne dìye| His three sons (A24:3)

ṭḷaθušeba n.m. Tuesday

ṭliba n.m. (pl. ṭlibe) fiancé, betrothed

ṭlibta n.f. (pl. ṭlibyaθa) fiancée, betrothed (f.)

ṭliya adj. (f. ṭlita, pl. ṭliye) asleep

ṭolaza n.m. (pl. ṭolaze) (K.) young man; womanizer | šəṭro ṭolaze baθra npile (My) beautiful one (lover)—young men followed after her (C2:30).

ṭōq n.m. (A.) necklace

ṭoriya, ṭoriθa n.f. (pl. ṭoriyaθa) (K.) jackal

ṭoṭiθa f. (pl. ṭoṭiyaθa) button | synon. tarəqta

ṭun n.m. (pl. ṭunne) (A./E.) ton

ṭunta n.f. fruit of a tree | ʾímət mṭéla ṭúnte dìye| When its fruit became ripe (A17:33); bíš yáwi ṭúnta ràbθa| They will yield more abundant fruit (B5:103).

ṭur → ʾrṭ

ṭura n.m. (pl. ṭure, ṭurane) mountain; region of mountains | rešət ṭura summit of a mountain; palgət ṭura middle, foothills of a mountain; bắyən pálṭən ṣɛ̀da,| ʾána ʾu-xuràne,| gu-ṭùra| I want to go out hunting, I together with friends, in the mountains (A4:1).

ṭurši n.m. (pl. ṭuršiye) (A.) pickled vegetable

ṭurxa n.m. (pl. ṭurxe) branch

ṭusa n.m. sign; example; ceremony; ritual | qa-ṭusa for example

ṭŭši‑ṭŭšo n.f. the game of hide-and-seek (B11:12ff.) → ṭappu, puq-əlli

ṭušṭuš n.f. (pl. ṭušṭŭše) type of sparrow

ṭuwa n.m. (pl. ṭuwawe) coloured gem | ʾən-ṭúwət ʾisə́qθi bdìlɛle,| mšadrátla ʾárye ṱ-àθa| If the gem of my ring changes (in colour), send the lions so that they come (to me) (A18:13).

ṭuwe part. fortunate, blessed | ṭúwe l-d-o-yòma| How fortunate was that day. if only | ṭúwe t-xazə̀nwale!| If only I had seen him!; ṭuwe t‑baryawa šarre If only there would be war! (C2:63); ṭuwe t‑pɛšanwa nəšra If only I were to become an eagle (C3:2); ṭúwe l-ó yòma,| b-xazə́nnəx ʾáti ʾɛ̀ni b-gáwrət| I look forward to the day when I see who you will marry (A25:18).

ṭuxma n.m. (pl. tuxme) type; shape, form; way

ṭxuna n.m. milled produce



/θ/

θaləθ adj. (A.) third

θallaja n.f. (A.) fridge

θani adj. (A.) second | θáni yómət ʾéða the second day of the festival (B10:2)

θarwa n.f. (A.) wealth

θəqa n.f. (A.) trust | lítlux θǝ́qa bìyi| You do not trust me (A12:40)

θlaθa num. (A.) three



/v/

vərra adj. invar. (K.) squint-eyed | vǝ̀rra píšle| He became squint-eyed (A24:28)



/w/

w, ʾu- part. and | Connective between clauses (§18.1.1.): ʾáti tú‑tiwa làxxa| ʾu‑súsi páyəš làxxa| ʾu‑ʾána bráta masqə́nna be‑bába dìya| You stay here and my horse will stay here and I shall take the girl up to the house of her father (A29:41); ʾo-yálət băyàwale| hóle ʾə̀θya-w| qəm-yawə́lla yalə̀xθa ʾə́lli| The young man whom she loved has come and has given me her scarf (A4:24). Connective between nouns in a nominal phrase (§14.11.): xá-yoma ʾíθwa xá-qaša ʾu-xà-malla| Once there was a priest and a mullah (A2:1); lát-xila xa-lə́xma-w xa-bèta?| Have you not eaten a loaf of bread and an egg? (A17:15). Concomitative sense: xá‑gaya y‑asqə̀xwa| … kút‑xa‑w táxte dìye| Sometimes we went up (onto the roof) … everybody with his bed (B10:58). Before hal (until) expressing a range: kùllən,| mən‑yále zóre ʾu‑hal‑gòṛe| All of us, from young children to old people (B16:4).

wădər adv. outside | wădər mən‑bɛθa outside the house; dámxəx l‑wằdər| Let’s sleep outside (A12:11); ʾazítu palṭítu l-wằdər| You should go outside (B1:13).

wadi n.f. (A.) valley

waduθa, waʿduθa n.f. (A.) promise | gắrəg mqàwlət| ʾǝ̀lla| kùllɛxu qaṭlənnɛ́xu.| mǝ́re wadùθa.| ‘But you have to promise, otherwise I shall kill all of you.’ He said ‘It is a promise’ (A12:14-15); waʿdùθa,| kú-məndit bắyət ʾána ṱ‑awðànnux| I promise, I’ll do for you anything you want (A24:47); hát ʾóða wadúθa l‑ʾiθàθux| until she makes a promise in your presence (A12:29).

waha →ʾăwaha

wajəbuθa n.f. (A.) duty; task | ʾàxči| šoqǝ̀tlən| ʾàxni| ṱ‑ázəx ʾay‑wajəbúθa mkamlǝ̀xla| Just let us go to complete this task (A12:14).

wajju n.m. (pl. wajjuwe) (A.) utility; utensil, tool | ʾáwwa dáwəq wàjju| He will be useful (A29:18); ʾàti| la-dóqət wájju mə̀nni| You have no use for me (A30:14). Pl. personal effects | qímela múttəlla gu‑ʾatnàbəl| ʾu‑wajjúwa díya kùlla| They put her in a car, with all her effects (A21:5).

wăkil n.m. (A.) deputy

wala n.m. wide valley between mountains | ʾəzzət wala wild goat, ibex (inhabiting mountains); táwrət wàla| wild ox (A12:40).

wă-law → law

walla part. (A.) and not | le-šóqən lá xolamwàθa| wálla ʾàti| wálla yǝ̀mmi| wálla ču-nàša| I shall not let servants, you, mother or anybody (look after them) (A8:18).

wana n.f. (pl. wane) ewe, adult female sheep

waqəʿ n.m. (A.) reality

wăraq, wăraqa n.m. (A.) paper, sheet

warda, wɛrda n.m. (pl. warde, wɛrde) flower | warde žeri wild flowers of various colours, including red and green growing in fields; wardət dəbba large red flower

wardakka n.f. (pl. wardakke) (K.) type of duck | This appears in Barwar in the winter

wardi adj. invar. (A.) pink

wardoniθa n.f. (pl. wardonyaθa) type of small flower | It consists of four petals.

wariða n.m. (pl. wariðe) root

wariða n.m. (pl. wariðe) vein/artery

waṣla n.m. (pl. waṣle) joint, joining piece

wasta n.f. (pl. wastiyaθa) chest section of women’s blouse

wăzīr n.m. (pl. wŭzărāʾ) (A.) vizier, minister

waʿd n.m. (A.) promise | waʿdə ʿărab (I give you an) Arab promise (A33:12)

waʾha → ʾăwaha

wəlaya n.f. (A.) region, district

wɛθa n.f. birth | ʾéðət be‑yálda ʾíle wɛ́θət Mšìxa| The festival of Christmas is (in commemoration of) the birth of Christ (B6:12)


/x/

xa, xaʾa num. (f. ða) one; a (§14.1.) | ʾíθwa xá‑ʾotəx yan‑trè| There was one room or two (B5:199); ʾíθwa xa-nàša| gu-ða-màθa| There was once a man in a village (A48:1); máxa xa‑mə́šxa gu‑be‑ʾéne dìye| They put some oil on his forehead (B6:36); xa‑xá‑ga márət bɛ́θa mbašə́lwa ʾixála ʾímə‑t hóya dànət ʾixála| Sometimes the owner of the house would cook food when it was time for food (B6:16); xa‑tré-yarxe xéne one or two months later (A1:16); šqílɛle xa‑ʾárba xamšà béʾe| He took four or five eggs (A23:6); bə́nyət‑əlla ʾótəx tàma,| qa-t mabə́sma kúd-yom xà| You have built her a room there in order for her to entertain somebody everyday (A4:52); ʾə́θyɛle xàʾa| A certain person came (A7:24); ʾánna xà-ṱ-ila| These are one (= they are the same); ʾína qəm-xazə́nnəx ʾáti rába hawnànta,| biš-mə́nni xa-tə̀rte| I see that you are very clever, twice as much as me (A40:16); ʾən-háwe dàwa-ži| ʾáxni t‑yawə́xla xa-b-ṭḷàθa ʾə́lle díye| Even if it is gold, we shall give him threefold (A7:10); kut-táwra mə́xyəlle xá gu-réše dìye| He struck each ox a blow on its head (A30:23).

xabra n.m. (pl. xabrane) (A.) word | ʾítli xákma xabráne ṱ‑amrə̀nnəx| I have a few words to say to you (A4:40); híwɛle xábra ta-wazíre dìye| He gave word to his ministers (A4:9); xábra plìṭle| Word went out (concerning the matter) (A4:21); šḗx hìwle xábre díye| The sheikh has given his word (has promised) (A7:11); ṱ-amrə́nnux xa-xàbra| I would like to tell you something (A18:7); wúð b-xàbri Do as I say (A8:43); wídla xàbra‑xa| They made an agreement (A12:37); ʾána hon-muθɛ́θa ʾáyya qùwwət láxxa| b-xábra ta-dìyi| I have brought this force here, which is at my command (A25:84).

xabuša n.m. (pl. xabuše) apple; apple tree | xabušət ʾupra sweet potato; xabušət paθa cheek bone; xabúše kúlla msujlìley| They registered all the apple trees (B1:18).

xabušta n.f. (pl. xabuše) apple, apple tree | xabúšta ʾixàla| apple tree bearing edible fruit (B5:104).

xačča mod. adv. a little (quantity); a few (§14.9.7.) | xáčča tùna a little straw (B5:146), xáčča ṭína a little clay (B5:190); xáčča šarníye a few sweets (B5:40); xáčča mən‑d‑án‑našət bɛ̀θa| a few of the people of the house (B5:51). Used independently: ṭla-d-áy dráyɛla xàčča| She serves a small amount for herself (A17:25). Modifier of an adjective: xáčča zàmət iyáwa| It was a little difficult (B5:3), xáčča mə̀rya xónəx| Your brother is rather ill (A32:27). Adverb: xáčča plìšela They fought a little (B5:163). xačča pyaša almost: xáčča pyáša plìšlun| They almost fought (B1:17).

xadama, xaddama n.m. (pl. xadame, xaddame) (A.) servant

xadamta, xadəmθa, xaddamta, xaddamθa n.f. (pl. xadamyaθa, xaddamyaθa) (A.) servant girl

xădaya n.f. (pl. xădayaθa) (A.) lunch

xadəmθa → xadamta

xadəssər, xadessər num. eleven

xaðuθa, xaduθa n.f. joy | bréla ðá xadúθa gu-d-ò-ʾalma| A (great) joy arose among the people (A4:56); hál ʾámra ṱ‑óðəx xaðùθa| Give us an order for us to celebrate (A14:46).

xāf part. lest (A.) | lɛ-ʾáθya mtanòye,| xā́f náše šmàʾəllɛni| It cannot be told, lest people hear us (A35:11).

xăfīf adj. invar. (A.) light (in weight)

xakma, xamka mod. some, a few, a little (quantity) (§14.9.10.) | xákma məndiyàne| some things (B5:62); xákma šə́nne xène| a few more years (B5:208); y‑ápəxwale xámka yomàne| We would bake for a few days (B10:91); báθər xákma dàna| After a little time (B165). Used independently: xákma doqíwale xúwwa qaṭlìwale,| xákma zădìwa| Some took hold of the snake and killed it, some used to be afraid’ (B5:78).

xala n.m. (pl. xalăwaθa) maternal uncle | xáli! Uncle! (vocative used to address men of an older generation irrespective of family relationship)

xălala, ḥălāl adj. invar. (A.) lawful, pure | ʾáwwa bɛ́θa xălàla-wewa| This house was pure (A15:18).

xalaqta n.f. (pl. xalaqyaθa) earring

xalda-k̭ora n.m. (pl. xalde-k̭ore) mole

xaliya n.f. (pl. xaliye, xaliyaθa) carpet

xalqa (i) n.m. (pl. xalqe) button, fastener, press-stud

xalqa (ii) n.m. (pl. xalqe) step, rung (on ladder) | xa xalqa mən-dăraje one step of a flight of steps.

xalta n.f. (pl. xaltaθa) maternal aunt | xalti! Aunt! (vocative used to address women of an older generation irrespective of family relationship)

xalta n.f. food

xalwa n.m. fatless curds of boiled yoghurt water (B6:43)

xam, xamma (with pronominal suffix: xammi, xammux, etc. pl. xamme) n.m. worry, concern (K./A.) | dwiqa xamme worried; b-xamme worried; ʾan-políse wéla pyáša b-xammèy| The policemen began to become worried (A8:10); xámmət qáša mămòðele| The only concern of the priest is the baptism (D2:52), i.e. he is not responsible for how a person turns out later; lítla xàm,| lítla xàmma| That’s fine, no problem. ʾxl xamma to be careful, to care (D for): gắrəg rába ʾáxlət xàm| You have to be very careful (B5:105); dawɛ̀ra| ʾi‑mtagbrə̀xwale rába,| yáʿni y‑axlə́xwa xam‑dìye| We looked after a mule very well, we took care of it (B5:126); xázəx məndiyáne bràya,| ʾu-lá-ʾaxləx xámma d‑áyya bằlad,| la-bàrya| If we see things happening and do not care for this country, it is not right (A18:8).

xaməštən adv. again | ʾi‑pɛ́ši qa‑tré‑yomaθa ṭḷá yomàθa| hál mə́dre xáməštən ṱ‑àsəq| They wait for two or three days and then once again go up (to fetch loads) (B5:122).

xamima adj. (f. xamimta, pl. xamime) hot

xamiṣoke n.f. bitter herb, grows in thickets (ṭarraše)

xamka → xakma

xamoqa adj. (f. xamoqta, pl. xamoqe) dark in colour, blurred in colour

xamra n.m. wine

xamša num. (f. xamməš) five| ʾurzət xamša the fifth man; baxtət xamməš the fifth woman.

xamšassər num. fifteen

xamšaθn– num. five of | base for pronominal suffixes: xamšaθnən the five of us; xamšaθnɛxu the five of you; xamšaθnéy the five of them.

xamši num. fifty

xamšušeba n.m. Thursday

xamuṣa adj. (f. xamuṣta, pl. xamuṣe) bitter, sour | ʾan‑ʾə́nwe xamùṣela| the grapes are sour (A43:3).

xamθa n.f./adj.f (pl. xamaθa) beautiful; beautiful woman; young woman | ða‑bráta rába xàmθa| a very beautiful girl (A29:26); ʾíθwa xa-bàxta| rába xàmθɛwawa| There was a woman who was very beautiful (A8:21); ʾáy biš-xámθɛla m-kùlla| She is more beautiful than them all (A25:26); baxtaθa xamaθa beautiful women.

xana (i) n.m lap | réše díye múttəlle gu‑xánət ða‑bràta| He had put his head in the lap of a girl (A29:26); yalúnka tíwɛle gu-xánət yə̀mme| The little child is sitting on the lap of his mother.

xana (ii) n.f. (pl. xanaθa) (A.) square (on a board); line (on paper);

xanana n.m. (pl. xanane) goat with a brown face

xananta n.f. (pl. xananyaθa) female goat with a brown face

xănăqiθa n.f. whooping cough

xanči, xanča mod. adv. a little (quantity); a few (§14.9.8.) | ṣále xánči ʾúpra gu‑réšət kyàlo| A little earth falls on the head of the bride (B8:34), xánči halúke ṱàrre| a few unripe plums (B8:19); ʾən-wɛ́wa xànči| If they were few … (B10:6). Modifier of an adjective: ʾína bušála t-ʾoðə́xwala ṭlàlən,| xánči miyànta| But the stew, which we made for ourselves, was a little watery (B10:17). Adverb: šaxə́nwa xànči| It heated up a little (B5:154), hal‑qayə̀rwa xánči| until it cooled a little (B5:164).

xanjər n.f. (pl. xanjɛre) (A.) dagger | qəm-xarə́zla xánjər gu-kàse| He stabbed the dagger into his stomach.

xanpa n.m. (pl. xanpe) pagan, heathen | ʾu‑Dùre| píštɛla muqyàmta| muxràwta| šawwà gáye| l‑xànpe| qaṭòle| t‑mušəlmàne| Dure was evacuated and destroyed seven times by pagan murders of Muslims (B2:2).

xanqa-xona n.m. (pl. xanqa-xone) small white flower

xanum n.f. (K.) lady | dax-xànum ʾay-tíwta gu-bɛ́θa| Like a lady she sits at home (A37:3).

xanuθa n.f. (pl. xanăwaθa, xanuyaθa) loom for weaving

xapa n.m. (pl. xape) wooden peg used to connect the main body of a plough to the beam (mašana)

xapaya adj. (f. xapɛθa, pl. xapaye) protecting, caring | báxta xapɛ̀θa| a woman is caring (A40:2)

xapro n.f. (pl. xaprăwaθa) small metal trowel for digging up vegetables

xaqla n.f. (pl. xaqlaθa) field (with irrigation)

xăraba n.m. (A.) ruin | ʾu‑máθa šwíqta xăràba-w| and the village was left a ruin (B1:8).

xărama adj. invar. (A.) unlawful, villainous | ʾáti xa-náša xăràmət| You are a villainous person (A16:11)

xa-ramša n.f. (pl. xa-ramšaθa) dinner | mó ṱ-áxləx xa-ràmša?| What shall we eat for dinner? (A2:2)

xăraškăra n.m. magician

xaraya adj. last, recent | ʾáy wela-ʾá-bráta xarɛ́θət mṭúmra gu-Dùre| That was the last girl to be buried in Dure (B1:12); ʾaw-tíwɛle xaràya| He sat last (in the queue) (A17:31); máṭət ʾɛ-xarɛ́θət ʾòtəx| You will reach the last room (A24:16); ʾánna šə́nne xaráye in recent years (B3:9); táwra zìlle| b‑xarɛ̀θa| Finally the ox died (A22:6); ʾɛ‑xarɛ́θət xarɛ̀θa| in the end (A27:36).

xaraye adv. finally | bə́nta xaráye (A29:65), béna xaràye| (B5:43) for the last time.

xarayuθa n.f. finality, end | bas-tàma| qə́ṣṣət dìyəx| ʾu-t-xònəx| pɛ́ša màṭya| l-xarayúθa dìya| There your story and that of your brother will (finally) reach its end (A8:88).

xarbuqta n.f. (pl. xarbuqyaθa) knot (joining two pieces of rope); loop of a bird trap (nəšwa) made of horse hair; metal loop set to catch pigs by the legs

xarədla n.m. mustard

xărīb n.m. (A.) stranger, foreigner

xarja n.m. (pl. xarje) (K./A.) tax | maθyánət xárje-w bárjət boṭanàye| the collector of taxes and the like of the people of Botan (A26:34)

xarnɛsa n.m. (pl. xarnɛse) hand-held distaff | Wool is twisted around bottom and wool is pulled by connecting it to a spindle (kuša).

xaršana adj. (f. xaršanta, pl. xaršane) non-fruit-bearing (tree)

xarsupana adj. (f. xarsupanta, pl. xarsupane) rough

xarṭmane n.pl. (sing. xarṭamta, xarṭamiθa) chickpeas

xarupa adj. (f. xarupta, pl. xarupe) sharp

xarθa adv. finally; afterwards, then; recently | ʾɛ́-ga xárθa θéle xa-jăwāb qa-màlka| Then, in the end, a report came to the king (A8:5); wéle spàra,| xárθa xá‑ga xéta xzèle| ʾo‑dìdwa| plíṭle mən‑d‑ó bórət kèpe| He waited and then he saw the fly come back out of the pile of stones (A11:5); yubqáθa b-áyya xàrθa| Skirts (have been worn only) recently (B10:41).

xasla n.m. (pl. xasle) cover put over mouth of small animals when they are weaned to prevent them from sucking

xāṣ adj. invar. (A.) special | y‑áwe mtúrṣa xāṣ‑d‑ó‑məndi| It is made specially for that thing (B5:193)

xaṣa n.m. (pl. xaṣe) back; waist | ʾu‑yatə́xwa xāṣ‑koðə́nta We would sit on the back of the mule (B5:138); xákma dwáqa xáṣe dìye| ʾu‑xákma darqúle dìye| Some supported him and others were against him (A7:20); ʾíθwa b-xáṣi kamằra| There was a belt around my waist (B10:37).

xaṣina n.f. (pl. xaṣine) axe

xaṣira n.f. (pl. xaṣire) (A.) mat

xašiše n.pl. boiled wheat

xašlana n.m. (f. xašlanta, pl. xašlane) crusher; a person using a grinding stone known as xašola

xašola n.m. (pl. xašole) hand-held grinding stone for grinding rice or wheat

xašolta n.f. (pl. xašolyaθa) grinding base with hole in centre in which xašola is turned

xašša n.m. sadness; suffering | bắyən lá-ʾaθi b-xàšša| I do not want them to come in sadness (A4:33); ʾo-m-xášše mìtle| He (almost) died of his grief (A32:12); rutət xašša Good Friday.

xaššana adj. (f. xaššanta, pl. xaššane) sad | ṣléla xaššàne l‑bɛ́θa| They went down to their home sadly (A14:20)

xaṭaya n.m. (pl. xaṭaye) sinner

xaṭər n.f. (K./A.) respect; good will; favour | Only in idiomatic expressions: xaṭərux t‑la twirali I who have not broken your respect (= have not disappointed you) (C2:13); xaṭə́rux lá torànna| I shall not break your respect (= I’ll do what I can for you); bàs| ʾɛ́ kawázət míya mattátla kəs‑réša díya ʾu‑bàs.| mə́ra bábi hè| dàx lítlux xáṭər.| ‘Put out for her only that jar of water by her head and that’s all.’ She said ‘My dear, yes, I’ll do as you say (literally: how do you not have respect).’ (A21:10-11); mǝ̀re| ʾána ʾədlɛ́le ʾárxa ṱ-áwən láxxa kə̀sləx.| mǝ́ra málka dax-lítlux xàṭər| He said ‘Tonight I shall be a guest in your home’. She said ‘Oh king, you are welcome.’ (A17:24); ṭlíbɛle xáṭər mə̀nna| He took his leave from her (literally: He sought favour from her) (A25:66). Part. because; for the sake of. (1) because | ṭḷá-bnone xilìli,| báxta xilàli,| xáṭər ṱ-ínwa mk̭onǝ̀drəlla| I have eaten the three children, I have eaten the wife, because I rolled her (down the hill) (A20:12). (2) for the sake of | mút ṱ‑óðən ʾàna,| xáṭər ʾaláha?| What can I do, for God’s sake? (A31:2); ʾámər xáṭər ʾalàha,| ʾu-xáṭər mšìxa,| bas-lá dáqrət bìyi| For the sake of God and the Messiah, do not touch me (A15:21); xáṭər xaṭràna| for the sake of respect (B5:10); bəd‑xáṭər d‑ó‑xona zòra| for the sake of that young brother (A12:22).

xaṭɛθa n.f. (pl. xaṭayaθa) sinner (f.)

xatma n.m. (pl. xatme) muzzle (preventing an animal from eating grain)

xaṭorta n.m.
