(pl. xaṭoryaθa) washing board | qaṭlíle b‑xaṭoryàθa| They kill him with washing-boards (B19:9); bəlbəlàwa| kut‑la‑yàwa| xaṭórta gàwa| Bəlbəlawa, whoever does not give, (will have) a washing board (knocked) on him (said by children when going around the houses asking for gifts in the celebrations at the end of winter B7:8).

xaṭrana n.m. (K./A.) respect | xaṭranət babux out of respect for your father; xáṭər xaṭràna| for the sake of respect (for our family relationship) (B5:10).

xatta n.m. (pl. xatte) line drawn on field by a plough | ʾən-xátta pč̣ìlle,| gnáyət táwra d-o-gòṛa| If the line (drawn by the plough) is crooked, it is the fault of the big ox (D2:19).

xatun n.f. (pl. xatune, xatane) (K.) lady | ṭḷá-mma xatáne b-xá xerìya.| Three hundred ladies with one head cover (D1:9); síqla mə́ra ṭla-xàtun| She (the servant girl) went up and told her mistress (A25:57).

xawəlta n.f. (pl. xawəlyaθa) short rope | made of goat’s hair

xawla, ḥawla n.m. (pl. xawle) rope

xawra n.m. (pl. xawrăwaθa, xawrane, xure) friend

xawxa n.m. (pl. xawxe) peach | Types of peach: xawxa koma black peach, xawxa č̣uwwa white smooth peach, xawxa serani white peach, xawxa məzzana hairy peach; ʾilanət xawxa peach tree.

xaya adj. alive. f. xɛθa in child birth | baxta xɛθa woman who is giving birth or has recently given birth (forty or less days beforehand) (pl. baxtaθa xayaθa).

xayaṭa n.m. (pl. xayaṭe) tailor

xaye n.pl.tant. life | b-xàyele| He is alive; kúlla záwni b-xáye ṱ‑àwyən| all the time I am alive (A4:43); bróni mìθɛle.| šwíqəlla xáye bìyəx.| My son is dead. He has left his life (which remained to him) to you. (A4:42)

xayən adj. invar. (A.) treacherous

xayənuθa n.f. treachery | y‑àwəð xayənúθa| He acts treacherously (A47:3).

xayoṭa n.m. (pl. xayoṭe) sewing machine

xayuθa n.f. life; livelihood; living creature; vital feature | rába xayúθa basìmtɛwa| Life was very pleasant (B3:7); hal‑hadíya xayuθèy| l‑xabùšela| Until now people’s livelihood is made by apples (B5:75); ku‑xayúθət ʾáwər gu‑d‑ay‑wàdi| ʾánna šəkwáne ṱ‑axlìla| every living creature that enters in this valley will be eaten by the ants (A14:55); ʾáwwa súla ʾíle xá xayúθət ʾaqàra kúlle Manure is a vital feature of the entire farm (B5:138).

xazada n.m. (pl. xazade) harvester | xazáda là-wele,| mágla mgubèle| He has not harvested anything, but he has chosen his scythe (D2:27), i.e. a bad workman blames his tools.

xăzăliya n.f. (pl. xăzăliye) (K./A.) gazelle

xăzina, xəzzina n.f./m. (pl. xăzine) treasure; storage vessel. (1) treasure | xa‑xəzzìnət dáwe| a treasure of gold (A11:7); xu‑lanwa‑mírəllux maxzə́tli xăzìna| I had not told you to show me a treasure (A14:23). (2) storage vessel, tank | dwíqla xəzzíne məndiyáne mìya| They kept the water in tanks and the like (A11:18).

xăzinta, xəzzinta, xəzzita n.f. (pl. xəzzinyaθa) small storage bin | This consisted of a hole excavated from the ground covered with wood and earth. In general it was used to store nuts (such as baluṭe acorns) and root plants (such as šalgəmme turnips).

xaθa adj. (f. xaθta, pl. xaθe) new

xaθa n.f. (pl. xaθăwaθa) sister

xelapa n.m. (pl. xelape) willow tree, branch of a willow tree | ʾíθ xelápa ma-xelàpa.| šangabì| ṭúrxe díye ʾi-ṣáli l-ằra.| xelápa drə̀stile.| There are different types of willow. The weeping willow—its branches hang down to the ground. The (common) willow is straight.

xelapta n.f. (pl. xelapyaθa) small willow tree

xena, xrena adj. adv. mod. (f. xeta/xreta, pl. xene/xrene) other, another; more; again; discourse particle. (1) adj. other, another | mattúli xá-šəmma xèna| Give me another name (A7:2); m-ya-góta xèta| from the other side (A25:30); ʾu-mòdi-xenət xə́zya?| What else have you seen? (A17:8). Additional: ða-kista-xéta max-d-áy yawə̀nnəx| I shall give you another bag like that one (A4:16). Used independently: xa‑xéna another one (A23:27); ða‑xéta another one (A22:9); ʾo-xéna the other one (A4:45). (2) more | tálga xèna| more snow; xákma šə́nne xène| a few more years (B5:208). (3) adv. more, again | ʾána xéna šúla la-pàlxən| I shall not work any more (A23:40); xéna ṛìšɛle.| He woke up again (A14:95). (4) mod. more | Modifier of a quantifer: šqílənwa xáčča xéna qàlya| ta‑ṱ‑axlə́nne b‑ʾùrxa| I took a little more roasted meat to eat on the way (A23:10); zmúrrən xánči xèna| Sing to us a little more (A35:8). (5) discourse particle | expressing boundary and prominence: xéna políse mù ṱ‑óði?| Well, what should the police do? (A8:9); xéna ʾána qɛ́mən ʾázən ʾùmra| Well, I shall go to church (A37:2); bàssa xéna| Well that is enough (B15:35).

xēr adj. (A.) good | xḕr-ila?| How are things? (A22:16); ha-xḕr?| Are you all right? (A27:22); ʾu-málla ṛìšɛle.| mǝ́re ha-xḕr málla?| The mullah woke up. He said ‘(Did you sleep) well, mullah?’ (A2:5); ʾən-šálla xḕr hawya-ʾúrxa| God willing, the way will be good (A8:69); xēr‑ʿala‑xḕr Well done, good for you (A12:26); ʾáy ṛìšla| qá-t ʾáwwa lɛ́le ʾǝ́θya b-xḕr| She felt that he had not come with a good purpose.

xera, xerətta n.f. (A.) enthusiasm, zeal | də́ryɛle xéra b-gáne dìye He took courage (A8:57); xére zílle mṭušyàle gáne| He quickly went and hid himself (A24:46); mtuxmǝ́nne ṱ-áwəð nxìlθa| ṭla-madréla b‑xerə̀tta| He thought of doing a mischievous trick to make her throw it (the cheese) down in her excitement (A49:2).

xerətta → xera

xeriya n.f. (pl. xeriyaθa) (K.) black head cover | Riddle: ṭlá-mma xatáne b-xá xerìya:| harmònta| Three hundred ladies with one veil: Pomegranate (D1:9)

xeta, xreta → xena

xewa n.m. (pl. xewe) hook used to adjust threads when weaving

xɛla n.m. (pl. xɛlăwaθa) strength, force, power | xɛ́la díya mòdile| t‑mazvə̀rra?| What is its power, which turns it? (B6:53); ʾə́θye xɛlăwáθət maymúne dart‑yóma The forces (of the army of) the monkeys came the next day (A14:54); ʾáni b-xɛ́la bắyi mbarxíla ʾə̀lli| They want to marry her to me by force (A7:18); b‑xɛ̀la náše xazíle| People scarcely see him; ʾu‑b‑xɛ́lət ʾalàha,| har‑Dúre lɛ̀‑ʾaθya l‑manšòye| By the strength of God, Dure will never be forgotten (B2:7). draya xɛla to apply force, to struggle; to attempt: də́ryɛle xɛ̀la| ta-t-šarə̀ṭla gáne| He struggled to release himself (A26:81). ṣlăwaθət xɛle prayers for his strength, goriyət xɛle a sacrifice for his strength (blessings prefixed to names of saints): ṣlăwaθət xɛle Mar-Sawa the Blessed St. Sawa; Mar-Gwirgis goriyət xɛle the Blessed St. George.

xɛlana adj. strong, mighty, huge | ʾína rába gabbàra| xɛlàna‑wewa| But he was a very mighty warrior (A11:1); ṣríxɛle xa‑qála ràba xɛlána| He shouted a mighty shout (A11:3); xa‑pláša ràba xɛlána‑wewa| It was a very fierce war (A11:16); məṭra xɛlanta heavy rain; talga xɛlana heavy snow; xa‑xlùla| ràba xɛlána| a huge wedding (A12:23). Used adverbially: qəm-maxéla ʾáqla biš-xɛlàna| He struck her leg harder (A33:12); ʾína ṣláya xɛlànɛle| It (the river) is flowing down in spate (A14:58).

xɛpuθa n.f. fog | ʾə́dyo xɛpùθɛla| It is foggy today; qáyəm qèdamta| ʾína xɛpùθa| ryáma mən-ʾằra| He got up in the morning and found that fog was rising from the ground (A25:43).

xəbloke n.f. a type of green herb | eaten by partridges

xəbra n.f. (A.) experience, knowledge

xəðya n.m. (pl. xəðyăwaθa) breast | reši bēl xəðya l‑xəðya My head is between one breast and another (C2:72)

xəðya adj. (f. xðiθa, pl. xəðye) joyful, happy

xəðyuθa n.f. joy; joyful occasion | sab‑ʾó‑yoma xa‑xəðyùθɛwa| because that day was a joyful occasion (B5:62).

xəgga n.m. (pl. xəgge) dance performed with a line of people in a row with linked arms | xa-d-ánna dwíqɛwa réšət xə̀gga| One of them was leading the head of the dance (B15:80). There are various types of this dance including: xəgga xḷiya (with bending of knees), xəgga belati (same as xəgga xḷiya), xəgga šexani, xəgga guršeni, xəgga šiša, xəgga yaqura.

xəlāl prep. (A.) within (time), during | xəlā́l tre-yomè| within two days (A8:38)

xəllepa n.m. (pl. xəllepe) beehive

xəllət, xəlleta n.f. (pl. xəllaθa, xəlletaθa, xəllətyaθa) (K./A.) gift | ʾítli xəlléta maxlə́nna qa‑d‑àni I have a gift to give to them.

xəlma n.m. (pl. xəlme) dream | ʾáwwa málka xzéle xa-xǝ̀lma| This king had a dream (A1:2); ʾu-málka mšuréle zdàya xáčča| … xǝ́lme díye pàləṭ| The king began to be rather afraid … that his dream would come true (A8:6).

xəlmət, xəlmətta (pl. xəlmətte) (K./A.) service (good deed or church ceremony) | kəmə́t ʾáwəð náša xəlmə̀tta,| hár béna xaràye| mxáyəlle l-máre dìye| Whenever a man does a service, always in the end he strikes the man performing the service (A47:2); gu-d-ánna tre-ʾumràne| xə́lmət ʾetanɛ́θa y-oðə́xwala gáwe dìye| In these two churches we used to hold church services (B1:6).

xəlṭa n.m. (pl. xəlṭe) (K./A.) mistake

xəlxale n.pl. (sing. xəlxalta) (K./A.) anklets

xəlya n.m. milk | xóni ʾo-zóra l-xə̀lya wéwa| My younger brother was on milk (B9:16)

xəlya adj. (f. xliθa, pl. xəlye) sweet

xəlyana adj. (f. xəlyanta, pl. xəlyane) producing milk | ʾítle ða‑ʾə̀zza| rába xəlyàntɛla| He has a goat, which produces a lot of milk.

xəlyuθa n.f. sweetness; sweet foods

xəmma n.m. heat | lɛ́le xə̀mma ʾəllɛ́xu?| Are you not hot?; gu‑bɛ́θa xə̀mma ʾiyéwa| It was hot in the house (B5:204); tawə̀rwa xə́mma The heat would break (in the evening) (B5:160).

xəmmana adj. (f. xəmmanta, pl. xəmmane) hot | xa-xamšušéba t‑Támuz xəmmàna| One Thursday in hot July (B1:15).

xəmmərta, xmərta, xəmmərθa n.f. (pl. xəmre, xəmməryaθa, xməryaθa) bead | xəmmə́rθə šə̀nθa| sleeping bead (magic bead used to induce sleep) (A19:3); xməryáθə tabzìye| beads of rosaries (A25:34); xmərta goṛta large bead (at the end of a rosary)

xəmxəma n.m. rash

xəmyana n.m. father-in-law

xənne adj.f. chestnut coloured (goat)

xəppərta n.f. (pl. xəppəryaθa) mud pit | where white clay for the facing of houses is excavated

xəppo n.f. (pl. xəppowaθa) bridal veil

xəpyaya adj. (f. xəpyɛθa, pl. xəpyaye) barefoot

xərba adj. invar. bad

xərbayuθa n.f. evil

xərqa n.m. ring | in neck cartilage: băláwala yabíšta xərqá xərqá gu‑qðála díya mabyə̀nwa| When she swallowed a raisin, it could be seen, ring by ring in her neck (A8:63); xərqət ʾilana growth-ring in tree; xərqət qana growth-ring in horn.

xərroza n.m. (pl. xərroze) string of dried fruit (e.g. figs, dates)

xərsa leprosy; mange; eczema | ṭə́pya xə̀rsɛle| He is afflicted with leprosy (A32:21).

xərša n.m. (pl. xərše) magic | wídla xə̀rša| She did an act of magic; ʾítlən ða-ṱóṱo y-óða xə̀rše| We have an old woman who does magic (A4:13).

xərṭa n.m. (pl. xərṭaṭe) line | xərṭaṭət ʾiða lines of the hand

xərxaṣa n.m. (pl. xərxaṣe) thick sash belt | worn by men and women

xərxəθ, l-xərxət adv. upside down, back to front | kúlla mnúle l‑xə̀rxəθ| They (the mules) are shoed back to front (with the shoes the wrong way round) (B4:13).

xərza n.m. (pl. xərze) string (of beads, roe, spawn); amulet hung around neck in the form of a necklace to deter jinn | xərzət xəmre sting of beads; xərzət kθɛθa string (of small unlaid eggs in stomach of a) chicken; oviduct of a chicken; xərzət pəqqa frog-spawn; tadpole; xərzət nune fish roe; young fish

xəškana adj. (f. xəškanta, pl. xəškane) dark

xəšxəšone n.pl. skating, skiing | hóle wáða xəšxəšóne rəš‑gðìla| He is skating on the ice; hóle wáða xəšxəšóne gu‑tàlga| He is skiing in the snow.

xəṣya adj. (pl. xəṣye) castrated

xətna n.m. (pl. xətnăwaθa) bridegroom; son-in-law; father-in-law; husband of a relative (e.g. husband of paternal or maternal aunt, husband of a sister)

xətnuθa n.f. state of being a groom

xəṭṭa m.n. (pl. xəṭṭe) (A.) plan | ʾána ṱ‑óðən xa‑xǝ̀ṭṭa| I shall make a plan (A12:35); mútte xə̀ṭṭa| They laid a plan (B4:11).

xəṭṭe n.pl. wheat (sing. xəṭṭiθa a wheat grain) | Four types of wheat: xwaraθa, huwedi, mərwəš and koča (without long hairs). xəṭṭət romaye, xəṭṭə romaye, xəṭ-romaye n.pl. maize | xa dəndəkθət xəṭṭə romaye a single maize seed. xəṭṭət šemaye n.pl. maize (= xəṭṭət romaye). Pl. xəṭṭane wheat plants | yárxət šáwwa tmànya,| mšɛ́ri xzáda xəṭṭàne| In July or August, they begin to harvest the wheat plants (B5:95).

xəyāl, xəyala n.f. (K./A.) thought; idea | qṭíla xəyála dìya| She has made up her mind (A8:49); xəyálɛxu mù‑qṭila?| What decision have you made? (B5:2); ʾu-gu-xəyála díya hóla màra| She says to herself (A8:75); mŭčə́zəlla xəyàli| He annoyed me (A17:7); la‑bắyən măčəzə́nna xəyalɛ̀xu| I don’t want to bore you; ʾítli xə̀yāl| I have an idea (A21:36).

xəzda n.m. (pl. xəzde0 reproach

xəzma n.m. (pl. xəzme, xəzmane) (K.) family relative

xəzmayuθa n.f. kinship relationship | bắyəx ṱ‑óðəx xəzmayúθa mənnɛ̀xu| We want to make a family relationship with you (by marriage) (B5:4)

xəzwa n.m. (pl. xəzwe) vision, revelation | xǝ́zwa škằra wéwa| It was a clear vision (A2:6)

xəzzəmta n.f. (pl. xəzzəmyaθa) nose-ring

xiča n.m. (pl. xiče) line (drawn on paper) | wídle xóθe xíča b-qălàma| He drew a line under it with a pen. Contrast xatta line drawn on the ground.

xiyara n.m. (pl. xiyare) cucumber

xiyoṭa n.m. (pl. xiyoṭe) sewing, sewn fabric

xiza n.m. (K.) sand

xlapa adv. in place of; for the sake of | ʾo dày| ya-xlápax dày| Oh mother, may I be your ransom, mother (A37:4); xlápa d-an-jundìye| (May I be a ransom) for those soldiers (= Oh woe for the soldiers) (C3:1); xlàpux ya‑ʾálaha| (Let it be) for your sake (Let it be as you wish) (A9:4); xlápət ʾàlaha| Thank God.

xlawta n.f. milking

xlima adj. (f. xlimta, pl. xlime) thick | qɛsa xlima thick wood

xliṣa adj. (f. xliṣta, pl. xliṣe) tight

xliṭa adj. (f. xliṭṭa, pl. xliṭṭe) wrong

xḷiya | xəgga xḷiya type of xəgga dance in which people bend their knees (→ xḷʾ). This is the same as the dance known as xəgga belati.

xloṣa adj. (f. xloṣta, pl. xloṣe) tight | šəbbaqa xloṣa a loose belt (anton. rpoxa loose).

xlula n.m. (pl. xlulane) wedding | wídla xlùla| They held a wedding (A4:56).

xmara n.m. (pl. xmare) ass | xmarət dudiya curved wooden piece attached to the top of a cradle

xmarta n.f. (pl. xmaryaθa) she-ass

xmaṭa n.f. (xmaṭaθa) needle | bóyət xmàṭa| the eye of a needle (A11:12); xmaṭaθət masərqa the spikes of wool-carding combing

xmaθa n.f. (pl. xmayaθa) mother-in-law

xmɛθa n.f. keeping, guarding

xmila adj. (f. xmilta, xmile) happy; festive

xmiqa adj. (f. xmiqta, pl. xmiqe) rotten; putrid | miya xmiqe foul water

xmira n.m. yeast | dɛrɛ́wa xmíra gáwa dìye,| xămèwa| They would put yeast in it (the dough) and it rose (B5:16).

xo, xoθ- prep. (with pronominal suffixes: xoθe) (§13.3.23.) under | múttəlla xo‑kosìθe| He put them under his hat (A23:6), tfíqla dàwe xo‑ʾáqla díya| She found gold coins under her leg (A10:7); dɛ́rət ʾíðux xo‑d‑ò‑kepa| Put your hand under that stone (A12:27); xo-qðala maxmore with jewels (hanging down) under her neck (C6:4); ʾáxni xoθ-tagbártət màlkəx| We are under the administration of the king (A8:80). After verbs of movement: y‑aθɛ́wa xo‑túθa č̣ùwa| They would come under the smooth mulberry tree (B5:203), kú ṱ‑íle ṣláya xo‑qárše ʾǝ̀ltəx,| pyáša dàwa| Everything that fell down under the beams became gold (A10:11), mṭeli xo-Dwile I arrived under (the village of) Dwile (C2:30). Combined with mən expressing static location: ʾu‑m‑xòθe| y‑oðíwa nùra| Then under it they would put fire (B5:183). Expressing movement: másta plíṭla m-xóθa dìya| The yoghurt came out from underneath it (A30:21).

xo-, xu-part. intensifying particle (§17.9.2.) | Intensifying negation with remonstrating force: xo-la-mɛ́θən làxxa| I shall not die here (A20:11); yába ʾan‑ʾə́mma dàwe,| xu‑là mbaqrə̀təlli| Well, do not ask me about those hundred gold coins (A14:65); xu‑lanwa‑mírəllux maxzə́tli xăzìna| I had not told you to show me a treasure (A14:23). In negative questions, usually remonstrating: xo-lat-mírta xà-məndi?| Did you not say something? (= surely you said something?) (A26:34); bábi tə́mməl ʾáyya mðíta xu-kùmta-wawa?| Father, was this town not black yesterday? (= surely this town was black yesterday) (A4:35). In positive questions: gúrzə šə́rmux xo-ʾána ṱ‑azə́nwa bìya?| Would I be finished off by your stupid club (literally: the club of your behind)?! (A52:17). Introducing apodosis: ʾən-šắrəṭ díyi qəm-yăðə̀tla,| xo-b-gawrànnux| If you know (the answer to) my challenge, I shall indeed marry you’ (A25:62); ʾən-θèli| xó bàxtiwət| If I come back, then you are my wife (A25:66).

xoð- pron. pronoun of isolation (§14.6.) | xòðiwən| I am alone (A22:32); pìšela| har-ʾàni-tre l-xoðéy| Only those two remained by themselves (A20:9); ʾáw xa-l-xóðe díye tămàha| He is all alone there (A27:5).

xona n.m. (pl. xonăwaθa) brother | xóna mənnɛ̀xule| He is a brother to you (A25:22). Pl. xonăwaθa siblings | ʾu-ṭḷáθa xonăwàθi,| ðá xáθa ʾu-tré xonăwáθa ʾìθwali| My three siblings—I had a sister and two brothers (B9:1).

xonuθa n.f. brotherhood, fellowship | pălə́xla kùlla| b‑ġðáðe b‑xonùθa| We shall share it among ourselves in fellowship (A14:18).

xorəkka n.m. (pl. xorəkke) little friend

xo-ruša n.m. (pl. xo-rušane) shoulder-blade

xoruθa n.f. friendship

xoš adj. (invar.) (K.) good | ʾáw xoš-nàšɛle| He is a good man; hàdəx-iwa xóš-naša| He was such a good man (A4:31); ʾíθən … biš-xoš-gùṛe| There are better men (A26:79); b‑álaha xòš‑məndila!| That is a good idea! (A14:18)

xoš part. deontic particle (§15.1.1.5. i) | xoš-ʾáwər ʾu-ʾáxəl ʾu-šáte gu-pərdɛ̀sa-w| Let him enter and eat and drink in Paradise (A2:8); ʾu‑bɛ́θux xoš-ʾàqəð| and may your house burn down (A17:6); k̭áwa xoš-ṱ-awéwa pìša| He should have remained alive (A7:20).

xošave n.f. (K.) sweet drink made of raisins | the raisins, with their stems removed, are soaked in water until they become swollen

xošeba n.m. (pl. xošebane) Sunday | xošeba xaθa New Sunday (= the first Sunday after Easter) (B5:228); xošebət bnaθa Girls’ Sunday (Sunday before the beginning of the Lent fast, B7:1ff., B16:18ff.); xošébə bnàθa| qə́ṭma b‑quṣràθa| On Girls’ Sunday there was (washing) ash in the cooking pots (i.e. the people fasted and washed their pots rather than using them for cooking) (B7:5).

xo-šxawθa n.f. (pl. xo-šxawyaθa) armpit

xoθa adv. below. xoθa xoθa prep. under | with actions involving movement: ʾu‑gríšle míya m‑ṭùra| muθéle xóθa‑xoθət ʾùpra,| muwə́rre gu‑Dəmdə̀ma| He drew water from the mountain, bringing it under the ground and directing it into Dəmdəma (A11:14).

xparta n.f. (xparyaθa) quarry

xqira adj. (f. xqirta, pl. xqire) honoured | hátxa bába xqìrɛwət| You are are a very respected father (A18:8).

xrawa n.m. (pl. xrawe) destruction; wicked act | y‑áwəðwa xràwe gu‑măḥálle| He wrought havoc in his neighbourhood (A14:7); hot-wáða rába xràwe| You are doing many wicked things (A25:81).

xriwa adj. (f. xriwta, pl. xriwe) bad; out of order (machine)

xroriye n.pl. sorghum

xṣipta n.f. (pl. xṣipyaθa) wooden door lock

xšawta n.f. (pl. xšawyaθa) thought; opinion | max-xšàwti| according my opinion (A6:3).

xtaya adj. (f. xtɛθa, pl. xtaye) lower | reša xtaya upside down; gallìyɛle,| hátxa réša xtàyɛle| It is a valley that slopes downwards (B19:3); ʾáθṛa t-xtàye| the land of the dwellers in the lowlands (A37:5); kúlla ṣalɛ́wa gota‑xtɛ̀θa| They would all fall down (B5:43); díge‑w kθàye| ʾáp ʾan‑zóre xtàye| The cocks and the chickens, and also the small lowly creatues (should observe the fast) (B16:15). xtɛθa adv. below: ʾàni| dɛrɛ́wa xtɛ̀θa| They put these (the mats) below (i.e. on the ground) (B5:199).

xṭiθa n.f. (pl. xṭiyaθa) sin | xṭìθɛla!| It is a sin! What a pity!; xṭiθèy-ila!| What a pity for them! (A8:11); xṭiθɛ̀xula!| What a pity for you (A8:26); xṭìθila| What a pity for me (A11:11); xṭíθi b-qðalɛ̀xu| bnóni qam-ʾɛ́ni là qaṭlítula| I implore you (literally: my sin be on your neck), do not kill my children before my eyes (B9:13); mắdərre xṭíθi dìye| Make him come back, I am feeling sorry for him (A24:53).

xuba n.m. dye

xubba n.m. love | npíltɛla b-xùbba| She has fallen in love (A4:14).

xulama n.m. (pl. xulamwaθa) (K./A.) servant

xulamta n.f. (pl. xulamyaθa) (K./A.) maid servant

xulaṣa n.m. (A.) end; summary | xuláṣa ʾaláha mutə́pqəlle gu-d-a-mðíta ṱ-íla ʾɛ-bráta d-o-màlka| In the end God made him come across the town where the daughter of that king was (A4:11).

xulqana n.m. (pl. xulqane) friend of the groom at a wedding | xulqane l‑bɛθət babe The friends of the groom are at his father’s house (B8:23).

xumala n.m. festivity; festive clothing | lwíša júllət xumàla| wearing festive clothes (A35:4); b-ʾaqla zargule ʾu-ʾəlla xumale On her legs are sheep‑skin shoes, and on her (body) festive clothes (C6:2)

xumlana n.m. merriment | ʾap‑ʾayyɛ́wa xa‑xumlàna díyən| This also was a form of merriment of ours (B5:33)

xumṣa (i) n.m. sour remainder (of cheese or yoghurt) | xumṣət gupta sour remainder of cheese used for making new cheese; xumṣət masta sour remainder of yoghurt.

xumṣa (ii) n.m. dish consisting of meat, rice and turnips

xumṣa (iii) n.m. (pl. xumṣe) large box (for storing grains)

xumθa n.f. anger

xumθana adj. angry

xura n.m. (pl. xure) tall willow tree | qíme tre-xùre.| síqa š-xa-xùra.| Two willow trees grew up. He climbed up one willow. (A18:26)

xurəgθa n.f. (pl. xurgaθa) step-daughter

xurət adj. invar. (K.) strong, valiant | ʾan‑díyən wéla biš‑xùrət| Our (men) were stronger (B8:5).

xurga n.m. (pl. xurge) step-son

xurja n.m. (pl. xurje) (A.) saddle-bag

xurma n.m. (pl. xurme) (K.) date (dark and soft) | ʾilánət xùrme| a date palm tree (A13:10).

xurta, xorta n.f. (pl. xuriyaθa, xoriyaθa) tall willow tree | xúrta mgăríla kut-tre-šə̀nne| They pollard the willow every two years.

xurzaya → xwarzaya

xusɛra n.m. dew

xuwwe n.m. (pl. xuwwawe, xuwwăwaθa, xuwwaθa) snake | types of snake: xuwwe təðya, xuwwe koma, xuwwe balakšənka

xuwwiθa n.f. (pl. xuwwiyaθa) small snake

xuya n.m. darkness | píšle xùya| It became dark (A14:73); héš xúya xùyɛle| It was still very dark (A30:36).

xuyana adj. (f. xuyanta, pl. xuyane) dark

xwara adj. (f. xwarta, pl. xware) white | xwarət beta the white of an egg

xwaraθa n.pl. type of wheat

xwār-dəqna n.m. (pl. xwardəqna) elder

xwarnaya adj. (f. xwarnɛθa, pl. xwarnaye) whitish

xwār-paθa adj. invar. white-faced, innocent

xwār-paθuθa n.f. innocence

xwaruθa n.f. whiteness; dairy products

xwarzaya, xwarza, xurzaya n.m. (pl. xwarzaye) (K.) nephew (son of sister) | xwàrza! Nephew! (vocative) (A29:17)

xwarzɛθa, xurzɛθa n.f. (pl. xwarzayaθa, xurzayaθa) (K.) niece (daughter of sister)

xwarθa n.f. (pl. xwariyaθa) (1) friend (f.). (2) companion spirit | thought to bring about a hallucinatory fever: y‑ámri ʾən‑xáyər b‑séra ràba,| qapxále xwàrθe| They say that if he looks at the moon a lot, his companion spirit will possess him. A metal object (e.g. a knife) is put under the pillow of a pregnant woman so that she is not afflicted by her companion spirit (qa-t‑lá maxyála xwàrθa). (3) placenta

xwiṣa n.m. dish made from chopped flat bread (zeðaye) and butter (č̣ita)

xyapta n.f. washing | xyaptət xətna the ceremony of the washing of the groom (before the wedding), accompanied by wedding songs (leliyane).

xzatta n.f. harvest | bar‑sàməq,| ṱ‑ámrəx dā́n-t xzattɛla| After it (the rice) becomes brown, we say that it is harvest time (B5:79).

xzirən n.m. June

xzura n.m. (pl. xzure) pig



/y/

ya (i) part. (A.) vocative particle | ya‑màlka| O king (A25:13); yá-qazi ṱ-áwət basìma| O judge, may you be healthy (A6:11).

ya part. (A.) which? | yà‑xăzina xzélux?| What treasure have you found? (A14:13)

yaʾisa n.m. (pl. yaʾise) husband of the sister of a wife

yaba interj. interjection opening speech turns | šḗx yába hole-mšúdra bàrux| The sheikh, take note, has sent for you (A7:8); yába ʾána ṱ‑àθən| Well, I’ll come (A7:9).

yabiše n.pl. (sing. yabišta) raisins

yadde n.f. (pl. yaddāt) (A.) handle

yaðuwa adj. (f. yaðuwta) knowledgeable

yaha → ʾăyaha

yăk̭ana, yek̭ana n.m./adj. (K.) only son | ʾaw-málka ʾíθwale xa-bròna,| yăk̭àna| That king had an only son (A4:1).

yăk̭anta, yek̭anta n.f./adj. only daughter | ðá-xaθa yak̭ànta| a single sister (A18:1)

yala n.m. (pl. yale, ʾayale) child | yálət mədràsa| school children

yălək, yălăkka → ʾilăkka

yaləxta, yaləxθa n.f. (pl. yaləxyaθa) handkerchief; scarf | This is waved around in a xəgga dance. It is usually decorated with tassels.

yalla interj. come on! let’s go! | de‑yàlla!| Let’s go ahead (with the plan) (A44:3). Sometimes combined with də- (particle of immediacy §15.1.5.2., §15.7.): də-yàlla!| Let’s go! (A8:82).

yalma n.m. (pl. yalme) face (of person)

yalta n.f. girl

yalunka n.m. (pl. yalunke) youth (approx. 6-14 years)

yama n.f. (pl. yamaθa) sea; lake

yamiṣa n.m. (pl. yamiṣe) rubbarb | It grows in cool places in high mountains.

yamnaya adj. (f. yamnɛθa, pl. yamnaye) right-handed

yamne n.f. right (hand, side)

yamta n.f. (pl. yamtaθa) lake

yan, ya part. (K.) or | ʾáwwa nablə́xle kəs-d-ày| yan-ʾáy nablə́xla kəs‑d‑àwwa?| Should we take him to her or take her to him? (A4:3); mjárbu mɛ́θu náše duxtùre-u| yan-náše spáy t-yắði bud-màrra| Try to bring doctors, or fine people who know about the illness (A8:32).

yapɛθa n.f. (pl. yapayaθa) baker-woman

yapyana n.m. (pl. yapyane) baker

yapyanta n.f. (pl. yapyanyaθa) baker woman

yaqura adj. (f. yaqurta, pl. yaqure) heavy; pregnant | sə́twa y‑awéwa yaqùra| Winter was hard (B5:155); báxta hóla yaqúrta bud‑yàla| The woman is with child; baxtáθa tə̀rwəθna hóla yaqùre| Both women were pregnant (A25:2).

yār n.m. May

yarəkθa n.f. (pl. yarəkyaθa) (K.) concubine, mistress

yarqa n.m. vegetables; vegetable stew | ṱ-oðánna yàrqa-lley| I shall make it into a vegetable stew for them (A34:18).

yarxa, yɛrxa n.m. (pl. yarxe, yɛrxe) month | təltàssər b‑yɛ́rxa| the thirteenth of the month (B16:22); yarxət tre February; yarxət ʾəč̣č̣a September; rešət yarxa the beginning of the month; ʾítla réšət yàrxa| She has a menstrual period.

yaṣila, yaṣilta n.m. (pl. yaṣile, yaṣilyaθa) outer edge (of wall, window); outer corner (of building); side (of door) | kút yaṣílət qàṣra| ʾíθ ða‑yàwna gáwe díye| On every corner of the palace there is a dove (A12:24); rúše díye qíθɛle b‑yaṣílət tằra| His shoulder hit the side of the door (A29:10). Cf. zawiθa inner corner

yasmin, yasmina n.f. (pl. yasmine) jasmin (yellow or white)

yasoṛa n.m (pl. yasore) tether | yasóṛe y‑asṛíwale b‑púmmət tàwra| Tethers tied it (the cross beam) to the mouth of the bull (B5:83).

yaṭṭana n.m. (pl. yaṭṭane) (Urm.) acquaintance

yatuma n.m. (pl. yatume) orphan

yawna n.f. (pl. yawne, yawnaθa) dove, pigeon

yaʾha →ʾăyaha

ye, yehe interj. yes

yek̭ana → yak̭ana

yek̭anta → yak̭anta

yɛrxa → yarxa

yəmma n.f. (pl. yəmmaθa) mother | yə́mmət marɛ̀θa| original leaven (cheese, yoghurt used as a starter to produce more) (B16:25)

yəmmonta n.f. little mother | yəmmonti my little mother, mummy

yoma n.m. (pl. yome, yomane, yomaθa; abs. yum) day; sun. (1) day | xa-yóma síqe-wawa l-ṣɛ̀da| One day they had gone up (the mountains) out hunting (A25:2); yóma qamàya on the first day (A25:14); hàr ʾo-yóma on the same day (A25:4); yómət xyáptət xə̀tna| on the day of the washing of the groom (B15:74); pálgət yòma| at midday (B5:62); zílla b‑yomàθa| They travelled for days (A29:37). In absolute state: kút‑yum ðà‑brata gawǝ́rwa| Every day he would marry a girl (A14:1). (2) sun | yóma xrùle| the sun was eclipsed; ʾɛ́-gət zarə́qwa yòma,| palṭə́xwa xorăwáθa kúlla m-ġðàðe| When the sun rose, we friends would all go out together (B15:5); zraqət yoma East: y-azíwa l-zràqət yóma| They would go towards the East (A8:22); yóma, yóma mgáli pàθux,| šáxni bnónux ʾu‑bnàθux,| ʾu-ʾap-kalàθux| Sun, sun reveal your face, so that your sons, your daughters and your daughters-in-law may be warm (said when a cloud goes over the sun); hádəx-ila šṭrànta| max‑d‑àwwa yóma| She is as beautiful as this sun (A7:17).

yomiyya adv. (A.) daily | yomíyya xá‑bena once a day (A12:46)

yubqa n.f. (pl. yubqaθa) skirt

yulpana n.m. learning, education

yunja n.m. (pl. yunje) type of plant | green in colour, fed to animals

yuqra n.m. weight



/z/

zăbun, zabbun adj. invar. (K.) weak; thin | báxta xáčča zàbbun‑ila| a woman is rather weak (A10:12).

zaga n.m (pl. zage) bell | ʾána maxə́nne zágət ʾùmra| I shall ring the church bell; qále díye ṣə́pya ʾax-zàga| His voice is clear as a bell.

zakkan interj. sound of splashing | guði daryən gu-ʾiθaθi zakke zakkan l-ʾiθaθi I put my churn in my hands, splash, splash on my hands (C5:8).

zakke interj. sound of splashing | guði măyanne b‑zakke I shall churn my churn with the sound of splashing (referring to the yoghurt splashing in the churn) (C5:2).

zala n.m. (pl. zale) thin cane, reed | cf. čiqa thick cane

zalala adj. (f. zalalta, pl. zalale) clear (liquid) | míya y‑áwɛ zalàle| The water is clear (B10:9); čay zalalta weak tea.

zaloma → ẓaloma

zamara n.m./adj. singer | rába zamàra-wewa| He was a fine singer (A25:43).

zamət adj. invar. (K.) difficult | zámətila wàðəlle| It is difficult to do it; ʾə́n zámət lá-hawya ʾə̀llux| hálli kθàwa| If it is not difficult for you, give me the book (= Please give me the book).

zamətuθa n.f. (K.) difficulty

zangīn, zaginta adj. (f. zangīn, zaginta pl. zangine) (K./T.) rich

zaqara n.m. (pl. zaqare) weaver

zaqarta n.f. (pl. zaqaryaθa) weaver (f.)

zaqaruθa n.f. weaving

zaqrana n.m. (pl. zaqrane) weaver

zaqra-qode n.f. (pl. zaqra-qode) spider (§10.17.1.)

zăra (f. and pl. zăre) (K.) yellow | zărət beta the yoke of an egg

zaraya n.m. (pl. zaraye) cultivator

zarba n.m. (pl. zarbe) (K./A.) blow (of weapon) → darba

zarda adj. (f. and pl. zarde) (marginal variant of zăra) yellow | ʾáw kawsèy| zàrda| their blond hair (A8:14)

žare n.f. (K.) suffering, catastrophe | žáre ʾə̀lle| It is a pity for him.

žare, žɛre adj. invar. poor, wretched | ʾo‑yála zóra žàre| The young boy, poor thing (A14:12); žɛ́re Fàrxo| ṱ-íwən ʾána b-hìwi díya| Poor (me), Farxo, who am waiting in hope for her (A25:18).

zarəqta n.m. (pl. zarəqte) wasp

zareta n.f. (pl. zarayaθa) cultivator (f.)

zargəf n.m. (K.) type of fabric

zargule n.pl. (sing. zargulta) sheep skin boots (worn in Winter)

zărin adj. invar. (K.) yellow

zaringər n.m. (pl. zaringɛre) (K.) goldsmith

zarnaya adj. (f. zarnɛθa, pl. zarnaye) yellowish

zarpəkka n.m. (pl. zarpəkke) (K./A.) red spot on skin, mosquito bite | plíṭla zarpə́kke gu-ʾíðe dìye| His hand came out in spots.

zarrək | ʾənwe zarrək type of yellow grape

zarrəkθa n.f. cleansing liquid | It was produced by boiling oakwood ash in water and used for washing clothes and washing grapes.

zăruθa n.f. yellowness

zarzar n.f. type of large red ant(s) | also šəkwanta zarzar

zarzariθa n.f. type of small brown ant(s)

zaṭe n.pl. measles

zawda, zoda part. (often combined with biš: biz-zawda/biz-zoda, bi‑zawda/bi-zoda) more (quantity), too much (§14.8.2.) | Expressing an increase in quantity: xá‑saʿat biz‑zòda| one hour more (B5:54); mə́ndi zàwda| something more (A3:1); kùl-məndi bi-záwda| more of everything (A3:3). In estimates of quantity: ʾəštà yarxé| xamšà yarxé| biz‑zàwda| five or six months, or more (B5:3). More than: ʾu‑bréle díya b‑xšáwən biz‑záwda mən‑ʾəč̣č̣á‑mma ʾálpa nàše| By now there have been born, I think, more than nine-hundred thousand people (B2:10); záwda mən‑ʾarbá‑mma šə̀nnele| It is more than four hundred years old (B6:31); ʾáxni be-Tòməx| lá-maxəx zóda l-xà| We the family of Toma do not strike more than one (blow) (A52:24). Excessive quantity: zàwdɛla mə́nni| It is too much for me (to tell) (A26:65). With adverbs: lá maspərə́xləx bi-zàwda| We shall not make you wait any more (A4:42); xắyiwa biz‑zàwda| They survived longer (B5:190). In combination sama zawda/zoda expressing the majority of a set: xákma har‑damxíwa l‑ằra| ʾap‑áni gàre.| ʾína sáma zóda ʾiyɛ́wala qaràwət.| Some would even sleep on the floor of the roof. Most people, however, had a bed. (B5:204); ʾína sáma zòda| y‑oðíwa ʾằraq| Most people, however, would make arak (B5:213). Idiom: mìr-e-mən| zàwdɛla mə́nni,| ʾána ṱ-amrənnɛ̀xu| mšáxəlpu dukàne| My lord, may I humbly suggest you change places (Literally: It is too much for me, let me say to you, change places) (A26:65).

zawdana, zodana adj. (f. zawdanta, pl. zawdane) excessive, extra | bas-ʾána zodànta-llɛxu| quṣárta mə́nni t-muθéli llɛ̀xu| But the cooking pot that I have brought you is an extra one for you (A5:6).

zawərta n.f. (pl. zawriyaθa) earthenware container for water for cooking in house or carrying on a journey | zawə́rtət kyàlo| the bride’s pot, which was filled with sweets and fruit and broken by the bride before entering the groom’s house (B8:33).

zawga n.m. (pl. zawge) pair; even number. (1) pair | dɛríwa xa‑záwgə tòpe| They used to fire a couple of shots; qyàmela| xá-zawgət xoriyàθa| A pair of willow trees sprang up (A26:90). (2) even number | zawge ʾu‑pare even and odd numbers; zawge ʾu-k̭atte even and odd numbers.

zawiθa n.f. (pl. zawiyaθa) (inner) corner | cf. yaṣila outer corner

zawna n.m. time; period of time | záwna lebàna-wewa| The time was tricky (A1:22); b‑awwa zawna at this time; ʾày| hălikòptər y-áwa,| ṭla-d-áw zàwna| It was a helicopter of that time (A27:20).

zawnana n.m. (pl. zawnane) purchaser, client

zawnaya adj. ancient, old timer | ʾaxni naše zawnaye We are ancient people (C1:16); ṣadra darga t‑zawnaye Her breast is a door of the ancients (C2:47).

zawzən n.f. (pl. zawzane) (K.) summer sojourn, summer pasture (for animals)

zaxma adj. (f. zaxme, pl. zaxme) (K./A.) huge; strong, tough | xá gáwṛa xɛlána-w zàxma wéwa| He was a powerful, tough man (A27:1).

zaya n.m. (pl. zaye) (K.) young (of animals and birds) | zayət qaṭu kittens; zayət ʾaqubra young mice; zayət ʾarya lion cubs

zdiya adj. (f. zdita, pl. zdiye) afraid

zduwana adj. (f. zduwanta, pl. zduwane) fearful

zduθa n.f. fear | síqela rəš‑d‑ay‑ʾilána m‑zdùθa| They climbed the tree out of fear (A13:11).

zeðaya n.f. (pl. zeðaye) round thick flat bread made from wheat cooked on the sides of an oven

zeriya adj. (f. and pl. zeriye) (K.) golden | qumta xlita zeriye her sweet golden stature (C6:7)

zeruwa n.m. (pl. zeruwe) (K.) leech

zeytūn, zeytuna n.m. (pl. zeytune) (A.) olive, olive tree | ʾilanət zeytune olive tree

zɛrăbi n.f. (K.) tall cane | used to weave baskets

zɛθa n.f. olive (tree); olive oil. ʾilanət zɛθa olive tree; məšxət zɛθa olive oil

zəbbara n.f. (pl. zəbbərwaθa) (K.) group of workers | Such groups consisted of men from the village who volunteered their labour to help a member of the village undertake various types of task, such as gathering leaves (ṭarpa), harvesting wheat (xzada xəṭṭe), harvesting rice (xzada rəzza) and building a house (bnaya bɛθa); yomət zəbbara a day in which work was done by such a volunteer group.

zəbla n.m. manure | zə́blət haywàne| the manure of animals (B5:134)

zədya adj. (f. zdiθa, pl. zədye) afraid | mà‑lux zə́dya?| Why are you afraid? (A11:6)

zədyana n.m. a type of oak tree | resembles a p̣aṛma

zeləkka n.m. (pl. zeləkke) splinter of wood

zəlpa m. slice

zəmra n.m. (pl. zəmre) song | šmili xa qalət zəmra I heard the sound of song (C2:6).

zəmzama n.m. (pl. zəmzame) (A.) deep natural pool

zəmzŭma n.m. (pl. zəmzŭme) (A.) waterfall

zēn part. (A.) all right, fine; lucky | mṭéle gu-d-ày-maθa| ham-zḕn| He was lucky to arrive in that village (A37:14).

zəndana n.m. (pl. zəndane) (K.) prison

zənja n.m. (pl. zənje) storage bin for straw | made of woven sticks, covered at the top by leaves (ṭarpa) and hay (puwuš).

zənjir n.f. (pl. zənjire) (K.) chain (for securing, e.g. prisoner) | síṛɛwa zənjíre b-rušàne| He had been tethered with chains on his shoulders (A26:81)

zənnara n.m. (pl. zənnare) (K.) cliff, precipice

zənzare n.pl. type of fly

zəpra n.m. animal fat

zəqqa n.f. (pl. zəqqe, zəqqaθa) (A.) waterskin

zəqqora n.m. (pl. zəqqore) woven/knitted product, woven/knitted fabric | zəqqora bəd-ʾìða a fabric woven/knitted by hand

zəqra n.m. (pl. zəqre) weaving, woven fabric

zəqta n.m. (pl. zəqte) point at the end of an animal goad (massa) | zə́qta mxéle l-tàwra| He stuck the point of the goad into the ox.

zərana n.m. slap | qəm‑maxənne xa zərana I slapped him

zər-baba n.m. (K.) stepfather

zərmaziya n.m. (pl. zərmaziye) (K.) small spiky type of oak gall (mɛša, paṛma)

zəyara n.f. (A.) visit, pilgrimage

ziləkka n.m. (pl. ziləkke) small reed

zina adj. (f. zinta, pl. zine) decorated | julle zine decorated clothes

ziqa n.m. neck of a shirt | truq ziqux! Wrap up well (literally: Button up the neck of your shirt); xóne b‑zìqa| his brother (who was as close to him as) the neck of his shirt (A32:26).

zirək adj. invar. (K.) strong, courageous | xákma doqíwale xúwwa qaṭlìwale.| rába zirə̀k‑wɛwa.| Some grasped the snake and killed it. They were very courageous (B5:78).

zlima → ẓlima

zliya adj. (f. zlita, pl. zliye) cracked

zlumya n.m. (A.) injustice

zmarta n.f. (pl. zmaryaθa) song

zōj n.m. (A.) trick | bắye ṱ‑awǝ́dlən zṓj He wants to trick us (A14:13)

zolala n.m. (pl. zolale) (K.) tendril of a plant; vein within a leaf | some plants have tendrils (zolale) that extend along the ground, e.g. paṭiroke

zoma n.m. (pl. zomăwaθa) (K.) summer hut in the mountains

zonana n.m. (pl. zonane) buyer

zonanta n.f. (pl. zonanyaθa) buyer

zor adv. (K.) hardly, barely | b‑kúlla yóma zór maṣìwa| xàzdi| xá‑mdi rába baṣòra| In a whole day they can barely manage to harvest a very small amount (B5:144); b‑zòr‑ṃaḷe| ṭla‑mapláxtət bɛ̀θa| There was scarcely enough for household use (B5:215).

zora adj. (f. zorta, pl. zore) small

zorna n.f. (pl. zorne, zornaθa) (K.) pipe

zornači n.m. pipe-player

zoruθa n.f. smallness, youth

zoxonaya n.m. /adj. man from Zaxo

zraqta n.f. sunrise; East | zraqtət yoma, zraqət yoma sunrise

zreta n.f. cultivation | zrétət rə̀zza| the cultivation of rice (B5:76)

zroqa adj. (f. zroqta, pl. zroqe) blue | rare equivalent of milana: šəṭrantux ʾɛna zroqe Your sweetheart—her eyes are blue (C2:33).

zruta n.f. (pl. zruyaθa) cultivation; agriculture | ; yála θéle mən‑zrùta| The young man came back from working in the fields (A21:8).

zuryat n.f. (K./A.) offspring, progeny | ʾína ʾaláha yíwle zúryat gawèy| But God granted progeny among them (B2:10).

zuwaġa n.m. (C.Syr.) marriage

zuze n.pl. (sing. zuza) money | ṱ‑óðəx zùze| We shall make money (A14:14); ʾána zúza lìtli| I have not got a penny (A22:19).

zvərta n.f. (pl. zəvre) spin | mə́xyəlle ʾáqle l-dudíyət Qaṭìna,| šawwí-zəvre zvìrtəlla| He kicked the cradle of Qaṭina and span it round seventy times (A52:2).

zwaða n.m. (pl. zwaðe) provision for journey | ʾu‑čánte díye dwíqla zwàðe| She packed his bag with provisions (A21:22); ma-yəmmi pɛli zwaðe Mother, bake for me provisions (for my journey) (A50:9).

zyatta n.f. increase | zyáttət mìya| increase in water, flood (B6:19)


/ž/

žeri (K.) | warde žeri wild flowers (of various colours, including red and green growing in fields)

ži part. (variant: žigən) (K.) also, even; connective particle (§18.1.4.). (1) also, even | ʾítle tắra gu-ḥadìqa| ʾu-ʾítle dàrga-žigən| There was a door in the garden and there was also a main gate (A17:23); də́ryəlla š‑qaràwət,| ʾánna wajjúwe díya‑ži múttəlla tàma| They put her on the bed and they also put her effects there (A21:7); ʾən‑háwe dàwa-ži| ʾáxni t‑yawə́xla xa-b-ṭḷàθa ʾə́lle díye| Even if it is gold, we shall give him threefold (if it is lost) (A7:10). (2) connective particle | marking topic constituent at boundary of discourse section: mǝ́re yába hàyyo,| ʾaθìtu,| čìdetu| ta-mšaxə́lpi šə́mmət Čùxo| mattúle xá-šəmma xèna.| ʾánna-ži ʾə̀θyela.| xìlela-w| šə̀tyela.| He said ‘Come, come, you are invited’ in order for them to change the name Čuxo and give him a another name.’ They came. They ate and drank. (A7:3). Adversative when in negative clause: ʾó‑yōm ṱ-ìle plíṭa| bróne díye mìθɛle.| ʾu-ʾáxni-ži láx muqíme m‑báθre díye màlka| On the day he left, his son died. But we have not installed (another) king after him (A4:32).


/ẓ/

ẓaləm adj. invar. (A.) unjust, cruel

ẓalmana adj. (A.) unjust, cruel

ẓaloma, zaloma n.m. (pl. ẓalome) tyrant

ẓlima, zlima adj. (f. ẓlimta, pl. ẓlime) wronged
